HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Can Revenue Ease Resistance to Industry?

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
THE rural Town of Oxford, just over the Fairfield line in New Haven County, maintains a low profile. Its 8,685 residents enjoy 33 square miles of unspoiled countryside and want to keep it that way.
But next month, when the new town budget is proposed, they will face a projected 50 percent rise in taxes from the current 21.73 mills to around 31. It could change their minds about continuing to resist industrial development. 
 The rise in taxes reflects bonding debt for $18.5 million spent from 1987 to 1990 on a new elementary school and on sewer and water lines to a 3,000-acre industrial park in the northern section of town. The park was zoned for industrial use in the 70's to accommodate more than 3 million square feet of construction. But local opposition has discouraged development, in spite of land priced modestly at $20,000 to $80,000 an acre.
"People are of two minds about new industry," said C. Thomas Tarby, owner of the Colonial Tavern, a popular restaurant at the edge of the park. "They will spend to get the best for their kids, but they won't recognize the need for additional revenues to offset expenditures."
In an effort to attract tenants to land that it has owned for many years, Omega Engineering of Stamford announced this month that it will begin construction this fall of a 40,000-square-foot building for itself on its 92-acre Omega Airport Science Center.
The two-story, curvilinear building with an exterior of prefinished silver-gray and steel blue panels was designed by the William Murphy Architectural Group of West Chester, Pa.
The rest of the complex will be built as leases are secured. Plans for an additional 54 acres owned by Omega have not been developed.
"We also own land in New Jersey, where our manufacturing plant is located," said Ralph Michael, Omega's chief financial officer, "but we found it unsuitable for a long-term commercial project like this. We think Oxford has tremendous potential because of its location between I-84 and the Route 8 Expressway, its fiber-optic capabilities, its airport, a quality workforce and affordable housing."
Oxford, in a 13-town market area with a population of 250,000, "has more developable land than any town in the region," said Peter Dorpalen, executive director of the Central Naugatuck Valley Council of Governments, a regional planning agency. "We see it as potentially the most rapidly growing community in the state over the next 20 years."
Nevertheless, only a handful of industrial condominium tenants, a few light manufacturing firms and Sky Pix, a satellite broadcast center on 12 hilltop acres, have moved in to date.
Tom Hill, a regional realtor based in Waterbury, feels the town missed its opportunity to grow in the 70's and 80's and may have a long wait for the next wave of development. "Oxford was late putting in sewers and water, and marketing itself," he said.
LAST year, he said, he showed a fully approved 92-acre site to the Morgan Stanley Group of Manhattan, which turned it down as too remote for a corporate headquarters. Lately, he has leased a few 10,000- to 20,000-square-foot existing spaces at $5 a foot.
"In 1989, the town rejected a distribution center proposed by the Marriott Hotels," said John F. Montefalco, who was then First Selectman. "It would have brought $650,000 a year in taxes. After listening to six months of outcries against it, Marriott went to Massachusetts. That sent a negative message to other companies considering Oxford."
Peg Daley, Oxford's director of economic development, wants to recruit communications, video and data transmission companies "because we have exceptional fiber optic digital switching capability through Woodbury Telephone, a very aggressive independent company," she said.
"Other areas don't have it and it's expensive to install," she said. "We also have static-free air, something that is considered desirable for such companies. With defense scaling down, we have to find alternative industries."
Most town residents work in Bridgeport, Danbury, New Haven or Waterbury and many are in defense-related jobs at Sikorsky Aircraft in Stratford.
Adjacent to the industrial park is Oxford's 20-year-old airport, the state's third largest with one 5,000-foot and one 2,000-foot runway. Only Bradley International in Windsor Locks and Tweed in New Haven are larger. Up to 130,000 takeoffs and landings are logged annually at Oxford, but there are no regular shuttle flights to major airports and no control tower for commercial aircraft.
The airport has never realized its full potential because of the lack of local industry and a state tax structure that limits revenues. A bill introduced this year could eliminate the tax on airplanes keyed to a town's mill rate and substitute one based on weight, like the tax on automobiles. Currently, a plane hangared at Oxford pays $21.73 for every $1,000 of assessment. On a $3 million plane "we are talking real money," said Joseph Tringali, president of Executive Flight Services, a charter operation at the airport. "Owners keep their planes out of state."
Despite the antidevelopment history of the town, commercial realtors say interest in Oxford has increased in the last several weeks. William Allen, partner in the ReMax franchise, said: "I am getting a lot more requests for industrial space from companies escaping high costs in New York and New Jersey. Land sales are still slow, but housing is being built, and that usually leads the way."
DAVID J. DADDARIO, senior vice president of North American Advisory Realty Services of Manhattan, nationwide real estate consultants, said: "Rather than lagging the big cities, the valley towns will lead Connecticut out of the recession, first with residential construction, then industrial, then retail. Having avoided inflated prices and overbuilding they are attractive alternatives to crowded and higher-priced cities."
Some 30,000 square feet of Oxford's modest commercial space is vacant (there are no town figures on the total square footage), compared with 22.5 percent in Stamford, where prices are $15 to $22 a foot.
"If the index of recovery is construction," said Alfred S. Remsen, executive vice president at William Pitt, Stamford realtors, "the thesis is correct. If the index is leasing, tenants will come here before getting involved with construction."

HEADLINE: Thousands Lose Homes In Mortgage Foreclosures

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
FROM one end of the state to the other, thousands of New Jersey residents -- owners and renters -- are losing their homes as banks and other lenders foreclose on delinquent mortgages.
The number of properties sold at public auction to satisfy unpaid mortgages has doubled and even tripled in some counties over the last few years. 
 And those sales may represent only the tip of the iceberg. Since 1989, the number of foreclosure lawsuits has risen by about 6,000 a year to 23,574 in 1991. Filings for the first two months of this year are running at about the same pace.
Since it takes about two years for the cases to wind their way through the state's heavily backlogged court system, most of the actual foreclosures from 1990 and 1991 suits have yet to occur.
"It's scary," said Dr. Paul Nadler, professor of finance at Rutgers University in Newark, "and I don't think it's peaked."
In county after county, the increase in foreclosures is disrupting the lives of homeowners and tenants. In fact, last week the office of the state's Public Advocate, Wilfredo Caraballo, said Mr. Caraballo planned to propose sweeping changes in the laws affecting homeowners involved in mortgage foreclosures; he has also recently challenged in court the practice of evicting tenants of property sold at sheriffs' sales. (Article on page 16.)
The increase in foreclosures has also strained the resources of courts and police officials. At the Hudson County Sheriff's office, Capt. Mary Tierney said: "The soaring number of foreclosures from 1987 until now is just outrageous. We used to have eight or nine sales a year. Now we have what amounts to one a day."
Rose Gentile, senior foreclosure clerk in the Middlesex County Sheriff's office, said: "We're tripling what we had last year. We thought it might start easing up, but it hasn't."
Though there are no statewide records available of foreclosure sales, each county keeps its own tally. In Middlesex County, for example, there were 89 sales in 1990 and 234 in 1991.
The increasing number of foreclosures, experts say, is a resounding echo of the collapse of the 1980's real-estate boom. That collapse, they say, and the recession that followed it resulted in decreased property values and dwindling incomes that left thousands of homeowners with mortgages they could no longer pay on houses they could no longer sell.
"In the old days," Dr. Nadler said, "what was really protecting people was inflation." If a person could no longer afford his mortgage payment, it was a simple matter of selling the property to pay off the loan.
Now, however, with property values static or declining, it is difficult at best to sell a house at a profit. And often, Dr. Nadler said, the decreased worth of the house has eliminated any equity the homeowner may have had, leaving him with a mortgage balance that exceeds the value of his home.
 
Mortgages Tied to Two Incomes
 In addition, Dr. Nadler said, many mortgages were made on the borrowing power of two incomes, the husband's and the wife's. If one of those incomes suddenly stops, he said, either because of loss of job or divorce, it is only a matter of time before household budgets reach a breaking point.
"I've often said that one of our main troubles is that the average mortgage lasts for eight years and the average marriage lasts for seven," he said.
The type of property that is the subject of a foreclosure lawsuit tends to vary with the nature of the real-estate market in different areas of the state.
In Cape May County, for example, where 594 foreclosure lawsuits were filed in 1991, about 90 percent of the properties being sold at foreclosure sales are summer homes that are not principal dwellings, said the Sheriff, James Plousis.
In Middlesex County, however, where 1,544 foreclosure actions were started last year, most involve houses that people bought to live in year round. In those cases, said Ms. Gentile, the county's senior foreclosure clerk, a job loss or a cut in pay starts a family on an inexorable slide into a financial quagmire.
 
'It's Easy to Miss Three or Four'
 "You miss one or two mortgage payments, and then it's easy to miss three or four after that," she said.
In Hudson County, where 1,661 foreclosure actions were started last year, many of the properties being sold are condominiums that have been recently built or converted from old apartment buildings. Often, Captain Tierney said, the condominiums that could not be sold were rented out at a loss, and though the tenants were paying rent to the owners, the owners were not paying the mortgage to the bank.
Eventually, the bank forecloses, the property is sold and the tenants have to be evicted. In Hudson County, the unwelcome task of evicting resident owners and tenants of properties sold at the foreclosure sales falls on Sheriff's Officer Michael Geerlof.
"We've evicted over 100 families so far this year," Officer Geerlof said. "And 90 percent of the people I'm evicting are innocent victims who have been faithfully paying their rent."
Many of them have nowhere to go, he said, adding: "They become street people. That's how you make a street person."
Theodore J. Doll, president of the Washington Savings Bank in Hoboken, said his bank would ordinarily not start a foreclosure action until a homeowner was three months behind in payments.
"We don't want to go to foreclosure, we don't want to go to sheriff's sale, but we do want to get paid," Mr. Doll said.
A foreclosure action is seldom started by a bank unless it has first exhausted all other possible solutions, including refinancing the loan or modifying the payment schedule in certain situations.
Once the action is started, however, the owner usually abandons any attempt to make further payments, putting the bank on the line for municipal real-estate taxes, insurance and the lost interest income for as much as two years.
 
The Other Side of the Story
 "The story you usually hear is about the person who is losing their house," Mr. Doll said. "But the other side is that they are living basically rent-free on some financial institution for up to two years."
Dr. Nadler agrees that despite the misery a foreclosure action inevitably brings, it is ultimately a necessary evil.
"It's easy to say we've got to protect the poor guy who isn't paying his mortgage," he said. "But in many ways we're protecting the guy who doesn't meet his obligations at the expense of those who do."
The money lost by banks that have to wait two years for a foreclosure to work its way through the courts, he said, results in lower rates paid on savings accounts and higher rates charged on other loans.
And the banks, he said, cannot be held completely accountable for making mortgages that in hindsight proved to be bad investments.
"We were all in this boom psychology; everybody listened to everybody else," Dr. Nadler said. "In 1989, who could have said that it would all end?"
 
A Backlog of Sales
 Captain Tierney, who is in charge of scheduling public auction sales of foreclosed properties in Hudson County, said the number of foreclosures had increased so dramatically that there was currently a backlog of sales to be scheduled.
"It's terrible, and I don't see a light at the end of the tunnel," she said. "We're fighting a losing battle. We get rid of 10 properties in one week, and 15 more come in the next week."
Officials of other counties echo her concerns.
"Last year we doubled any previous year in our history of doing the sales," Sheriff Plousis of Cape May County said. "And this year we are going to surpass last year's numbers."
In Middlesex County, officials say they have already scheduled more foreclosure sales in the first three and a half months of this year than they did during all of last year.
 
 
 
 
PUBLIC ADVOCATE'S PLAN
 The office of Wilfredo Caraballo, the state's Public Advocate, said last week that he was planning to propose legislation that would significantly change the options of homeowners in a mortgage foreclosure. Mr. Caraballo has also recently challenged in court the practice of evicting tenants of property sold at sheriffs' sales.
Once a property owner is 30 days late with a mortgage payment, the lender can generally demand payment of the entire mortgage and begin foreclosure proceedings. The lender has no obligation to accept less than the full amount remaining on the mortgage.
The Public Advocate's proposal would require a lender to reinstate the mortgage of a property owner who pays all back payments, including interest and fees associated with the foreclosure, at any time prior to the actual foreclosure sale.
The Public Advocate has also challenged a recent court decision that allowed the buyer of a property at a foreclosure sale to evict tenants living on the premises.
Mr. Caraballo maintained that tenants are protected by a 1986 amendment to the state's landlord-tenant law that prohibits landlords from evicting tenants without "good cause" to do so. Good cause includes such things as nonpayment of rent or disorderly behavior on the part of the tenant.
Mr. Caraballo argued that a buyer at a sheriff's sale should be subject to the same requirement of proving good cause as the original landlord was.
In a recent Essex County case brought by a bank against tenants in a property that the bank had taken back in foreclosure, Judge Irwin I. Kimmelman of State Superior Court ruled that the amendment did not apply.
Mr. Caraballo, whose office represents the tenants in the case, has appealed Judge Kimmelman's ruling to the Appellate Division of the Superior Court. It is the first appeal in a case of this type in New Jersey. If the appeal is successful, experts say, it could spell trouble for lenders.
Myron D. Milch, a Hackensack lawyer who specializes in mortgage foreclosures, said prohibiting buyers at foreclosure sales from evicting tenants would discourage active bidding.
In addition, he said, it would make it difficult for banks that take property back at sheriffs' sales to sell the property later with tenants in it. "Banks want to be banks," Mr. Milch said. "They don't want to be landlords."

HEADLINE: A Housing Goal For Every Town

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
WESTCHESTER municipalities already struggling with the county's month-old plan to build 500 units of affordable housing can now consider the impact of 10 times that number, as they study a report released last week by a citizens advisory group.
The report specifies the share of affordable housing that each of the county's 43 municipalities should provide to meet the county's goal of providing 5,000 units of permanent affordable housing for households with incomes ranging from $22,000 to $52,000. 
 It was approved at Tuesday's meeting of the Housing Implementation Commission and sets goals that range from 15 units in Buchanan to 825 units in Yonkers. [A map listing each community's allocation appears on page 10.]
The commission, an advisory board appointed by the County Executive, agreed more than a year ago that every municipality in the county should participate if a housing plan is to be truly fair; it has now defined that responsibility, giving each community an allocation -- the first time such an effort has been made in Westchester.
 
2 Attempts to Outline Policy
 The report relies on the estimates of housing need in the county provided by the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University last summer in an $80,000 study commissioned by the County Board of Legislators. Although legislators have said that they will not be able to assess each community's fair share without additional census data, commission members say that further delay is unnecessary.
The commission's report and the study commissioned by the Board of Legislators are separate attempts to outline a defensible housing policy amid growing concern that courts in the state, under pressure from developers and housing advocates, may soon mandate an affordable-housing program for local communities the way New Jersey courts have done, starting with the Mount Laurel decision of 1975.
To determine where affordable housing belongs in the county, the commission consulted housing specialists, reviewed court rulings and ran computer simulations. The commission said that communities with lots of available acreage should be considered as housing sites because they have the space and that communities with dense populations should be considered because they have sewer and road systems.
 
Commercial Space Is a Factor
 A critical factor in determining the amount of affordable housing each community should build, the commission said, is the growth in commercial space in those municipalities. "Communities that have benefitted from commercial growth are creating traffic jams, housing and school expenditures in other municipalities," the report said. "These communities have a responsibility to provide housing for the population that works within their boundries."
Bernice Giscombe, a vice president at Citibank and a real estate specialist, headed the commission task force that produced the report. "If you are a municipality that attracts jobs," she said, "you have to realize you are burdening surrounding municipalities if you don't have the housing for your workers. You have increased ratables, but your neighbors haven't."
The community housing plan will now be reviewed by municipal leaders, along with two other commission reports: one suggesting ways that communities can provide more low-cost housing and one exploring reasons for the county's current lack of rental housing and the substandard quality of much that exists. Their reactions, due within 45 days, could come during public hearings that the commission is planning to hold before it submits its final report to County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke.
The ad hoc group of planners, financial analysts, developers and community leaders was appointed two years ago by the County Executive and given a mandate to develop 5,000 units of permanent affordable housing before it is dissolved in June 1993.
The group's mission was short-circuited by State Attorney General Robert Abrams and by Mr. O'Rourke, who in mid-March produced his own plan to build the first 500 of the 5,000 units less than a month after Mr. Abrams ruled that counties have the authority to build and finance low-cost housing and to override local zoning if necessary.
The County Executive released his plan without consulting the commission. Relations with the group have been strained since last fall when Mr. O'Rourke fired the commission's chairman, David Bogdanoff, a builder in the county, after he accused Mr. O'Rourke of moving too slowly to persuade municipalities to build housing.
Although no new leader has been appointed and few regular meetings have been held, the commission, under an acting chairman, Guy Liebler, has continued its work of assessing the county's long-term housing needs.
Acting at the urging of its pro bono staff director, Joseph F. Dzaluk, executive director of the Westchester Housing Forum, a nonprofit agency promoting affordable housing for the middle class, the commission provided its own assessment of Westchester's need for affordable housing.
 
Allowing Accessory Apartments
 In a second task force report, a committee headed by Morton A. Smith, a partner in the White Plains law firm of Hall, Dickler, Lawler, Kent & Friedman, suggested that housing could be increased by allowing accessory apartments in every community and changing rent-control laws to allow the renting of vacant apartments in cooperative or condominiumum buildings.
"We have lots of illegal apartments in Westchester where landlords are gouging tenants," Mr. Smith said. "If you legalize them, you can control them a lot better while helping elderly people living alone to rent space."
Changing rent-control laws, Mr. Smith said, as has been done in New York City, would have an immediate effect in Westchester, "freeing 1,000 rental units to come on the market immediately." Landlords are reluctant to rent these apartments because current law requires leases of at least one year, Mr. Smith said, making them unattractive to potential purchasers of the properties.
A third report on existing housing, also issued by the commission, urges the county to begin planning for adequate housing for families earning less than $20,499 when it completes its housing plan. The report also calls on the county to develop a property-improvement program to help owners maintain existing housing stock.
Last week Mr. O'Rourke and the County's Acting Planning Commissioner, Lynn Oliva, attended the commission's meeting and briefed members on the status of the county's affordable-housing plan. The commission approved a resolution endorsing the plan as a "positive first step," but it recommended that more attention be paid to housing for families earning less than $28,000, the elderly and the homeless.
The reports by the Housing Implementation Commission will eventually go to the Board of Legislators, which is already considering the County Executive's plan as part of its own housing policy, one that the legislators say will pay more attention to the need for rental housing. The Housing Implementation Commission also passed a resolution urging quick adoption by the legislators of a statement of need as a first step in implementing an affordable-housing plan.
As his committee formulates its housing proposals and readies its statement of need, Timothy C. Carey, co-chairman of the Committee on Housing and Community Affairs, has said repeatedly that determining each community's fair share of any new housing will have to await 1990 census data that won't be available until next year.

HEADLINE: Point Man for the Rescue of the Century

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
WASHINGTON
Michel Camdessus, the head of the International Monetary Fund, visibly winces when he is confronted with some of the harshest criticisms of the fund's attempts to help hard-pressed developing nations by lending money and prescribing economic reforms.
John Cavanagh, an expert on developing countries at the left-of-center Institute for Policy Studies in Washington, says: "The I.M.F. in many ways is like a medieval doctor where no matter what the ailment, you apply leeches and bleed the patient. My experience is they are very successful in steering countries' resources toward paying debts to commercial banks, but they are disastrous in terms of the long-term economic health of these countries." 
 Alan Reynolds, an economist at the right-of-center Hudson Institute, a think tank in Indianapolis, harbors similar feelings. "We know what works, and the I.M.F. just doesn't get it," he said. "They use a form of central planning -- with high taxes, high tariffs and weak currencies -- that hasn't worked in promoting growth." One of Mr. Reynolds's favorite I.M.F. disaster stories: Haiti, which has gone through 21 I.M.F. programs and is still in dire straits.
But the epithet of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt is the most succinct -- and cutting -- of all. He called the I.M.F. the "International Misery Fund."
In its 48-year history, the I.M.F. has never wanted for critics, though the fund also has plenty of equally vocal supporters who say it has been indispensable in righting the faltering economies of numerous developing countries.
The amount of criticism heaped upon Mr. Camdessus will no doubt jump sharply over the next few months as he assumes a new high-profile role. He has suddenly become the Western world's point man in what could be the biggest economic challenge of the century: seeing that Russia and the other former Soviet republics survive the wrenching transition from seven decades of Communism and central economic planning to market-based economies.
 
Including Ex-Soviet Republics
 In a historic move here tomorrow, the I.M.F. is expected to announce that its 156 member nations voted to let Russia and the other republics become members. The stakes couldn't be higher. Mr. Camdessus believes that if the I.M.F. and Group of Seven industrial nations fail to snatch the republics from the jaws of economic chaos, there could be a new hostile dictatorship in Russia, a rebirth of the cold war and many more years of hardship for 290 million people.
"Certainly I fear failure; I fear reactionary forces will come back to power," Mr. Camdessus said, sitting in his sun-drenched, mahogany-paneled office three blocks west of the White House. "If we fail, it will be a failure for the whole international community."
The impressions from a recent trip to Russia still haunt him. "When you go to Moscow you have a tangible sense that it is a place where the history of the world is being made," he said. "But in the streets, you see utter poverty. You feel you have to mobilize yourself to help."
The aid effort to Russia and the other republics is by far the most ambitious undertaking in I.M.F. history. Mr. Camdessus (pronounced cahm-duh-SUE) estimates they will need far more than $100 billion in foreign aid over the next four years. The fund is rushing to send dozens of experts to Russia, Azerbaijan, Uzbekistan and other republics to advise them on how to balance their budgets, remove price controls, build social safety nets and slash money supply growth to reduce inflation. It is also coordinating aid efforts by individual nations, and the World Bank and other international agencies.
As the I.M.F. is drawn into the affairs of the republics, one of the world's most powerful economic institutions will become larger and more powerful. More than 50 nations are already following its reform programs, which helps explain why it has long been demonized as an all-powerful, behind-the-scenes puppeteer for the third world. Forty more countries are negotiating such programs and hope to receive billions in I.M.F. loans in return.
Whether the I.M.F. will have enough money to help the former Soviet Union and all these other countries is a question often debated at its offices, and in the corridors of Washington and other capitals. The problem is that the I.M.F. needs $60 billion, which its members provisionally approved two years ago. But formal approval -- and the actual flow of funds -- is lagging, particularly because Congress still hasn't authorized the $12 billion that would be the United States' share.
"We can't do the work we have to do, not only in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, but Africa and Asia, unless we have the financial means," Mr. Camdessus said. With a focus on Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, many African, Asian and Latin American leaders fear that they will get short rations if additional funds don't appear soon.
The I.M.F. has at times been an institution in search of a mission. It was founded near the end of World War II to supervise a fixed exchange-rate system and help industrialized countries cope with temporary payments imbalances. With the end of the fixed rates in the early 70's, it looked as if the I.M.F. had no role. But when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries stormed onto the scene in 1973, the I.M.F. began to help channel petrodollars from rich Arab states to developing nations.
In the early 1980's, the fund became enmeshed in the third-world debt crisis and was an intermediary between developing countries and commercial banks eager to be repaid. With the debt crisis ebbing in recent years, the I.M.F. again appeared to be casting about for a mission. Then Communism collapsed.
"We don't have the right to miss this opportunity," Mr. Camdessus said. "Alone, we can't do anything, but we can be the catalyst for international support." He said the former Soviet Union will need $44 billion in aid this year; close to $5 billion is expected to come from the I.M.F.
Over the last few months the fund has radically reoriented its staff. It has expanded to 2,200 employees from 2,000 and assigned more than 150 to work full time on the former Soviet Union.
 
The Butt of Jokes
 Sending an I.M.F. army of advisers to Russia has brought sardonic jokes from critics, who wonder whether Russia, the patient, will survive the medicine of I.M.F., the doctor.
"There are two kinds of economic policies," Mr. Camdessus responds. "Those that work and those that don't work." He argues that Russia, and any other countries sincere about regaining their economic health, have little choice but to adopt the reforms recommended by the I.M.F.
I.M.F. programs typically aim to slash inflation and stop capital flight by getting countries to reduce budget deficits and tighten money supply growth -- moves that cause people from Poland to Peru to complain. The fund also works with countries to reduce the financing gaps that result from trade deficits and debt servicing costs. The programs often call on countries to increase exports and reduce imports, which generally hurts consumers. Many nations are told to reduce bloated bureaucracies and get rid of money-losing state businesses, both moves that can throw thousands out of work.
Not surprisingly, many countries follow some recommendations but ignore others. Mr. Camdessus contends there is a simple reason why so many of the countries that had I.M.F. programs remain in bad shape: they failed to follow the program.
Mr. Camdessus takes a full-speed-ahead approach to reform. "If one wants to go fast, it's more painful," he admitted. "But if one goes slowly one just prolongs the pain, and that's not good for anyone."
The I.M.F.'s recommendations for Russia are aimed at slashing inflation, which is expected to reach 1,000 percent this year. It wants Russia to balance its budget, after the former Soviet Union's deficit came to about 20 percent of gross domestic product last year. Fund officials are also pressing Russia to remove all price controls, privatize retail operations and restrict the flow of credits to inefficient enterprises teetering near bankruptcy. But to the frustration of I.M.F. officials, state enterprises have persuaded Moscow to ease credit and provide 200 billion rubles in new loans to keep them afloat.
The fund has also called on Russia to lift its oil prices fifteenfold, to world levels. This would shock consumers and reduce consumption at home, but would enable Russia to increase exports and export revenues. The fund has called for removing across-the-board food subsidies and targeting aid to the vulnerable -- like the elderly and unemployed. Like I.M.F. countries before it, Russia will have to navigate between the Scylla of what society will tolerate and the Charybdis of the I.M.F.'s demands.
In recent months, I.M.F. experts have flocked to Russia and other republics to teach the ABC's of market economies. With the help of other international agencies, these experts are explaining how to run central banks, compile accurate statistics, control budget expenditures and administer a tax system.
"The difficulties will be greater in Russia than elsewhere because they have never known capitalism," said Mr. Camdessus. "It's going to be a long road for them."
Mr. Camdessus, who is 58 years old and left his post as head of the Bank of France to become the I.M.F.'s managing director in 1987, is generally credited with making the I.M.F. a kinder, gentler institution. He has made it put less emphasis on austerity, which can lead to social unrest, and more on growth. In the speeches he gives in places like Lagos, Nigeria, and Lima, Peru, he reminds audiences that the purpose of the I.M.F.-approved straitjackets is to produce more growth long-term. To that end, he has introduced highly subsidized loans of one-half of 1 percent a year to the poorest countries.
Mr. Camdessus's critics concede that he has, far more than his seven predecessors, stressed the notion of social safety nets. It reflects his central banker's hunger for order, discipline and getting things done, combined with the French intellectual's love for social democracy. (Although he was recommended by President Francois Mitterrand of France, he disclaims any political affiliation.)
In Russia's case, Mr. Camdessus says that creation of an adequate safety net is crucial. He nervously watched the Russian Parliament's recent near-revolt against the painful reforms implemented by President Boris N. Yeltsin and how that tussle almost caused his Cabinet to resign.
"The situation is dangerously chaotic over there," he said. "Everyone knows that revolutions often devour their children. It took my country 2,000 years to develop a market economy. In Russia, they are trying to telescope it into a few months."
Responding to his critics of the right, Mr. Camdessus said the fund does not always offer a recipe of higher taxes, asserting that the fund sometimes recommends lower taxes to help spur industry. I.M.F. officials point to Argentina, Costa Rica and Jamaica as countries where taxes were lowered at the I.M.F.'s urging. But as a general rule, he says, solid tax revenues are needed to help hold down budget deficits and inflation.
He counters critics of the left who say the fund is a collection agency for the industrialized world's commercial banks by noting that in recent years he has pressed banks to forgive some third world debts. I.M.F. officials point to pressures the fund put on banks with troubled loans in Argentina, Mexico and Venezuela.
Mr. Camdessus admits the left has a valid point that safety nets set up under I.M.F. programs often have too many holes. "Sometimes there just aren't the resources to set up the type of safety net we would like," he said.
Mr. Camdessus also rebuts charges that the I.M.F. causes hunger: "Mismanagement of national economies hurts the poorest most. You don't correct in 15 months the consequences of 15 years of mismanagement."
These criticisms from the left and right have had a particular resonance here in recent months as Congress has dragged its feet on approving the $12 billion in new funding and the Bush Administration remained silent on the matter. In an election year when voters are opposed to foreign aid in the face of recession at home, Congress has been reluctant to vote the money. And President Bush, stung by criticisms that he is too focused on foreign affairs and neglects the domestic economy, has not wanted to push the lawmakers.
I.M.F. officials were clearly delighted when President Bush called on Congress April 1 to approve the $12 billion, which will in effect be an interest-bearing investment in the fund. Although most officials say Congress will eventually approve the money, many say that probably will not happen until after the election.
Mr. Camdessus, who in January began a second five-year term as the I.M.F.'s head, has learned to view all the commotion here and abroad with equanimity. If imitation is the sincerest flattery, then the I.M.F. is succeeding splendidly. Despite what critics contend is the fund's penchant for trauma-inducing reforms, he is proud that many countries have begun to embrace -- on their own -- policies that the I.M.F. has long promoted. He cites Mexico, Argentina and Czechoslovakia as sterling examples.
"They have been inspired by examples of success that have occurred elsewhere," he said. "There are spirals of success, just as there are spirals of failure."
 
 
 
AHEAD OF THE CURVE AT I.M.F.
 Michel Camdessus sometimes finds himself on the other side of the fence from the Bush Administration. He sought to bar I.M.F. loans to third world nations unless they cut their military budgets, but the United States and several other industrial nations blocked that idea. He began pushing for debt relief for the third world, not just rescheduling, before the United States and other industrial nations were ready to accept that notion.
He frequently chides Washington for its astronomical budget deficit, saying it is unfair that at a time when the developing world badly needs money for investment so much of the world's savings go to finance the American deficit.
"Camdessus has usually been ahead of the curve," said Richard Feinberg, president of Inter-American Dialogue, a public policy group specializing in hemispheric issues. "He has been a bold, imaginative civil servant who has been foresighted and courageous enough to get out ahead on many issues."
The son of a journalist in Bayonne in southern France, Mr. Camdessus graduated from France's famed Ecole Nationale d'Administration and joined the French Treasury in 1960. He became director 22 years later and in that position was chairman of the Paris Club, which oversaw rescheduling efforts of government-to-government debt owed by the third world.
Despite its occasional differences with Mr. Camdessus, the Bush Administration turned to the I.M.F. to coordinate efforts to help the former Soviet Union. Officials in Washington say that after the Group of Seven industrial nations chose the European Community executive commission to coordinate aid to Eastern Europe, Washington felt left out. Washington turned to the I.M.F., officials say, partly because the United States has the strongest voice there.
 
 
 
DO THE I.M.F. TARGETS WORK?
 The ultimate test of the I.M.F.'s success is whether countries that follow its reform programs grow faster than they would have without the programs. Some studies have been encouraging, some less so.
A study by the I.M.F. Assessment Project, a nonpartisan group of economists, found that in the late 1980's countries that met economic-reform targets in I.M.F. programs raised their annual growth rate to 4.3 percent from 1.2 percent. Those that missed targets saw their growth rise to 1.4 percent from 1.1 percent.
But Gregory A. Fossedal, the economist who supervised the study, said these figures did not necessarily show that the I.M.F.'s recommendations were the reason for success. "It's easier for countries that have more growth in the first place to meet the I.M.F. targets," he said.
The project's study also showed that a country's balance of payments swung from deficit into surplus if it met the I.M.F. targets. In countries that missed their targets, the deficits more than doubled.
But a 1990 study by the I.M.F. itself reached a less sanguine conclusion -- an I.M.F. fiscal reform program made almost no difference to a country's growth. This appeared to buttress those critics who argue that the I.M.F.'s tilt toward fiscal austerity squeezes growth out of a country's economic system. I.M.F. officials assert, however, that the reform programs at least prepared the groundwork for future growth by pushing down inflation and improving balance of payments.
Confusing attempts to assess the I.M.F. is the frequency with which countries fail to meet targets. A study by Jacques Polak, a former senior I.M.F. official, found that in 1988 and 1989 countries missed I.M.F. monetary and fiscal targets 60 percent of the time.
That research drives home one basic point that Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F.'s managing director, preaches. A fund program can achieve little unless a government is serious about sticking to it, he says.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Supply of Stocks Rises to Meet Demand for Cash

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Supply will rise to meet any demand.
That may not be true for all businesses, or for all time. But it certainly helps explain what has been going on in the stock market in 1992. 
 The decision by General Motors to issue as much as $2.8 billion in common stock, some of it to its pension funds but most of it to be sold to investors, is only the latest piece of evidence that demand for stock, no matter how great, may be matched or even exceeded by corporate America's desire for cash.
G.M.'s shares have soared 37 percent in 1992, as investors looked for the economic rebound and then gleefully reacted to the G.M. coup, when the board discovered it had authority over management. (It was a bloodless uprising. Lloyd E. Reuss may be out as president, but he is still on the payroll. Layoffs are for hourly workers.) For G.M., grabbing the money before investors have a chance to see just how the new G.M. will perform is probably a good idea.
Unfortunately for stock market investors, G.M.'s share performance this year has been the exception, not the rule. The average stock is down a bit since Dec. 31, and the market surge after the Fed eased credit on April 9 has almost entirely vanished. "This rally has been the weakest one we've had" in at least a couple of years, notes Bob Farrell, the chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch.
The Dow Jones industrial average, down 42.04 to 3,324.46 last week, is still up 4.5 percent since the last Fed move. But the Nasdaq composite fell 3.2 percent last week, its worst weekly showing since small stocks bottomed in October 1990, and is now at its lowest level of 1992.
The failure of stocks to do much in 1992 is all the more amazing in that mutual fund purchasers have probably put something like $25 billion into stocks this year. That is a record pace, but it has not been enough to absorb all the new shares being issued.
The mutual fund figures now are more important than ever because pension funds are not seeing much new cash. Individual investors, whether directly or through funds, have been the ones soaking up the billions of new stock offerings.
Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services of Arcata, Calif., which tracks mutual fund cash flows, says there were signs of a slackening of buying interest earlier in the month, but it seems to be coming back. And Fidelity Investments says that retirement money is still flowing in, as investors abandon banks.
The stock market is not the only one dependent on mutual fund investors. The funds are the major buyers now of junk bonds and of municipal bonds. "What happens," asks Henry Kaufman, the economist and money manager, "when short-term interest rates start to rise?" The answer, he suggests, could be a lot of volatility as money is pulled out of mutual funds.
That, in a nutshell, is the problem. Mutual fund demand for stocks could be temporary. But the supply of shares now being issued will not soon vanish.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1602 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/April 19-24

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
G.M.'s New Leadership Begins Putting Its Team in Place 

Earlier this month, there was a coup at the General Motors Corporation, which lost $4.5 billion last year. Last week, when John F. Smith Jr., the company's president, introduced the new junta on closed-circuit TV, analysts said it finally looked as if the world's No. 1, auto maker had brought in the "A" team. J. Michael Losh, general manager of Oldsmobile, will run G.M.'s sales and marketing operations and its Canadian and Mexican divisions. Michael Mutchler will be in charge of North American Passenger Car Platforms, the division that actually builds the cars, and J. T. Battenberg III will oversee G.M.'s worldwide components business. All good people, the analysts said. G.M. plans the largest common stock offering in American history -- up to $2.8 billion. Its pension funds get $500 million of stock, with the rest going to the public. "Market psychology is with them," said Mary Ann Sudol of Fitch Investors Service.

American Air Muscles Its Rivals
 
Since the seats they sell are all pretty much the same, airlines can really only compete on price. That kind of competition is brutal, but it is one that American Airlines, with its low-cost operations, is betting it can win. Last week, American lowered its ticket prices for the second time this month and eased advanced restrictions to 14 days from 21 days on some of its fares. To stay aloft, American's weaker rivals -- bankrupt T.W.A. and America West Airlines -- have been forced to do the same. But those debt-laden carriers may not survive American's bruising confrontation, analysts say. "There's going to be another round of consolidation here," said Kevin Murphy, an airline analyst at Morgan Stanley. T.W.A. and America West could be forced into merging with stronger carriers, he said.

Like a Magnate
 
Not only does the "Material Girl" cut quite a figure on stage, she also cuts quite a deal. Last week, Time Warner Inc., agreed to a 7-year contract with Madonna worth $60 million. With Time Warner, she will form a multi-media entertainment company -- Maverick -- to nurture new talent and develop movie, TV and music projects. The contract gives her a $5 million advance for each of her next seven albums and a 20 percent royalty rate -- the same as mega-star Michael Jackson gets. Time Warner will commit another $2 million a year to Maverick. "In other deals where artists get their own labels, such perks are usually window-dressing to satisfy their egos. Madonna is different," said Charles Koppelman, chief operating officer of EMI Records North America. Madonna is indeed different. She has sold 70 million copies of her albums so far.

The High-Tech Flashcard
 
Flashcards are what people used to use when they needed to learn Latin -- or the multiplication tables. Not anymore. The term now applies to compact computer memories. Last week, the Intel Corporation said it would sell credit-card-sized flash cards that can store 20 megabytes of information. Those cards could replace bulky hard-disk drives. Intel's card, which will sell for $600, has no moving parts, can be erased, does not lose information when the electrical power is switched off and is not bothered by vibration. "You can put them in small computers that don't have room for a drive and where you want extended battery life," said Michael Murphy, editor of the California Technology Stock Letter. Mr. Murphy expects the market -- now tiny -- to reach $1.5 billion by 1995.

Teledyne's Troubles With Justice
 
The Justice Department accused Teledyne Inc., the big Los Angeles-based military contractor, of falsifying tests on electromagnetic relays, which it produces at the rate of 200,000 a month. The relays are used in military weapons systems, missiles, airplanes and rockets. The civil suit said Teledyne certified to the Government that its relays had passed rigorous tests that were either never done or were done improperly. Teledyne charged the Government a $20 testing fee on each $6 part. Teledyne may have defrauded the Government of $250 million, the Government said.

A Dirty Diamond Deal?
 
Last week, Edward J. Russell filed a suit in a Cincinnati court alleging that the General Electric Company and De Beers, the South African diamond cartel, conspired to fix prices on industrial diamonds. The Justice Department confirmed that it is looking into the charges. Mr. Russell, who worked for G.E., said he was dismissed last year after objecting to the company's dealings with De Beers. He said that when he left G.E., it raised diamond prices 15 percent. That increase was matched by De Beers. "Generally industrial prices follow gem prices, although not in a one-to-one manner," said Peter Bell, of Norton Inc., a leading user of industrial diamonds. But during that period, the market for gem-quality diamonds was flat. Mr. Russell is seeking reinstatement at G.E. and unspecified monetary damages.

Caterpillar Gets Its Way
 
Differences remain, but last week members of the United Automobile Workers Union trudged back to Caterpillar Inc., after a five-month strike. Negotiations will continue over salaries; Caterpillar offered its top workers $39,000; the Union wants $40,000.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Loosened Controls on Exports
 
High-tech weapons won the war in the Persian Gulf for America and its allies. But some items also wound up in the hands of the Iraqis, although export controls were supposed to prevent that. But those controls hurt business and should be eased, the high-tech manufacturers argued. Besides, the cold war is over. Last week, the Administration heard the manufacturers' pleas. It relaxed the rules governing exports of American technology, including supercomputers and gadgets that detect airplanes and submarines, to Europe, Japan and Australia. "We relaxed trade restrictions on exports that served us well during the cold-war era, but are no longer necessary in our new world," President Bush said last week. Critics, like Gary Mihollin, director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control, disagree. "We should learn something from the Gulf War," he said.

It Isn't Exactly al Dente
 
As recoveries go, this one has about as much snap as a soggy noodle. Orders for durable -- big-ticket, long-lasting items like washing machines, airplanes and refrigerators, were no different. According to the Commerce Department, orders increased by 1.6 percent last month after remaining unchanged in February. Nearly all the gains were accounted for by the aircraft industry.
Unemployment Lines Thin Out
Good news on the employment side. For the last three weeks, new unemployment claims have fallen, the Labor Department said. Claims for the week ending April 11, fell to 404,000 the lowest level in six months.

Now, the Rich Are Very Different
 
Report cards on Reaganomics -- most of them mixed -- have been arriving for years. But the latest one, from the Federal Reserve and the Internal Revenue Service, was the first from the Government. Overall, private wealth grew in the 1980's, the reports said. But the richest 1 percent of the country snatched the largest gains. The top 1 percent had 37 percent of the country's total net worth, up from 31 percent in 1983. By 1989, the top 1 percent (834,00 households) was worth about $5.7 trillion -- more than the bottom 90 percent (84 million households). "Its another example of a big, unprecedented jump in inequality to Great Gatsby levels," said Paul Krugman, an economist at M.I.T.

The Income Slope Gets Slipperier
 
The good news, the Commerce Department said last week, was that personal income rose last year by 2.1 percent. Though that's not a strong increase, at least the sign was positive. But the bad news was that last year's inflation rate was 4.1 percent. That meant most Americans lost ground.

 
 
INTERNATIONAL


Conversation Continues at GATT
 
President Bush and Jacques Delors, president of the European Community's executive commission, sat toe-to-toe in Washington last week talking about trade. They got nowhere. Mr. Bush failed to persuade the community to reduce the subsidies its gives its farmers. Those subsidies allow European farmers to undercut their American counterparts on the world market. Farmers have plenty of political clout in Europe. The failure of last week's discussions puts in doubt other trade negotiations through the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs. "No topic on our agenda is more crucial than the Uruguay Round. We are committed to achieve an early agreement," Mr. Bush said. Early? The current negotiations have been underway for nearly six years.

Is Rolls Downwardly Mobile?
 
The recession has been particularly tough on aristocratic Rolls-Royce Motor Cars. Sales of its elegant land yachts fell last year by 50 percent, to 1,731 cars, prompting its parent, Britain's Vickers P.L.C., to put the company on the block. Japan's Toyota kicked the tires. But last week, Shoichido Toyoda, its president, said he was being rushed by Vickers to make up his mind. "They wanted an answer very quickly," he said. So the answer they got was 'no.' Rumor has it General Motors, Ford Motor, Fiat and Mitsubishi are also interested in the car maker.
 
Imported Beer Drinkers Lament
 
Americans who like to swill their Molson, Moosehead and Labatt are likely find that Canadian brews will soon cost more. The Administration said last week it would slap duties on Canadian beer.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Alamo's Big Drive to Lower Prices

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Vacationing travelers may find plenty of reason to applaud Alamo Rent A Car's "Great American Rates," the program of sharply discounted uniform nationwide rates that the company announced last week.
For example, a Cadillac that rented for $36.99 a day in Miami and $64.99 in Chicago now goes for $29 at all 102 Alamo outlets. Mid-size cars were reduced to $19 a day, and economy cars were cut to $15. The only hitches: 24-hour advance booking is required and the renter must keep the car over a Saturday night. 
 The cut-rate program was not welcome news, however, to competitors in the beleaguered auto rental business, which has been struggling lately with declining prices, rising costs, slim profits and customers who skip around to save a dollar.
For his part, Macdonald Clark, Alamo's executive vice president in charge of sales and marketing, is betting that a bigger slice of the $11.4 billion car rental market will more than make up for thinner profit margins from Alamo's discounted prices. Alamo now has roughly 10 percent of the business.
"Overall, we should come out ahead of the game," said Mr. Clark, 52 years old, for whom the auto rental industry is a third career, following more than a decade in retailing and five years practicing law. He joined Alamo in 1983 as vice president for sales.
With the new program, Mr. Clark appeared to rip a page out of American Airlines's playbook. On April 9, the carrier announced sweeping changes to simplify its fare structure and cut many prices. But Mr. Clark said he had hatched the idea for Alamo's cuts the weekend before.
He nonetheless welcomed the timing of the two announcements. Increased flight bookings mean more business for all rental-car companies and, presumably, better results from the millions of dollars Alamo is spending to market the new program.
"The airlines set the tone and pace for what happens, and the timing is at the right point," Mr. Clark said last week in a telephone interview from his office at Alamo's headquarters in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.
The announcement by American, the industry leader, quickly set off an avalanche of similar changes by other airlines. But the shift by Alamo did not rouse its larger competitors to respond to the same degree. Hertz bested Alamo's daily rate for economy cars by a penny and Avis matched it at some locations. Otherwise, they are standing pat.

HEADLINE: For One American, Britain Is the Land of Opportunity

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

DATELINE: WOLVERHAMPTON, England

 BODY:
Anne Evans wants to go home.
The British Government and tire dealers may be glad to have the 35-year-old American entrepreneur in this industrial city near Birmingham. But to hear her tell it, she was forced to come here to save her family's eastern Connecticut real estate business, which has been pushed to the brink by the recession. 
 "I have no choice. There are no opportunities at home," Mrs. Evans said.
The opportunity for her here was applying American technology to a problem that Britain is only now facing up to: discarded used tires. There are about 250 million stacked around the country and the piles are growing by about 21 million a year.
Mrs. Evans is heading a group that is building and will own Britain's first electricity-generating plant to use tires as fuel. As part of its diversification efforts, Nipsco Industries Inc., parent of Indiana's largest gas and electric utility, is providing the vast majority of the equity financing for the project as well as technical expertise.
Sites in Britain where tires can be dumped or buried have become scarce. And Britons are also discovering something that Americans have long known: not only can tire dumps be a nightmare if they catch fire like a nearby one did recently but they also serve as an ideal breeding ground for disease-carrying mosquitoes.
In 1990, the British Government decided to provide subsidies to encourage private companies to build tire-burning power plants. Projects like that -- which involve not only getting the plant built, arranging tire deliveries and selling the electricity -- are exactly what Mrs. Evans knows how to do.
She has advised the United States Government and tire industry on ways to dispose waste tires and served as a project consultant for a tire-fueled power plant in Sterling, Conn.
The $80 million plant being built here by Elm Energy and Recycling (U.K.) Ltd., the company that she founded and heads, will burn about 10 million tires a year to generate 25 megawatts of electricity, enough to supply 25,000 homes. Construction began in April and the plant should be completed by the fall of 1993. Its incinerators are being designed by Basic Environmental Engineering, an Illinois company.
Tire dealers can't wait for the plant to go into operation. "You can still find landfills for chopped tires but it's hard if not impossible to get them to take whole tires," said Carmel Prosser, an owner of Challenger Tyres, a local dealer and retreader that has get rid of 25,000 to 30,000 tires a year. It now has to pay up to 60 cents per tire for disposal. "Anne's plant will halve that," Ms. Prosser said with a big smile.
Mrs. Evans has also signed contracts with big tire-dealer chains owned by American and European corporations like Goodyear, Michelin, Dunlop, Pirelli, Continental and Shell.
It is stretching it to call Anne Evans a modern-day version of the people who fled from the Dust Bowl of the 1930's in search of work. She is not exactly destitute.
She was able to scrape up $250,000 to invest in the power-plant project. She also can afford to commute regularly to her home in Hebron, Conn., although she now only flies home twice a month instead of every weekend as she did for most of the two years she has been working on the project. Nevertheless, she is an economic refugee.
Long before coming here, Mrs. Evans was an entrepreneur in her own right. She built a tire dealership that her grandfather had founded into an international tire distributor and broker. It buys surplus tires from manufacturers and then gets them quickly to anyone around the world who needs particular tires in a jiffy.
Thanks to the recession, though, that business is barely in the black and is not generating nearly enough money to bail out the debt-laden real estate business that her husband, Russ, runs.
"I stuck with this project because the recession is so bad in Connecticut. It forced me to see this through the times I said it is more than I can bear."
She grimaced as she recalled the insults she had to tolerate from British bankers with dim views of entrepreneurs, especially female entrepreneurs.
She also has had the pleasure of contending with problems left behind by industrial concerns that inhabited the plant's six-acre site during the preceding centuries. There were coals mines to be filled and slag piles to be removed.
Whom does she blame for her family's financial woes? Mostly the New England banks that have sharply cut lending to would-be home buyers and real estate developers. "I hold them responsible for being so irresponsible in lending to all the big developers. Now those bad debts are biting all of us little guys," she said.
She insists that she doesn't think the Republicans or Democrats or a particular leader can be blamed for the recession. "We were all part of the 80's," she said. But when she discusses the Presidential election, it's obvious that her faith in the Republicans has been shaken. "I just can't say because I'm a Republican I'll vote Republican. I want to think long and hard about it," she said.
The fact that Mrs. Evans, a former Republican activist, feels this way would not seem to bode well for George Bush's chances for re-election. In the mid-1970's, she and her husband worked on the staff of Robert Steele, a Republican Congressman from Connecticut who lost the state's 1974 gubernatorial contest. In the late 70's, she was on the staff of the Republican National Congressional Campaign Committee, a fund-raising group.
With her bright green outfit, warm smile and exuberance about the power-plant project, Mrs. Evans initially comes across as an archetypal go-getter American entrepreneur.
But not very deep beneath that exterior lie the doubts about the future that now seem to pervade middle- and even upper-class America.
She told of a dinner party she had attended during a recent visit home. The 20 people there included a teacher, bankers, an insurance broker, realtors, a building contractor and other small-business owners. "There was nobody in that room who knew if in six months they would be employed or have a business," she said. "There was a lot of hopelessness.
"I was the lucky one. I was about to close on the bank financing for this project, which would remove the danger of us losing our house. I'm very fortunate because Britain's Department of Trade and Industry had invited me here and because I've got Nipsco, who thinks this is a neat project." Nipsco's backing helped Mrs. Evans secure $60 million in bank loans.
Nipsco is interested in working with Mrs. Evans to build additional European plants, said Stephen P. Adik, the company's chief financial officer and president of one of its two units responsible diversification. Nipsco, whose assets total about $3 billion, aims to increase the portion of its assets outside traditional utilities to 5 percent within four years from about 1.5 percent now.
He thinks the demand for such plants could be greater in Europe than in the United States because many existing coal-fired electric-power plants in America can use some tires as fuel while European plants cannot.
Mrs. Evans is already exploring the possibility of building a smaller tire-fueled power plant in Scotland and is interested in another in Belgium. That sounds a bit surprising given how she claims to be pining for her husband and her dog, a white Samoyed named Oscar Bear whose photos adorn her office.
"I don't want this to happen again. I want everything I own never again to be at risk," she explained. "That dream is affordable if I do this horribleness for three more years."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anne Evans, entrepreneur from Connecticut, at one of the British retreaders which will sell scrap tires to her. (Jonathan Player for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: At Work;
Caterpillar's White-Collar Lessons

SERIES: First of two articles on structural changes in work.

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
The contrast in images couldn't be harsher. Two weeks ago, the strikers at Caterpillar gathered in lines five-angry-and-noisy-men deep at plant gates. Last week, solidarity made moot, they shuffled back to work, accepting Caterpillar's terms while talks on a new contract continue.
Middle-class, white-collar workers may see nothing but losers and monster-truck-racing fans in the group, instead of events involving an institution that once wielded the power to protect its members from portal to portal and cradle to grave. Why should a corporate employee care whether a company breaks with its tradition of relatively cordial worker relations to play hardball and bring a manufacturing union to heel? Labor economists and employment experts warn that the experience of Caterpillar's workers may be a harbinger for white-collar employees. 
 "The implicit social contract between employers and employees has changed," said Carrie Leana, an associate professor at the graduate school of business at the University of Pittsburgh. "What used to be thought of as ruthless isn't anymore. That is true for accountants as well as steelworkers." She added: "It used to matter to companies that an employee had worked there for 10 or 20 years. It doesn't matter anymore."
Clearly it mattered more, say, 30 years ago, when more than 35 percent of the work force was unionized, a figure that has dropped to 16 percent. But did it matter because so many workers were unionized and seniority was institutionalized or because the world was a nicer place?
Experts find the precise impact of unions difficult to assess. At the very least, there was the "threats" effect. "Nonunion companies were always looking over their shoulders," said Stanley Aronowitz, a sociology professor at the City University of New York, "worried about what unions might do."
For example, labor's decision to fight for pensions and benefits in the immediate post-World War II period shaped the private pension system nationally. "The unions pushed for pensions, which were matched for white-collar workers," said Richard Freeman, an economist at Harvard University.
The impact of the decline in unionization is already being felt in some quantifiable ways. According to Richard Belous, senior economist at the National Planning Association, in 1980, 50 percent of the work force was covered by a pension; by 1993, he estimates, that will drop to 40 percent.
The decline is also being seen in an increase in wage inequality as the practice of "pattern bargaining," or pegging wage demands to compensation at other companies in a particular industry, comes under attack. The practice -- the major issue in the Caterpillar-United Auto Workers strike -- became a model for compensation throughout corporate America.
"The breakdown of pattern bargaining means you are more dependent on your company," Dr. Freeman said, adding, "It may put blue- and white-collar people together. It's more Japanese-style. You get both the benefits and detriments."
The distinct shades of collar colors, long cherished by white-collar workers, especially those moving up the hierarchy from one generation to the next, is another likely casualty of union decline. Barry Bluestone, a professor of political economy at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, sees a blurring of lines now that workers are no longer tethered to a machine. "Now blue-collar workers are in teams," he said, "they are given more discretion and they have some decision-making powers."
Improvements for blue-collar workers have occurred while white-collar workers have become more vulnerable. "They would be less so if they were unionized," said Adrienne Eaton, a labor studies professor at Rutgers Unversity.
In the United States -- unlike in other industrialized countries -- white-collar resistance to unionization is extensive. But even when the current downturn passes, few labor experts believe workplace relations will be as amicable as in the high-growth period after World War II -- or that employer generosity will be restored. "I am a white-collar worker," said Dr. Leana of the University of Pittsburgh. "It makes me nervous to see the balance of interests between employees and employers so out of whack."
 
 
 
WHERE MOST MANAGERS FIT IN
 For their continued employment, white-collar workers typically depend more on the kindness of market forces than the contractual relationship that inheres between labor and management. That fact may leave lower- and middle-managers, the bulk of the white-collar work force, particularly maladapted for a new order in employee-employer relations.
"White-collar workers in the current climate are vulnerable to layoffs and job insecurity and cutbacks," said Adrienne Eaton of Rutgers Unversity. The current climate -- a recessionary economy -- is likely to change, but the new corporate lean-and-mean ethos is not, and that leaves many corporate white-collar workers feeling betrayed. The people emblematic of the good times -- deal-doers and chief executives with astronomical compensation and platinum parachutes -- represent a portion of the white-collar work force roughly the size of a paramecium.
"C.E.O.'s have nothing to do with white-collar workers," said Carrie Leana, who with Daniel Feldman is the author of "Coping With Job Loss," a study of layoffs. "They are an aristocracy of managers. That is not the way life is for most managers." Lower- and middle-management, she contends, have more in common with the Caterpillar workers than with C.E.O.'s in terms of how they are treated and their prospects, a reality many managers find painful. "They believed in the system more," Dr. Leana said.

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Northwestern;
A Charity That Never Filed A Tax Return

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill.

 BODY:
Northwestern University's largest student-run organization, which has raised about $1.5 million for charity in its 18 years of operation, never filed for tax-exempt status and never filed tax returns. It may thus be liable for thousands of dollars in taxes and penalties, according to tax experts.
If the organization, Dance Marathon, registers now with state and Federal authorities, the $1.5 million could be looked upon as taxable income, or Dance Marathon could ask to be retroactively declared tax-exempt, tax experts say. Either way, the experts say, it still could be liable for up to $75,000 in penalties. 
 And Harvey Dale, director of the New York University Law School program on philanthropy and the law, said that, without the exemption, the organization's donors may not be able to take a tax deduction for their contributions.
 
Reported in Student Paper
 Dance Marathon's failure to obtain tax-exempt status was reported last week by the campus newspaper, The Daily Northwestern, which was investigating how the organization dispenses the money it raises.
Dance Marathon is a 30-hour dance marathon held each winter for which student groups raise money to send contestants; the money benefits one charity each year. The unpaid student staff of 24 executive board members and 400 committee members spends the year planning the event. The organization has an office in the student center, but receives no money from the student government or Northwestern.
It is the "largest all-student-run activity at Northwestern," said the organization's publicity co-chairwoman, Amy Falk, a senior in communication studies from Hickory Hills, Ill. The organization said some 20,000 students and community members attended this year's event, which raised $273,000 in cash and prizes. Of that, $200,000 went to the American Diabetes Association; of the remaining money, $18,000 was for overhead and $55,000 was the value of donated prizes and food at the event.
A university student activities adviser attends its meetings and "helps with contracts and answers questions about administrative things," Ms. Falk said. The adviser works for and is appointed by the Norris University Center, and appointments can change every year, said Bruce Kaiser, the center's director.
This year's adviser, Karin Lacour, did not return repeated telephone calls. But Mr. Kaiser said that he did not believe she knew about the failure to file tax returns.
 
First Event in 1975
 The history of Dance Marathon is sketchy and its tax status all these years is unclear. It began in 1975 as an event sponsored by the Associated Student Government and Alpha Tau Omega fraternity. In 1977, a group of students formed a permanent organization that worked to plan the event. Ms. Falk said that nothing else is known about the group's origins.
To receive tax-exempt status an organization must file within 15 months of its founding, tax experts said, which Dance Marathon's founders failed to do.
Bryan Turriff, the group's new general co-chairman, said a financial manager with the student center, George Dooley, told him earlier this week that the organization is covered by the university's tax-exempt status.
But Ingrid Stafford, Northwestern's controller, told The Daily Northwestern that Dance Marathon's money is held in trust by the university and is not included on its annual tax return. Ms. Stafford has declined further comment.
Should the organization be challenged by the I.R.S., the cost could be steep. "The penalty for failure to file is $10 a day with a cap at $5,000 per taxable year for which you did not file a return," said Michael A. Clark, a a tax lawyer and partner in the Chicago law firm Hopkins & Sutter. "The I.R.S. doesn't always go that aggressively after charitable organizations, but it is a risk that the organization might get hit with these penalties."
The university's legal counsel is looking into what action, if any, the university should take, said Kenneth Wildes, director of university relations.
Karen Zelmar, the current Dance Marathon co-chairwoman, told The Daily Northwestern earlier this month that Dance Marathon is covered by the charities it benefits and need not file tax returns. Ms. Zelmar, a junior in economics from Deerfield, Ill., has also declined further comment.
But Leo Senus, director of finance for the Leukemia Society of America, whose Illinois chapter has benefited from Dance Marathon, said, "We do not allow anybody to claim our exemption as theirs for fund-raising purposes. I've never heard of that being done."

HEADLINE: Coins

BYLINE: By Jed Stevenson

 BODY:

For Buyers and Dreamers
Coin shows are the dress balls of the hobby. Everyone attending gets a chance to meet other collectors. Impromptu talks are given on just about every numismatic topic, and scheduled lectures are usually presented in some side room. Dealers in almost every conceivable type of coin or medal display their pieces side by side with their competitors, and showgoers wander the aisles, fiddling with one coin after another, lusting, dreaming and sometimes buying. 
 One of the best of the coin shows, a three-day event run by the Greater New York Numismatic Convention, opens on May 7 at the Omni Park Central Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 56th Street in Manhattan.
It will feature a three-part auction of United States paper currency, including the curious fractional currency that circulated in the mid-19th century in lieu of coins. The auction is being presented by Stack's.
Medals and United States coins will also be sold, especially Washington and Lincoln medals, which were struck by private mints both to commemorate the two Presidents and to capitalize on their popularity. Strangely, most of the Washington medals were minted in England shortly after Washington had orchestrated the Colonies' victory in the war of independence.
John Kleeburg, the curator of modern coinage at the American Numismatic Society, will speak at 1 P.M. on Saturday, May 9, on the evolution of Germany's silver thaler into today's dollar.
A special children's program, from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. on Saturday, will include various exhibitions and speeches, culminating in a free lunch and an auction of real coins bought with play money.
The show is free. For more information: Moe Weinschel at (718) 634-2240.
 
Honoring Columbus
 The Newark Museum has just opened an exhibition of Early American and European copper, silver and gold coins. The show, in honor of the 500th anniversary of Columbus's stumbling on the Americas in his westward search for the Orient, also includes coinage, maps and artifacts from the early colonization of the New World.
William L. Bischoff, the show's curator, draws from the Newark Museum's very fine collection of coins, one of the best in the East. It's being held in the C. Malcolm Davis Numismatic Gallery through Feb. 14, 1993.
The museum is at 49 Washington Street in downtown Newark. PATHtrains run directly to downtown Newark from the World Trade Center every 20 to 30 minutes. From elsewhere in Manhattan, the trains run at about the same frequency but require a transfer at Journal Square in Jersey City.
 
Four-Footed Friends

Various mints around the world rely on the minting and selling of various motif coins. These are considered bullion coins, because their worth is related to the value of the metal they contain. As investments, they rarely appreciate with anywhere near the rapidity of other more established collectibles like old coins or stamps. Nevertheless, they remain an important supplier of income for some very small economies, and they are a source of amusement for their collectors.
Currently, Gibraltar is offering designs in gold and silver that will appeal to dog lovers. The first of a series of dog coins features Queen Elizabeth II's favorite breed, the Welsh corgi. It's a low-slung herding dog bred to nip at the heels of cattle, while its shortness enables it to avoid any kicking hooves. Its portrait adorns the reverse, while the Queen's is on the obverse.
Another series in gold and silver, this one from the Isle of Man, depicts cats. This series is well established, entering its fifth year of issue with its fifth design. This year's star is the Siamese.
Both the dog and cat designs are available in 24-karat gold in sizes ranging from one twenty-fifth of an ounce of gold to the largest, the one-ounce size. Prices range from about $30 for the smallest size to about $365 for the largest. More information on prices and purchasing is available from the MTB Banking Corporation at (212) 858-3300 or (800) 535-7481.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gold bullion coin from Gibraltar, with Queen Elizabeth II on the obverse and her favorite dog, the Welsh corgi, on the reverse. (MTB Banking Corporation)
