HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Cornell;
Project Studies Social Adaptation Of Korean Grocers

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y.

 BODY:
In an unusual combination of classroom and field work, a Cornell University class here is studying the cultural adjustment of Korean grocers in New York City.
The 15 students enrolled in "Modernization and the Korean Family," 13 of whom are themselves Korean-Americans, spent the better part of their winter break in Manhattan, conducting interviews with 100 grocers based on extensive questionnaires they developed in the fall semester. 
 There are about 2,400 Korean grocers in New York City, and this was the most comprehensive study of the city's Korean population in a decade, said David McCann, a professor of Korean literature who helps teach the class.
The other instructor, Jeanne Mueller, a professor of human-service studies, said, "This was designed as a course in which students would learn about their ethnic heritage and understand research methodology first semester, and then get out in the field and learn from the field experimental method as well as in classroom lectures."
The students are spending this semester compiling and coding their data. By the end of this semester they will present their preliminary findings to student and faculty groups. Professor Mueller said she would analyze the data this summer and issue a report.
 
Greater Hopes for Daughters
 "A majority of the grocers came here for political freedom and for economic reasons and to get what they consider to be a better education and more opportunities for their children," Professor Mueller said, noting that "they had the same aspirations for both sons and daughters, even though in Korean culture girls are supposed to get married and have kids."
Yet, she said, the students found that most grocers and their families maintain strong ties with relatives overseas, and that most regularly read a Korean language newspaper.
"Most of our parents were in similar situations," said David Kim, a class participant and senior in economics from Over Land Park, Kan. Such parallels, he said, helped many of the students relate to what the grocers had experienced.
Mr. Kim said he enrolled in the course because it "looked at the traditional values of Korea, and how the immigration process affects the status of that culture in America." Mr. Kim was born in Korea and came to the United States with his family when he was 2 years old.
While in New York City, the students were divided into seven groups to conduct their interviews. At least one member of each group spoke fluent Korean, which the students said encouraged the grocers to trust them.
 
Strength of Korean Culture
 "These interviews were 110 questions long and were taking up more than an hour of their time, and we just weren't confident they would be receptive," said Yeon Shim, a senior in biology from Elizabeth, N.J.
The students said they were struck by the strength of the Korean grocers' cultural ties with home -- many are supporting families in Korea -- and by the 70-hour weeks that they devoted to running their stores.
One non-Korean student said the project helped her to better understand her own culture. "It makes you put in perspective your own experience, and appreciate everything you have," said Elizabeth Vega, a senior in human development and family studies who grew up in Mexico and whose family now lives in Los Angeles.
While the course's instructors said the project's findings were intriguing, the immediate purpose of the course was more utilitarian: it was intended to teach students how to combine research methods, field work and cultural analysis.
"The most interesting part of the whole thing is how excited the students have been," Professor McCann said. "It's like surfing a great wave."

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Skidmore;
Students Start Fund to Enhance Curiculum

DATELINE: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.

 BODY:
A group of Skidmore students have decided that while talking about a multicultural curriculum is cheap, financing research into multicultural course materials is a more effective way to change the curriculum on campus.
Those students, banded together in the year-old student group called Risen (for Reforms in Student Education Now), recently presented a $600 check to Skidmore's board as the first installment of a fund to expand the multicultural aspects of faculty research. 
 David H. Porter, the college's president, has matched the contribution with college funds.
"It's important to continue talk," said the organization's founder, David Murphy, a junior who is an English major from Amherst, Mass., "and it's important to continue action. So we decided to put our money where our mouths are."
Mr. Murphy said Risen plans to raise an additional $1,400 at this month's benefit concert and through donations from campus clubs and organizations.
In a letter accompanying the check, Risen members said the money is to be used for "summer faculty development programs that will enable interested faculty members to learn how to incorporate into their classes issues of race, ethnicity, and gender, as well as a more diverse pool of authors and contributors within their respective fields."
 
'Groundwork Has Been Laid'
 The money will "direct curricular enhancement," said Phyllis Roth, the dean of faculty.
"The groundwork has been laid," Ms. Roth said. "There is a cadre of faculty we know would be interested" in a program this summer.
She said that with the initial installment, Skidmore plans to sponsor at least one faculty member to develop a new course or revise an existing one.
The new or revised courses will focus on issues of diversity of experience in the United States, said Sandra Baum, an economics professor and the college's associate affirmative action officer.
Efforts such as that of Risen will eventually provide the on-campus workshops and expert speakers needed for intensive faculty training, Professor Baum said, adding, "It's wonderful that the students have raised this money. Taking this action shows how much the issue means to them."
The college's Committee on Educational Policies and Planning has also been discussing changes in the curriculum and the development of new courses geared toward increased awareness of multicultural issues. But Mr. Porter said, "It really is a stimulus of a special kind. It's a useful thing to have students say, 'We know funds are limited but we, too, think the academic part is so important to the college, and we are willing to raise money.' "
Mr. Murphy and several friends founded Risen in the spring of 1991 in response to what he said was "a lack of support curricularly and socially for minorities."
"People were complaining, but no one was doing anything to change the situation," he said. "I really see it as a part of everyone's education to learn about people who are different from ourselves."

HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK REGION;
Dinkins Barnstorms, and the Barn Burns

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
In what initially appeared to be a major turnaround for financially strapped New York City, Mayor David N. Dinkins spent much of last week announcing good budget news in a political barnstorming act that took him from the Bronx to Brooklyn and back to City Hall. In a series of optimistic speeches, he announced that libraries would be open longer hours, that new health clinics would be built, new tuberculosis programs would be created, and other improvements in city services would be made.
But the recovery abruptly dissipated by week's end when the Dinkins administration, seeking to quell growing euphoria over the news, said that despite a big budget surplus the city was still in poor fiscal health and could not afford to share any of its windfall with the many constituencies who emerged to lay claim to it. 
 Leaders of the city's municipal labor unions, which are all working without contracts, demanded wage increases and accused the Mayor of distorting the budget outlook to get concessions from them.
State lawmakers said the surplus meant that the city no longer needed the $115 million tax package it is has been lobbying for.
The furor was a dose of political reality for Mr. Dinkins, who after two years of unpopular budget cuts had sought to bring good tidings as his reelection campaign approaches. He may have grossly underestimated the skepticism and anger with which the good news would be received.
The administration undoubtedly raised false hopes by disclosing both that the city would restore hundreds of millions of dollars in planned cuts in the budget for construction and that it would end the fiscal year with a $455 million surplus. The two developments are essentially unrelated, but disclosing them in the same week created the impression that they were.
The programs that Mr. Dinkins announced last week -- 20 clinics offering the poor an alternative to emergency rooms, money for stalled public works projects, restored library hours, tax credits for businesses who give to cultural institutions -- represent less than $50 million in a budget of $29 billion. The programs result from cost savings due to financial rejiggering, not from the surplus, which stems from penny-pinching cost control measures and pessimistic forecasts of tax revenues.
"Labor organizations, advocates and constituents are thinking, 'Oh, well there's all this money floating around and we should be able to spend it on what we need,' " said First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel. "That is clearly not the case, and there should be no false sense of euphoria because we continue to have very pressing problems."
The entire surplus will be rolled over into the next fiscal year. It will be used for two things, Mr. Steisel said: to avoid borrowing $250 million in a bond refinancing that was opposed by the agencies that evaluate the city's creditworthiness, and to replace $200 million in Federal aid that the city did not receive. Budget officials estimate that the city will need to close a $1.8 billion deficit in next year's $29 billion budget.
Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's press secretary, said that there was no attempt by the administration to manipulate public perception. "Everybody knows things are not all fine and dandy," he said. "Some would say that we are the victim of our own impression, but you might also argue that we are a victim of the media, which uncovered and reported the surplus without our announcing it."
The city has had budget surpluses for 12 years, although the last two have been small and have been rolled over into the next year.
Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the Financial Control Board, which monitors the city's finances, said that the Dinkins administration has a "perception problem that needs to be reversed.
"And I hope they can reverse it because the facts are on their side," he said. He praised the administration's plan to use the surplus to avoid borrowing and to replace Federal funds.
 
Good News and Bad
 Alair A. Townsend, former budget director and deputy mayor for finance and economic development in the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, said that a surplus is both "the best news and the worst news that you could give the Mayor because the first thing people will do is accuse the budget director of not being able to count."
The Dinkins administration has vowed not to grant raises to union workers without productivity gains. When he learned of the latest surplus, Stanley Hill, president of the American Federation of State, County, and Municipal Employees District Council 37, accused the administration of negotiating in bad faith. "They simply have not been telling us the truth," he said.
The unions' anger was echoed by Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, who demanded that the city explain where the surplus came from and warned that the administration may have jeopardized its relationship with labor.
To avoid misunderstandings like this, Ms. Townsend, who is now the publisher of Crain's New York, a business journal, said that it is vital for budget officials to explain early to elected officials and labor leaders that surpluses are not generally there for the taking.
"There's no trickery going on here with the Dinkins administration because we have always had surpluses," she said. "This one just happens to come at a time when we are still in very poor financial condition."

HEADLINE: The Global Economy's Engines Are Out of Tune and Sputtering

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
THE haphazard spectacle of what is called the world economy seems to operate like some Rube Goldberg contraption, with lags and lurches, ups and downs. An economic surge or slump in one country yields an effect in another, often unforeseen or unintended. And lately, the machine's engine appears to be sputtering.
In the United States, the economy has recovered from being flat on its back to being up on its knees -- not much of a recovery. Germany is saddled with a very un-Germanic budget deficit, inflation and high interest rates, mainly the result of generous spending to bring eastern Germany along. Even Japan has lost its vigor. 
 The gathering in Washington today of finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven industrial nations convenes at a time of diminished expectations. Last Wednesday, the International Monetary Fund cut its estimate of world growth in 1992 by nearly half, to a sluggish 1.4 percent, down from the 2.7 percent forecast last October. And also last week, Treasury Undersecretary David C. Mulford conceded "growth this year will be significantly below potential and inadequate to reduce high levels of unemployment in many countries."
So things are sluggish in general, but how closely are the world's major economies linked? How concerned should Americans be that the Japanese stock market has lost about 50 percent of its value since the end of 1989? Pessimists warn that deflation in Japan could reverberate as Japanese banks, invested heavily in Tokyo shares and property, cut back lending abroad, slowing growth in the West.
To say that we live in a global economy has become a modern mantra. But just what it means isn't so clear. Surely, the flows of goods, services and money across borders have increased greatly during the postwar years. The major economies are much more open -- and exposed -- to developments in other countries than they were a few decades ago. For example, imports and exports now represent 21 percent of the American economy, up from 9 percent in 1959. Yet the economic interdependence of nations is just beginning to return to the levels of the turn of the century, before the two world wars and the Depression squelched world trade and international investment.
Postwar history is filled with looming disasters that never materialized or proved far less threatening than originally imagined. In the late 1940's and early 1950's, experts warned that a "dollar shortage" would mean insufficient capital for a postwar recovery. After currencies were set afloat to be priced by market rates, there were dire warnings that national economies would be destabilized as currency values rose or fell endlessly. The oil-price shocks of the 1970's prompted the challenge of "petrodollar recycling" and fears that Arab nations would own the world. The third world debt crisis was said to threaten the banking system, and so on.
Yet rarely have international problems had as much impact on the American economy as home-grown travails -- big Government deficits, the savings and loan crisis. "But foreign devils, or exotic global forces, are more plausible villains than humdrum domestic problems," said Paul Krugman, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Still, the links among national economies are real and increasing. Take Japan's predicament. Its asset prices have fallen precipitously, hurting Japanese banks and companies, because the government decided in 1990 to crimp the supply of money and credit. The government did that to deflate the speculative bubble of soaring stock and property prices. The previous runup was the result of another government remedy: Tokyo's decision starting in 1986 to roughly double the growth rate of Japan's money supply and to cut interest rates.
Tokyo's easy-money policy, in turn, was an effort to soften the blow from the "yen shock," the sharp rise in the value of the yen after the leading industrial nations decided in September 1985, at a meeting at the Plaza Hotel in New York, that the value of the United States dollar should be pushed down and other major currencies up. The yen shock was the expected blow to Japan's export economy as a result of the sharp shift in currency values, making Japanese exports much more expensive. Japanese exporters proved quite nimble in adjusting to the stronger yen, but the government's monetary generosity meant more money was chasing Japanese property and shares, fueling the 1986-90 speculative boom.
Next, look at America. By September 1985, Washington wanted a cheaper dollar to stem the yawning United States trade deficit and rescue the Rust Belt, which was being eviscerated by cheaper imports from abroad. The decision marked an abrupt reversal of policy for the Reagan Administration, which had long held that a strong dollar proved America's economic prowess. The dollar peaked in early 1985, well before the Plaza agreement, but the intervention by central bankers and adjustment of interest rates accelerated the downward trend.
By the third quarter of 1986, the dollar's value in foreign exchange markets had dropped to 156 yen, down from 258 yen in early 1985. The policy prodding worked so well that by 1987, the major industrial countries were alarmed at the possibility that the dollar would go into a free fall. The governments agreed to try to ease the dollar's descent through coordination of interest rates and central bank buying and selling, which is more or less what happened. Today, the dollar is worth about 135 yen, and the dollar has fallen similarly since 1985 against the German mark, the other benchmark currency.
Sure enough, America's exports to the rest of the world have doubled since 1985 to $422 billion last year. Indeed, the robust export performance has been one of the few bright spots in the American economy in recent years. "The strong export growth was one of the reasons the U.S. economy sailed through the 1987 stock market crash with hardly a flutter," said Edward McKelvey, an economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
In Europe, economic expectations changed markedly in 1986, when the 12-nation European Community agreed to form a single market by the end of 1992. In an investment boom, as companies scrambled to get ready, talk of Eurosclerosis -- sluggish growth and rising unemployment -- was replaced by Europhoria. Europe got another fillip in 1990 from the unification of the two Germanys, and the subsequent surge in spending by Bonn to absorb its poorer eastern cousin. "What Western capitalists could never do -- get Germany to really stimulate its economy -- the Germans did because of the collapse of Communism," said Robert Z. Lawrence, an economist at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government.
But the German spending spree has been followed by a hangover with consequences for other nations. The government spending raised Germany's budget deficit and inflation. To control inflationary pressures, Germany raised its interest rates to the highest levels since the 1930's. Because Britain, France and other European economies are tied to Bonn via the European Monetary System, they are forced to follow Germany's lead, depressing growth throughout Europe. "Those countries can't escape that international financial discipline anymore," noted Mr. Lawrence of Harvard.
Both politics and economics are enlarging the global marketplace for goods and capital. The former Communist states seem destined to become full-fledged members while developing giants like China and India are opening up. "The economic interdependence we see today is minuscule compared to what we're going to have in the next decade or so," said David Hale, chief economist of Kemper Financial Services Inc.


GRAPHIC: How the effects of economic summits and international developments have rippled through the economies of Japan, Germany and the United States
 
Bonn Summit - 1978: The major ecnomic powers ask Japan and West Germany to stimulate their economies. The U.S., whose trade deficit is climbing, hopes that this will boost economies worldwide.
 
1983 to 1985 - The Dollar's Ascent: Investors funnel funds into the U.S., attracted by strong growth and high interest rates. As the dollar increases in value, U.S. products become more expensive overseas. Exports plunge. The Reagan Administration does nothing to stem the dollar's rise.
 
Plaza Agreement - 1985: The U.S. decides that the dollar is too strong, and the other major economic powers agree. The central banks intervene, helping to push the dollar down rapidly and bring the yen and the German mark up.
 
Late 1985 to early 1987 - Yen Shock: The stronger yen makes Japanese products more costly in foreign markets, reducing sales abroad. To soften the impact on its economy, Tokyo eases monetary policy. But the easy-money situation means more funds are chasing assets at home, starting the sharp run-up in the Japanese stock market and in property prices.
 
Late 1980's - Tokyo's Spending Spree: The more muscular yen makes foreign investments cheaper for Japanese companies and investors. In the U.S., the Japanese buy everything from U.S. Treasury bonds to the Pebble Beach golf course. Japanese corporations buy several American companies and build dozens of factories in the U.S.
 
1990 - Hitting the Brakes: Concern for the astronomical jump in real estate and stock prices causes the Japanese central bank to tighten monetary policy to cool an overheated economy.
 
Now - Japanese Slump: The Japanese economy begins to contract. Property Prices and the stock market plummet. Bad loans held by Japanese banks could prompt them to lend less overseas, possibly tightening the credit crunch in places like California.
 
1986 - Europe Unites: The agreement that the 12 nations of Western Europe would unify their economies by 1992 prompts many companies to invest in the future marketplace. Expanding companies purchase more U.S. goods, like computers.
 
1990 - Communism Collapses: West Germany spends heavily to absorb its poorer eastern sister. The added spending boosts growth in Germany and Europe, but the German budget deficit rises and inflation heats up.
 
Now - Stagnation in Europe: Germany hikes interest rates to curb inflation. But higher German rates worsen the economic weakness in neighboring countries like Britain and France. They cannot cut interest rates to stimulate growth because Germany is the dominant economic power in the European Monetary System; other European nations must follow the lead of the German central bank.
 
Late 1980's - Resurgence of American Manufacturing: With a weaker dollar, U.S. manufacturers that survived the tough times begin to find that they are competitive again in export markets. The growth in exports helps cushion the economic shock waves from the 1987 stock market crash.
 
Now - A Bright Spot: U.S. exports more than doubled from 1985 to 1991. Exports remain one of the few bright areas in the economic picture.
 
Drawings
Chronology: "Trickling Down"

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Why It's Proven Difficult To Make Qaddafi Give In

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
Despite all the maneuvering, the standoff continues over Libya's refusal to surrender two purported bombers of Pan Am flight 103. So far, say Western officials in London and Rome, there have been no cracks in the embargo mandated by the United Nations Security Council two weeks ago. But neither has Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi handed over the two men for trial outside Libya.
Like Saddam Hussein during the gulf crisis, Colonel Qaddafi has elected to hang tough, even though there is little obvious solace to be drawn from the example of Iraq; if a global coalition dominated by the United States could drive Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait by force, it can be reasoned, why should the same array of forces unravel on the far less risky issue of punishing Libya? 
 But the parallel is incomplete. The Libyan affair is far more ambiguous than Iraq's invasion of Kuwait; the prizes are far smaller and the stakes not nearly so high.
On April 15, the United Nations Security Council ordered a ban on airline flights and arms supplies to Libya and a reduction of diplomatic contact. Its aim was to force Mr. Qaddafi to deliver two Libyans, Abdel Basset Ali al-Megrahi and Lamen Khalifa Fhimah, whom American and British intelligence agencies hold responsible for downing Pan Am flight 103.
Perversely, it is in part because Operation Desert Storm became such a clear and largely successful show of American will in the post-cold war era that this latest coalition has run into crosscurrents of divergent interest around the Mediterranean: For some, once was enough.
In the salons of Cairo and Damascus, and among Palestinians, moreover, the talk has again turned to resentment of what is seen as an American-led manipulation of the United Nations to the detriment of the broader Arab nation. "Egypt's interests are part of Arab interests," the Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak, said after meeting with Colonel Qaddafi last week.
And Syria, for its part, abandoned the temporary, pro-Western image it adopted during the gulf war and openly sought to send a passenger flight to Tripoli. The plan was aborted when other nations refused overflight rights, but Syria's President, Hafez el-Assad (a dictator who could one day conceivably face sanctions himself), had used the moment to promote himself as a rallying point for those who feel American pressures in the region have simply become too cavalier.
Even among the West's strongest Arab allies, notably Egypt, the level of single-minded enthusiasm that marked the gulf coalition seems much reduced. Last week, when President Mubarak met Colonel Qaddafi near their border, the Egyptian emerged saying there was still a "ray of hope" to untangle the dispute.
Simply by meeting the Libyan leader, Mr. Mubarak seemed to be signaling his own country's special interest in maintaining some stability in its western neighbor. Over a million Egyptians work there and, for several years, Mr. Mubarak has tried to coax Colonel Qaddafi into respectability. The last thing he wants to reap from those efforts is chaos on his border, inviting a resurgence of the militant Islamic fundamentalism that he and Colonel Qaddafi have both assiduously suppressed.
To many in the Middle East and Europe, the Libyan affair is far more opaque than the invasion of Kuwait. If the Libyan agents are handed over to stand trial and make free disclosures about what they know, who else -- and which other lands -- will they implicate? Libya, after all, is only the most recent culprit cited in the Pan Am massacre. For several years, American policy -- and investigators -- held Syria and Iran responsible.
 
Diverse Interests
 In the drive to force the extradition of the two men, Britain and France are leading the Europeans, and both have their reasons. Pan Am 103 crashed over Lockerbie, Scotland, on a flight from London to New York in 1988; French investigators accuse Libya of complicity in the downing of a French UTA airliner over the Sahara in 1989. The two disasters killed a total of 441 people.
But European countries approach Colonel Qaddafi from markedly different perspectives.
In 1986, Europe was left divided by an American bombing raid on Tripoli. Margaret Thatcher's Britain -- angered then as much as now by Libyan support of the Irish Republican Army -- agreed to the use of British bases for the raid, but France refused overflight rights. Today, Spain, Germany and Italy have strong economic interests in Libya and have privately opposed any tightening of the current sanctions into a trade embargo affecting Libya's high-quality oil. Spain imports one-fifth of its liquefied natural gas from Libya, while Italy buys over a quarter of its oil there. Italian companies are closely intertwined with Libya's oil industry. And, as the former colonial master, Rome enjoys an odd love-hate relationship: when, a few years back, Colonel Qaddafi lifted import restrictions, one of the first things Libyans bought was Italian ice cream machines.
Economics, history and a perilously close proximity across the Mediterranean, thus, dictate a particularly delicate relationship between Rome and Tripoli.
For all that, and despite its private disquiet, Italy, like other Europeans, has gone along with the present levels of pressure. The Italian Air Force scrambled two warplanes to warn off a Libyan airliner approaching its airspace, and six Libyan diplomats have been expelled. Alitalia's lucrative Rome-Tripoli flights have been suspended. Neither does Italy wish to be perceived as the soft underbelly of European resolve. "We think that escalation is always dangerous," a senior Italian official said, "but if you have to choose between escalation and terrorism, we choose escalation."

HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK REGION;
Immigrants Jam Schools, Invigorating a System

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
Despite turn-of-the-century photographs of hollow-eyed Jewish and Italian children gazing at their teachers with gratitude and zeal, history presents a less rose-tinted picture of immigrants in the New York public schools.
The swarms of children in the Lower East Side ghetto were often crammed into classrooms of 60, and truancy and delinquency were rife. Reading and math scores plummeted and history classes were curtailed so more English could be taught. A 1911 Teachers College study shows that only 60 percent of elementary school children went on to high school; even the most ardent pupils had to work to support their families. 
 But history also shows that waves of immigration have enlivened New York's schools at the same time as they have overwhelmed them. The news two weeks ago that 120,000 immigrant children from 167 countries have entered the city's schools over the last three years was greeted as a sign of renewal as robust as the cherry and apple blossoms coloring the cityscape.
During the 1970's and 80's, the city's schools had seemed doomed to fade slowly, hurt by the middle class's steady exodus to the suburbs, by fiscal cuts, decaying buildings and a growing population of poor youngsters from chaotic families.
Now immigrant families from the Dominican Republic, Jamaica, Russia, Guyana, China and other countries have rejuvenated some floundering schools.
Many families are fleeing political oppression or poverty. "Every time there's an upheaval anywhere in the world, the schools in New York are the first to absorb it," says Mitchell L. Moss, director of New York University's Urban Research Center.
Some arrive illiterate even in their native languages. But others, says Dr. Emanuel Tobier, an economics professor at N.Y.U., are among the most ambitious and best educated of their compatriots, with an enormous craving to make it and an energizing fear of catastrophe if they don't.
Seward Park, the Lower East Side's neighborhood high school, was for a long time a place to avoid, but an influx of Chinese and Latin American students has brightened its academic tone. The annual dropout rate, for example, fell from 13.5 percent in the 1982-83 school year to 10.7 percent in 1989-90.
The prestigious Westinghouse national science competition is still dominated by New York City schools, as it has been since it began in the 1940's, but the faces have changed. Winning often requires working after school in a laboratory for two years, and many of the recent winners hungry enough to do that have been the children of immigrants from China, India and the Soviet Union.
Soundings like these, says Dr. Tobier, buoy many executives, who have long despaired about the quality of the city's work force.
Also, countries like South Korea and Thailand are gaining new prominence in the world economy. Today's immigrants raised in New York will be well-positioned for international commerce.
"This is a multicultural world, and we're rich in terms of who is in our system," said Joseph J. Saccente, who is retiring as the Board of Education's chief executive for monitoring and improving schools.
But an influx of immigrants brings problems too. District 6 in Washington Heights is so crowded that students are sent to the east Bronx. In District 24 in Queens, classes are held on the auditorium stage and two assistant principals moved into the principal's office so classes could be held in their offices.
 
Hunting Albanian Teachers
 Schools are scrounging around for bilingual teachers, and not just in Spanish and Chinese. District 11 in the northeast Bronx is considering hiring teachers of Albanian, but they are hard to find. Most immigrants who don't speak Spanish must take their classes entirely in English, and some educators fear they will suffer in mathematics and science classes.
The debate over bilingual education, settled legally but not philosophically, is being stirred up by the new wave of immigrants. Some teachers complain that students are being funneled into bilingual classes to furnish jobs for bilingual teachers, and say immigrants would learn more English the old-fashioned way -- by breaking with their own language cold turkey.
But others who grew up in the old system argue that it forces students to endure years of feeling stupid in subjects like mathematics when their handicap is linguistic, not arithmetical.
 
Ambition, Pluck and Pressure

 "I was competent in my own language," recalls Angel Villarreal, the Puerto Rican-born assistant principal of Junior High School 98 in the Bronx.
Schools are also being asked to revamp their curricula to take account of the cultural backgrounds of newcomers. Such sensitivity, says David Reimers, a historian of immigration, was never shown the Irish and German immigrants of the mid-19th century.
And experts like Mr. Moss believe that new immigrants have injected the system with ambition, pluck and pressure for better schools. He says Asian families in the Forest Hills neighborhood where he grew up are joining longtime residents in demanding improvements.
Perhaps cognizant of that emerging constituency, Mayor David N. Dinkins last week decided to restore $600 million of almost $1.5 billion he had taken out of a $4.3 billion school construction plan. Overcrowded District 24 is already building one elementary school, has a junior high school on the drawing board, and has five other additions in the works.
"It's more or less the way my family arrived in this country a generation or so ago," said John Falco, the district's deputy superintendent. "You have industrious people who come to this country for all the benefits our family came for -- freedom and economic prosperity -- with children eager to learn."

GRAPHIC: Photo: P.S. 19 in Elmhurst, Queens, is overcrowded, with 2,100 students from 45 countries. (Nancy Siesel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
On Health Insurance, Some States Are Going Back to Basics

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Although health insurers see themselves merely as blameless messengers bearing the bad tidings of rapidly rising medical costs, that position promises scant protection from the heavy fire now directed at them by state government officials and members of Congress. As recent developments in several states demonstrate, the pressure is mounting to control the costs and practices that have left an estimated 30 to 40 million Americans without health insurance.
State officials say that insurers and their employer-clients have much to answer for, notably the splintering of the national pool of the insured into thousands of groups that are often too small to bear the financial risk of even one member's serious illness. Many insurers now agree that dividing the market, which was accomplished by offering lower rates to groups unlikely to need much care, has helped put coverage out of reach for many. 
 "The need for health insurance market reform is clear," said Earl R. Pomeroy, North Dakota's insurance commissioner, speaking for the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. "Some small businesses and individuals cannot get coverage at all because of current or prior health problems. Even small businesses with relatively low rates face the prospect of large premium increases, or the potential loss of coverage if a worker develops a serious illness."
The National Governors Association has also recognized the problem. The governors called for national minimum standards to "encourage broader and more equitable sharing of risk."
In a backlash that has overcome vigorous opposition from commercial insurers, at least 14 states have taken steps toward a concept of insurance called community rating. The community-rating approach means an insurer must accept all applicants at virtually the same rates. This is the method used by the country's 73 nonprofit Blue Cross and Blue Shield health plans for individuals and small groups.
Some states also limit or prohibit setting rates based on health status, age, sex, occupation and geographic location. The intent is to spread risks more widely so that the healthy help pay for the sick. In the bargain, the generally healthier young participants have to pay somewhat higher rates in return for protection against the time when they, too, will be older and may need care.
Vermont, Maine and Oregon have enacted sweeping community-rating laws, which take effect this year and next. Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey proposed one this month. And Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, included a limit on rate variations in the health-care package that was passed by the Senate recently as part of the tax bill. (The provisions were dropped in a House-Senate conference and the tax measure was vetoed by President George Bush.)
 
Minnesota Subsidizes Coverage
 Last week, Gov. Arne H. Carlson of Minnesota, a Republican, signed a health-care law that forbids basing rates on sex and limits the variations in charges between rural and urban areas. The state will subsidize coverage for uninsured middle-class Minnesotans (maximum income about $38,300).
The New York State Assembly also has passed a community-rating bill, proposed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to help rescue some financially pressed Blue Cross associations. Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, which serves 16 counties including New York City, says it has suffered heavy losses because it was stuck with a preponderance of high-risk customers when commercial insurers lured away lower-risk people with lower rates.
In the state Senate, where the bill is under consideration, Republican leaders say it would unfairly benefit Blue Cross, which already gets lower hospital rates to help insure all comers. Mr. Cuomo has warned that if the measure is not passed, he will be forced to raise rates for Empire Blue Cross in October, shortly before election day.
The Health Insurance Association of America, a commercial insurers trade group based in Washington, purchased large advertisements in newspapers last week to contend that insurance rates "could go up 30 percent" if the New York bill passes. "Higher rates, particularly in today's economy, would leave many with no choice but to drop their coverage entirely," the ad said.
Chris Petersen, a lawyer with the group, said the H.I.A.A. would be willing to compromise, accepting a prohibition on rates linked to health status if "demographic factors" were permitted. "We don't think younger healthier workers ought to be subsidizing older people," he said. The commercial insurers also want New York to authorize a reinsurance arrangement, which would permit the companies to lighten their risks of paying for high-cost patients. This was tried in Connecticut, where several Hartford-based companies backed creation of a reinsurance pool that has provided policies to a few thousand people who had been denied coverage and were able to pay high premiums.
The Vermont law, which takes effect July 1, applies to groups of 49 or fewer employees and self-employed individuals and also prohibits rates based on health status. .
Under the Oregon law, any group of 3 to 25 would have to be accepted at rates not more than 33 percent higher or lower than a midpoint.
Maine took a gradual approach in a law signed this month by Gov. John R. McKernan Jr., a Republican. Insurers must accept any group of fewer than 25 at a community rate starting in July 1993. The rates may vary, plus or minus 50 percent, in the first year, on the basis of age, sex, occupation or geographical area, but permissible variations drop to zero over five years.
The gradual approach is favored, said Alicia Pelrine, a human resources analyst with the National Governors Association, because a cold-turkey approach, requiring pure community rating from the start, might bring sharply higher rates and result in even more people giving up their coverage.
Robert Laszewski, executive vice president of the Liberty Mutual Group, also favors the gradual approach. "If we had to take all comers we would be out of business in 48 hours," he said. But he said legislation to improve access to insurance is overdue. "It can't come quickly enough," he said, "so we can get on to debate the real issues: the cost of health care."

HEADLINE: Just Imagine;
It's January 1993 And Ross Perot Is the President

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
President Perot. President Perot! President Perot?
More than an independent, not even a politician, able to leap ballot access requirements in a single bound, Ross Perot might, just might, get elected President. And then what would happen? 
 His fans hope that his distance from the route most Presidents take to the White House might make him succeed where recent Chief Executives have failed, getting the budget under control and the economy in motion, working together with Congress instead of fighting. They think, as he seems to, that the government can be run like a good business.
But a Perot Presidency might also reflect Harry Truman's expectation about the last non-politician to become President, Dwight D. Eisenhower: "He'll sit here, and he'll say, 'Do this! Do that!' And nothing will happen. Poor Ike, it won't be a bit like the Army." As it happened, Mr. Truman greatly misunderstood both his successor's skills and the efficiency of the Army, but a take-charge businessman might have the preconceptions Ike didn't.
As Richard Neustadt, professor emeritus of government at Harvard, said Friday, a new President arrives at the White House to find that all the administrative services work beautifully. The switchboard is the best in the world and helicopters are always ready. Personal tastes can be satisfied, whether it was Fresca wherever Lyndon Johnson went or air-conditioning so strong that Richard Nixon could indulge his desire for wood fires in July. Then, said the author of the classic "Presidential Power: The Politics of Leadership," new occupants "get the illusion it means something to be President." In fact, he said, "hardly anybody will do what you tell them without argument or evasion or compromise."
That is a gamble with any new President, especially one with little acquaintance with Washington, like Jimmy Carter or Ronald Reagan.
But Mr. Perot would bring another risk. That is his very independence. His absence of connections will be an electoral asset, if he decides to run. But it would make him a very different kind of President if he wins, unable to depend on a hard core of fellow partisans to back him even when they think he is mistaken, as the Republicans in Congress often do for Mr. Bush today. And for Presidents who want to accomplish things in office, having friends or at least loyalists always helps.
When it comes to preventing results he deplores, a President can use a veto. Lowell Weicker, who quit the Republican Party to win the governorship of Connecticut as an independent, did that to one state budget after another until he got the income tax he wanted. But except in that confined area, Mr. Weicker has lacked entree to bend the legislature to his will.
In Mr. Perot's case neither the risks nor the opportunity are all that likely to materialize. He may not run. If he does, victory is unlikely. If President Bush does not survive a feeble economy and an even less muscular vision of the future, Bill Clinton represents the other major voting tradition in the United States and the party that has traditionally capitalized on economic distress. And both have established political organizations.
But the combination of Mr. Perot's own resources -- no other campaign can just ask the candidate to write a check -- and the nation's dismal pessimism gives the Texas billionaire an outside chance. That was more than most people gave Jimmy Carter in 1975.
No one knows what an immense dose of television advertising would do for a candidate like Mr. Perot, about whom only 30 percent of registered voters now have an opinion, according to last week's New York Times/CBS News Poll. But it is a measure of attitudes about Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton that about a tenth of those with no opinion about Mr. Perot are now for him anyway, and he draws 23 percent of registered voters in a three-way test, to Mr. Clinton's 28 percent and Mr. Bush's 38 percent.
That 23 percent could dwindle. Mr. Perot could be the political flavor of the month, as Paul Tsongas and Jerry Brown have already been.
But advertising could make 23 percent a foundation to build on. And 23 percent might be enough to win some states. Of course, if Mr. Perot wins a few and Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton run close, the election could be thrown into the House of Representatives for the first time since 1824. And there, unless Republicans make startling gains, Mr. Clinton would probably prevail.
 
The Old School Reform Try
 Guesswork about the potential of would-be presidents is a quadrennial political enterprise. The guesses are especially chancy in Mr. Perot's case. The other candidates not only have records in public office, which he lacks, but their inclinations can also be measured by their associations and their parties. Mr. Bush, for example, is not suddenly going to side with unions; Mr. Clinton is not going to join the right-to-life movement.
At the moment, of course, one has to guess not only how well Mr. Perot might do in advancing policies but also what those policies would be.
His best-known sally in public policy, his leadership of school reform in Texas, was a tour de force in dealing with the legislature. "He can out-politick politicians," said George Christian, a political consultant in Austin. But, Mr. Christian observed, a number of reforms that depend on more than the legislature, especially those requiring improved teacher training, have foundered on the educational bureaucracy.
The Congress might well be cowed at first. The victory of an independent would strike most Republicans and Democrats on Capitol Hill as a truly shocking precedent. And few would want to be blamed for obstructing a popular new President. "He'd have a moment of opportunity," said Professor Neustadt.
But after a time, the fact that no one in Congress would "have a stake in Perot's success" would become decisive, said Prof. Samuel Kernell of the University of California at San Diego. Congress would be harder to restrain -- for example, its growing affection for protectionism might take root.
Professor Kernell offered another caution, arguing that businessmen never made good politicians, or even good White House chiefs of staff. They misunderstand what the Presidency is all about, believing it's a matter of efficiency and administrative skill. Real Presidential leadership, said the author of "Going Public: New Strategies for Presidential Leadership" does not lie in "administering the government; it's making the difficult decisions that aren't being made or can't be made elsewhere."
Those decisions are the President's to make, and not the product of tabulations of the 800 number call-in system Mr. Perot has proposed. Most of all, they have to be made with some raucous disorder that guarantees that all interests are considered. Businessmen, he said, do not "appreciate the need for disorder."

International 3-17

AFGHAN REBELS TAKE KABUL
The Afghan capital suddenly fell to Islamic guerrillas after nearly 14 years of civil war against a succession of Soviet-backed Governments. Rebel factions swept through the city and occupied key Government ministries and installations. 1
 
PERU FIRES ON U.S. PLANE
An American military transport plane flying off Peru's coast was fired on by two Peruvian fighter jets. An American crewman was lost, but Washington and Lima both seemed to be trying to minimize confrontation over the incident. 1
 
BURMA EASES CLAMP ON PRISONER
The Burmese military Government said it would allow the family of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the detained opposition leader and Nobel peace laureate, to visit her. It said it had freed a former Prime Minister and 11 other political prisoners. 3
 
MANDELA SEES PLOY BY RULERS
Nelson Mandela rejected President de Klerk's plan for a popularly elected executive council during the transition to democracy in South Africa. The African National Congress leader said it was a ploy to keep the National Party in power. 4
 
HEADY SPRING IN RUSSIA
It may not be as dramatic as showdowns at the Kremlin. But in planting on private farmland, the Batyrovs and many other families in Russia are striking at the core of the Communist legacy. 1
 
TRANS-ATLANTIC BUDGET SPAT
A dispute between the United States and Germany over domestic budget policies threatened to siphon attention from poor countries as finance ministers gathered in Washington for meetings on the troubled international economy. 9

THE BATTLE OF BOSTON
As another baseball season unfolds, storm clouds are gathering in Boston. At issue is the custody of the city's beloved and accursed Red Sox and, most likely, the future of Fenway Park itself. 1
 
ANOTHER CALIFORNIA QUAKE

A DROUGHT PERSISTS

HEADLINE: After 14 Years, Afghan Guerrillas Easily Take Prize

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 25

 BODY:
Kabul fell to Islamic rebels today as rival guerrilla groups swept through the capital and occupied Government ministries and installations. The capture of the city came after nearly 14 years of civil war against a succession of Soviet-backed Communist Governments.
The Presidential palace, army garrisons and armories, police stations and the television and radio complexes were swiftly occupied by heavily armed guerrillas who met almost no resistance. 
 Two rival groups, the Jamiat-i-Islami of Ahmad Shah Masood and the militant Hezb-i-Islami of Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, vied to capture portions of the city's center, a competition that led to occasional shoving matches but apparently no serious armed clashes in the daylight. But as dark fell, the stutter of rifle and heavy machine-gun fire could be heard throughout the city.
 
Fundamentalist Offensive
 The suddenness of the takeover, initiated by the Hezb-i-Islami, which represents the southern Pathan ethnic group, gave rise to speculation that Mr. Hekmatyar was trying to grab the capital and power for himself at the expense of the many other rebel groups that have formed an alliance.
But very quickly, other guerrillas, particularly fighters from Jamiat-i-Islami, emerged from hiding and outflanked the Hezb-i-Islami forces to occupy most of the important installations in the capital. Many of these groups are dominated by northern and western ethnic minorities who resent centuries of dominance by the Pathans.
Earlier this morning, in the Pakistani border town of Peshawar, a gathering of Islamic rebel groups announced the formation of an interim governing council, although Mr. Hekmatyar, the most rigid fundamentalist among the Islamic rebel leaders, declared that he would not participate. It was not clear this evening whether the council would travel to Kabul to take the reins of the government.
The Associated Press reported that at the Pakistan headquarters of the resistance, nine rebel chiefs -- not including Mr. Hekmatyar -- issued a communique saying Mr. Masood was in charge of Kabul until their arrival.
While the political prospects were unclear, the capture of the city today was clearly the crowning military victory of a struggle that began nearly 14 years ago when the first Islamic rebels took to the mountains to fight the Communist Government of Noor Mohammed Taraki.
The conflict soon became the last cold-war battleground between the United States and the Soviet Union. The Soviets intervened in December 1979, sending the first of more than 100,000 troops to fight the Muslim guerrillas. The United States responded by sending arms to the guerrillas at their bases in Pakistan.
Unable to crush the resistance and facing growing internal problems, the Soviet Union completed its withdrawal in February 1989. The rebels continued fighting President Najibullah, who was installed by Moscow in 1986 and who finally fell from power last week.
As the Soviet Union began to collapse and warmer ties developed with the United States, Moscow and Washington agreed to cut off aid to their clients. The rebels continued to press the Najibullah Government, and a string of victories north of the capital last week presaged today's triumph.
 
Many Losses, Few Victories
 An estimated two million Afghans died in the fighting and nearly six million became refugees in Pakistan or Iran. Countless others were injured. Many villages today are hollow shells of shattered buildings and overgrown fields. More than 30 million mines litter the landscape, and the country's economy has collapsed.
The first move by the guerrillas this morning came when more than 500 fighters from Mr. Hekmatyar's units, who had been hidden in the Ministry of the Interior, took up positions outside the iron gates of the complex.
Quickly, light machine guns were deployed and guerrillas were posted at the entrance, mixing easily with the ministry's own rifle-toting security forces. Many of the guerrillas wore khaki army jackets with patches reading "U.S. Army."
Mohammed Kareen, a commander of Hezb-i-Islami, said: "We came two days ago. We stayed in the ministry until now. They told us to go to the Ministry of Interior. This ministry belongs to Hezb-i-Islami."
The commander, who said he directed about 500 fighters, said he did not know of any agreement with the forces of Mr. Masood.
 
'We Do Not Want to Fight'
 "We are not yet together with Ahmad Shah Masood," he said. "We do not want to fight. If they want to fight, I will start fighting. But it is better for us to be together, because they are my brothers."
Elsewhere in Kabul, a group of rebels shouting "God is great!" stormed the headquarters of the secret police, and here and there across the city crowds of people waving the green banner of Islam paraded through the streets shouting "Long live the mujahedeen," or holy warriors.
Yet even as some of Kabul's citizens celebrated the arrival of the guerrillas, others, including many Government workers and members of the once-dominant Watan Party, hurried to take refuge in their homes. By mid-afternoon, the streets were deserted, except for an occasional jeep or armored car speeding along raising clouds of dust.
As night fell, the blackness over Kabul was torn apart by the crimson stitching of tracer bullets arcing into the sky, the white flash of flares and the crackle of automatic weapons as guerrillas celebrated their victory. Deep thumps of tank fire echoed in the hills and occasional explosions of uncertain origin mingled with the splatter of light weapons.
 
Masood Accuses Hekmatyar
 Mr. Hekmatyar was believed to be outside the city, as was Mr. Masood. At his base in Charikar, 35 miles north of here, Mr. Masood told reporters that Mr. Hekmatyar had collaborated with Communist elements to try to take over the city.
The collapsing Kabul Government had been weakened by defections in the military; and as Hezb-i-Islami forces moved to capture sites around the center of the city, the extent of cooperation between elements of the Government's forces and Mr. Masood became clear.
Late this afternoon, 18 air force helicopters began ferrying 1,800 of Mr. Masood's troops to the capital from Jabal-us-Siraj, about 40 miles north of here. Earlier, a column of heavily armed fighters from Jamiat-i-Islami wearing backpacks marched into the capital's television station. Machine-gun nests were set up on the roof and army guards at the gates were supplemented by Jamiat fighters.
"We asked them to come to control the station," said Akbar Nihad, who said he was the general director of advertising. "We called them today, in the morning. It is necessary for them to have control of the television station. It is important."
Kabul's fall became inevitable as the rest of Afghanistan entered the embrace of Islamic guerrilla organizations. Across the country, varied coalitions and alliances of rebel groups, former government militia and army units assumed control over every major city and town in recent weeks, with the last major provincial capital, Jalalabad, falling on Friday.
Many of these coalitions are bound together by regional, ethnic and linguistic identities, or by loyalties to prominent leaders.
On Friday, many of Kabul's neighborhoods were infiltrated by rebels from many organizations. In the southwest of the city, an area populated by Hazaras, Shiite Muslims from the west of the country, forces of the Iranian-backed guerrilla groups Hezb-i-Wahadat and Harakat-e-Inquilab-e-Islami established offices, set up checkpoints and occupied police stations.
Thousands of rebels, perhaps as many as 100,000 from various factions, took up positions in the mountains surrounding Kabul and along the main roads. For the most part, the north of the capital was dominated by Mr. Masood's forces, while Mr. Hekmatyar's fighters took up positions to the south.
Afghan Army soldiers and troops from the northern coalition headed by General Abdul Rashid Doestam, supported by Mr. Masood's fighters, had established a defensive perimeter on the southern edges of the city. But over the last week, the boundaries of the city became so porous that as many as 20,000 guerrillas filtered in.
Today, rebels in the city rushed to capture Government armories. The Kabul garrison, led by General Nabi Azimi, a Tajik who supervised the Government's military council in the waning days of the regime, invited Mr. Masood's fighters into his cantonment several days ago.
 
Awaiting Orders
 Early this afternoon, a group of Hezb-i-Islami guerrillas seized a national guard armory. From a ground-floor room, weathered fighters in loose turbans handed out new AK-47's, their barrels gleaming with fresh oil, and bayonets to the 100 rebels commanded by Turran Sarshar.
"We arrived one hour ago," Mr. Sarshar said. "We control this building and are guarding the area. So far there has been no fighting. Every party wants an Islamic country so there should be no fighting."
But Mr. Sarshar was adamant in backing Mr. Hekmatyar's refusal to enter an alliance with other groups.
Apart from securing his neighborhood, Mr. Sarshar said he was unclear what was expected of him. "We want a program," he said. "We want orders."
The collapse of the Kabul Government began last winter, first with the disintegration of the Soviet Union, Mr. Najibullah's principal benefactor. As the flow of weapons and money dried up, Mr. Najibullah stepped up his calls for a peaceful settlement. At every turn, the guerrillas rejected his pleas for compromise, vowing they would not lay down their arms until he was removed from office.
In January, alarmed at the rising ethnic chauvinism within the armed forces, Mr. Najibullah tried to replace a group of generals in the north, all of whom were either Uzbeks or Tajiks, with Pathan commanders. But the officers rebelled and formed an alliance with General Doestam, the most powerful militia commander in the north and an Uzbek.
 
Ally of President Rebels
 Time and again in the last three years, General Doestam had sent his soldiers to shore up Government defenses around the country, but the President's attempt to assert the control of Pathan officers over the military drove him into revolt.
Alliances between commanders and guerrilla factions proliferated, with many coalescing into shuras, or governing councils, that assumed administration of towns and cities.
Then nine days ago, Mr. Najibullah, without informing his senior aides, attempted to flee in the plane belonging to the United Nations special envoy, Benon Sevan. But control of the airport had been turned over to General Doestam's soldiers, who refused to let the former President leave the country. He fled to sanctuary in a United Nations building in the city, and his whereabouts today were not known.
Kabul's fall may spell an end to the four-year campaign to find a peaceful settlement. Mr. Sevan worked strenuously, meeting with rebel factions in Peshawar and Teheran, as well as with Mr. Najibullah and his Government. Last month, it appeared that his efforts had finally borne fruit when Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, in Geneva, announced the outlines of a plan for an interim administration and elections for a new government. That plan seemed to lie in shambles amid the jubilant gunfire thundering in Kabul's streets tonight.
Mr. Sevan is in Pakistan with the Secretary General and is to return to Kabul on Monday. But it is now unclear whether he will, or what he can accomplish if he does. And while guerrillas and their supporters cruised the streets of Kabul jammed into the back of trucks, and while the faces of fighters who have spent many of the last 14 years in the mountains of Afghanistan show genuine smiles at their victory, there is little sense of what will happen tomorrow.

HEADLINE: PERU JETS ATTACK U.S. AIR TRANSPORT

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 25

 BODY:
An American military transport plane flying off Peru's coast was fired on by two Peruvian fighter planes Friday afternoon, resulting in the loss of one crewman, but Washington and Lima appeared today to be trying to minimize confrontation over the incident.
American officials in Washington expressed concern and said the incident, which involved a C-130 transport plane on a routine counterdrug surveillance mission, was being investigated. 
 Peruvian officials expressed regret and said their pilots had sought to prevent an incident.
The shooting could increase tensions between Peru and the United States three weeks after President Alberto K. Fujimori seized extraordinary powers, saying the move was necessary to bring political and economic order in light of challenges from Maoist guerrillas and drug traffickers.
 
Plane Lands in Peru
 The shots damaged the plane's fuselage and forced it to land at an airstrip in the northern Peruvian city of Talara. Peruvian officials said that the plane was off course and that it had not responded to radio or visual contacts.
One American official here said the plane was off course because it was being tracked by fighter planes and was seeking to escape.
[In Washington, a Pentagon spokeswoman said the plane was en route to its base in Panama. A White House spokesman, Bill Harlow, said: "Obviously we're concerned over the incident. Our plane was shot down and one of our people was killed. We don't know what happened and we're investigating."]
In addition to the crew member who reportedly was sucked out of the plane when a door blew open from the machine-gun fire, two other airmen were wounded, one superficially. Peru and the United States have been searching for the lost airman, who is presumed dead because the plane was flying at 30,000 feet when it was attacked. He was not identified.
"We deeply regret this incident and consider it to be an accident," said a Peruvian Air Force official, who insisted on not being identified.
The American Ambassador, Anthony C. E. Quainton, called President Fujimori, and an embassy spokesman said Mr. Fujimori had expressed "regret and concern," apologized for the incident and promised a thorough investigation. While a Peruvian radio station said Mr. Fujimori had called President Bush to apologize, the White House said the two had not spoken.
Relations have been tense since the United States took the lead in condemning Mr. Fujimori's seizure of power on April 5 and stopped aid to Peru.
According to United States officials, the C-130 was on a mission over the Upper Huallaga Valley, a coca-growing area. For three years the United States has operated a base there called Santa Lucia, and more than two dozen Drug Enforcement Administration agents work with the Peruvian police to destroy cocaine-processing labs, eradicate coca plants and stop trafficking.
 
Eye-to-Eye Contact
 Peruvian Air Force officials said they assumed the C-130 was on a surveillance mission. They said that after the plane was spotted in the Upper Huallaga region, it veered off course more than 300 miles to the coast. The plane was over the Pacific Ocean, 60 miles off the coast, when it was hit.
Peruvian Air Force officials say that permission had been granted for the plane to fly in the drug trafficking area. They said that once the plane started moving off course, Russian-made SU-200 fighters armed with missiles, rockets and machine guns began to follow it. "As far as we know, the pilots tried to communicate in every way with the pilot of the C-130," said an Air Force official. Hesaid the Peruvian pilots had told their superiors that they tried to make radio contact with the C-130, then approached and established eye contact and motioned for the plane to land, before firing warning shots.
 
Shots Fired at 5 P.M.
 "Only after that did they open fire," the official said, adding that the pilots fired at a part of the cargo plane that would not force the plane to crash.
"If they had wanted to they could have put that plane in the bottom of the sea," the official said.
The Peruvian jets fired at shortly after 5 P.M. The Pentagon did not announce the incident until midnight in Washington.
The Peruvian Air Force appears to be trying to take a more aggressive posture against unidentified aircraft in the region. Days after Mr. Fujimori dissolved Congress and the judiciary, he gave the Air Force control over all airports and airstrips in the Upper Huallaga, including the Santa Lucia air base. Municipal governments and police had generally controlled the airports in the past.
There was speculation that the change in command could have created confusion over flight procedures between the two countries.
 
Tension in Washington
 The incident is certain to complicate the relationship between the two countries in the fight against drugs. Many in Congress and in the Bush Administration are already pressing to reduce the United States role in Peru's drug war.
After Mr. Fujimori's seizure of power, the United States removed 20 Green Berets who were training the Peruvian Army in counter-narcotics work. Moreover, American officials say they are planning to dismantle two radar stations that track planes used by drug traffickers and remove the 60 Air Force troops who are running them in the Upper Huallaga Valley.
In a communique, Peruvian officials said their fighter pilots had to take some kind of action since the C-130 did not identify itself and that it cannot just assume that if a plane has United States markings they are genuine.
Peru has also had tense relations with Ecuador over areas of its border.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Investigates Attack

WASHINGTON, April 25 (Special to The New York Times) -- A Defense Department spokesman, Glenn Flood, said that all details of the attack were being investigated and that he did not know when the investigation would yield answers.
Capt. Barbara Summers, a Pentagon spokeswoman, said, "When the aircraft was fired upon, it was 60 miles off the coast of Peru on its way home to Howard Air Force Base in Panama."
Mr. Flood said the flight's precise purpose had been "approved by the two Governments" of the United States and Peru.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: POLL;
POLL SHOWS PEROT GAINING STRENGTH TO RIVAL CLINTON'S

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
Riding a wave of discontent with politics-as-usual, Ross Perot is now the preferred Presidential alternative of more than a fifth of the registered voters, putting him just behind Gov. Bill Clinton, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
More than two-thirds of registered voters admitted knowing little about Mr. Perot, who has not yet officially entered the race but is considering an independent candidacy. More than half in the new survey were unable to describe him as a liberal, a conservative or a moderate. But the Texas businessman is increasingly seen as an option by voters dissatisfied with Mr. Clinton, the likely Democratic nominee, and President Bush, the poll showed. 
 Asked how they would vote if the election were held today, 23 percent of registered voters said they would back Mr. Perot, 28 percent Mr. Clinton and 38 percent Mr. Bush. A month ago, Mr. Perot was at 16 percent, Mr. Clinton at 31 percent and Mr. Bush at 44 percent.
 
Mean Season Favors Perot
 In a mean political season that seems to reward those who stand outside the fray -- witness Paul E. Tsongas's strong second place finish in the New York primary after withdrawing from the race -- Mr. Perot is thriving as an undeclared candidate. Mr. Clinton's negative ratings have soared during the hard-fought primary campaign, and Mr. Bush's have jumped as well.
Mr. Perot, who is just beginning to draw the scrutiny afforded a Presidential candidate, is now the only contender who is viewed positively by more people than those who view him negatively. Mr. Perot's fans said he offered real change, and they said they liked his business background and expertise.
Still, polls in the spring do not necessarily predict votes in the fall. In 1980 John Anderson, the last major independent candidate for President, had the support of 20 percent at this stage of the campaign but pulled only 7 percent of the vote.
 
Advantage of Being Unknown
 Moreover, non-politicians sometimes take poorly to the white heat of the political process. A recent example was Clayton Williams, the Texas oilman whose apolitical charm in early 1990 turned into a series of verbal gaffes by fall that destroyed his campaign for Governor of Texas.
In Kansas City, Mo., yesterday, Mr. Clinton said the poll reflected public disenchantment. "People have been so disappointed for so long by what's happening in Washington, and they're so frustrated by the economic problems of their states," he said. "And they want it to be fixed."
Robert M. Teeter, chairman of the Bush campaign, said it was not unusual to see such signs of discontent "at the end of a long economic downturn." He predicted that voters would ultimately make their decisions on the basis of "who has the leadership and the experience needed to govern the country."
The poll, conducted Monday through Thursday, was based on telephone interviews with 1,530 adults nationwide, of whom 1,151 were registered voters. It had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
The poll suggested that the Perot phenomenon was broad and diffuse, as befits a candidacy rooted in a series of television interviews earlier this year. His support cut across the lines of party, political philosophy, age and income. In many cases, it seemed to have little to do with Mr. Perot himself; 28 percent of those who said they would vote for him were unable to say whether they had a favorable or unfavorable opinion of him.
 
Perot Support Has Breadth
 An analysis of the current poll showed Mr. Perot sapping strength from both Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton, although slightly more from the Democrat. He ran about the same among liberals, moderates and conservatives, but did particularly well among men, Westerners and college graduates.
Perhaps most worrisome for the two parties, the survey suggests that Mr. Perot, at the moment, is a vehicle for the voters' frustration with the candidates this year. Fifty-nine percent of the registered voters surveyed said they were dissatisfied when their choices were confined to Mr. Bush or Mr. Clinton. When Mr. Perot's name was added to their options, only 36 percent remained unhappy.
This discontent with conventional politics has become a hallmark of the 1992 campaign, and poses a serious challenge to both parties. It helps explain why both Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton are struggling to present themselves as agents of change running against an established order, even though both men are career politicians.
 
A Call for Fundamental Change
 In a measure of the voters' disaffection, the survey asked whether Americans thought their political system needed minor change, fundamental change, or a complete rebuilding. Only 15 percent said minor change; 57 percent called for fundamental change and 27 percent said it needed to be completely rebuilt.
Their alienation continues to rise. Forty-four percent said government does not pay much attention to what people think. In the fall of 1988, only 28 percent took that view.
The survey suggests that Mr. Perot's supporters are on the cutting edge of this angry mood. Sixty-one percent of them said the Government would work better if "we voted in all new people" Fifty percent of Clinton's supporters and 36 percent of Mr. Bush's supporters felt that way.
Against this backdrop, the survey suggests that both Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton will enter the general election campaign with formidable problems.
Mr. Bush's job approval rating remained stuck at 39 percent among all adults, statistically unchanged from his showing in March and February. Even his conduct of foreign policy, once a sure winner in public opinion polls, got favorable marks from only 44 percent, while 46 percent disapproved of his performance there.
Mr. Bush also got poor grades on a series of domestic issues that he has tried to address on the campaign trail this year. Fifty-six percent of registered voters said the Bush Administration has not done a good job dealing with the drug problem; 65 percent said it had done a poor job on education, and 78 percent said it had done a poor job on the economy.
The President's personal image has also worsened over the past month. Thirty-five percent of those polled said they have a favorable opinion of Mr. Bush, while 44 percent reported an unfavorable opinion. This is the first Times/CBS News poll this year that showed Mr. Bush's negative ratings exceeding his positive.
 
Bush Leads Clinton One-on-One

It was not all bad news for the President, who maintained a lead over Mr. Clinton. In a two-way race, Mr. Bush was preferred by 46 percent of the registered voters, while Mr. Clinton was the choice of 40 percent. And more than two-thirds said they expect Mr. Bush to win this fall, compared with only 19 percent who cited Mr. Clinton and 7 percent who cited Mr. Perot.
As Mr. Clinton wraps up a brutal primary season, 40 percent of the registered voters said they had an unfavorable opinion of him, as against 26 who viewed him positively. In comparison, at this point in 1980, Ronald Reagan was viewed unfavorably by 34 percent, and favorably by 43 percent.
The Arkansas Governor is vulnerable on the personal quality voters most frequently cite as important in a President -- honesty and integrity. Only 24 percent of the registered voters said he had more honesty and integrity than most people in public life, while 59 percent said he does not.
After months of being derided by his critics as "Slick Willie," Mr. Clinton is viewed by many voters as hiding something when he answers charges about his personal life. Twenty-three percent said they thought Mr. Clinton was telling the entire truth, while 53 percent said he was "mostly telling the truth but hiding something" and 11 percent said he was lying.
Still, most of those who said he was hiding something also said it was not "something the public needs to know," and nearly half of those polled said they thought the news media had been tougher on Mr. Clinton than on other candidates for the Presidency. Only 16 percent thought Mr. Bush had been given tougher treatment.
Mr. Clinton, in the aftermath of New York, consolidated his standing in the party; 64 percent of the Democratic primary voters said they preferred him as the nominee, compared with 24 percent who backed former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California.
But only 22 percent of Mr. Clinton's Democratic primary supporters described themselves as "strongly" favoring him for the nomination.
 
 
 
HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Monday through Thursday with 1,530 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii. Of them, 1,151 said they were registered voters.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened so that calls would be placed to residences only. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into a residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for results based on those registered voters who said they would vote for Ross Perot for President, it is plus or minus six percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.
