HEADLINE: Burmese Rulers Releasing a Dozen Political Prisoners

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
After years of mounting international pressure over its dismal human rights record, the military Government of Myanmar said yesterday that it had released a dozen political prisoners and would allow the family of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the detained opposition leader and winner of the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize, to visit her.
The offer to visit Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, who has been under house arrest since 1989 and won the peace prize for her nonviolent campaign for democracy in her homeland, was quickly accepted by her husband, Michael Aris, a Briton who is a visiting professor of Tibetan and Himalayan studies at Harvard University. 
 "It is very good news -- we've waited a long time for this," Mr. Aris told The Associated Press as he made plans for the trip. He and the couple's two sons, Alexander, 18, and Kim, 14, who accepted the prize in Oslo last October for their mother, have not been allowed to visit her since Christmas, 1989.
 
Express Skepticism
 But experts on Burmese affairs and exiles opposed to the military junta in Myanmar, formerly Burma, expressed skepticism yesterday over the junta's moves. They called them largely conciliatory gestures aimed at placating an international community fed up with the junta's human rights record.
"The junta is one of the most ruthless dictatorships that ever existed and now they're trying to change their image," said Josef Silverstein, a professor at Rutgers University who has written extensively on Burmese affairs. "They intend to hold power if they can. But once they begin this process, I'm not sure they're going to be able to hold it in check. If they can't, maybe there is going to be something very exciting out there."
Khin Nyo, the editor of Burma Review, a monthly newsletter for Burmese dissidents in the United States and other countries, also called the junta's moves cosmetic, intended not as first steps toward democracy but to ease international criticisms.
He noted that the junta's actions came two days after the resignation of Gen. Saw Maung, who had led the junta since its founding in 1988, and he said the new leader, Gen. Than Shwe, was less moderate than his predecessor.
Burma, a largely Buddhist nation of 40 million with large Muslim and ethnic minorities, has a long, troubled history of dictatorship. After nearly 30 years of isolationist, autocratic rule by Gen. U Ne Win, pro-democracy demonstrations erupted in 1988. Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, the daughter of U Aung San, the founder of modern Burma who was assassinated in 1947, returned from a self-imposed exile and became the opposition's leader.
Human rights groups say thousands were killed when troops fired into crowds of peaceful pro-democracy demonstrators. In the ensuing turmoil, Mr. Ne Win resigned, but continued to wield considerable power behind the scenes as the junta that replaced him suspended political rights and set up the State Law and Order Restoration Council, led by Gen. Saw Maung.
 
Election Ignored
 Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi was placed under house arrest in July 1989. But under international pressure, the junta carried out a pledge to hold national parliamentary elections in May 1990 and her movement, the National League for Democracy, won by overwhelming margins.
The junta simply ignored the results, and the international outcry has grown steadily louder. Dissidents say the army has repressed two million ethnic Kachins in the north and four million ethnic Karens in the east, while 200,000 Burmese Muslims in the west have fled from famine and persecution into neighboring Bangladesh, where Burmese army raiders have sometimes pursued and killed them.
Amid the international protest, The United States and Germany withdrew aid programs in 1988, as did the World Bank. And Japan -- Myanmar's largest supplier of aid, giving $61 million last year -- recently warned the junta to improve its human rights record.
Last December, the United Nations General Assembly rebuked Myanmar for refusing to surrender power to a democratically elected parliament. And last February, 46 nations in the Middle East called on the junta to halt persecution of Muslim minorities.
Mr. Silverstein said Myanmar's economy has faded with its international standing and is now essentially flat. Mr. Khin Nyo said the country faced a possible rice famine this year.
With pressures mounting, Gen. Saw Maung resigned and his successor announced the release of former Prime Minister U Nu, 85, who had led the nation briefly after the ouster of Ne Win in 1988, and 11 other political prisoners, all members of the Patriotic Old Comrades League.
The junta also said it would allow a long-promised conference to set policies for writing a democratic constitution. Finally, it said it would let Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's family visit her.
Little is known of the new junta leader, Gen. Than Shwe, because biographies of Burmese army leaders are not made public. But Mr. Silverstein said he was 58, joined the army in 1953, had led an infantry division and became Defense Minister last month.
But Mr. Silverstein and Mr. Khin Nyo said real power in the junta was held behind the scenes by Ne Win and his protege, the Burmese intelligence chief, Khin Nyunt, who said recently that the nation would "never accept" Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi as its leader.

HEADLINE: Euphoria Is Scarce as Dinkins Loosens Fiscal Belt

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Jose Delgado lingered at the doorstep of a decaying South Bronx apartment building last week watching Mayor David N. Dinkins promise millions of dollars in projects. After a while the politicians dispersed. The television cameras were packed up. The onlookers dribbled away. But Mr. Delgado remained, as he always does.
"Every time they want to be elected, they come here," said the 41-year-old building superintendent. "They say they are going to do things to fix the neighborhood, but it's been like this since 1972." 
 But Perry Gasparis, 54, who had left his nearby coffee shop still in his white apron to watch the Mayor, hoped that this time would be different. "This is a prime location in the Bronx," he said of the corner where only the shells of two former court buildings remain. "I don't know why they let it go down like this. But I'd like to see them do something here. I'd like to see it before I die."
After years of recession and fiscal trauma, after more than two years of watching the Mayor seem to dispense only things like homeless shelters, city residents appeared to be caught off guard last week by Mr. Dinkins's cornucopia of library openings, day-care centers, health clinics and development projects. There was even a projected $455 million budget surplus for the fiscal year ending on June 30.
 
Orchestrated Good News
 Likewise, in the corridors of power, from City Hall to Albany, the orchestrated wave of good news brought forth a cascade of grievances, as lawmakers and fiscal monitors raged that the administration had been misrepresenting the budget. Municipal union leaders demanded a share of the surplus.
Outside City Hall, many New Yorkers found the Mayor's sudden change in tone hard to grasp. Some people, longing for the recession to end, said tentatively that perhaps the city had turned a corner. Some looked for the fine print or the bookkeeping tricks that would make the announced projects diminish. And others were so cynical, so fed up with politicians, that they said they doubted the Mayor really had the money.
"I find it very hard to believe," said Linda Chiarel, 38, a private school teacher who was out with her two small sons in Woodside, Queens, on Friday. "Nothing looked good up until now."
Kenneth Luft, 40, of Brooklyn's Canarsie section called the week's announcements "fantasy news" and said they were timed to coincide with a fund-raising dinner for the Mayor tomorrow. "Obviously he's got a dinner coming up and he's got to get support," Mr. Luft said.
 
Easier to Do Homework
 But Keisha Scott, a 17-year-old student at Brooklyn Technical High School, was delighted that expanded library hours would make it easier for her to do homework. "I think it's a start," she said. "If people see that this is happening, more things will begin to get better."
In the Bronx, Mr. Delgado dismissed the largesse as politics as usual, waving his arms to spots where former Presidents and other mayors once posed. "Carter, when he was running for President, stood over there and talked about cleaning up this place," he said. "and I remember Koch stood over on the corner and did the same thing."
What Mr. Dinkins had to offer was often simply the restoration of former services like five-day-a-week libraries, or the return of projects that were delayed when the fiscal crisis hit. The proposed new police academy for the Bronx was first announced by Mayor Edward I. Koch when he was running for re-election in 1989. It was shelved by the Dinkins administration when hard times hit. Half of the $4 million that Mr. Dinkins allotted to finish building Prospect Park Children's Zoo in Brooklyn was money that had been promised earlier but then deferred.
And some of the development projects Mr. Dinkins proclaimed in the Bronx and Brooklyn would not be fully financed until 1997. But after half a term of bad tidings, they could be announced with fanfare.
 
Sign of Re-election Campaign
 City politicians said the barnstorming dispelled any doubt whether Mr. Dinkins would seek re-election. "There is no doubt that the Mayor has designed a strategy to reconstitute himself again, and you can't blame him for that," said the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden. "He's a political animal."
But among some members of the public, the Mayor's announcements brought only mistrust and no break in the gloom about the city's prospects.
Mr. Luft of Canarsie was unimpressed, even by the library openings, though he has two children and education on his mind. "My cousin lives in Plainview," he said. "Libraries there are open at night. And they actually have books in there too." For the last few years, he has debated whether to stay in the city, though Brooklyn has long been home. For now, a good local school program has tipped the balance in Brooklyn's favor.
Mr. Luft said he worried about his property values, about taxes and about crime. "What we want is someone who knows what's going on," said Mr. Luft, 40. "Dinkins doesn't and Koch didn't."
 
'Not if I'm Alive and Conscious'
 He said he voted for Mr. Dinkins in the last election. But asked if he would again, he snapped, "Not if I'm alive and conscious."
Mary Gibson, 54, shopping in Woodside, tried to take solace in the better budgetary news. "It's a good sign," she said. "Let's hope things are coming back." But she spoke of the city in the past tense as if discussing the dead. "New York was a great city," she said. "I don't know if it's all Mayor Dinkins's fault. It's hard to say."
Maria Smalls, who had taken her 7-year-old and 5-year-old to the Brooklyn Public Library for the afternoon, gave the Mayor the benefit of the doubt, though she too was puzzled at the budget news. "I'm personally wondering where did he get all this money all of a sudden," said the Flatbush woman. But she was ready to be grateful for his plan for health-care clinics for the poor and restored library hours.
"I hope they've come to realize you really do need libraries," she said, missing her bus because she was so intent on making her point. "To me education is power."
 
Library Vandalized and Closed
 She was gentle towards the Mayor. "I think what he inherited from the Koch administration was a big burden, a big problem," she said. "Considering what he has to work with, he's doing a great job."
In another section of Brooklyn, in the corner of inner-city devastation where Brownsville, Bushwick and Bedford-Stuyvesant meet, the Saratoga library branch stands shuttered behind a fence. Vandals had stripped the building's copper flashing and gutters and the roof had leaked. The city couldn't spare the $42,000 for repairs. In 1990, with the ceiling collapsing, the library was closed.
Across the street on Thursday several girls sat on a stoop near piles of rubbish, braiding the hair of their dolls. They hadn't heard that Mr. Dinkins had pledged $250,000 to rebuild the library. But told that it might reopen, they squealed with delight. "We could do our homework in there," said 10-year-old Simone Minter.
But Develelyn Goodin, 33, homeless for five years and now living in city-owned housing around the corner, had no enthusiasm for Mr. Dinkins or his proposals. "He speaks more of what he wants to do, before he knows he can get it done," he said. "This is a very poor community. They need things here."

HEADLINE: Cleanup Gets Little of Superfund Settlements

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 25

 BODY:
Only one-tenth of the money spent by insurance companies to settle Superfund environmental claims is used to clean up hazardous materials, according to a new study.
About 90 percent of the money from the insurance companies goes to legal fees and related costs, the report said. It was made public Thursday by the Rand Corporation, a nonprofit research group with headquarters here. 
 The Federal Superfund program calls for the cleanup costs at each site to be divided among those who dumped the wastes. Critics have said that this emphasis on liability will lead to more arguments than cleanup. The Rand study supports this view but concludes that "the verdict is not yet in."
Costs involved in a cleanup but not directly related to it are likely to remain high while insurers challenge several aspects of the Superfund law, said an economist, Jan Paul Acton, a co-author of the report who left Rand to join the Congressional Budget Office.
 
Industries Doing Better
 The report also said that the spending for actual cleanup efforts usually rises over time, so the proportion of non-cleanup costs should fall as more toxic waste dumps are cleaned.
In contrast to insurance companies, the biggest industries are spending about 80 percent of their Superfund-related expenses for actually cleaning up toxic waste, the study said.
The report on the insurance companies is based on data from four national insurance carriers that together received 13,000 claims seeking insurance payments for hazardous waste cleanups. The figures on industrial companies were from five concerns involved in 700 toxic waste dumps. Rand agreed not to name the companies in exchange for their cooperation.
Rand said the study is the first attempt to measure the use of money from private industry under the Federal Superfund law, which is aimed at reducing the nation's toxic waste hazard. The report said the proportion of cleanup versus non-cleanup costs by the Government and small companies is unknown.
Fewer than 5 percent of the 1,200 toxic waste dumps on the Environmental Protection Agency's Superfund priority list have been cleaned up completely, said the report by Mr. Acton and another economist, Lloyd Dixon. About 75 percent of the sites are still in the early stages of cleanup.
 
Defending Policyholders
 The study found that insurance companies spent an estimated $470 million on Superfund-related claims in 1989, almost twice their 1986 expenditures.
"But $410 million went to the legal costs of defending their policyholders and disputing whether their policies covered the cleanup," Rand said. That amount of money could have paid to clean up 15 toxic waste sites, Rand added.
Rand reported that non-cleanup costs were quite low at sites where the waste had been dumped by a single company. They were much higher for sites where many companies dumped waste and were presumably disputing their share of liability.
The industries in the study spent an average of $6.1 million in 1989 for Superfund-related cleanups. That was triple the 1986 figure, but still low considering that each concern dumped waste at an average of 140 sites.
Two years ago, Rand described the pace of Superfund cleanup efforts as "super slow."

HEADLINE: Accord Is Reached to Ease Canadian Restrictions on Beer From U.S.

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 25

 BODY:
In a compromise aimed at avoiding a trade war, Canada and the United States today reached an agreement in principle to ease the restrictions that Canada imposes on imports of American beer.
The accord was reached after late-night meetings in Washington and telephone calls between Washington, Ottawa and the seats of provincial governments in Canada. President Bush and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney did not directly take part in the talks but had recently discussed the need to reduce trade tensions, officials of both Governments said. 
 Mr. Mulroney is to visit Washington May 20 for discussions that are expected to center on trade issues. And both Governments are negotiating with Mexico over the creation of a North American free trade area embracing the three countries. Mr. Bush reiterated on Thursday that he wanted such an agreement, which would expand trade among the three countries, to be concluded this year.
The talks that achieved the breakthrough today centered on when Canada would open its markets to American beer. Washington had wanted access by this summer; Ottawa wanted three years. In today's agreement, the two Governments split the difference, agreeing that American brewers would be given access to Canadian retailers by Oct. 1, 1993.
"We're pleased that we've been able to arrive at this agreement and remove this longstanding issue from the U.S.- Canada agenda," said Julius L. Katz, Deputy United States Trade Representative.
Mr. Katz described today's pact as "an agreement in principle" and said it needed to be "more sharply defined" in coming days.
 
U.S. Beer Faced Many Hurdles
 American brands have faced many hurdles in Canada. In Quebec, only Canadian-brewed beer is available in grocery stores. In Ontario, only Canadian-brewed is sold in the popular provincially operated beer stores. Some provinces also subject imported beer to bigger markups than domestic brands and maintain a variety of size restrictions. Ontario, for instance, allows imports to be only in six-packs.
Canada has complained that Federal and state alcohol taxes in the United States unfairly limit Canadian beer sales. That issue is being negotiated separately and more slowly.
Canada and the United States, with the largest two-way trade of any two countries in the world, concluded a free-trade accord in January 1989. The dispute over beer has been so difficult and long-lasting that it was not included in that agreement.
In addition to beer, conflicts involving automobiles, lumber, magnesium and carpets have inflamed tempers in recent months -- partly because the lingering economic slump and approaching elections in both countries have increased sensitivities about job losses from imports.
The United States took its complaints about Canadian restrictive practices on beer to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade in Geneva, which found the Canadians to be unfairly discriminating.
Howard Collins, acting general manager for the Brewers Association of Canada, said his members were pleased with the agreement although they would have preferred a longer transition.
The three largest American brewers -- the Anheuser-Busch Companies, the Coors Brewing Company and the Miller Brewing subsidiary of the Philip Morris Companies -- have longstanding licensing arrangements with Canadian brewers under which their major brands are produced in Canada.
The G. Heileman Brewing Company and the Stroh Brewery Company, which do not have arrangements with Canadian brewers, led the fight for increased access.
American beer producers supply about 3 percent of the Canadian market, and Canadian beer accounts for about 1 percent of the much larger American market. The actual value of Canadian sales into the United States, at $160.7 million last year, was more than six times the value of American exports to Canada.

HEADLINE: War on Poverty Symbol Accused of Murder

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: INEZ, Ky., April 25

 BODY:
The unemployed Appalachian coal miner whom Lyndon B. Johnson visited 28 years ago as President to announce a national war on poverty has been charged with murder in the fatal poisoning of his 3-year-old daughter.
President Johnson used Tommy Fletcher's humble foothills house as the backdrop to tell the nation on April 24, 1964, that it was time to stamp out poverty. At the time, Mr. Fletcher was 38 years old, had not worked in two years and was struggling to support a family of 10. 
 His wife at that time later died. Mr. Fletcher, now 66, and his current wife, Mary Porter Fletcher, 25, were indicted March 26 on charges of murder and first-degree criminal abuse. They are being held on $100,000 bail each and are scheduled for trial on Sept. 23.
The couple, who until they were jailed lived in the same tar-paper house that President Johnson visited, are accused of killing their daughter with a drug overdose and trying to do the same to their 4-year-old son.
The girl, Ella Rose Fletcher, died on Jan. 4 of what doctors originally believed to be an epileptic seizure. But when her brother, Tommy Fletcher Jr., was hospitalized a month later for drug poisoning, the state police had her body exhumed. An autopsy showed that she had died of an overdose of an antidepressant and had been sexually molested.
An attorney for the state, Leo Marcum, said the couple had taken out a $5,000 insurance policy on each child. He also said that Mrs. Fletcher had told an investigator that she feared her six-year marriage was deteriorating and that she and her husband had not had any problems before the children were born.

HEADLINE: After Years of Aiding Rebels, Little U.S. Influence

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
As Afghan rebels take control of Kabul, the Bush Administration is exercising little influence after years of doling out military aid to the guerrillas who are now emerging victorious.
In part the reduced American role demonstrates the transience of alliances bought with arms supplies. American leverage diminished quickly once military aid was cut off last year in hopes of fostering a settlement to the civil war. But some regional diplomats and scholars also say that as the struggle reaches a climax, prudence may dictate that Washington let events run their own course. 
 "The warring sides in Afghanistan have their own agendas, often in conflict with those of their external supporters," Kenneth Katzman, a regional analyst at the Congressional Research Service, said in a briefing paper on United States policy options issued nine days ago as the Government of President Najibullah collapsed.
And Barry Rubin, a foreign policy fellow at the Johns Hopkins School for Advanced International Studies, said that by quietly supporting United Nations mediation efforts and urging a peaceful close to the civil war, the Administration may also be seeking to shelter itself from blame should diplomacy collapse into renewed fighting.
 
'U.N. Responsibility' Seen
 "Anything they can work out will be acceptable to the United States," he said of the negotiations that continued today even as rival rebel groups poured into Kabul, the Afghan capital."And if it breaks down, it is a U.N. responsibility, not the U.S. responsibility, to handle it."
At the moment, American efforts are concentrated in three areas, none of them highly visible.
The first goal is to back up United Nations mediators by quietly discussing their aims with Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and indirectly Iran, along with the rebels themselves.
The second is to insure that relief supplies continue to be delivered. The United States shipped 10,000 tons of food to Kabul this month to help stabilize the capital.
The third is to try to retrieve some of the advanced arms, like Stinger missiles, that are still in the hands of the rebels, an objective that is difficult to achieve and that the Administration refuses to discuss in detail.
Beyond these limited efforts, experts said, it makes sense for the United States to play a cautious game as long as the power struggle seems to be breaking the way it prefers, with a new government emerging that could grant the least possible power to the most militant rebel groups, like the Hezb-i-Islami of Gulbuddin Hekmatyar.
The cautious approach also preserves avenues for exerting future influence, perhaps using generous economic aid, should a coalition emerge that is strong enough to govern amid the turmoil of the devastated country. Such a coalition, experts said, might bring together militia who abandoned the Government of Mr. Najibullah only recently and joined in a partnership with rebels led by Ahmad Shah Masood, who has the implicit support of the Bush Administration and whose forces are now taking over Kabul.
And diplomatic experts said the American posture mirrored those of other outside powers. That includes not only the former Soviet Union, which agreed last fall to cut off aid to Kabul and is now virtually absent from the scene, but also Pakistan, which has also been losing sway over rebels who no longer need sanctuary across the border, and Iran, which has internal preoccupations.
 
'A Relatively Low Priority'
 "Of course, the U.S. does have a stake, but the issue is a relatively low priority," Mr. Rubin said. "It wants a stable government with a minimal amount of violence, and there is some concern that it does not want radical fundamentalists to take over." A fundamentalist government in Afghanistan could bolster the regional power of Iran and undermine the stability of the predominantly Muslim former Soviet republics in Central Asia.
Robert Oakley, a former United States Ambassador to Pakistan who now studies the region at the Peace Institute in Washington, said the United States should seek to exert continuing influence, perhaps through an economic aid program to Afghanistan.
But he acknowledged that United States influence throughout the region is modest.
He said humanitarian aid should be increased if only to repay what he called a debt owed to the Afghans for their role in toppling the Soviet empire.
Direct humanitarian aid for Afghans, including refugees, runs about $70 million a year, with the United States also contributing to international relief agencies.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Pennsylvania;
In Delegate-Rich Contest, Candidates Are Making Very Little Noise

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 25

 BODY:
Only three states have more delegates to the Democratic National Convention than Pennsylvania's 169.
But it is difficult to tell that from the desultory activity that has passed for campaigning in the weeks leading up to the state's Presidential primary on Tuesday. From Independence Hall in Philadelphia to the Golden Triangle in Pittsburgh, from the Poconos to Lake Erie, many Pennsylvanians are unaware of the primary and many others have trouble suppressing yawns. 
 "People are underwhelmed," a county chairman said. "Me too."
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, still struggling to free himself of questions about his integrity, has a wide lead in the polls, and he is expected to win going away. But there is no sound of trumpets, no rumbling of a bandwagon to be heard. A month ago, in New York, 56 percent of the voters surveyed on Election Day said they wished someone else were running; in the latest Pennsylvania poll published in The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette this week, the number reached 65 percent.
 
'No Intensity' by Clinton
 Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California has spent more time in the state than Mr. Clinton, whose arrival here was delayed for almost a week by strained vocal cords. But Mr. Brown's exertions have won him little support, even in depressed areas, like the Monongahela Valley near Pittsburgh, where his attacks on big business and indifferent government might have been appealing.
The Pennsylvania Poll, which surveyed 445 Democrats from April 15 to 18, with a margin of sampling error of five percentage points, showed Mr. Clinton with 43 percent among the most likely voters, as against 20 percent for Mr. Brown, 20 percent for former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, whose name remains on the ballot even though he withdrew from the campaign several weeks ago, and 17 percent undecided.
That is not a powerful showing for the Arkansas Governor at a time when he has been conceded the nomination by most politicians and analysts.
"Pennsylvania is a conservative state where economic issues count the most," said G. Terry Madonna, director of the Center for Politics and Public Affairs at Millersville State College. "There's nothing trendy, flamboyant or avant-garde about Democrats here. They don't care much about so-called character issues. But Clinton has been a no-show. His campaign events have been well staged, but there haven't been many, and there's no intensity."
In sharp contrast to the New York primary, Mr. Brown has for the most part refrained from attacking Mr. Clinton, although this week, walking in Aliquippa, where the closing of steel mills has devastated the local economy, he said, "Voting for Clinton is like taking out a ticket on the Titanic." He has done little advertising on television as his contributions have faded.
A third-place finish in New York, behind Mr. Clinton and the ghost candidacy of Mr. Tsongas, has made Mr. Brown a less appealing alternative to many voters and helped create the possibility that the same fate could befall him here.
Mr. Clinton has all but ignored Mr. Brown, attempting to refocus his campaign on President Bush and the fall. His primary strategists, Paul E. Begala and James Carville, speak about using the primary to introduce him to a state that the Democrats must win in November if they are to have a chance nationally.
In the last decade, Pennsylvania has lost 300,000 manufacturing jobs. Its population is shrinking as places like Altoona, where the railroads were once king, and Johnstown, once a steel center, search for new identities. But despite that, and despite a big Democratic registration edge, Pennsylvania has gone Republican in each of the last three Presidential elections.
 
Seeking Reagan Democrats
 For Mr. Clinton, bringing Republican-voting Democrats back home -- regaining the so-called Reagan Democrats -- is the key to general-election victory here as well as in other industrial states. Pennsylvania, Mr. Begala said last week, has "11.5 million of the type of people we are trying to address in this campaign."
To help him do it, Mr. Clinton has traveled around with Senator Harris Wofford, carrying him along like an amulet. With the help of Mr. Carville and Mr. Begala, Mr. Wofford lured the swing voters in his upset victory over former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh last year. His big issue was health care, and he was at Mr. Clinton's side Friday at the Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia, describing Mr. Clinton as "the kind of man who I believe can turn the right of affordable health care into reality."
A large number of the Reagan Democrats are union members, and Mr. Clinton picked up two valuable endorsements on Friday from the 900,000-member United Automobile Workers and the 200,000-member United Mine Workers. Owen F. Bieber, the U.A.W. president, said this week that the union was "entirely comfortable with Clinton's ability to force the Bush campaign to expose its weaknesses on the issues."
But the presumptive nominee's efforts to turn the primary here into a preview of a Bush-Clinton contest in the fall have been hampered by two men, Ross Perot and Pennsylvania's unconventional Governor, Robert P. Casey.
Mr. Clinton descended from the "Presidential" plane on which he has tried to pitch his campaign to attack Mr. Perot, the potential independent candidate, asserting that Mr. Perot's lobbying activities and contributions to politicians made him every bit as much a politician as other candidates.
Concentration on Mr. Perot by the press for the last week has made it harder for Mr. Clinton to draw attention to his own substantive speeches, on which he is relying to make him seem a big enough man for the White House.
The bigger threat has been Mr. Casey, a conservative Democrat now in his second term, who is extremely popular in this state. In a series of interviews in the last week, he has bluntly stated his conviction that Mr. Clinton has been so seriously damaged by questions of probity that he cannot defeat Mr. Bush this fall.
"This is the worst possible nightmare for our party," Mr. Casey said in an interview on Thursday. "Nobody's going to vote in the primary -- tiny turnout. Clinton has barely emerged from a very weak field. In terms of staying power for the fall, there are red flags everywhere, and they'll stay there unless he can convince people that he's trustworthy.
"In one poll, 85 percent of the Democrats in the state say they think the country's on the wrong track, which ought to be Bush's death sentence. Yet Bush is ahead of Clinton here, because people don't trust Clinton. Nobody's cheering, nobody's happy. As things stand now, they're not going to vote for a President Clinton in this state, I can assure you of that."
Whether Mr. Casey's views will change large numbers of votes is dubious; he himself says Mr. Clinton will win "by plenty" and argues that "Jerry Brown has lost his fast ball." But his pointed remarks only remind people of the doubts that Mr. Clinton had hoped to banish here next week.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Germany Tussle at Monetary Talks

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25

 BODY:
As finance ministers from around the world gathered here for several days of meetings on the troubled international economy, an unusually harsh dispute between the United States and Germany over their domestic budget policies continued unabated today.
Like the scheduled welcome of Russia and the other former Soviet republics into the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund on Monday, the trans-Atlantic jousting threatens to detract attention from the international lending institutions' traditional clients in the third world. Planning sessions for the lending institutions' semiannual conference have given little attention to the new problems of the poor countries, such as the drought in Africa, or to their new economic growth. After years of following the stiff prescriptions of the World Bank and the I.M.F., dozens of them are buying more Western exports. 
 The neglect of poor countries comes at a time when the industrial world is increasingly dependent on third-world markets, as President Bush pointed out in a speech on Thursday to Western Hemisphere business executives.
The latest German-American discord began on Thursday, as David C. Mulford, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, made no mention of poor countries when he outlined the American agenda at the lending institutions' conference and at a separate meeting on Sunday of finance ministers from the seven largest industrial democracies.
Mr. Mulford called on Germany to move faster to lower its interest rates because they were slowing growth around the world. On Friday in Bonn, Horst Kohler, the state secretary in Germany's Finance Ministry, accused the United States of making "one-sided statements."
Today, a senior German official here tried to convince reporters that there were no hard feelings.
"There's really no clash, really no big problem between the United States and Germany," said the official, who also spoke on condition of anonymity.
But within minutes, the official was expressing indignation and citing American budget problems. "Suddenly these people, or some of them, give us the advice to increase taxes. I'm really a bit surprised," he said.
Faster growth in Europe would help American exports and the American economy before the November elections. The senior German official said that with the German economy growing at an annual rate of slightly more than 4 percent in the first quarter of this year, no further stimulus was needed.
The meeting on Sunday of the finance ministers of Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States is one of a periodic series on international monetary and economic policy. The finance ministers of the Group of Seven are also prepared to endorse on Sunday, as expected, a ruble stabilization fund run by the I.M.F., the German official said.
The most visible event this week may be the vote planned for Monday by the 156 member countries of the I.M.F. and the World Bank to admit the former Soviet republics.
The nearly forgotten ghosts at the finance ministers' banquets this week will be the more than 4 billion people who live in poor countries. Representatives of 24 poor countries worked today on a draft listing their concerns, led by a call for assurances that assistance to the former Soviet republics will not reduce aid for the third world, said an official involved in the drafting.
Financial officials from wealthy countries met Friday and today to review further contributions to the International Development Association, the World Bank's arm for lending to countries where average economic output per person is less than $750.
The level of contributions is adjusted every three years, with the next change scheduled for July of 1993. In the past, the World Bank's staff has sought contribution increases exceeding the worldwide inflation rate, to make ever more money available for the 40-year, no-interest loans.
But this time the bank is only seeking to keep pace with inflation, and Washington has been struggling over whether it can endorse even that.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sanctions Against Haiti Seem Ineffective

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 24

 BODY:
American diplomats here are expressing growing exasperation as their efforts to reverse the violent army coup here last September have either backfired or gone virtually ignored by forces opposed to the return of the elected president, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
Most political, military and business leaders here have stubbornly held out despite a punishing, five-month old trade embargo, repeated hints at armed intervention and most recently the cancellation of American visas for a score of wealthy Haitians thought to have supported the coup. 
 Conditions for the poor, meanwhile, have grown increasingly desperate, prompting renewed departures of large numbers of boat people. Diplomats fear the exodus could easily get out of hand just weeks after the strenuously contested forced return to the country of more than 15,000 would-be refugees, who were intercepted by the United States Coast Guard.
Emboldened by their successful resistance to international pressures to restore democracy so far, Haitian leaders have become openly defiant, directing public taunts at the United States.
In the official newspaper, the newly appointed Information Minister, Gerard Bissainthe, has begun publishing regular, signed columns newspaper written in rhymed verse that deride the American ambassador and United States diplomacy in general.
Calling Haiti the "Bermuda's Triangle" of diplomats, Mr. Bissainthe's series has ridiculed the Ambassador, Alvin P. Adams Jr., as a "fatally wounded" envoy and describes him as an "arrogant, violent, authoritarian" personality.
Mr. Bissainthe has also denounced a senior State Department official who visited here recently to revive efforts to ratify a negotiated solution to the country's crisis that calls for Father Aristide's eventual return. Among other things, the minister's columns have called the official, Robert Gelbard, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, a "glory-thirsty" adventurer.
 
Warning by Envoy
 During a stormy visit here this month, diplomats said, Mr. Gelbard warned Haitian leaders of dire consequences, including the possibility of armed foreign intervention, if they failed to quickly back the settlement, which was brokered by the Organization of American States.
Among many Haitians opposed to Father Aristide return, however, the visit was quickly enshrined as an example of purported American racism and arrogance toward Haiti. These charges were revived by provocative comments that Haitian legislators say Mr. Gelbard made to them during a dinner at the home of Mr. Adams.
"Haitians," Mr. Gelbard is said to have announced to his guests, "have one chromosome too few, the one for consensus and compromise, and one chromosome too many, the one for conflict and discord."
"It was like he was saying, 'you have a basic deficiency, you guys, I cannot really even blame you for what you are,' " said Marc L. Bazin, a conservative politician who was an invited guest at the dinner. "Coming from a senior diplomat, I thought it was absolutely astounding."
American officials acknowledged the substance of Mr. Gelbard's comments and conceded that they had come as "a shock," but said there was no offense intended.
"The message they got out of that visit is that the Americans are not going to give up here," said a diplomat, angered by the high-volume campaign built around Mr. Gelbard's remarks. "It's not about marking points. We are trying to let people in on what kind of future they can expect, and there is no hope for these guys on the horizon. Nothing."
Despite Mr. Gelbard's warning that there must be movement by May 18, when O.A.S. foreign ministers will meet in the Bahamas, the provisional president, Joseph Nerette, in a palace interview on Thursday, ruled out any adherence to O.A.S. prescriptions, saying he would forge ahead in building a "consensus government."

HEADLINE: Bush to Make It Easier To Sell Public Property

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
President Bush will issue an executive order next week making it easier for state and local officials to sell public assets like airports, roads, bridges and sewage treatment plants to private businesses, White House officials say.
Plans for the order are the latest move in a campaign of deregulation and privatization driven in part by the Administration's ideology but also aimed at showing a President coping with domestic issues in an election year. 
 On Friday, for instance, the Administration announced new steps in a continuing effort to lighten regulation of financial institutions. At the same time, White House officials said Mr. Bush was expected to announce next week an extension, into the summer, of the 90-day Government regulatory moratorium he ordered in January as one step to fight the recession.
The order dealing with state and local governments' sale of public property was first reported Friday night by NBC News. In confirming plans for it, White House officials said its main provision entailed giving such governments a financial incentive to let private business buy some of their assets.
 
How the Incentive Would Work
 Airports, sewage treatment plants, bridges and other installations operated by local governments are often built with the help of Federal money. Under current Federal rules, Washington is entitled to a share of the proceeds from the sale of such property.
For example, if the Federal Government paid 60 percent of the cost of building a local airport, it may be entitled to 60 percent of the proceeds. That kind of provision discourages the local authority from selling.
Speaking on condition of anonymity, White House officials said the new executive order would reduce the share of the proceeds to be paid to the Government. The Administration has not yet settled on a formula that will determine that share.
Administration officials said the Government would not lose any money under the arrangement because the current regulations are so restrictive that hardly any sales now occur in any case.
 
Response by Governors
 Asked about the effect of the new order, James L. Martin, director of state-Federal relations at the National Governors Association, said he was not aware of any great desire by governors to sell state-owned properties to private investors.
Similarly, Michael W. Brown, a spokesman for the United States Conference of Mayors, said he had not heard much discussion of such sales. "This issue has not hit our agenda as yet," Mr. Brown said.
But an Administration official said the President's order would give local officials an incentive to put the issue higher on their agenda. "In general," said this official, "we think it's good to privatize government services."
Indeed, like the Reagan Administration before it, the Bush Administration contends that many government activities can be performed more efficiently, at lower cost, by businesses.
Independent assessments have questioned that premise, however.
The General Accounting Office, Congress's investigative and auditing arm, warned in November that "the Government should not contract out its responsibilities to serve the public or to exercise its sovereign powers."
Specifically the accounting office said that several Federal agencies, including the Transportation Department, the Energy Department and the Environmental Protection Agency, had probably gone too far in hiring private contractors to perform Government functions. The accounting office said that many tasks being contracted out by those agencies were core Government responsibilities and that in any case the use of contractors sometimes cost more than if the agencies performed the work themselves.
As for the steps announced Friday on easing regulation of financial institutions, the most significant was the issuance of a final rule by the Environmental Protection Agency to protect lenders from financial liability for damage to the environment caused by their borrowers. Some lenders fear that under Federal law they may be held responsible for the cost of cleaning up contaminated properties.
The American Bankers Association welcomed the new rule, saying it would help banks that lend to such businesses as dry cleaners, gas stations and farms.
The Administration also announced a program to establish uniform policies for Government examination of financial institutions. The four Federal agencies supervising such institutions agreed to work together to overcome what the White House called the "balkanization" of authority.

HEADLINE: N.F.L. DRAFT;
How the Draft Was Born and How It May End

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY W. SMITH

 BODY:
Any talk of the National Football League going without a college draft is enough to cause heart palpitations among the draftniks around the country, especially those who have turned prognostication on the picks into a cottage industry.
No draft means no more secretive whispers about vertical jumps, 40-yard sprint times and bench presses. No more scouting combines. No more draft-day trades. No more No. 1 picks that don't blossom. And -- yipes -- no more draftniks on the balcony of the draft room at the Marriott Marquis screaming at their teams for making terrible picks? 
 But it could happen.
After 56 years, the N.F.L. draft is faced with extinction. This is the last year that the league's college draft is protected under the 1982 collective bargaining agreement with the players. Without the protection of the bargaining agreement, the draft will surely come under legal attack from the Players Association as an antitrust violation.
"They can't conduct the draft that they do now without violating the law," said Doug Allen, assistant executive director of the Players Association. "There's no collective bargaining agreement to bless it with."
The N.F.L. commissioner, Paul Tagliabue, maintains that the league will go forward with the draft in 1993.
"I think that we'll continue to have a draft pretty much in the form in which it is presently because the draft that we now have is reasonable under any legal standard," Tagliabue said during the N.F.L.'s owners meeting in Phoenix in March. "It was set out in negotiations with the Players Union in 1977 in its current form and I think it will continue."
The current form of the draft emerged after years of experimentation and changes. The original proposal to conduct a draft, in which players who had used up their college eligibility were selected in a lottery by teams in inverse order to a team's finish the year before, was adopted in 1935.
Bert Bell, the Philadelphia Eagles owner and later N.F.L. commissioner, proposed the draft.
Guess which team had the first pick in the first draft held in 1936?
The Eagles made Jay Berwanger, University of Chicago halfback and Heisman Trophy winner, the first No. 1 pick in the college draft. And like most No. 1 picks who aren't signed before the draft, Berwanger never signed and sat out the season.
The Eagles traded his rights to Chicago, but the Bears couldn't sign Berwanger either. Berwanger never played pro football, because at the time a team held a player's rights forever. That rule didn't change until 1977, when the league, under an agreement in the bargaining agreement, allowed unsigned college players to go back into the draft pool the next year.
The draft's future could hinge on current litigation before the court. In a case set to begin on June 15 in a Federal court in Minneapolis, N.F.L. players are seeking free agency.
While the draft is not an issue in the case, if the veteran players are granted free agency by the court the mood for free agency could trickle down to those entering the league for the first time.
Free agency for all players, rookies included, would mean that N.F.L. teams would have to do a considerable amount of courting before they could get a player to walk down the aisle.
Teams in places like Green Bay, Wis., would have to come up with a heck of a sales pitch and maybe loads of cash to get great players to come out into the cold.
Conceivably, without a draft, N.F.L. teams would have to scour the country like college recruiters, selling the virtues of their team and trying to work out attractive financial packages to entice players to sign contracts. Just think, a system where a recruit could be offered a car, above the table, for signing. The thought is frightening to the N.F.L.
"It would be chaotic," said Harold Henderson, N.F.L. executive vice president for labor relations and chairman of the N.F.L. Management Council. "It would be counter to the competitive balance of the league. The teams with the most money and most desirable locations will be able to cherry pick the cream of the crop."
 
Revenue Is Shared
 Allen said the league already shares a great deal of its revenue, most of which comes from the network and cable television rights package, so free agency does not pose a financial drain on individual teams. He said the N.F.L. will be hard-pressed to show that the league's competitive balance will be altered by free-agent rookies.
"It's just a myth that they've used to justify the need for a restrictive system," Allen said.
 Henderson's argument that the draft and its inverted lottery system preserve the league's competitive balance would draw protest in some quarters. Consider that Indianapolis, New England and Tampa Bay have had 8 of the 10 No. 1 picks in the last 10 years and only New England has been to a Super Bowl (1986).
The Colts and the Buccaneers have made the playoffs only once (Tampa Bay in 1982 and Indianapolis in 1987) in 10 years.
On the other hand, Dallas has used trades for draft picks to build a playoff caliber team. The Cowboys, using the No. 1 pick in 1990 and 1991 and trading for other first-round picks, went from 1-15 in 1989 to 11-5 and the playoffs last season.
Jerry Jones, the Cowboys' owner since 1989 and a man noted for his draft-day wheeling and dealing, knows about the possible challenges to the draft, but he will continue to conduct business as usual, which means making trades based on next year's picks.
Jones thinks some form of a draft will always exist in the N.F.L.
"Basically, I don't give a very high percentage to having wide-open selection of players," Jones said. "I don't give that much credence. I think if any way the rules are changed, by agreement or in the court, economic gravity will dictate some type of orderly draft."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
More Than Bosnia

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
As Serbian forces attacked Croatia last year, I asked a British official with much experience in conflict-resolution what he thought Americans and Europeans should be doing. Without hesitation he replied: "We should tell the Serbs that unless they call off their aggression, we will bomb Belgrade."
It was an answer startlingly at odds with official policy. The U.S. and the European Community then were refusing to label Serbia the aggressor, and refusing to recognize the republics that had broken off from Yugoslavia. Our policy was to mediate the conflict from a neutral posture. The use of force was not in remotest contemplation. 
 But with time the answer has become more and more compelling. Mediation, though carried out by Cyrus Vance and Lord Carrington with high dedication and skill, has not ended the Serbian aggression. Serbian irregulars and elements of the federal army are now ravaging the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Europe and America are no longer in their stance of aloof neutrality. The E.C., followed by the U.S., recognized the republics. As Serbian military brutalities have mounted, the Bush Administration has begun talking with the E.C. about imposing sanctions on Serbia. But still the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret Tutwiler, speaks in almost pathetic tones about the fighting.
"We're calling on everyone," Miss Tutwiler said last week, "to please do whatever they can or use whatever influence they can to halt this."
Three guesses how Slobodan Milosevic, the Communist leader of Serbia, will respond to a pretty please. He has made it about as clear as anyone can in the last year that he understands only one kind of language: the language of force.
Of course it is true that outside intervention in ethnic conflicts like those in the republics of the former Yugoslavia presents dangers. There were reasons that the United Nations Charter barred international intervention in "internal" affairs.
But to define such ethnic conflicts as "internal" is becoming increasingly difficult. When Mr. Milosevic sought to expand Serbian power, and the other nations in Yugoslavia responded in fear by withdrawing from the federal state, were the Serbian bombing and shelling that followed "internal"?
Moreover, for the world to let military savagery rage unchecked in Bosnia and Herzegovina threatens far more than the life of that small state. All over Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union there is ethnic tension: in Czechoslovakia, Romania, Azerbaijan, Armenia, Georgia, Russia.
In those places, and others, communities that define themselves by language or religion or history are minorities within a state. They feel threatened. They want security for themselves and their communal identities. Yet the states of which they are a part fear that minorities, in asserting their rights, will shatter the state structure.
The problem urgently requires an answer -- an international answer. Edward Mortimer, writing in The Financial Times of London, explained why:
"States should be able to recognize self-defined 'communities' on their territory without feeling that they have opened the door to secession and disintegration. An internationally accepted regime of minority rights and obligations is indispensable if much more chaos and bloodshed in Eastern Europe are to be avoided."
Working out international definitions and mechanisms to protect minority rights will be a formidable task. But let it begin.
Mr. Mortimer suggests starting in the (Helsinki) Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, where the Netherlands has proposed a High Commissioner for Minorities. Mr. Mortimer's is a wise thought, because the immediate need for reassuring action is in Europe and the responsibility should be here, too.
But the Serbian problem will not wait for larger political solutions. The time has surely come to tell Mr. Milosevic that continued Serbian aggression will be met at once by absolute economic isolation and then quickly, if still necessary, by force. If we can ground Saddam Hussein's helicopters, we can much more easily silence Slobodan Milosevic's guns.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Gender Contender

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
To: Governor Clinton
Re: Half the Voters
 
Dear Governor,
How's your sore throat? What's happening in the Pennsylvania primary? Is it my imagination or has Hillary been muzzled since the cookies vs. career controversy? Will Bob Kerrey be your running mate? There aren't any more bombshells, are there?
How come you haven't noticed us? 
 There are millions of agitated female voters out here and you have a golden opportunity to persuade us to support you. We're the people who upset Senator Alan J. Dixon in Illinois and could make Carol Moseley Braun the first woman of color to serve in the Senate. We're the people who have taken Lynn Yeakel from 0 to 60 in a couple of months in Pennsylvania, relishing the spectacle of a smart woman taking on Arlen Specter in a Senate race.
They say this is our year. The issues once called women's issues have become cutting edge. Since this last momentous fall, when the Judiciary Committee sent Anita Hill back to Oklahoma like a doctoral candidate who had failed her orals, our anger has become a recognized national phenomenon. One of our fund-raising organizations, Emily's List, has doubled the number of its contributors since then.
Hasn't anyone told you?
We have no reason to support George Bush. Even some Republican women will say so. During the New Hampshire primary the reporters who cover the President got some yuks out of one commercial. In it, Mr. Bush was sitting at his desk when a woman assistant came in and handed him some papers. The joke was that it was the first woman assistant seen in the Oval Office since the Administration began.
But it's not simply that Barbara Bush is the best-known woman in this Administration. After all, your wife is the most prominent woman in your inner circle, too, although she has the experience to be part of a policy partnership as well as a domestic one. Your closest campaign advisers are the standard-issue white guys.
And this is not just about abortion. By the way, Governor, what was going through your mind last Wednesday? There was only one story in this country that day, and it was the future of legal abortion, writ large in Supreme Court arguments and in arrests in Buffalo. And you gave a speech about the environment. Great issue, bad timing, even if it was Earth Day.
Back in 1988 George Bush evoked significantly less enthusiasm from women than he did from men. And that was before he vetoed family leave, gagged the doctors at family planning clinics, said Clarence Thomas was the best man for the job and spent a year pretending that the economy was A-O.K. Opinion polls showed that we women were much less enamored of his antiseptic war in the Persian Gulf than our male counterparts.
You could fashion a victory out of this gender gap. If you are going to stand for a new generation, you can begin by standing for a generation that has come of age during the fight for equality at work and at home, a generation that has been irrevocably shaped by the changing roles, concerns and problems of women. You could show that you get it, as the post-Hill shorthand goes. But first you have to convincingly recognize our existence.
You cannot assume that the gender gap automatically benefits you. You have a gender gap of your own, a personal one. Some women look at you and see every charming and evasive rover they ever had the bad fortune to tangle with.
You could defuse that if you spoke out in a constant and concerted way about your commitment to family planning clinics and prenatal care programs, family leave policies and early childhood education initiatives, legal abortion and a polyglot inner circle. You've been out there romancing black voters, Jewish communities, labor unions. But you haven't romanced women enough. (Look, you're going to have this problem with double-entendres. Just grin and bear it and everyone will think you're a sport.)
We're raising hell in state races; we could raise hell in this one too. But we're too ticked off to be taken for granted for long, and lots of us are still looking at you as the lesser of two evils, which doesn't inspire anybody to hire a sitter and trudge to the polls come November. The good ol' boys keep saying you need to bring Joe Six Pack back to the Democratic Party in November. But for every Joe, there's another voter out there searching for a candidate. Name's Jane. We're waiting.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
