HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Clinton's Standard Campaign Speech: A Call for Responsibility

BYLINE: GWEN IFILL

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton's standard campaign speech has evolved since October from a broad discussion of policy that was detailed and long-winded to a more focused talk about his vision for America.
For a while, such speechmaking was almost entirely put aside as Mr. Clinton
spent much of his time explaining himself on personal issues, including marital fidelity and his military draft history. 
 The core of his message has changed little, though he shifts the emphasis depending on the predominant concerns of the area where he is campaigning.
In both the South and the North, his appeals for racial unity strike a chord, but in the South he speaks of race in a confidential tone that appeals to shared experience.
Mr. Clinton usually does not speak from notes but touches on the same primary points in each speech, often shifting paragraphs of thought around as he speaks. Lately, as he has tried to rehabilitate his image before audiences who know little that is good about him, he has infused his talks with personal reminiscences, calling on his audiences to respond to the demands of citizenship by voting.
Following is the text of the campaign speech, excluding a brief introductory passage, that Gov. Bill Clinton delivered at the University of Pittsburgh branch at Johnstown, Pa., on April 22, as transcribed by The New York Times.

 	 	 		. . .	 	I want to make just a few sort of basic points about this election. And I'd like begin with two little statistics, one of which was published a day or two ago in America's newspapers and one of which will be out tomorrow. Statistic No. 1: According to the Federal Reserve Board, 1 percent of America's people at the top of the totem pole now have more wealth than the bottom 90 percent, the biggest imbalance in wealth in America since the 1920's right before the Great Depression.
Statistic No. 2, out tomorrow: For the first time in a decade personal income in our country as a whole fell last year. That says we've got problems. And I want to tell you that behind that, I live in a state that is one of the worst states in America, where we were abandoned with farm income going down, factories closing and moving away. The Federal Government cutting back on money for economic development, education, environmental protection. We've got a lot of counties that went through just what you went through in this county.
And in the last 11 years, I had to try to put together an economic strategy to deal with it. I don't like to bore people with statistics, but let me tell you, what's happened here might be worse than what's happened in some other places in Pennsylvania, but it's not all that different from what's happened in America.
For more than two years now, the average middle-class family has worked harder for less money to pay more for health care, for housing, for education, for taxes. Poverty has exploded, especially among working people.
I just got out of a rather bruising campaign in New York State. You might have read about it. But one of the things that really moved me about that was that I met so many courageous people, people you never see on television, who live in the Bronx and Brooklyn, who live in high-crime neighborhoods and get up every day and literally risk their physical security, going to and from jobs that still pay them less than top-level wages, to support children in difficult circumstances, playing by the rules.
For millions and millions of Americans, the dream with which I grew up has been shattered. The ideal that if you work hard and play by the rules you'll be rewarded, you'll do a little better next year than you did last year, your kids will do better than you. But that idea has been devastated for millions of Americans.
How did this happen? I would argue it happened for two reasons. No. 1: We lost our economic leadership. Other nations began to do some things better than we do, and their economies started growing faster and faster as ours slowed down.
 
Big, Simple Ideas
 No. 2, and this is why I'm running for President: We elected people to high office who had the wrong response to the problem. And that's what this election is all about. Three or four big, simple ideas, even though the problems are complex.
What is President Bush's theory about what's good about the economy? That the Government would mess up a one-car parade, and you can't trust anybody in politics or Government. So the answer to our economic problems is to make taxes lower on corporations and high-income individuals, and get out of the way and let the market do the rest.
That's their idea. The other day, the President vetoed a bill passed by the Congress that a pro-business Democrat, Lloyd Bentsen from Texas, got through, a tax bill that would have made it easier for plants to modernize their equipment, for people to start small businesses, for people to buy houses, for people to invest in housing in low-income areas. All these things would have been done and George Bush vetoed the bill. Why? Because those incentives were going to be paid for by raising taxes on upper-income people. And he didn't want to do that, because his theory is keep the taxes low on the rich and the corporations and everything will be fine.
Well everything is not fine. We have had it their way for 11 years. And we're going downhill as a nation. The middle class is collapsing. Poverty is exploding. Even the wealthiest people know that we're on the wrong track.
What is the alternative? That's what I represent. It isn't just more tax and spend. It isn't just fighting over the pie that we've been fighting over for 11 years in Washington. It is a dramatically different economic policy which the Government says we -- starting with the President -- says we're going to work in partnership with business and labor and education, and we're going to create a high-wage economy in this country.
We're going to have a smart-work, high-wage country, not a hard-work, low-wage country. And we're going to do it by beating the competition. Let me give you some examples.
Taxes. In this country if you run a plant, and you're getting competed against by someone who runs a plant with low wages, if you looked at the tax laws of this country, you would think your Government wants you to shut your plant down and move it overseas.
You know why? Let's suppose you have a little plant in Johnstown and you make light bulbs. And you work with 400 folks. And your competition is from overseas. And the only way you can beat the competition is to stay in Johnstown and spend $2 million on a modern piece of equipment. This is a practical example. Your Government will not give you a tax credit to write that equipment off. But if you shut your plant down and move it overseas, you get a tax deduction for shutting the plant down.
Then you start your plant overseas and you lose money the first couple of years when you start the plant. You get to deduct those losses from your American income tax. Then when you start to make money, if you leave your money in a foreign bank, you never have to pay a penny of tax on it.
I'm old-fashioned about this. I think it's O.K. with me if people decided to invest money in other countries because they need to be there. It's O.K. with me if the Europeans invest money in our country and put people to work because they need to be here.
But I'll tell you something, you look at the German tax code. They don't subsidize shutting plants down in their country and moving them overseas. They subsidize people retraining and putting new equipment in their country. And that could be why 32 percent of the German work force is in manufacturing and only 17 percent of the American work force is. If you vote for me, I'm going to try to turn that around and invest in this country again.
Let me give you another example. Health care. You elected Harris Wofford to the Senate on the health-care issue. Why? Because people are scared to death they can't afford their health-care bills, and some people don't have health insurance, and other people are afraid they've got it but they're going to lose it. And the cost of it is going up at two or three times the rate of inflation every year.
You may just assume that's normal in the world. But it isn't. It isn't. You live in the only advanced country where your Government does not step in to organize the health-care system so we keep cost in line with inflation and everybody gets basic health care.
So your country spends 40 percent more of its income than any nation on earth on health care and gets less for it. Why? Let me give you a couple of examples.
Your nation is the only one where there are 1,500 separate health insurance companies, writing thousands of policies covering different things, insuring groups that may be very small. So much so that only 84 cents of the health-insurance dollar goes into health care in America. You know what it is in Europe? Ninety-five cents. You know what the difference is on our health insurance bill? Sixty billion dollars a year.
Your country is the only country in the world where the employment of clerical workers in hospitals has gone up by four times the rate of the employment of nurses and doctors and other health caregivers. Because we are drowning in a sea of paper work brought on by health-insurance organizations, health-care bureaucracies and the Government itself.
We have steel mills. Look what happened to steel employment. We have steel mills in this country that have over $4 an hour in health-care costs for retired steelworkers. How can you compete with the rest of the world?
Look at what's happened with automobiles. I get mad at the automobile manufacturers, and the auto workers have done a good job of changing the work rules trying to be more productive. But one thing that's not the auto companies' fault is health-care costs. If you drove here in an American car today that you bought in the last three years, you have got $500 in health-care costs more than if you drove here in a European or Japanese car. How can we compete?
Why did this happen? Because your Government has arrogantly refused to do what all of our competitors have done and crack down on the cost of health care and provide a basic health-care package to all. The people that don't have health insurance, do they get health care? You bet they do. But when it's too late, too expensive, they show up at an emergency room, and those of you with health insurance pay the bill.
And I'm telling you, if you don't ask the President to give you national health insurance, it won't matter if 100 percent of the Congress is for it, you're not going to get it. If you vote for me, I'll give you a national health-insurance plan.
Example No. 3: We live in a world in which what you earn depends on what you can learn. We live in a world where the average 18-year-old will change work eight times in a lifetime. Think about it. That means we live in a world where institutions like this one will become more and more important.
And yet, in your country, we have no system to train all the young people who finish high school but don't go on to college. The people who don't go to four-year schools that don't want to be in dead-end jobs. What happened?
Earnings of younger families under 30 have declined 42 percent in the last 15 years. What happened? Younger high school graduates with no higher education, their earnings have gone down massively in the last 15 years.
High school dropouts in the work force -- out there working for a living -- what's happened to them? Their earnings have gone down over 40 percent in the last 15 years. Why? Because we live in a world in which what you earn depends on what you can learn.
What is the answer? The answer is to look at what the competition does. Look at what the Europeans do. Look at what the Japanese do. Look at what the countries who are paying people better do. If you don't go to college and you get out of high school, you ought to be in an apprenticeship program in this country, and everybody ought to have the right to two years of further training after high school, and Government ought to organize a partnership to get it done.
The earnings of college graduates now are 70 percent more than the earnings of high school graduates in the first year of work. That's over two-and-a-half times what the difference was 10 years ago. What does that mean? That means anybody who wants to go to college and is able to academically ought to be able to go.
But the cost of a college education has gone up by more than health care in the last 10 years. And the dropout rate in college is two and a half times the high school dropout rate.
Here's what I think ought to be done. I think we ought to tell every sixth and seventh and eighth grader, if you stay in school and make decent grades and you want to go to college, you'll be able to go. Here's how.
We ought to scrap the student loan program that exists now. It wastes a lot of money and it doesn't work very well. Here's what I would put in its place. I would put in its place a domestic G.I. bill, a national service trust fund. Anybody can borrow the money to go to college. Any American, without regard to income, no questions asked. Here's your obligation. You would sign a contract to pay it back in one of two ways: your choice. Either as a small percentage of your income over time after you get out of school and go to work, paid at tax time so you couldn't beat the bill.
But you pay according to what you earn, not just how much you borrowed but what you earn. So it wouldn't punish people if they wanted to be police officers or teachers, or work in public service work, people would pay according to what they earn.
Or what I would hope would happen: Every American who borrowed the money would have the option to pay it off with a year or two of national service where you could go back home and you could actually work for a reduced pay; the Federal Government would pay you, just like the Peace Corps except here at home.
Go home and be a police officer; go home and be a preschool teacher; go home and work in a drug program; go home and work in a housing program; go home and help the homeless. Help to solve the problems of America.
 
A Call for Change
 We can educate a whole new generation of Americans. That's the first big idea this election time. Is that what a government does or not? If you vote for President Bush, he'll give you four more years of the same, except he'll say a little more, just like he did in 1988, when he put out the kinder, gentler number, education and the environment.
So now he'll be for a little more. But look at the evidence. They've had 11 years. Ten years ago we had the highest wages in the world. Now we're 10th. Income went down last year for the first time in a decade, but two-thirds of the American people have had their incomes going down for more than 10 years. If we vote for four more years of the same, we're going to get what we deserve.
The second big idea you've got to face is this. What kind of people do you want to be? What kind of citizens are we?
There are a lot of things wrong with America that the Government can't fix. We got this idea in the 80's that we all ought to get it while we can and forget about our friends and neighbors and turn a quick buck. Some people did that by joining gangs and selling drugs on street corners in devastated cities.
Other people did it by selling their companies down the drain with leveraged buyouts and funny financial transactions that made a ton of money for the people who were pushing the paper, and threw all the factory workers out on the street with no future.
And as a result of that, this country is very divided today. We're divided by race and region, by income, by age, by gender. We are all cut up. And I'm telling you, we can't fake it. There's only one President. There's only 535 members of Congress. There are 250 million Americans. We have got to say we want to be one nation again.
We also have to say we also know there are some things the Government can't do. No one can give us an opportunity if we will not take the responsibility for seizing it.
The Republicans always talk about welfare. I know a lot about the welfare system. I spent a lot of time studying it. I hate it. I want to change it. But you know what? The people who are trapped in it, they hate it, too. It's like being caught on a reservation and kept in dependency. And it's no good for anybody.
But you know the right way to change it? I'm for making people on welfare go to work, but you've got to understand why they don't. Most people who are trapped on welfare and don't go to work don't do it because they have no education, they have no skills. If they went on to work, they'd get a minimum-wage job, they couldn't afford child care and they'd give up the Medicaid coverage which gives their children medical benefits. Nobody in their right mind hurts their kids.
You wouldn't do that. So what should we do? Give education, training, child care and medical coverage that make people go to work where they can get jobs. In the culture, require people to be responsible but give them the opportunity to do it.
We ought to have more help for families in this country, but we also ought to require more responsibility. I live in a state where we can fine parents if they won't show up when their kids are in trouble in school. A lot of people think that's harsh but it's a little statement that there are some things the Government can't do if people aren't willing to do for themselves.
I favor giving working poor people an earned income tax credit that can actually give them some money back from the Government to get them above the poverty line. I think if somebody's out there working 40 hours a week, raising kids they ought to be rewarded.
And I favor putting with that the toughest conceivable system of child-support enforcement. I'm tired of people bringing kids into the world and leaving them for the Government to raise.
We've got to decide what kind of people we are.
 
Responsibility of Citizens
 The last thing I'm going to tell you is this. You've got to decide whether you believe in citizenship or not. It's always so fashionable to hate politicians today. Especially me, look at all the stuff you've heard about me.
I'll tell you how bad it is. I was at home the other day at a fund-raising lunch in Little Rock where 1,000 people paid $100 to come have lunch with me. Just my friends and neighbors trying to boost my campaign. And this guy who's like a brother to me, he's about 61 years old, has a 9-year-old daughter who's a genius. This kid is brilliant. And she made up a joke. Here's the joke of a 9-year-old:
A child asks her father: "Dad do all fairy tales begin 'Once upon a time . . .'?" The father says: "No. Some fairy tales begin 'Now, when I'm elected . . .' "
I realize that people don't believe in the political system anymore. And that they believe the worst in politicians when they hear it.
But when I was a kid, my mother was widowed just before I was born. She went off to nursing school and left me to be raised by my grandparents until I was 4. My grandparents ran a tiny grocery store in an integrated neighborhood in a little Southern town. My grandmother was a private duty nurse, but they told me that in the Depression, Franklin Roosevelt was President and gave people hope again by giving them jobs again and giving them work to do.
And they told me if I worked hard and studied hard and played by the rules I could do anything. And I remember how they taught me to count and taught me to read when I was 2 and 3 and 4 years old. They had very little formal education.
Then I came up through the public schools because of the Government. I went to college and got a loan from the Government. I went to law school and got a loan from the Government. Even though I had six jobs while I was in law school, I had to have a loan, and I paid back every penny of it. Because that gave me a chance to make a decent living and have a future.
And when I was the age of the youngest people here, because we had a sound economic policy, I lived in an economy with 3 percent unemployment, 3 percent inflation and 3 or 4 percent real economic growth every year. Because we were competing and winning.
The best thing that the incumbent President has going for him today is that people no longer believe Government can produce anything. They're prepared to believe the worst about politicians. And folks have really given up on the American dream.
This country was set up over 200 years ago by people who believed they had a moral obligation to vote, and who knew if they were well acquainted with the issues, well acquainted with the politicians and the people would do what they were supposed to do at election time, that this country would last forever as a democracy.
And we have made it. Because the people have fought cynicism, and have fought their own doubts. And in all the tough times have made the right decisions.
I want you to go out there Tuesday and vote, and I hope that you will vote for me. I want you to go in November and vote, and if I'm there, and I think I will be, then I hope you will vote for me.
But to say that all the politicians are a bunch of bums and the country can't work anymore and everything's gone downhill, is a cop-out. Because this system begins with you, and this election is about you. It isn't about me. It's about you and your problems and your promise and your future, and all these little kids who are here tonight.
You need a different kind of President. You need people committed to pulling together. And you need to believe again that we can make a difference. The beginning of everything is believing that we can do better. Thank you very much.

HEADLINE: Red Sox Are the Subject of a Custody Battle

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK

 BODY:
The nighttime scene has the stark hues of an Edward Hopper painting: the chartreuse and tan of the diamond, the clean whites of the home team, the red of the pulsating Citgo sign beyond the famous left-field wall.
Another season of baseball has begun in Fenway Park in Boston, and despite the bluster of a New England April, the fans are out in force. After all, they have endured fates far worse than a little freezing rain. 
 But even as the game unfolds, another contest looms in the cushy private boxes above and behind home plate. It concerns the custody of the Red Sox, Boston's beloved and accursed team, and, most likely, the future of Fenway Park itself.
The troubles flow directly from the death in February of Jean R. Yawkey, the team's majority owner and the widow of Thomas Yawkey, who bought the team in 1933. They pit against each other two of the many surrogate sons of the childless Mrs. Yawkey: John L. Harrington, the executor of her estate and custodian of her two-thirds interest in the club, and Haywood C. Sullivan, the backup catcher on ignominious Red Sox teams of the 1950's who owns the third share of the team's general partnership.
Cynics say the Red Sox are finally due to win the World Series this year; as their last Series-winning season, in 1918, attests, they always win after Russian revolutions. But the storm clouds coming down the Massachusetts Turnpike, which rained and snowed out yesterday's game against the Texas Rangers, are trivial when compared with those now hanging over this precious franchise.
Mr. Harrington and Mr. Sullivan each says he is the best custodian of what they commonly call the "Yawkey tradition": the couple's knack for befriending m.v.p.'s and groundskeepers alike, for running the team with low-key benevolence and neighborliness. On opening day this season, "The Star-Spangled Banner" was not sung by a Robert Merrill type but by Arthur Rawding, Mrs. Yawkey's favorite concierge at Boston's Four Seasons hotel, where she owned a condominium.
Mrs. Yawkey's initials are stitched onto the sleeves of this year's Red Sox uniforms. And the chair in her private box, where she watched and scored the last of the thousands of ball games spanning the eras of Ted Williams, Carl Yastrzemski and Roger Clemens, will remain empty all season. But with her passing, the name Yawkey is poised to join names like Stoneham, Wrigley, Comiskey, Crosley, Griffith and others on the long roster of baseball's former first families.
New England's shaky economy permitting, Mrs. Yawkey's interest in the team will be sold soon, presumably to a corporation or consortium of individuals, for $150 million or more. But to whom, and how? Her death threatens to kick up a contractual dispute that was dormant during her last few years, one that divides the occupants of two adjoining executive boxes.
 
No Radio Necessary
 In the larger box sits Mr. Harrington, a onetime accounting professor at Boston College. Twenty-five years ago, when the Red Sox won their first pennant in a generation, he could not even buy his way into the deciding game. Instead, he and his family circled Fenway in their car, listening to the game on the radio. But after Mrs. Yawkey brought him in as team treasurer in 1981, Mr. Harrington and his wife, Maureen, became her closest companions and confidants.
Now, Mr. Harrington wears many hats: co-executor of Mrs. Yawkey's estate; president of JRY Corporation, which owns Mrs. Yawkey's interest in the team; trustee of the Yawkey Baseball Trust, which controls the stock of JRY, as well as a trustee of various Yawkey charities and foundations. Mrs. Yawkey also gave Mr. Harrington a limited partnership interest in the team, worth roughly $5 million.
 
Offers Not Taken Yet
 But the 55-year-old Mr. Harrington, a quiet family man of such conspicuous earnestness that he mouths the words to "O, Canada" when the Toronto Blue Jays are in town, does not want to buy the team. In fact, he maintains that he would rather watch games from the grandstands, where one can ignore the agents and multiyear contracts and still see the remnants of baseball's lost innocence.
Mr. Harrington said that out of deference to Mrs. Yawkey, whom he described as "a boss, a friend, a relative," he is not yet entertaining offers for the team. Indeed, he still gets choked up at the mention of Mrs. Yawkey's name. But in the next year or two or three, he says, he will sell the team. It will, as required by the state law covering charitable trusts, go to the highest bidder, or at least the highest bidder sensitive to the team's special status from Winooski to Woonsocket. And any sale would require the approval of both the American and National Leagues.
As Mr. Harrington sees it, Mr. Sullivan and his backers would be welcome to pursue the team, but would prevail only if they paid top dollar in open bidding. "John would definitely not shut out Haywood and has told him so, but at the same time Haywood does not have a right of first refusal," said Justin P. Morreale, a lawyer with Bingham, Dana & Gould, who represents the Red Sox and the Yawkey estate.
 
Just Business or Betrayal?
 But in the adjacent suite, Mr. Sullivan sees things very differently. He and his lawyer, Kitt Sawitsky of Goulston & Storrs in Boston, say that under the partnership agreement, he has the first option to buy Mrs. Yawkey's interest in the team at fair value. Anything else represents a betrayal of trust, the kind of trust on which Tom Yawkey insisted.
"I know good legal people can break anything, but if this comes to a head there's going to be trouble," Mr. Sullivan said. "Whatever my rights are, that's all I want. But I'll go to the nth degree to defend those rights."
The difference is more than a matter of symbols. For most entities, fair value approximates actual market value. But, for what both Mr. Harrington and Mr. Sullivan called the "Mona Lisa" of sports franchises, rationality might not reign. So strong is the team's lure that some egomaniacal plutocrat could well pay far more than its worth for the privilege -- and publicity -- of owning the Red Sox.
The dispute, like everything about the Red Sox, is likely to arouse intense feelings all along the New England talk show circuit. Among other matters, the new owner will probably determine whether the team remains in storied, gloriously irregular Fenway, or moves to something more profitable, expansive and antiseptic somewhere else.
The matter could well end up in court -- appropriately, perhaps, because Mr. Sullivan blames Bingham, Dana & Gould, one of Boston's most prominent law firms, for the current fix.
 
He Sees a Conflict
 As counsel for both the Red Sox and Mrs. Yawkey's various interests, Mr. Sullivan argues, the firm had a conflict of interest. Throughout, he maintained, the firm placed the interests of Mrs. Yawkey and her estate over the team's, an attempt, he said, to preserve its ties to one of its most illustrious clients by circumventing the partnership agreement it drew up.
That agreement requires any general partner seeking to sell to give first consideration to remaining general partners. But both Mr. Harrington and Mr. Morreale contend that when the time comes, the Yawkey estate will merely sell its shares of JRY Corporation stock, not its actual share of the Red Sox. Such transfers would not require the consent of any other Red Sox stockholders.
Bingham, Dana & Gould, which began representing the Red Sox in the 1920's, shortly after they sold Babe Ruth to the New York Yankees, is not subtle about its ties to the team. Its glossy promotional brochure contains five references to the Red Sox, including a photograph of Mr. Harrington and Mr. Morreale at Fenway. It has handled the team's television contracts and recent renovations of Fenway Park, and drafted Mrs. Yawkey's will.
 
'You Lose the Account'
 Mr. Sullivan said he complained of Bingham, Dana's multifaceted relationship to the team as far back as 1987, only to be rebuffed by Mrs. Yawkey. Should he gain control of the team, he said, he would drop the firm and bring in another.
Mr. Morreale denied that Bingham, Dana had acted in any way to perpetuate its ties to the team and was, in fact, reconciled to losing the team once it changes hands. "Generally, when your clients sell you lose the account; that's life for a lawyer," he said. "We love the people, we love to do the Red Sox work, but it's less than 1 percent of our billings."
He said Mr. Sullivan was kept fully informed of the alternative procedures for selling the team. "I'm sorry Sully's upset about this stuff, but he's not supported by the facts or the law," he said. "I don't think we will end up in court, in part because Sully's as free to bid for the team as anyone else. But if we do, I'm not concerned at all about the result."
Mr. Sullivan, a lifetime .226 hitter, nurtured his filial relationship with Tom Yawkey over dozens of dinners in the mid-1960's, when he became the Red Sox director of player operations. His ties to Jean Yawkey were initially cordial, but foundered in the 1980's as the two clashed over the hiring and firing of managers, free agents and other matters. In the manner of some parents, even surrogates, Mrs. Yawkey apparently construed his every disagreement as disloyalty.
Their relationship might have survived had the team fared better on the field. The team's particularly humiliating fate in 1986, when it came within a pitch of winning the World Series, strained things still more. Mrs. Yawkey and Mr. Sullivan did not speak for the final few years of her life, a feud that filtered down to groundskeepers and clubhouse workers. And as Mr. Sullivan's star fell, Mr. Harrington's rose rapidly.
"I keep saying, 'Why is He doing all these good things for me?' " Mr. Harrington said recently, reflecting on his good fortune. " 'When is He going to put me to the test?' "
"The next World Series, probably," Mr. Morreale replied.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 4; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: The Nail-Biting Delays on Mortgages

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
WHEN Jill and Robert Miller signed a contract for a two-bedroom co-op on the East Side of Manhattan just before Thanksgiving they thought they would be in their new home by now.
But the Millers are still in their rental apartment because the lender from whom they sought a mortgage took so long to handle their application. They finally got a loan from another bank and closed on the apartment at the end of March. They will be moving in after renovations have been completed. 
 Like thousands of other buyers in this frenzied time in the home-loan market, the Millers were trapped by the inability of many lenders to handle even routine applications with dispatch, stretching processing time from weeks to months.
"Getting the mortgage was one of the most frustrating experiences I have been through," said Mr. Miller, who has an insurance business in Manhattan with his father.
Mr. Miller said that the first lender they applied to was taking so long that by the beginning of January their sales contract had expired and the bank was still asking for documentation. Meanwhile, the sellers were getting anxious because they had plans to move out of state and the Millers' lawyer was telling them that they were vulnerable to losing their deposit.
At the beginning of January the Millers withdrew their loan application with United States Trust and switched to Apple Bank, where Mr. Miller had a contact.
"Even with pull," said Mr. Miller, "it took eight weeks to get a loan approval. We were making a down payment of 50 percent of the purchase price because that is what the co-op required. I do not know how people with no bank contacts, and who are going in with less of their own equity, manage today."
United States Trust did not respond to requests for an explanation of the handling of the Millers' application.
WHEN asked if it takes significantly longer for home buyers to get loan commitments today than in the past, many lenders say no. But they acknowledge that an unexpected crush at their doors starting in January, when interest rates fell to their lowest levels in more than 18 years, has pushed their mortgage-loan departments to their limits.
Mortgage brokers and real-estate professionals say that another reason for the delays is that there are fewer lenders making loans today and that those that do are putting applications through a finer screening process.
Lenders say that delays are sometimes created when borrowers submit incomplete applications.
A survey of 20 lenders by the Mortgage Bankers Association showed that the application process had stretched from an average of 20 days to 50 days.
With 30-year, fixed-rate mortgages offered by most area lenders inching back up to the 9 percent level, a gradual slowdown in applications is expected. Even so, the delays have left both buyers and sellers biting their nails and have put some transactions on a wobbly courses.
An irony of the current home-mortgage scene is that while lenders have cut interest rates to make more loans, their tougher evaluation polices and delays are making mortgages harder to come by.
"Everybody is frustrated," said Elinor Racz, a sales agent with Audrey Short Real Estate in East Brunswick, N.J. "I think that if sellers were not so desperate to keep buyers we would have seen more deals fall through over this."
Ann Moore, vice president of William Pitt Relocation Corporate Services in Stamford, Conn., said the delays are adding to the costs for her corporate clients, who pay an average of $40,000 for each relocation.
Ms. Moore said that in the past it took an average of four to six weeks from contract to closing in most transactions that her company handled. "Now," she said, "six to eight weeks from sale to closing is closer to the norm."
John A. Ward 3d, president of Chase Manhattan Personal Finance Service, the Chase bank division that deals with jumbo loans of $202,300 or more, says he understands the frustration that borrowers are feeling these days.
"The worst thing that can happen is for a borrower to have his loan turned down after the bank has had the application for three or four weeks," he said. "That can happen now. The mortgage departments are swamped."
Mr. Ward said that in his segment of the mortgage-money market, where loans average $375,000, most of his applications can be processed in a few days.
"At the high end," he said, "what I offer is a level of service that you cannot give when you are processing $150,000 to $200,000 loans. But even for us the problem is that with the huge increase in refinancing activity, the process has slowed down."
"We are usually held up by the appraisals," he said. "There are not enough appraisers to do the job."
Currently Mr. Ward's division at Chase has 5,000 customers in the pipeline nationwide, three times the volume of 18 months ago.
Jay McGorty, New York State home loan director for Great Western Savings Bank, a California-based lender that has been active in the metropolitan area for the past few years, said that his company is able to make mortgage commitments within 14 to 18 days once borrowers have provided all the data and documents needed to complete their applications.
"Our strength is that all of our documentation people are on staff including appraisers," he said. "Some lenders have to wait for outside people to finish their work before they can commit."
Mr. McGorty also said that because Great Western holds its mortgages instead of selling them on the secondary market, it has greater flexibility and does not have to meet the strict requirements of home-loan buyers like the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae.
ANOTHER factor in Great Western's ability to process loans faster is that it no longer makes loans on co-op apartments, which require a close scrutiny of the financial condition of co-op corporations.
Margaret Scott, president of Mortgage Advisory Service, said matching borrowers with lenders takes longer and is harder theses days, particularly if the buyer is looking for a co-op loan.
"There are fewer banks doing residential loans," she said. "Some that are still making loans are not dealing with co-ops or not lending to co-op apartments in certain categories like studio apartments or in buildings that still have sponsor-owned apartments."
In the past year, she has scratched eight lenders off her list as potential sources for mortgage money. Among them are Goldome Bank, which sold its New York branches to Manufacturers-Hanover, Dollar Dry Dock, which was sold to Emigrant Savings Bank in February and Crossland Savings, declared insolvent and now being supervised by the Resolution Trust Corporation.
"The loss of these lenders is putting a greater burden on the banks that are making loans," said Mrs. Scott.
MANY lenders, still smarting over the losses they suffered as a result of foreclosures and sponsor defaults, are, borrowers and mortgage brokers say, much less forgiving of blemishes on the credit records of applicants, like late charge card payments. As a result, there is more of a chance that a loan will fall through after a tentative commitment has been made.
"Lenders seem to be looking for reasons to screen out people," said Barbara Corcoran, who heads the Corcoran Group, a Manhattan real estate agency. "In the past, once a borrower had a tentative commitment from a bank it was unusual for the loan not to come through. But now things are less sure. We don't even count on loans that are squeaky clean being a sure thing anymore."
Diane Murray, who has been waiting since January for approval on refinancing on a co-op loan, said that a sticking point with her lender is that she changed jobs late last year.
"I had been with my previous job for 13 years," she said. "My credit is good, I am not looking to increase the size of my loan but I still don't have a 'yes' from the bank."
When a loan application is received by a lender it passes through several steps on its way to a commitment. After the loan officer checks to see that all required documents have been received, it moves to the department that verifies the information. If mortgage insurance is required, the application must pass the scrutiny of the insurer's underwriters.
Essentially, these people check employment and income, job stability, the source of a borrower's down-payment money, the borrower's assets and credit history including payments to department stores, finance companies and credit-card companies.
The people who do this kind of work are among the thousands of employees that lenders dismissed in the late 80's when home sales slowed. As a result banks and mortgage companies are scrambling to keep up with a reduced workforce.
Borrowers and real estate brokers say a point in the process that can be particularly problematic is the appraisal. It is not just the shortage of professional appraisers that is contributing to the delay, they say. Sometimes the appraiser's valuation will be lower that the sales contract price.
This sort of snag not only puts the loan commitment into question, but may force the borrower to come up with more cash, seek a lower price from the seller or negotiate a reappraisal.
"We seem to be having more trouble with appraisals now than I can ever remember," said Ms. Corcoran. "It is not just a difference of a few thousand dollars. We are seeing differences of 25 percent or more. It is our biggest concern right now because the appraisal report is a prime consideration in whether or not a lender will commit to a mortgage and how large a loan they will offer if they do."
Ms. Corcoran, said she tries to prepare for potential delays by negotiating longer sales contracts.
"The typical contract used to be for 30 or 45 days," she explained. "That is not enough time now. It is important for the sellers to understand that because, when the bank holds up the process, everybody blames the buyers when it is not their fault."
Borrowers seeking loans underwritten by the State of New York Mortgage Agency, also know as Sonny Mae, have an advantage in the current market in that lenders participating in the agency's low-interest loan program are required to commit to mortages within 60 days of preliminary approval.
THESE borrowers, who usually must be first time home buyers and meet income and purchase price requirements, have more steps in the process than the conventional borrowers. In addition to bank's application, these borrowers must complete paperwork required by the Internal Revenue Service and satisfy the requirements of the mortgage insurer.
"When banks give the Sonny Mae borrowers a tentative commitment," said John N. Spano, who heads the agency's single-family housing unit, "we make a reservation for that loan. If a final approval is not given within 60 days, the reservation is lost."
Both Sonny Mae and the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency saw their loan applications drop earlier this year when the interest rates being offered by conventional lenders drifted down to the level where mortgage agency loans had been.
To remain competitive, both agencies dropped their interest rates last month. Sonny Mae's new rate -- the lowest level in eight years -- is 7.25 percent for the first five years and 8.20 percent for the remaining 25 years.
The New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency dropped its rate from 8.8 percent to 7.85 percent. The lower rate is linked to a new $30 million mortgage revenue bond. The loans are 30-year, fixed- rate mortgages with a minimum 5 percent down payment required.'

CORRECTION-DATE: May 10, 1992, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on April 26 about delays in getting home mortgages referred erroneously to the time taken by the U.S. Trust Company to act on a recent loan application. The article noted that U.S. Trust had not responded to telephone calls requesting its response to an assertion that it had taken two months. After the article was published, U.S. Trust said that within 24 hours of the loan request it had advised the applicant's mortgage broker that it would not make the loan. The mortgage broker confirms that account.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
A Nasty Mood at Jefferson-Pilot

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
It shakes one's faith in Southern civility to observe the ugliness of the battle being waged between Louise Price Parsons and the gentlemen who run the Jefferson-Pilot Corporation, a $1.1 billion life insurer based in Greensboro, N.C.
Mrs. Parsons, a real estate developer in Pawley's Island, S.C., is a substantial shareholder and the granddaughter of one of the company's early chief executives. She is leading a proxy contest to put up to seven new members on the company's 20-member board. In the course of that battle, which will culminate at the annual meeting on May 4, she has accused the company of negligently misleading shareholders about important executive compensation arrangements. 
 In response, Mrs. Parsons and her husband have been subjected to intense personal attacks by company loyalists. She was rudely rebuffed at last summer's annual meeting by the company's long-time chief executive, W. Roger Soles, who later told Forbes magazine she was an ingrate who "ought to be on her hands and knees thanking the good Lord that the stock has appreciated the way it has."
But last week, the giant California Public Employees Retirement System, known as Calpers, decided to support her challenge, and Jefferson-Pilot's largest institutional investor is reported to have privately pledged its support. Suddenly, what had been belittled as a quixotic mismatch is turning into one of the most interesting contests of this proxy season.
"We are very pleased that Calpers has agreed to support us," said Mrs. Parsons on Friday. "We feel we have gotten good support from the institutions, but we really won't know until next week." One of her advisers, J. Craighill Redwine of the Resources Planning Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., agreed that the race will be close. With a nod to the upcoming Kentucky Derby in Lexington, Ky., he said, "I tell people that there are going to be two really important races next week, one in Kentucky and one in North Carolina."
The Parsons group had announced April 14 that Jefferson-Pilot's "largest institutional shareholder" had filed a proxy supporting their position, although that proxy can be revoked at any time before the final tally. Mr. Redwine said he is not permitted to divulge the investor's identity. According to public records, the company's largest investor as of Dec. 31, 1991, was Invesco MIM in Atlanta; a spokesman there said the firm "has an internal policy not to disclose or comment on its investment decisions."
Jefferson-Pilot executives, for their part, seem undiscouraged. "We've got a long way to go, since institutions tend not to vote until the last minute," said John T. Still 3d, senior vice president for corporate development. "But we are very optimistic." He added, "The key to this whole thing is financial performance, and ours has been excellent. We have never had a shareholder complain about our performance before she did."
Indeed, several Wall Street analysts who cover the company can't see what all the ruckus is about. They see a company with a capital cushion that is three times the industry average, respectable earnings growth and steady gains in book value and dividends.
But some members of Mrs. Parsons' advisory team see something else: A sleeping giant hoarding capital rather than using it to nourish growth. "The economic story, as opposed to the governance story, is a company that is not getting as much out of its capital base as it should," said John A. Pound, a professor at Harvard's Kennedy School and a consultant to Mrs. Parsons.
Other advisors note that the company's average annual stock price has chronically hovered around its per-share book value -- suggesting, they said, that the market doesn't place much of a premium on the things that current management is emphasizing.
Mr. Still dismissed that analysis. "We think we can figure out what is important to shareholders," he said. "A responsible management cannot manage a public company based on the current whims of the market."
The debate on the economic issues is just part of the story, however. The other part, what Professor Pound calls "the governance story," is where the real bitterness begins.
Mrs. Parsons charges that the Jefferson-Pilot directors have become lax in their oversight of an autocratic, well-entrenched management team. Exhibit A in her argument is the way the board has handled important executive compensation matters.
In its 1990 and 1991 proxy statements, the company asked shareholders to approve grants of "restricted" stock as an incentive to key executives, including Mr. Soles. In the Wall Street lexicon, restricted shares are not freely transferrable and thus are less valuable than unrestricted shares. The grants were approved by shareholders.
One problem: The shares that were issued were unrestricted, not restricted shares.
When Mrs. Parsons learned of this, at last year's annual meeting, she sued the company, charging that it had issued a materially false and misleading proxy report -- twice.
The company insists the frequent references to "restricted stock" were simply meaningless mistakes by the corporate secretary -- albeit ones that went undetected by senior management and by the board for two years. At the May 4 meeting, the company will ask shareholders to retroactively approve the grants.
Federal District Judge Richard C. Erwin in Greensboro sees the matter a bit differently. In a decision early this month, he ruled that the company had indeed negligently misled investors about substantial stock grants made to Mr. Soles and several other executives. And he spread the blame around. "Each of the directors who reviewed the proxy statement is equally as negligent for failing to notice the use of the word 'restricted' ten times in the document," he said.
He nullified the stock grants -- and forbade the recipients from voting those shares in the upcoming contest. In a close race, those votes might be sorely missed.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 10, 1992, Sunday

An article on April 26 about a proxy contest at the Jefferson-Pilot Corporation of Greensboro, N.C., misidentified the site of the Kentucky Derby. It is Louisville, Ky., not Lexington.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Clinton's Standard Campaign Speech: A Call for Responsibility

 BODY:
Following is the text of the campaign speech, excluding a brief introductory passage, that Gov. Bill Clinton delivered at the University of Pittsburgh branch at Johnstown, Pa., on April 22, as transcribed by The New York Times.

 	 	 		. . .	 	I want to make just a few sort of basic points about this election. And I'd like begin with two little statistics, one of which was published a day or two ago in America's newspapers and one of which will be out tomorrow. Statistic No. 1: According to the Federal Reserve Board, 1 percent of America's people at the top of the totem pole now have more wealth than the bottom 90 percent, the biggest imbalance in wealth in America since the 1920's right before the Great Depression. 
 Statistic No. 2, out tomorrow: For the first time in a decade personal income in our country as a whole fell last year. That says we've got problems. And I want to tell you that behind that, I live in a state that is one of the worst states in America, where we were abandoned with farm income going down, factories closing and moving away. The Federal Government cutting back on money for economic development, education, environmental protection. We've got a lot of counties that went through just what you went through in this county.
And in the last 11 years, I had to try to put together an economic strategy to deal with it. I don't like to bore people with statistics, but let me tell you, what's happened here might be worse than what's happened in some other places in Pennsylvania, but it's not all that different from what's happened in America.
For more than two years now, the average middle-class family has worked harder for less money to pay more for health care, for housing, for education, for taxes. Poverty has exploded, especially among working people.
I just got out of a rather bruising campaign in New York State. You might have read about it. But one of the things that really moved me about that was that I met so many courageous people, people you never see on television, who live in the Bronx and Brooklyn, who live in high-crime neighborhoods and get up every day and literally risk their physical security, going to and from jobs that still pay them less than top-level wages, to support children in difficult circumstances, playing by the rules.
For millions and millions of Americans, the dream with which I grew up has been shattered. The ideal that if you work hard and play by the rules you'll be rewarded, you'll do a little better next year than you did last year, your kids will do better than you. But that idea has been devastated for millions of Americans.
How did this happen? I would argue it happened for two reasons. No. 1: We lost our economic leadership. Other nations began to do some things better than we do, and their economies started growing faster and faster as ours slowed down.
 
Big, Simple Ideas
 No. 2, and this is why I'm running for President: We elected people to high office who had the wrong response to the problem. And that's what this election is all about. Three or four big, simple ideas, even though the problems are complex.
What is President Bush's theory about what's good about the economy? That the Government would mess up a one-car parade, and you can't trust anybody in politics or Government. So the answer to our economic problems is to make taxes lower on corporations and high-income individuals, and get out of the way and let the market do the rest.
That's their idea. The other day, the President vetoed a bill passed by the Congress that a pro-business Democrat, Lloyd Bentsen from Texas, got through, a tax bill that would have made it easier for plants to modernize their equipment, for people to start small businesses, for people to buy houses, for people to invest in housing in low-income areas. All these things would have been done and George Bush vetoed the bill. Why? Because those incentives were going to be paid for by raising taxes on upper-income people. And he didn't want to do that, because his theory is keep the taxes low on the rich and the corporations and everything will be fine.
Well everything is not fine. We have had it their way for 11 years. And we're going downhill as a nation. The middle class is collapsing. Poverty is exploding. Even the wealthiest people know that we're on the wrong track.
What is the alternative? That's what I represent. It isn't just more tax and spend. It isn't just fighting over the pie that we've been fighting over for 11 years in Washington. It is a dramatically different economic policy which the Government says we -- starting with the President -- says we're going to work in partnership with business and labor and education, and we're going to create a high-wage economy in this country.
We're going to have a smart-work, high-wage country, not a hard-work, low-wage country. And we're going to do it by beating the competition. Let me give you some examples.
Taxes. In this country if you run a plant, and you're getting competed against by someone who runs a plant with low wages, if you looked at the tax laws of this country, you would think your Government wants you to shut your plant down and move it overseas.
You know why? Let's suppose you have a little plant in Johnstown and you make light bulbs. And you work with 400 folks. And your competition is from overseas. And the only way you can beat the competition is to stay in Johnstown and spend $2 million on a modern piece of equipment. This is a practical example. Your Government will not give you a tax credit to write that equipment off. But if you shut your plant down and move it overseas, you get a tax deduction for shutting the plant down.
Then you start your plant overseas and you lose money the first couple of years when you start the plant. You get to deduct those losses from your American income tax. Then when you start to make money, if you leave your money in a foreign bank, you never have to pay a penny of tax on it.
I'm old-fashioned about this. I think it's O.K. with me if people decided to invest money in other countries because they need to be there. It's O.K. with me if the Europeans invest money in our country and put people to work because they need to be here.
But I'll tell you something, you look at the German tax code. They don't subsidize shutting plants down in their country and moving them overseas. They subsidize people retraining and putting new equipment in their country. And that could be why 32 percent of the German work force is in manufacturing and only 17 percent of the American work force is. If you vote for me, I'm going to try to turn that around and invest in this country again.
Let me give you another example. Health care. You elected Harris Wofford to the Senate on the health-care issue. Why? Because people are scared to death they can't afford their health-care bills, and some people don't have health insurance, and other people are afraid they've got it but they're going to lose it. And the cost of it is going up at two or three times the rate of inflation every year.
You may just assume that's normal in the world. But it isn't. It isn't. You live in the only advanced country where your Government does not step in to organize the health-care system so we keep cost in line with inflation and everybody gets basic health care.
So your country spends 40 percent more of its income than any nation on earth on health care and gets less for it. Why? Let me give you a couple of examples.
Your nation is the only one where there are 1,500 separate health insurance companies, writing thousands of policies covering different things, insuring groups that may be very small. So much so that only 84 cents of the health-insurance dollar goes into health care in America. You know what it is in Europe? Ninety-five cents. You know what the difference is on our health insurance bill? Sixty billion dollars a year.
Your country is the only country in the world where the employment of clerical workers in hospitals has gone up by four times the rate of the employment of nurses and doctors and other health caregivers. Because we are drowning in a sea of paper work brought on by health-insurance organizations, health-care bureaucracies and the Government itself.
We have steel mills. Look what happened to steel employment. We have steel mills in this country that have over $4 an hour in health-care costs for retired steelworkers. How can you compete with the rest of the world?
Look at what's happened with automobiles. I get mad at the automobile manufacturers, and the auto workers have done a good job of changing the work rules trying to be more productive. But one thing that's not the auto companies' fault is health-care costs. If you drove here in an American car today that you bought in the last three years, you have got $500 in health-care costs more than if you drove here in a European or Japanese car. How can we compete?
Why did this happen? Because your Government has arrogantly refused to do what all of our competitors have done and crack down on the cost of health care and provide a basic health-care package to all. The people that don't have health insurance, do they get health care? You bet they do. But when it's too late, too expensive, they show up at an emergency room, and those of you with health insurance pay the bill.
And I'm telling you, if you don't ask the President to give you national health insurance, it won't matter if 100 percent of the Congress is for it, you're not going to get it. If you vote for me, I'll give you a national health-insurance plan.
Example No. 3: We live in a world in which what you earn depends on what you can learn. We live in a world where the average 18-year-old will change work eight times in a lifetime. Think about it. That means we live in a world where institutions like this one will become more and more important.
And yet, in your country, we have no system to train all the young people who finish high school but don't go on to college. The people who don't go to four-year schools that don't want to be in dead-end jobs. What happened?
Earnings of younger families under 30 have declined 42 percent in the last 15 years. What happened? Younger high school graduates with no higher education, their earnings have gone down massively in the last 15 years.
High school dropouts in the work force -- out there working for a living -- what's happened to them? Their earnings have gone down over 40 percent in the last 15 years. Why? Because we live in a world in which what you earn depends on what you can learn.
What is the answer? The answer is to look at what the competition does. Look at what the Europeans do. Look at what the Japanese do. Look at what the countries who are paying people better do. If you don't go to college and you get out of high school, you ought to be in an apprenticeship program in this country, and everybody ought to have the right to two years of further training after high school, and Government ought to organize a partnership to get it done.
The earnings of college graduates now are 70 percent more than the earnings of high school graduates in the first year of work. That's over two-and-a-half times what the difference was 10 years ago. What does that mean? That means anybody who wants to go to college and is able to academically ought to be able to go.
But the cost of a college education has gone up by more than health care in the last 10 years. And the dropout rate in college is two and a half times the high school dropout rate.
Here's what I think ought to be done. I think we ought to tell every sixth and seventh and eighth grader, if you stay in school and make decent grades and you want to go to college, you'll be able to go. Here's how.
We ought to scrap the student loan program that exists now. It wastes a lot of money and it doesn't work very well. Here's what I would put in its place. I would put in its place a domestic G.I. bill, a national service trust fund. Anybody can borrow the money to go to college. Any American, without regard to income, no questions asked. Here's your obligation. You would sign a contract to pay it back in one of two ways: your choice. Either as a small percentage of your income over time after you get out of school and go to work, paid at tax time so you couldn't beat the bill.
But you pay according to what you earn, not just how much you borrowed but what you earn. So it wouldn't punish people if they wanted to be police officers or teachers, or work in public service work, people would pay according to what they earn.
Or what I would hope would happen: Every American who borrowed the money would have the option to pay it off with a year or two of national service where you could go back home and you could actually work for a reduced pay; the Federal Government would pay you, just like the Peace Corps except here at home.
Go home and be a police officer; go home and be a preschool teacher; go home and work in a drug program; go home and work in a housing program; go home and help the homeless. Help to solve the problems of America.
 
A Call for Change
 We can educate a whole new generation of Americans. That's the first big idea this election time. Is that what a government does or not? If you vote for President Bush, he'll give you four more years of the same, except he'll say a little more, just like he did in 1988, when he put out the kinder, gentler number, education and the environment.
So now he'll be for a little more. But look at the evidence. They've had 11 years. Ten years ago we had the highest wages in the world. Now we're 10th. Income went down last year for the first time in a decade, but two-thirds of the American people have had their incomes going down for more than 10 years. If we vote for four more years of the same, we're going to get what we deserve.
The second big idea you've got to face is this. What kind of people do you want to be? What kind of citizens are we?
There are a lot of things wrong with America that the Government can't fix. We got this idea in the 80's that we all ought to get it while we can and forget about our friends and neighbors and turn a quick buck. Some people did that by joining gangs and selling drugs on street corners in devastated cities.
Other people did it by selling their companies down the drain with leveraged buyouts and funny financial transactions that made a ton of money for the people who were pushing the paper, and threw all the factory workers out on the street with no future.
And as a result of that, this country is very divided today. We're divided by race and region, by income, by age, by gender. We are all cut up. And I'm telling you, we can't fake it. There's only one President. There's only 535 members of Congress. There are 250 million Americans. We have got to say we want to be one nation again.
We also have to say we also know there are some things the Government can't do. No one can give us an opportunity if we will not take the responsibility for seizing it.
The Republicans always talk about welfare. I know a lot about the welfare system. I spent a lot of time studying it. I hate it. I want to change it. But you know what? The people who are trapped in it, they hate it, too. It's like being caught on a reservation and kept in dependency. And it's no good for anybody.
But you know the right way to change it? I'm for making people on welfare go to work, but you've got to understand why they don't. Most people who are trapped on welfare and don't go to work don't do it because they have no education, they have no skills. If they went on to work, they'd get a minimum-wage job, they couldn't afford child care and they'd give up the Medicaid coverage which gives their children medical benefits. Nobody in their right mind hurts their kids.
You wouldn't do that. So what should we do? Give education, training, child care and medical coverage that make people go to work where they can get jobs. In the culture, require people to be responsible but give them the opportunity to do it.
We ought to have more help for families in this country, but we also ought to require more responsibility. I live in a state where we can fine parents if they won't show up when their kids are in trouble in school. A lot of people think that's harsh but it's a little statement that there are some things the Government can't do if people aren't willing to do for themselves.
I favor giving working poor people an earned income tax credit that can actually give them some money back from the Government to get them above the poverty line. I think if somebody's out there working 40 hours a week, raising kids they ought to be rewarded.
And I favor putting with that the toughest conceivable system of child-support enforcement. I'm tired of people bringing kids into the world and leaving them for the Government to raise.
We've got to decide what kind of people we are.
 
Responsibility of Citizens
 The last thing I'm going to tell you is this. You've got to decide whether you believe in citizenship or not. It's always so fashionable to hate politicians today. Especially me, look at all the stuff you've heard about me.
I'll tell you how bad it is. I was at home the other day at a fund-raising lunch in Little Rock where 1,000 people paid $100 to come have lunch with me. Just my friends and neighbors trying to boost my campaign. And this guy who's like a brother to me, he's about 61 years old, has a 9-year-old daughter who's a genius. This kid is brilliant. And she made up a joke. Here's the joke of a 9-year-old:
A child asks her father: "Dad do all fairy tales begin 'Once upon a time . . .'?" The father says: "No. Some fairy tales begin 'Now, when I'm elected . . .' "
I realize that people don't believe in the political system anymore. And that they believe the worst in politicians when they hear it.
But when I was a kid, my mother was widowed just before I was born. She went off to nursing school and left me to be raised by my grandparents until I was 4. My grandparents ran a tiny grocery store in an integrated neighborhood in a little Southern town. My grandmother was a private duty nurse, but they told me that in the Depression, Franklin Roosevelt was President and gave people hope again by giving them jobs again and giving them work to do.
And they told me if I worked hard and studied hard and played by the rules I could do anything. And I remember how they taught me to count and taught me to read when I was 2 and 3 and 4 years old. They had very little formal education.
Then I came up through the public schools because of the Government. I went to college and got a loan from the Government. I went to law school and got a loan from the Government. Even though I had six jobs while I was in law school, I had to have a loan, and I paid back every penny of it. Because that gave me a chance to make a decent living and have a future.
And when I was the age of the youngest people here, because we had a sound economic policy, I lived in an economy with 3 percent unemployment, 3 percent inflation and 3 or 4 percent real economic growth every year. Because we were competing and winning.
The best thing that the incumbent President has going for him today is that people no longer believe Government can produce anything. They're prepared to believe the worst about politicians. And folks have really given up on the American dream.
This country was set up over 200 years ago by people who believed they had a moral obligation to vote, and who knew if they were well acquainted with the issues, well acquainted with the politicians and the people would do what they were supposed to do at election time, that this country would last forever as a democracy.
And we have made it. Because the people have fought cynicism, and have fought their own doubts. And in all the tough times have made the right decisions.
I want you to go out there Tuesday and vote, and I hope that you will vote for me. I want you to go in November and vote, and if I'm there, and I think I will be, then I hope you will vote for me.
But to say that all the politicians are a bunch of bums and the country can't work anymore and everything's gone downhill, is a cop-out. Because this system begins with you, and this election is about you. It isn't about me. It's about you and your problems and your promise and your future, and all these little kids who are here tonight.
You need a different kind of President. You need people committed to pulling together. And you need to believe again that we can make a difference. The beginning of everything is believing that we can do better. Thank you very much.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Bill Clinton speaking in Philadelphia. His campaign speech has evolved to a focused talk about his vision for America. (Associated Press)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography; Text

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); 

STATE: PENNSYLVANIA, USA (94%); NEW YORK, USA (79%); 

CITY: PITTSBURGH, PA, USA (90%); JOHNSTOWN, PA, USA (90%); PHILADELPHIA, PA, USA (78%); 

COMPANY: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH (84%); UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH (84%);

HEADLINE: School Districts Pool Funds for Investment

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
A CASH management program whose first five clients were Westchester school districts has expanded to 140 school districts and municipalities in several states -- all seeking to earn competitive returns on public investments by pooling their resources.
Sharing services for special education, insurance coverage and garbage removal is a common practice among school districts. Extending this concept to investments was the brainchild of Francie Heller, a former speech teacher and school administrator who lives in New Rochelle. She is now executive vice president of M.B.I.A. Municipal Investors Service. 
 "I sought economy of scale," she said. "All schools have the same problem of how and where to invest. Why couldn't they band together and share investment services, since professional money management is a luxury that individual school districts can't afford?"
By law, public funds in New York State can be invested in only three vehicles: New York State bank certificates of deposit, United States Treasury bonds and New York State municipal tax-free bonds.
"Safety of public funds has always been first and foremost," Ms. Heller said. "But I thought we could realize a greater return."
 
Searching for the Best Rates
 Ms. Heller, a speech pathologist, said that when she became school administrator for the eight schools in the Ossining School District: "I was put in charge of a $20 million budget that came from state aid and tax money paid by property owners. We had eight paydays a year, and it was the job of our assistant superintendent for business to invest the money as it came in.
"We always had to spend an inordinate amount of time rate-shopping, evaluating the credit quality of short-term investments, searching for the best way to invest our funds. Although he did better investing our funds than a lot of other schools, the procedure was time consuming and it locked our money up for a set length of time."
Thinking that there must be a better way, Ms. Heller sat down, identified the need for a school government money-management service and wrote a proposal.
"I took it around to five Wall Street houses," she said. "Three were not interested in any idea presented to them by an outsider. One thought it might have merit and offered me a job as a trainee. But the last house I went to, Bear Stearns, thought it was a great idea. They offered to let me develop it."
On the strength of that, Ms. Heller resigned from the school district in June 1989 and started commuting to Wall Street.
 
'I Knew I Was in the Right Place'
 At first, Ms. Heller recalled, she felt she had entered a different culture. "Even the language and the vocabulary was foreign to me," she said. "I'd surreptitiously write down words and phrases that I didn't understand and look them up at night. But in my bones, I knew that I was in the right place. I have always been interested in the market."
As a single parent, Ms. Heller said, her own research in the investment market helped put her four children through college.
After two years of legal review, research and meetings with municipal and school officials responsible for making investment decisions, Ms. Heller, by then president of the Bear Stearns Public Funds Investment Group, created her new program. She called it Class, a cash management program for municipal and school business officials.
"We were up and running and got our first clients very quickly," Ms. Heller said. "They were five Westchester school districts -- Croton-Hudson, Ossining, Hendrick Hudson in Montrose, Northern Westcheter/ Putnam Boces and Peekskill -- and they knew the value of banding together because they had worked together on an insurance co-op."
 
Insuring Municipal Securities
 In January last year, the Class program was acquired by Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation of Armonk, and Ms. Heller joined M.B.I.A. Municipal Investors Service, a wholly owned subsidiary, as executive vice president.
The parent company, M.B.I.A., was founded in White Plains in 1974 and was a pioneer in developing municipal bond insurance. It is now the country's leading insurer of municipal securities.
"But up until 1990, we only had one product," said Leon J. Karvelis Jr., president of Municipal Investors Service, the subsidiary that now offers and administers the Class program. "When we decided to diversify, we called in a consultant to help us find a compatible product in the field of municipal financial services. When he found Ms. Heller and the Class program at Bear Stearns, we knew it was a perfect fit."
Since M.B.I.A. acquired the program, it has expanded to include 140 clients: villages, towns, school districts, cities and fire districts with a combined $550 million to invest.
The fee for the program is 40 basis points (slightly less than one-half of 1 percent) deducted from the interest. When an interest rate is quoted to a municipality or school district, it is a net rate, Ms. Heller said.
"We have already expanded out of New York State into Connecticut and Rhode Island," Mr. Karvelis said. "We are taking it nationwide. In each state, funds are only invested in high-quality instruments that are legally permitted in that state."
"With cash in hand, schools can often take advantage of discounts for such things as snow removal, fuel delivery, scholarships and grants," Ms. Heller said. She is now responsible for expanding the program nationwide and for administrative and marketing activities.
As an example of how the program can help a client, Ms. Heller cited the Rye City School District and its construction of a stadium at Rye High School. William Barrett, assistant superintendent of the district, praised what he called the convenience and liquidity of the program, which allowed him at the start of construction to increase his account balance.
"In that way we were able to pay our bills when they came due instead of having to wait for CD's to mature," he said. "That made us the preferred project under contract, and we were able to finish the stadium two months earlier than planned."
Leonard Verastro, Clerk-Treasurer of the Village of Mamaroneck, also is happy with the Class program. "I am very pleased with the increased yield, which coupled with the liquidity factor makes this program unique," he said. "Additionally, we are given a degree of control through the quarterly meetings we have with all the other participants and M.B.I.A. advisers."
Eleanor McDonald, Comptroller for the town of Harrison, said, "The Class program allows full use of our funds with enhanced safety for the town." And the assistant comptroller of Harrison, Lawrence Schopfer, added, "It gives us competitive rates of return in an uncompetitive interest-rate environment, without tying up our funds."
