HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
When Democracy Is Sold to the Highest Bidder

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Who Will Tell the People
The Betrayal of American Democracy
By William Greider
464 pages. Simon & Schuster. $25.
In "Who Will Tell the People: The Betrayal of American Democracy," it is William Greider's not altogether startling or original contention that the wishes of the American people are no longer being expressed by what goes on in Washington. Instead, special interests are getting their ways, particularly monstrous corporations that seek to reach their global tentacles wherever labor is cheap and environmental laws are lax.
Mr. Greider contends that these groups work their will through money and manipulation. He writes: "A major industry has grown up in Washington around what might be called 'democracy for hire' -- business firms and outposts of sponsored scholars devoted to concocting facts and opinions and expert analysis, then aiming them at the government. That is the principal function of all those enterprises along Washington's main boulevards like K Street -- the public-relations agencies, the direct-mail companies and opinion-polling firms. All these work in concert with the infrastructure of think tanks, tax-exempt foundations and other centers that churn out reams of policy ideas for the political debate. Most are financed by corporate interests and wealthy benefactors." 
 He argues that this undemocratic network of influence produced such recent disasters for Americans as the savings and loan scandal, a shifting of the tax burden from the wealthy to the less well-off and a systematic corruption of environmental standards by industries spreading toxic wastes. All this has been done behind the scenes, he says. Nobody ever told the people.
What does Mr. Greider propose to do about this "betrayal of American democracy," as he calls it, besides write a 400-page book in which he jumps up and down and points his finger and yells? All is not lost, he concludes somewhat surprisingly. In his decades as a reporter and through his experience writing such books as "Secrets of the Temple: How the Federal Reserve Runs the Country" and "The Trouble With Money," he has traveled around the land and come to believe in the fallibility of the governing elite and the viability of the people. He intones: "There is a 'reassuring anarchy,' as I once called it, in the most exalted realms of power and this encourages my conviction that rigid arrangements of power are much more vulnerable to intrusion and change than the experts and authorities wish people to believe."
This is not terribly reassuring. It is also faintly pompous. Worst of all, by the time you get to it your mind has been pretty well numbed by the disorganization and repetitiveness of Mr. Greider's case.
Which is too bad, in a way, because when he rolls up his sleeves and gets down to specific cases, he can light a fire or two that helps one to see through the gloom. For example, in describing the "class shift" that he believes has changed the American press into part of the ruling elite, he writes an arresting memoir of his newspaper experiences in which he compares the "reporters" of the old Cincinnati Post with the "journalists" of the new Washington Post. In illustrating the "awesome reach and capabilities of one corporate political organization," he makes a damning case against what he sees as the arrogance of the General Electric Company.
Elsewhere, he argues provocatively that to bash Japan for paying agents of influence to promote its business interests is to single it out unfairly from all the American corporations that do precisely the same thing. And in asking why the generation raised on television has lost interest in mainstream politics, he makes the intriguing point that the future of American democracy may lie in understanding the implications of the program "America's Funniest Home Videos."
But all the nuggets in "Who Will Tell the People" are washed away by the mud slide of Mr. Greider's prose, which when not focused on particulars arouses the misgiving that its yield will not be equal to the effort it takes to read it. And all the faith he professes in the system gets swept away by those nuggets.
The reader even begins to feel a little cynical. Although Mr. Greider blames the Democrats as much as the Republicans for betraying the American people, and although he echoes his acknowledged mentor Theodore J. Lowi ("The End of Liberalism") in tracing the origins of interest-group lobbying to the rise of the New Deal, you nonetheless find yourself thinking that Mr. Greider is merely complaining as a member of the out-group. All that may be bothering him is 12 years of Republicans in the White House.
Of course this accusation isn't fair. He's arguing that the system is flawed, not the electorate, which, he says, increasingly feels alienated by its distance from the levers of power. "The most troubling proposition in this book is that the self-correcting mechanisms of politics are no longer working," he writes. "Most of them are still in place and functioning but, for the most part, do not produce the expected results." Moreover, it's not politics as usual that worries him, but rather the threat of global economics in the wake of the cold war's conclusion.
Yet the imbalance of his critique and his idealism is finally crushing. In one of his book's most revealing passages, he describes how a Washington lobbyist argued that environmentalists and other reformers waste energy attacking the White House oversight machinery. Instead, this observer suggested, they should concentrate on electing the kind of Presidents who will be sensitive to upholding the environmental laws rather than serving corporate interests.
"But, I asked, doesn't that sound as if the law is up for grabs?" Mr. Greider writes. " 'Of course the law's up for grabs!' he responded. 'The law's always up for grabs. That's why you win elections and appoint judges. That's why Reagan appointed 500 Federal judges. The law is not an inflexible instrument like a cannon that can be lined up and fired. It's a flexible human instrument that responds to political power.' "
The biggest problem with "Who Will Tell the People" is that we are expected to be appalled by this statement. The second biggest problem is that we are not.

HEADLINE: LENDING AGENCIES ADMIT EX-SOVIETS AS FULL MEMBERS

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank formally offered membership today to Russia, Ukraine and most of the other former Soviet republics. It was a major step to tie the republics into the rest of the world's economy.
Western and Russian officials said offering membership would also help make billions of dollars of Monetary Fund and World Bank aid available to the republics as they emerge from seven decades of Communism and make the painful transition to market economies. 
 "This is indeed an historic day," said Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Norman Lamont. "Some 46 years after its foundation, the I.M.F. has at last become a truly global institution, and the countries of the former Soviet Union are taking their place in the world economy."
 
Negotiations to Begin
 Now that membership has been offered, Russia and the other republics will begin negotiating in earnest with the Monetary Fund and World Bank on accords in which they agree to sweeping changes to build stable market economies. The I.M.F. has called on the republics to slash their budget deficits, remove price controls and reduce subsidies to industry.
Such agreements will reduce the economic sovereignty of Russia and the other republics by requiring them to meet strict conditions in exchange for receiving more than $20 billion in loans over the next three years.
American officials say that when Moscow signs an I.M.F. agreement, that will begin triggering much of the $24 billion aid package for Russia that President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany unveiled April 1 on behalf of the Group of Seven major industrial democracies.
 
Components of Package
 That package includes $4.5 billion in aid in 1992 from the I.M.F. and World Bank, a $6 billion ruble stabilization fund, $2.5 billion in debt deferral and $11 billion in government-to-government aid, including $2 billion from the United States. Group of Seven officials say that not only Monetary Fund and World Bank loans, but also the ruble fund and much of the debt deferral and bilateral aid, are contingent upon signing of an I.M.F. accord.
Michel Camdessus, the fund's managing director, said he hoped that Russia would sign an agreement in June or July and that other republics, which trail Russia in reforms, will complete agreements later this year.
Yegor T. Gaidar, the Russian Deputy Prime Minister who is representing his Government in the Monetary Fund meetings, said that signing an agreement would greatly help Russia in its transformation to capitalism, which he said would take most of the decade. "It is a slow process, a process that is politically difficult, socially depressing," he said.
He said the agreement would provide a basis for stabilizing the economy and would give Russia a seal of approval that would spur foreign investment.
Monetary Fund officials said that when balloting ended at noon today, a majority of its 156 members had voted for Russia and all of the other republics except Azerbaijan to join. Approval of Azerbaijan's application was delayed by paperwork, but fund officials said they expected to offer membership in early May.
"They can take justifiable pride in passing this historic milestone on the road from central planning to market-based economic systems," said Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady at a meeting of the fund's top policymaking committee. "For our part, we can use this occasion to re-dedicate ourselves to helping the new states complete the journey."
The Monetary Fund and the World Bank announced their membership offers at the two institutions' annual spring meeting.
The Soviet Union took part in the international conference held in 1944 in Bretton Woods, N. H., which set up the I.M.F. and World Bank to promote development and to supervise the world's monetary system. But Moscow ultimately refused to join the two institutions after disputes with Washington about the operation of the fund and the bank.
The membership offer to the former Soviet republics and the decision on Sunday by the Group of Seven to approve the $24 billion aid package for Russia are widely viewed as major steps propelling its transition to a market economy.
 
Specific Actions Urged
 The Group of Seven -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, Britain and Canada -- welcomed the tough economic reforms that President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia has pushed through since January. But they urged Russia to sign an agreement with the Monetary Fund that would mandate further action in these specific areas:
*Reducing the budget deficit.
*Curbing growth in the money supply to bring inflation under control, and halting the extension of credit to uncompetitive enterprises.
*Establishing a legal framework and contractual rights to allow the development of a market economy, including private ownership.
*Reforming the farming and energy sectors to spur production and increase foreign exchange earnings.
*Developing a fiscal system that insures that the central Government obtains enough hard currency to meet its international obligations.
*Establishing a single rate for the ruble, rather than continuing several different ruble rates.
"The task is historic," Michel Sapin, France's Finance Minister, said at a news conference in Washington today. "The task is difficult. The task is long."
In a morning speech to potential investors at the United States Chamber of Commerce, Mr. Gaidar disclosed that his Government planned to establish a single ruble rate by July 1. Economists say this is a crucial step toward making the ruble freely convertible and for activating a planned international fund to stabilize the ruble.
 
Trying to Stabilize Ruble
 At a related gathering in Washington, the finance ministers of 11 industrial nations formally approved setting up a $6 billion ruble stabilization fund that will come into being once Russia and other republics have taken steps to steady their teetering economies.
The 11 include the Group of Seven countries plus Belgium, the Netherlands, Sweden and Switzerland.
The money would come from an emergency fund known as the General Arrangements to Borrow, which industrial nations could draw on if they needed to prop up their own currencies.
Finance ministry officials attending today's meetings said many obstacles remained before a ruble stabilization fund could be set up. The steps they outlined paralleled the actions the I.M.F. is calling for. One is putting the unitary ruble rate in place.
Russia will also have to decide what rate it wants the ruble to trade at, and whether it wants a fixed or somewhat flexible rate. Russia, they said, would also have to clamp down on inflation to create a minimum of confidence that the stabilization fund would seek to build on.
 
Need to Curb Money Supply
 A senior German official said that perhaps the most difficult obstacle was to get not just Russia, but all the republics using the ruble, to rein in their money supplies at the same time.
"I can't imagine that this can be solved in one, two, three, four weeks," the German official said. "Maybe in one, two, three, four months. It's not a decision for tomorrow."
Several Group of Seven officials said the Netherlands sought to block the way the fund would be financed unless plans to increase the I.M.F.'s overall financing by $60 billion was first approved. In this way, the Netherlands sought to put pressure on the United States, whose failure to approve its $12 billion contribution has prevented the overall increase from taking effect. But the Dutch Government backed down when it saw that the group was intent on approving the ruble fund.
Monetary Fund and World Bank officials said they expected Russia and the other republics to join their institutions over the next few weeks once their Parliaments approve whatever laws are necessary for membership.
Russia is being given a 3 percent share in the capital of the Monetary Fund, which works in many ways like a cooperative bank. Within six months after accepting membership, Russia will have to pay $3.94 billion into the fund as a membership contribution, with 22.7 percent -- $895 million -- in hard currency and the rest in its own currency.
Under Monetary Fund rules, countries following the Fund's reform agreements can usually borrow three times the amount of their membership contribution over three years.
Altogether, the other 14 republics -- including Azerbaijan once it joins -- will have 1.75 percent of the fund's capital, and will have to put up about $2.8 billion, with almost $640 million in hard currency.
To join the World Bank, Russia would have to pay $333 million as a down payment on its shares in the bank, while the 14 other republics would have to pay about $250 million. The World Bank often allows countries to borrow many times what they pay in.
The World Bank said today that it was offering membership to all the republics except Azerbaijan and Turkmenistan. The applications of those two republics were delayed by paperwork, but are expected to be approved next month.
Addressing the Monetary Fund's policymaking committee, Treasury Secretary Brady urged the industrial nations to do more to spur global growth, asserting that economic sluggishness would hurt the republics' transition to a market economy. "The time for concerted action to promote recovery and boost its strength is now," he said.

HEADLINE: DINKINS PROPOSES A MODEST GROWTH IN HIS BUDGET PLAN

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday proposed a modest growth in the New York City budget that would be achieved through a gentle upturn in the economy, some new taxes and substantial cuts in some city services.
The plan drew a positive response from fiscal monitors. It was based on a projection of the city's economic future that is a bit more optimistic than in either of the Mayor's previous budgets. [Page B4.] 
 The spending plan also assumes $115 million in new taxes that the Mayor and the City Council support but that the Council Speaker acknowledged yesterday were not likely to pass the State Legislature.
 
Cuts and Increases
 The budget would substantially cut some services, like park maintenance and pothole repair, while providing millions of dollars in additional spending to provide longer library hours, health clinics for the poor and other welfare programs.
Overall spending would rise from last year's $28.7 billion proposal to the $29.5 billion recommended by Mr. Dinkins for the fiscal year beginning on July 1.
Acknowledging the tenuousness of his plan for new taxes and in an effort to apply pressure to win approval for them, Mr. Dinkins said that if the Legislature blocked the new taxes, he would make deeper cuts in the budget, including laying off workers and eliminating some of the programs he has spent the last few days announcing. Those programs include the longer library hours and the opening of additional city school buildings for after-school programs.
 
'Almost Impossible'
 The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, yesterday praised the Mayor's overall spending proposal, citing its lack of property tax increases, and encouraged the Mayor to press forward with the tax package, saying that even though he believed it was all but dead, it should be considered because it was fair. "The Mayor is entitled to ask for it and we are not stopping him, but we think that it's almost impossible," Mr. Vallone said.
Mr. Dinkins's budget plan is virtually the same as the four-year financial plan that he introduced in January, except for two major changes. First, the Mayor's latest spending proposal identifies a $455 million budget surplus that budget officials said would be used to eliminate the city's plans to borrow $250 million with the help of the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation and to offset $200 million in Federal aid that the city will not receive.
Second, the Mayor plans to cut only about 16,500 jobs through attrition over the next four years from the city's work force of a quarter-million, down from the 20,000 he proposed in January, in part to meet new needs for health care and for special education for teachers.
 
Working Without Contract
 When the size of the surplus was disclosed last week, state lawmakers and leaders of the municipal labor unions, which are working without a contract, accused the Dinkins administration of hiding the surplus to distort the budget outlook to get new taxes and wage concessions.
Despite demands from labor unions for a share of the surplus in the form of raises, Mr. Dinkins repeated his vow yesterday not to increase wages for the next two years except in exchange for gains in productivity. "For all the talk of a 'surplus,' there is no secret largess up our sleeves," Mr. Dinkins said yesterday. "For all the talk of recovery, there is still a whole lot of recession we must scrimp and save and struggle our way through."
The Mayor noted, however, that he believed that labor would benefit from any improvement in the city's fiscal condition. City budget officials estimate that a 1 percent wage increase costs the city about $150 million.
Over all, the new budget, which requires the approval of the City Council, would cut city services by $222 million, resulting in fewer jail beds, bumpier roads, dirtier parks, larger public school classes and deferred sewer repairs. "Make no mistake: this was not a good-news budget in January, and it's not a good news-budget today," Mr. Dinkins said. "
 
A Stark Contrast
 But the new budget is in stark contrast to last year's plan, in which the Mayor laid out the specter of $1 billion in tax increases, along with cuts ranging from the shutdown of all municipal swimming pools to the elimination of infant-mortality-prevention programs.
The Mayor's latest budget plan also cuts spending by $235 million through "streamlining" initiatives, like reducing administrative and office staffs at city agencies, and by $129 million through "restructuring initiatives," including "privatizing" some city-owned housing and consolidating scofflaw towing.
Outside fiscal monitors and analysts yesterday applauded Mr. Dinkins's use of the budget surplus to avoid borrowing $250 million to help balance the budget. Bond raters had stongly resisted such financing, warning that it would jeopardize the city's credit rating and shut it out of a crucial market.
 
'Deserves High Marks'
 "The Mayor deserves high marks for proposing a balanced budget for the third year in a row," said Raymond Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group. "But his decision to use the surplus to avoid deficit financing is particularly good and he ought to be praised for that."
Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was set up during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's to sell bonds on the city's behalf, said yesterday that he was studying the Mayor's proposal and declined to comment on it. Mr. Rohatyn said last week that he was pleased that Mr. Dinkins was using the deficit to avoid the borrowing, but he criticized the Mayor for not revealing the surplus earlier.
Penelope Pi-Sinyer, executive director of the City Project-Alterbudget, an advocacy group for health and human services, lauded plans in Mr. Dinkins's budget to open 20 health centers, which would provide poor people with family doctors, and 10 new "beacon" schools, which would provide community assistance, including job training, health education and counseling.
 
A Contingency Plan
 But the Mayor said yesterday that those programs might be cut, and layoffs imposed, under a contingency plan if the city did not get the $115 million tax package it was seeking from Albany.
Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's press secretary, maintained that the tax proposal was still alive and that the administration was building support for it in Albany. "We have done some impossible things in the past with the help of others, and we never count our smashed eggs until they are smashed," Mr. Jones said.
But John A. McCardle, a spokesman for Ralph J. Marino, the Republican majority leader of the State Senate, said the Senate was very skeptical of providing additional aid to New York City until the Mayor explained how the city needed new taxes at a time when it has posted a surplus.
Some fiscal monitors criticized the Mayor's budget plan for not doing more to achieve a "grand scheme" to shrink the size of government. "Most people believe that the city has too many employees and that a lot of the employees are underpaid," said Mr. Horton of the citizens budget panel. "Does his budget address these issues in any significant way? The answer is a disappointing no."
Elinor B. Bachrach, deputy state comptroller for New York City, agreed, saying it appears that Mr. Dinkins had abandoned a long-term view of solving the city's problems. Ms. Bachrach also expressed disappointment that the city's budget plans for the 1994 fiscal year included a substantial amount of the transitional borrowing that bond raters have warned against.

End of an Era at Macy's
Edward S. Finkelstein resigned abruptly as Macy's chairman, closing a sad chapter in the saga of the 134-year-old retail company. He was the last of the merchants who presided over the golden age of department stores. [Page A1.]
In earlier times, Edward Finkelstein had used imagination and flair to rejuvenate stores, but there were doubts that he was the best man to guide Macy's out of bankruptcy. [D9.] 
 The board chose two men to run Macy's -- a financier, Myron E. Ullman 3d, and a merchant, Mark S. Handler -- an unusual step intended to address competing pressures facing the company. [D9.]

National City stockholders agreed to buy Merchants National, a $5.4 billion Indianapolis bank holding company. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Xerox's Profit Increases 10.3%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., April 27

 BODY:
The Xerox Corporation today reported a 10.3 percent increase in first-quarter earnings and said economic slumps in Japan and Europe contributed to flat revenue.
In the quarter that ended March 31, Xerox earned $128 million, or $1.12 a share, up from $116 million, or $1.01 a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Revenues were $4.24 billion, compared with $4.2 billion. 
 Paul A. Allaire, the chairman and chief executive of Xerox, said the overall performance was affected by economic sluggishness in Japan and Europe.
The work force was cut by about 1,000 employees in the quarter as part of a plan to eliminate 2,500 jobs.
Xerox has said it expects eventually to save $200 million annually through the reduction, which should be completed by midyear.
Xerox shares closed at $73.25 today on the New York Stock Exchange, down $4.625.

HEADLINE: Home Resales Up 12.5%; Gains Are Expected to Continue

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes jumped 12.5 percent in March from a year earlier, and gains are expected to continue through the rest of the year, the nation's largest real estate association said today.
The group, the National Association of Realtors, said some 298,000 existing single-family homes were sold last month, compared with 265,000 in March 1991. It was the third month in a row that sales increased over the previous year. 
 Rising sales reflect a strong demand that is expected to be sustained as the economy continues to recover, the group said.
"The economy is finally moving clearly toward recovery, and we're feeling it not just in housing but other areas as well," the group's president, Dorcas Helfant, said in a statement. "Consumer confidence appears to be on the rebound, new construction is blossoming -- in economic terms we're finally seeing signs of spring."
So far this year sales have risen 13 percent, to 712,000 units, from 629,000 in the first quarter of 1991.
Home prices have also risen, the association said, reporting that the national median price for an existing home in March was $104,000, up 5.4 percent from a year earlier. The median price is the point where half the homes cost more and half cost less.
The association said low interest rates and relatively stable prices were making home ownership "affordable to consumers in a broad income range."
Average interest rates on a conventional 30-year mortgage rose to 8.91 percent in March, from 8.76 in February, but have since declined, the group said.
Regionally, sales increased in all four of the group's tracking areas.
The largest increase was in the Northeast, which has been particularly badly hit in the recession. Sales rose 18 percent, to 40,000 units, from 34,000 a year ago. The median price rose 2.5 percent, to $145,000 from $142,000.
In the West, sales rose 16 percent, to 66,000 from 57,000. But prices fell 2 percent, from $146,100 to $143,200.
Midwest sales totaled 85,000 units, up 10.3 percent from 77,000. The median price rose 3.6 percent, to $81,000, from $78,200 a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Plan to Aid Defense Concerns In Search for New Customers

BYLINE: By THOMAS LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREENLAWN, L.I., April 27

 BODY:
Saying New York State had lost more than 65,000 jobs since 1987 because of cutbacks in Pentagon spending, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo visited an electronics company here today to announce a state program to help military contractors find customers in the private sector.
The program, begun with limited financing from the state and the Department of Defense, is the nation's first "defense diversification" project to to receive Federal financial support, the Governor said. 
 Nine high-technology concerns on Long Island, which is home to the largest share of New York State's military industry, were named as recipients of grants, with $170,000 in state and Pentagon funds to be divided between them.
State officials said the money would be used for studies of the companies' operations, aimed at finding commercial markets for a host of products and technologies, ranging from radio antennas to electronic guidance systems, that have been developed for the Pentagon.
 
'Dying Product Lines'
 The announcement was greeted by skepticism among defense industry analysts, who said the aid was far to little to matter, and might be misdirected even if more was offered.
"I'm not convinced that the politicans have thought through the problem," said Howard A. Rubel, a military industry analyst for C.J. Lawrence Inc., a Wall Street securities firm. He added that government assistance might be better used to retrain military workers for other jobs, instead of trying to find new markets for "dying product lines."
"This is not like the end of World War II when there was a pent-up demand for civilian goods, and makers of battleships could switch to washing machines," he added. "This is a tough new era."
But while neither Governor Cuomo nor several corporate exeuctives at his announcment today held out much hope that small government incentives would lead to large new markets, they said the program will help foster innovation.
"The downsizing of our industry is enormous and necessary," said Martin Bloch, chairman of Frequency Electronics Inc., a Mitchel Field electronics concern that was one of the nine companies named as recipients of state and Federal assistance. But because of the advanced engineering and scientific skills among defense contractors, he said "there have to be alternatives" involving new private sector markets.
While announcing the assistance program, state officials released the results of two years' study on New York State's reliance on Pentagon spending, the fallout of Pentagon cutbacks.
It said that as recently as 1987, 500,000 people in the state were dependent on the Pentagon for their paychecks, either as military personnel at New York's 10 military bases or employees of defense contractors or their subcontracts.
 
Unrelenting Job Losses
 In five years, it said job losses have been unrelenting, particularly among the defense contractors, which shed 28 percent of their workers. Defense contracts in the state, which totaled $9.62 billion in 1987, fell to $6.86 billion in 1991, the report said.
The economic impact has been most severe among Long Island concerns, which have 57 percent of the state's defense contracts, it said, and where military-industry employment fell by 30,000 over the last five years. The report says the state may lose 56,000 more jobs in the next five years.
Governor Cuomo made his announcement at the Hazeltine Corporation, a maker of aircraft instruments, communications gear and other electronic products, which received $2.1 million in state aid in 1990 to help it develop new markets.
Partially as a result of the state aid, the company has developed a radio antenna system, original produced for the Stealth fighter, that can be used on commercial aircraft, allowing their passengers to listen to radio stations while in flight.
Governor Cuomo said Hazeltine's commercial venture provided a "model" for the nine Long Island companies that will receive state and Federal aid, all of them electronics and communications concerns that have been reliant on Pentagon contracts.
Besides Frequency Electronics, based in Uniondale, they are the General Microwave Company of Amityville; IMC Magnetics of Westbury; Dayton T. Brown Inc. of Bohemia; Logitek of Ronkonkoma; Aerodyne Controls of Ronkonkoma; Astrosystems Inc. of Lake Success; Republic Electronics Inc. of Hauppauge, and the EMS Development Company of Farmingdale.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Strange Limbo For Fibreboard

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
JOHN D. C. ROACH is a chairman with an unusual problem. Because of circumstances totally beyond his control, Fibreboard Inc. may wind up filing for bankruptcy within a year. On the other hand, if circumstances break the right way, the company may look attractive as a takeover target.
That situation, which reflects legal questions related to historic production of asbestos at Fibreboard, may explain its unusually aggressive wooing of Wall Street and of institutional investors. In a world where promises for the future are usually made quietly, or at least out of earshot of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Fibreboard is putting forecasts in its annual report. The company "believes that within three years Fibreboard has the potential to achieve annual pretax income of $15 million to $20 million," the report said. 
Mr. Roach, in an interview, said that income would translate into after-tax profits of $2 to $3 a share. Such profits would not be bad for a company that was trading for less than $3 a share earlier this year and was under $5 earlier this month, before the forecast was released. The share price has since climbed to $8.75, largely on the basis of the forecast, along with rising first-quarter earnings and a highly qualified "settlement" with one of its asbestos insurers.
In print, the profit prediction is hedged with qualifications. But Mr. Roach is not so restrained in person. "We used the word 'potential,' so analysts would not think it was a forecast," Mr. Roach said. "But I'm highly confident we can deliver on it."
A few problems must be overcome along the way, however, if that rosy forecast is to become reality. One is that the economy cooperates, providing good news for the company's three operating divisions, which are lumber and wood products, industrial insulation products and a California ski resort.
And then there is the asbestos litigation. Fibreboard, which was spun off from Louisiana Pacific in 1988, may owe its status as an independent company to its former parent's fears concerning that litigation. "It was too hot to handle," Mr. Roach said, when asked if Louisiana Pacific was trying to escape possible liabilities. "That was the intent, and the very wise intent."
Fibreboard's view is that it has two insurance policies that provide virtually unlimited coverage of cases where the exposure to asbestos began before March 1959. Its strategy seems to have been to lock in those coverages, and to find a way to get some of that coverage effectively to finance its costs for post-1959 exposures.
It may have achieved that goal with its settlement, announced on March 30, with the Pacific Indemnity Insurance Company, a subsidiary of the Chubb Companies. That agreement provided an immediate $10 million and additional payments of $20 million pending Pacific's appeal of a California court ruling on its liability.
If all the legal issues go Fibreboard's way in the appeal, Pacific will end up paying a total of $360 million, and the other leading carrier, Continental Casualty, a subsidiary of the CNA Financial Corporation, will be left to pay large amounts without being able to seek repayment from Pacific. Effectively, it appears that some of Pacific's money could go to pay post-1959 claimants. The company did not stop making asbestos until 1972.
On the other hand, Fibreboard could get less under the settlement if some legal issues go Pacific's way, and at the worst might even have to pay back the $10 million it has already received. If that happens, there is little doubt that the company will have to seek protection under the bankruptcy statute.
Mr. Roach was recruited in 1991 from the Manville Corporation, which has its own asbestos problems, to become chairman, president and chief executive of Fibreboard. He promptly engaged in the "big bath" school of accounting, in which new management reports big losses from assorted write-offs. The result was a loss of $43.9 million, on sales of $234.1 million.
But in the first quarter of this year, the company reported net income of $5.5 million, or $1.35 a share, on sales of $70.9 million. Because its ski resort makes the bulk of its profit in the first quarter, there is a seasonal bulge to those profits, but it still impressed investors and helped propel Fibreboard's share price higher.
The company's current asbestos reserves are expected to pay for the costs of all new asbestos health claims in the current decade, assuming Fibreboard prevails in its insurance litigation. But the company has not set up any reserves for the possible costs of meeting claims for asbestos removal from buildings.
Mr. Roach says he worries that if and when it is clear that the asbestos problems are behind the company, a raider may appear and buy it for less than its real value. That is one reason, he said, he has been courting investors.
That the courting has worked is clear from Fibreboard's 192 percent gain in share price so far in 1992. Whether that gain will endure, however, will not be clear until the California appeals court rules, probably in late 1992 or early 1993.

HEADLINE: At Dinkins Fund-Raising Soiree, Turnout and Spirits Are High

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins held a major fund-raising dinner last night that many Democrats were watching carefully as a barometer of his political support and campaign credibility.
The Spring Gala event at the Sheraton Hotel and Towers came on the same day that Mr. Dinkins released the budget voters will likely judge him on in the 1993 election. The soiree was three months after City Council President Andrew J. Stein, the Mayor's main Democratic rival, raised nearly $2 million at a glitzy event at the Waldorf-Astoria, luring several of the Mayor's 1989 supporters to a $5,000-a-plate affair. 
 Many political consultants and Democrats agreed that Mr. Dinkins needed to restore the confidence in his campaign that was eroded when his former finance chairman, Arnold I. Biegen, admitted in January that he had stolen $158,000. Mr. Dinkins also needs to show, they said, that he can still draw the standard list of politically powerful people who traditionally finance politics in New York City.
If last night's $1,000-a-plate dinner were any measure, Mr. Dinkins has come through the Biegen scandal, as well as recent criticism from labor and fiscal watchdogs about how he handled the city budget, relatively unscathed. About 1,028 people attended the event, which was expected to raise at least $1 million.
"We expected it to be a financial success," the Mayor said at the dinner, "as it obviously is."
Leonard Riggio, the Mayor's new campaign finance chairman and the chief executive of Barnes & Noble Bookstores Inc., said the event should dispel any qualms that Dinkins supporters might have had after Mr. Biegen was indicted.
"This one will send a signal out there that we are in business and we can still raise money for David Dinkins," Mr. Riggio said yesterday afternoon.
Among those who attended were leaders of the business and legal communities including Arthur Levitt Jr., Roger Altman, Jonathan M. Tisch, Bruce Ratner, Lewis Rudin and Anthony Gliedman.
While Mr. Stein held a black-tie dinner in January with a performance by Frank Sinatra as a draw, Mr. Dinkins opted for business attire and a inspirational 10-minute video put together by his campaign about his accomplishments in office.
The video, "The Promise, The Performance," recounted the Mayor's Harlem roots and rise to power. It also touted several mayoral programs as successes, several of them initiatives announced in the last two weeks, like a move to reopen libraries five days a week and to establish neighborhood health clinics.
 
Praise From Cuomo
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo gave a short speech praising the Mayor for balancing his budget three years in a row, despite a faltering economy, a feat the Governor called enviable, considering the state's budget problems.
"He has done all that can be done," Mr. Cuomo said, "and much more than others might have done." But when asked whether he would endorse Mr. Dinkins, the Governor said, "When there's a race and candidates, then there will be people to endorse."
The probable Republican candidate, Rudolph W. Giuliani, is planning a fund-raising event on May 18 with Willie Mays and the comedian Joe Piscopo. Mr. Giuliani has about $200,000 in his campaign treasury.
 
Support on All Sides
 Some of those at Mr. Dinkins's dinner also attended Mr. Stein's event, in the age-old tradition of hedging political bets.
One of them, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts, pastor of Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, gave the invocation at Mr. Stein's dinner and was listed a chairman of Mr. Dinkins's event. "In the African American community, there are too many who feel estranged," Mr. Butts said before the dinner yesterday. "Now either that estrangement is perception or reality, but the feeling is still there. And we are concerned about it, so much so that while I support him as Mayor, I reserve my endorsement for re-election."
Another person supporting both campaigns is John A. Catsimatidis, president of Red Apple Company, the grocery store chain, who said he was planning to give both men money and put off his final decision. "You shouldn't mistake buying a table at the man's dinner with support," Mr. Catsimatidis said. "When the election comes up and people announce, that's when you make your decision."
But other prominent business people who attended said the turnout had dispelled notions of Mr. Dinkins as a vulnerable candidate. "I think the Mayor has gone through his worst years," Mr. Rudin said. "I think it is an enthusiastic crowd full of genuine feeling."

Dinkins was every bit the candidate as he greeted supporters last night at the Sheraton Hotel and Towers. Organizers hoped to raise $1 million from the more than 1,000 guests. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Russian-Language Edition Of The Times Begins Today

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The New York Times today introduces its first foreign-language edition, a biweekly paper in Russian called The New York Times News in Review.
Arthur Sulzberger Jr., publisher of The Times, announced arrangements for the publication yesterday at a news conference at The Times. It is a joint venture with The Moscow News, a weekly paper that emerged in the mid-1980's as one of Russia's first independent journalistic voices. 
 News in Review, which will appear every other week and will vary from 16 to 24 pages, will carry articles and editorials that have already appeared in The Times. The paper costs 5 rubles, about 5 cents, and is being distributed in some 30 major cities with an initial circulation of 100,000, including about 3,000 copies that will be sent free to senior Government and business leaders.
In recent years, the Hearst Corporation, the Reader's Digest Association, Rodale Press Inc., International Data Group Inc., Business Week and other communications companies based in this country have also begun Russian-language enterprises in the former Soviet Union.
Yevgeny Abov, deputy editor in chief of The Moscow News, said yesterday by telephone from Moscow that a Russian version of The Times would principally appeal to an elite audience that wanted a better understanding of the United States and the American perspective on world affairs.
Mr. Abov added that such understanding was important because there are now "high hopes" in the former Soviet Union for a variety of political and business partnerships between the commonwealth states and the Unites States.
Ann Hagen Kellett, founding editor of the new paper, said that initial prototypes placed articles about Russia in the first several pages, but the order was changed after the Russians who saw the prototype said they preferred to have articles about the United States first.
She said that an editor based at the Times Company's syndication headquarters in New York would select about 90 percent of the articles that appear in the Russian-language paper, which will include pieces on science, health and the arts, as well as coverage of business and foreign and domestic affairs drawn from The New York Times. The remaining 10 percent of the content will be selected in consultation with editors at The Moscow News, from an array of material from The Times.
The Moscow News will mainly be responsible for translation and distribution; it has a similar arrangement with Paris Match, the French magazine.
 
Described as Experiment
 Mr. Sulzberger described the venture as an experiment that is expected to break even but not make a profit during the first six months. The plan is for the publication to appear weekly, beginning early in 1993, if some transmission problems can be solved.
In a statement, The Times said its costs would be covered by advertising from American Express, Archer Daniels Midland, the Coca-Cola Company, Estee Lauder International, Goldman Sachs, I.B.M. and T.W.A. Each has agreed to purchase 12 full-page ads in the paper.
The Moscow News has proved a vigorous organization in the new commonwealth, and the paper's editors approached The Times 18 months ago with an idea of a joint venture to publish a daily version of The Times in Russian. But daily publication was quickly abandoned as too expensive, primarily because of the high cost of newsprint in the former Soviet Union.
While Mr. Sulzberger said that The Times had only modest profit expectations for the venture, The News could profit significantly, in relative terms. Under the current arrangement, The News will get 50 percent of the revenue from ads sold in the United States and all advertising revenue generated in the commonwealth countries.
But the venture also holds potential for The Times, which, like other newspapers, has been seeking ways to repackage its news product to generate additional revenue.
Mr. Sulzberger said there were no plans to start other foreign-language editions of The Times.
The huge potential audience and evolving society in the commonwealth states have proved a potent lure for attracting a variety of publishing ventures, but the market is hardly one without problems, from telecommunications difficulties to pockets of ideological hostility.
"It's a tough nut to crack," said George D. DeVault, editor of Rodale Press's Novy Fermer (New Farmer), which has circulation of 40,000 and is aimed at private farmers, a group that is viewed with enduring suspicion after decades of collective farming. Various difficulties forced Novy Fermer, a joint venture with Russian partners, to switch from bimonthly to quarterly publication. The Rodale Press, which is based in Emmaus, Pa., also publishes Organic Gardening, Prevention and other magazines.
International Data Group Inc., a Boston-based publisher of computer information, has begun four Russian-language publications, including Russian versions of PC World, a monthly, and Computer World, a weekly.
 
Hearst and Izvestia
 This year The Hearst Corporation began publishing We, an ambitious paper in both Russian and English, in partnership with Izvestia, which was formerly the newspaper of the Soviet Government and is now an independent paper with five million daily circulation.
William J. Hallenbeck, publisher of We, said the paper had a circulation of about 300,000 in Russian and 50,000 in English, and is produced by its own staff of Russian and American journalists working together in Moscow and Washington.
The Reader's Digest Association's Russian-language edition is not a joint venture but one of 41 editions The Digest publishes in 17 languages. Some 100,000 copies of the monthly magazine are sold, and all of the contents come from outside the commonwealth, the association said.
Business Week publishes a monthly version of its magazine translated into Russian in a joint venture with Kniga, a state-owned printing enterprise.

HEADLINE: A Risky Fiscal Plan;
Dinkins's Budget Relies on Tactics That Were Abandoned as Unrealistic

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins's proposed New York City budget counts on a modest economic recovery and rebounding tax revenue to help balance the city's books in the coming years -- a forecast so far buttressed by only the first glimmers of fact.
That forecast is just one of the optimistic assumptions on which Mr. Dinkins's spending plans are built, and it will have to be measured over time. A more immediate uncertainty is his request to the Legislature for $115 million in new taxes on commuter incomes, fuels, tobacco and liquor, a package that politicians say is already dead. 
 The taxes, and estimates for about $100 million in higher tax revenue, which are pinned to a recovery, are the biggest potential risks in the $29.5 billion budget for the fiscal year that starts July 1. The risks grow swiftly after that, with the reliance on the new taxes alone more than doubling, to $297 million by 1994.
What is more, to help close projected gaps between revenue and expenses averaging $2.5 billion a year from 1994 to 1996, the Mayor's budget shows the city depending on the very strategies -- borrowing hundreds of millions of dollars to cover expenses and hoping for hundreds of millions of dollars more in Federal aid -- that it had abandoned as unrealistic for the coming year.
"Money does not grow on trees," Mr. Dinkins said, assessing the risks, "and if the scorched-earth policies in Washington continue, the miracle of economic recovery will not flower overnight. The challenges are still tremendous."
 
Avoiding Future Pitfalls
 Yet yesterday's problems seemed like nothing compared with the pressing budget crises of last spring, and the Mayor and his team seem relieved that the future was the worst thing they had to worry about. They acknowledged that big borrowing in the future would pose the same problems with Wall Street bond raters and fiscal monitors that it does now, and they said they would do all they could to avoid it.
"The fact that it's not something that has to be done now, and it's more than a year and a half away from actually happening, lets everyone pause and not be too alarmed about it," said the Budget Director, Philip R. Michael. "But if we go six or eight months from now, and it's still being reflected in our plan, that'll be a matter of greater concern."
Just how the city will avoid such pitfalls remains unclear, and if there was any alarm among fiscal watchdogs yesterday, it was that the administration had chosen to pause a bit. The Mayor still faces pressure from the city's labor unions, and while he has vowed to grant raises only in exchange for improved efficiency over the next two years, he said yesterday that "if we do see some relief from a long and painful recession, I fully expect that our work force -- as well as all residents and businesses in our city -- will benefit."
Mr. Dinkins would not speculate on whether that meant raises without concessions -- which would cost $150 million for each percentage point of increased pay. Business groups praised the Mayor's efforts but said he had still not done enough to win work rule changes and bring the city's labor policies more in line with the cutbacks and increases in efficiency already undertaken by the private sector.
 
Tax Revenue and Job Losses
 But even the most pessimistic among the fiscal monitors allowed that the budget for the coming year would undoubtedly be balanced, and economists said the future economic estimates, while hopeful, were not unrealistic.
The city actually projects more job losses for the city economy this year than it did in January, 118,000 compared with 72,000 then, and employment growth of just two-tens of 1 percent in the coming years. But it believes an increase in wages, fueled by record profits and big bonuses on Wall Street, will make up the difference.
"Wall Street is now generating so much income that it's really starting to spin off into the tax revenues, and so those revenues are going up, even though the job losses are continuing," said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "There's a kind of taffy-pulling going on between the two."
Of the $455 million budget surplus that the city managed to eke out for the current year, the single largest part -- $158 million -- came from higher than expected tax revenue, with about $100 million of that coming from economically sensitive taxes. But that was possible only because the city revised its projections downward again and again, and still represents less than the city expected to collect when it adopted the current budget last June.
 
Stressing a Cautious Outlook
 City officials insist that their outlook remains cautious, in part because a sluggish real-estate market and Mr. Dinkins's pledge of a four-year freeze in property tax rates will hold down growth of the city's most reliable revenue source, the property tax. Overall, including the proposed new taxes, the city expects tax revenue growth of only 1.4 percent next year, or $243 million on a base of $17 billion, far below the 8 and 10 percent annual growth of a few years ago.
"Revenues are performing slightly better, but we're not talking about a material change," said David Smith, a deputy budget director. "We're seeing a little bit of strength a little sooner than we thought, but we do not think this recovery is going to look like the recovery of the 80's."
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said skepticism was well-advised because job losses continued and had all but wiped out the 350,000 jobs added to the local economy between 1976 and 1987. Even growth in wages might not be enough to assure growth, Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
"To project that is to walk down memory lane and think you're headed for the future," he said.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

METRO DIGEST
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
DINKINS OFFERS BUDGET PLAN
Mayor Dinkins proposed a budget for the next fiscal year that includes substantial cuts in New York City's services and work force, but not as deep as had originally been projected. The $29.5 billion budget provides millions of dollars for longer library hours, health clinics for the poor and other welfare programs. It is based on a projection of the city's economic future that is more optimistic than either of the Mayor's previous budgets, reflecting a slight rise in the city's tax revenues. It also assumes $115 million in new taxes that the Mayor and the City Council support but that officials acknowledged may face trouble in the State Legislature. A1.
 
CUNY ADOPTS TOUGHER STANDARDS
In its sharpest change of direction since adopting open admissions in 1970, the City University of New York yesterday approved a broad plan to tighten educational requirements over the next decade. Although open admissions will be retained, students will have to have taken college-preparatory courses in high school or take extra courses at the university before getting their degree. The program will likely lead to major changes in many of the city's public high schools. University trustees also improves a tuition increase. A1.
 
FIFTH DEATH IN PARK CRASH
Bryant Fonseca turned 20 on Saturday. On Sunday night he became the fifth person to die as a result of a car crash in Washington Square Park on Thursday. "We can try to find someone to blame because that would give us a resolution, but that is useless," his father, Michael, said. B3.
 
BABY FOUND IN TRASH BIN
A newborn boy, barely breathing, was found in the garbage bin of a six-story apartment building in the Bronx after he was apparently dropped down the building's garbage chute. The child was found by a porter who was about to pull the bin from under the chute and push it a few feet to the garbage compactor. B3.
 
JUDGE BACKS DEATH-PENALTY LAW
A judge said she would uphold the constitutionality of a new Federal death-penalty law in the narcotics-murder trial of a reputed Mafia member in Brooklyn. Judge Reena Raggi said she would reject a defense motion to declare the death-penalty provision unconstitutional. B3.
 
In Federal Court, Tarzan v. Vogue. B3.
 
REGION
 
A PLAN TO SELL CITY HALL
Short of cash? Why not sell City Hall? That, in effect, is what the Suffolk County Legislature will be considering today. As a way to raise a quick $25 million, Suffolk wants to sell its most prominent government building to a newly created public trust, which would then lease it back to the county. Most Democrats and Republicans, say they can support the concept, which has been used at the state and county level from New York to California. B5.
 
HELP FOR MILITARY CONTRACTORS
Saying New York State had lost more than 65,000 jobs since 1987 because of cutbacks in Pentagon spending, Governor Cuomo visited an electronics company here to announce a state program to help military contractors find customers in private industry. The program is the first of its kind in the nation to win Federal support, the Governor said. B5.

HEADLINE: Perot Backers Make Gains on Election Barriers

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
The Presidential campaign mounted on behalf of Ross Perot is targeting New York State for a particularly intense petition drive aimed at surmounting the obstacles in its election law.
Thomas D. Barr, a prominent Manhattan lawyer and adviser to Mr. Perot, said yesterday that the Perot Petition Committee, the group that is trying to get Mr. Perot on the ballot, would open an office in Manhattan to deal with the intricacies of the law -- long considered the most arcane and difficult in the nation for insurgents to overcome -- and also to coordinate the efforts of numerous Perot for President efforts that have cropped up around the state. 
 A spokesman for the committee, Sharon Holman in Dallas, said this would be the first campaign office outside of Dallas.
But the sentiment against insider politics that has fueled the Perot boomlet may have already contributed greatly to increasing his chances of making it on to the New York State ballot.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo released a memorandum yesterday outlining what he said were changes in the election law agreed to by his administration and Democratic and Republican legislative leaders. These measures could reduce the number of petition signatures independent candidates like Mr. Perot would need to qualify for the ballot.
It is not clear whether the change will help Mr. Perot himself, since negotiators have not agreed on when the new laws could take effect. The memorandum left open the question of whether the Legislature would deal with many of the thorniest aspects of the election law. [Page B2.]
Whatever the breadth of the revisions, political insiders say it is doubtful that officials of either major party want to be seen as the backroom maneuverers who killed the opportunity to vote for Mr. Perot.
Across the New York metropolitan region, Perot proponents report that thousands of people have volunteered to help with his potential campaign.
Those most active in Perot efforts say the support spans economic and cultural lines, but among the most enthused appear to be large numbers of small business people who are white, middle class and, at least among those queried in spot interviews, often Republicans.
 
It's Tough in New York
 While getting Mr. Perot onto the ballot in New Jersey, where only 800 signatures are required, or in Connecticut, where 14,620 are needed, is not particularly difficult, in no state is it tougher than in New York.
Under the present law, during five weeks from July to mid-August, Mr. Perot's forces would have to gather 20,000 signatures, including 100 from each of half the Congressional districts in the state.
None of the signatures could come from voters who signed petitions for any of the candidates in the Democratic Presidential primary or any of the delegates selected to attend the Republican convention.
"We are very confident we can collect 100,000 signatures," said Kurt Koenig, who is running a Perot drive in the state. "By August 12 we expect to have more volunteers than the necessary number of signatures."
In any event, John Marino, the Democratic State Chairman, said that his party would not stand in the way of the Perot petitions. William Powers, the State Republican Chairman, said through a spokesman that it was too soon to tell how the party would evaluate a Perot challenge, but a leading Republican operative in the state said that it was doubtful his party would challenge the petitions either.
 
Two Million Calls Tallied
 A flap over Mr. Perot had developed after an item in U.S. News & World Report said that national Republican tacticians were encouraging the New York party to challenge Perot petitions on technicalities, a hallowed local political tradition. But last week Mary Matalin, political director of President Bush's campaign, denied the report, as did a spokesman for Mr. Powers.
Mr. Perot set off a telephone call-in spree on March 16 when he said on a cable interview show that he would consider running for President if supporters could get his name on the ballots in all 50 states. He has eased up on that position since, saying he would run even if he did not get on the ballot in New York.
The Perot petition committee, largely supported by hundreds of thousands of dollars from Mr. Perot, says that more than two million calls have come in since the cable show.
In New York Mr. Koenig and Charles Donnelly, who owns an advertising company where Mr. Koenig works, say they are working with the names of several thousand people who called Mr. Perot's number or a New York City number they featured in a three-line advertisement on the front page of The New York Times last month. They say they have contacts in more than 25 of the state's 33 Congressional districts and that small contributions totaling $5,000 or so have been placed in a newly opened bank account.
 
New Recruits to Politics
 A registered Republican, Mr. Donnelly seems typical of the kind of support that Mr. Perot is picking up in the New York metropolitan region. He said he never truly became involved in party politics, but was swayed to the cause of Mr. Perot after hearing him on television several times.
They describe themselves as "people who just honestly want a change," in the words of Mr. Donnelly, who has given over the top floor of his office to the effort; as "bleeding heart conservatives," in the words of Jacqueline Joy, a homemaker married to a construction manager who lives in upstate Dewittville; and as voters whose ballots are "wasted in the system," in the words of Rocky Lee, who runs a chrome plating company in Linden, N.J.
Combining middle-class stability and patriotism with economic and more free floating edginess, they believe, that "The overall structure of America is the best in the world, but you need a leader -- a true, competent leader. The whole process is stopped up," in the words of James Grady, who runs a wholesale tree business in Albany.
In New Jersey Thomas O'Neil, a construction consultant, said he had compiled more than 7,000 names on a mailing list since scheduling his first meeting of Perot supporters about seven weeks ago.
Describing himself as "rather apathetic and apolitical for years," Mr. O'Neil, of Lawrenceville, said he had seen Mr. Perot speak a number of times over the years and always left thinking, "Why can't we get guys like that to run for higher office in this country?"
 
Dallas Sends Names
 In Connecticut, when Perot forces gathered at Manero's Restaurant in Greenwich earlier this month, 188 people showed up, only four of whom had been actively involved in politics before. Sarason D. Liebler, a registered Republican and a public relations professional who describes himself as a co-chairman of the communications committee of the state Perot organization, said the election of the state's independent Governor, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., in 1990 could help the effort.
"In a sense, it did break the ice on people saying, 'Who cares what party it is, we've got to do something,' " he said.
Mr. Weicker has not taken a position on the race, but several officials of the party created for his candidacy are openly pushing for a Perot endorsement.
Those involved in the petition drive headquarters in Dallas and longtime advisers to Mr. Perot say that with the exception of advice about Federal election regulations and state election laws, the groups get little more than names of 800 line callers from the central office. They receive this help from a few paid staff members in the Perot operation.
In the most successful third-party Presidential campaigns of recent years, former Alabama Gov. George Wallace in 1968 collected 358,864 votes in New York or 5.3 percent of the vote. He received 262,187 votes or 9.1 percent of the total vote in New Jersey and 76,650 votes or 6.1 percent of the total in Connecticut. Nationally, Mr. Wallace pulled 13.5 percent of the total.
In 1980, former Representative John Anderson of Illinois pulled 467,801 votes or 7.5 percent of the total in New York, 234,632 votes or 7.9 percent of the total in New Jersey, and 171,807 votes or 12.2 percent of the total in Connecticut. Mr. Anderson garnered the lion's share of the 5,720,000 votes cast for independent candidates nationally. The independent vote was 6.6 percent of the total.
Despite some polls showing him doing far better than this if the election were held today, many observers say it is far too early to tell how Mr. Perot will fare in November.
"My gut feeling is that he'll hurt Clinton more in New Jersey because the Republicans in the state have been on a roll," said Stephen A. Salmore, a professor of political science at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University in New Brunswick and a Republican campaign consultant.
Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion, in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., said: "I think there's a general sense that by November he would tend to draw more from the Republican than the Democratic candidate, based on his matching up more closely with Republicans ideologically. The counter argument is that as a challenger, he divides up the challenger vote and cuts into Clinton's effort to be the change agent.
"In New York, I think the picture is unclear about where he would draw. He's somewhere between a curiousity and a candidate. It's still quite a way to governing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Charles Donnelly, standing, said he never became involved in party politics and was swayed to the cause of Ross Perot after hearing him on television several times. He recently planned strategy for Mr. Perot in Manhattan. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 'Fight With Us' Against Military, Ousted Haitian Urges Americans

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
Raising a fist in salute to more than 2,500 cheering Haitian students at Brooklyn College, the deposed President of Haiti, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, extolled his faith in the youth of his country yesterday and said he was certain that they would "rally the resistance so that Haiti will become a democratic country once again."
Then, addressing Americans, Father Aristide, whose Government was toppled by the Haitian military last September, said, "We need you to fight with us in the same way we saw Americans fight in Nicaragua." 
 Earlier, in remarks to 200 members of the Baptist Ministers' Conference of Greater New York and Vicinity at the Convent Avenue Baptist Church in Harlem, Father Aristide reportedly called for a stepped-up embargo of Haiti and said he believed that Washington should take stronger action to force the Haitian military to give up its hold on political power.
"He said they have given beautiful statements," said the Rev. V. Simpson Turner, the president of the ministers' conference, referring to the support voiced so far by Washington officials. "But he said what's needed is action."
 
Any Criticism Is Muted
 In a telephone interview yesterday, though, Father Aristide had no criticism of the Bush Administration. He did not believe, he said, that United States or other foreign troops should be sent to Haiti, as some supporters in New York have suggested during his visit here. He said he believed that the Administration was doing everything it could and that he was "sure they will see the result of what they are doing."
The United States cut aid to Haiti and imposed an economic embargo shortly after the Sept. 30 coup. Administration officials said last week that they were considering further steps against the military Government, including tightening the embargo. On May 18, the Foreign Ministers of the Organization of American States are to meet in the Bahamas, with Haiti the most urgent matter on their agenda.
After four days of meetings in New York that went for the first time far beyond talks with Haitian-Americans, Father Aristide is to spend today seeing journalists and members of his government in exile before leaving for Boston on Wednesday.
He came to New York from Washington on a visit of several weeks that journalists and diplomats who follow Caribbean affairs say was partly an effort to insure that the issue of Haiti's political turmoil remains in the public eye.
 
Suggests Internal U.S. Pressure
 Mr. Turner said Father Aristide urged the Baptist ministers to "pressure our Congressmen" and city officials so they would insist that the Bush Administration not relax and begin to accommodate the Haitian military.
Father Aristide began his New York visit with a breakfast Friday with business and labor leaders, then went to City Hall to talk with Mayor David N. Dinkins and members of the City Council.
On Saturday, he drove to a resort in the Pocono Mountains of Pennsylvania to address a regional meeting of the National Association of Black Journalists and that evening attended a $150-a-plate dinner in Queens that was organized to pay for the visit. On Sunday, Father Ariside spoke privately with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and then strode onto a stage in Central Park, where he was cheered by tens of thousands of Haitian exiles.
Speaking of Mr. Cuomo, Mayor Dinkins and of Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Democrat who represents Harlem, Father Aristide said: "Those people are so good by the way they welcome us here. We are proud to be their friends."
Fritz Longchamp, who speaks for Father Aristide's exile government at the United Nations, was at the ousted President's side yesterday. He said the Haitian leader had sought a broader audience on his visit because "there is a sense of urgency in Haiti.
"He wants to go back to Haiti with the full support not only of the U.S. Government," Mr. Longchamp said, "but of the American people."

HEADLINE: Russian, in Western Mode, Makes His Case

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
Seeking billions of dollars to heal its economic ills, Russia presented a smooth young face to the West today, a 36-year-old Deputy Prime Minister full of enthusiasm for free markets.
In his gray suit, light blue shirt and dark tie, Yegor T. Gaidar could have passed for a bureaucrat of any Western European government. With his unwrinkled cheeks and detailed descriptions of how to sell state-owned industries, he offered a clear-cut contrast to his boss, President Boris N. Yeltsin, a rough and bluff politician of an age to be his father. 
 Mr. Gaidar is in Washington to reassure Western aid donors and investors that his country is still loping toward a market economy with him in the saddle of management. While the initial reaction was enthusiastic, some skepticism remained.
"He's a very brave man with a lot of responsibilities," said Land Grant, an export management executive, after hearing Mr. Gaidar speak at breakfast today. "He seems to have every ball in the air at once. I hope they don't all come down on his head."
 
A Full Schedule
 Like any good salesman, Mr. Gaidar used every available hour. Arriving Saturday evening, he sought financial aid for his country Sunday afternoon at a meeting of finance ministers and central bankers of the seven wealthiest industrial democracies, then had dinner with Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund.
He delivered a speech and answered questions this morning at the United States Chamber of Commerce, enthusiastically describing the need to reduce government control over the Russian economy and lure foreign investment. Then he presented his plans to a top policy-making committee of the I.M.F. and met with Louis T. Preston, the president of the World Bank, before dinner at the Russian Embassy with senior European Community officials.
"He really resembles a Western finance minister in the way he presents things," said a European official who heard Mr. Gaidar's statement to the I.M.F. committee.
In his remarks at the Chamber of Commerce, Mr. Gaidar repeatedly tried to impress potential investors with how far his country had already come as a way to persuade them that the future would be much better.
"If anybody would half a year ago tell the story that Russian Government will liberalize the prices, cut down drastically subsidies and military spending and increase the taxation, and you'll survive not only politically but physically, it would be greeted as a joke," he said. "Now this joke comes true."
Mr. Gaidar's continued political survival in Moscow has depended partly on his success in impressing Western financial officials, said Dmitri K. Simes, a Russian affairs expert at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington.
By establishing himself as an international symbol of economic change in Russia, Mr. Gaidar has made it difficult to remove him without shaking the trust of Western leaders and, more important, their willingness to lend, Mr. Simes said.
Senior financial officials who met Mr. Gaidar on this trip were full of more compliments for him. "I would have to say, Mr. Gaidar, as you know, is an enormously convincing person," Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said Sunday night.
 
'He Knows His Numbers'
 An international financial official who met Mr. Gaidar today said the Russian had quickly grasped the many problems facing his country. "He knows his numbers," the official said. "He knows his problems. He thinks in a fairly comprehensive perspective."
But Mr. Gaidar's strongest supporters in the West may be economists, who admire and envy his rise to the top economic policy position late last year from his job as a director of an economics research center in Moscow.
Jeffrey Sachs, the Harvard professor who is now advising the Russian Government, said Mr. Gaidar had surrounded himself with other young, bright economists. "These are intellectual, very top-notch people," Mr. Sachs said, "and half the time you make a point, they say, 'Yes, we know, we know, we know.' And you're not even making an obvious point."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
In Pennsylvania, Clinton Is Seeking Solid Victory

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, April 27

 BODY:
Hoping to follow the trail of Democratic success blazed by Harris Wofford in his come-from-behind victory for the Senate last year, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas ended his final day of campaigning in the Pennsylvania primary by hopscotching across the state in search of blue-collar votes.
The series of rallies began on Sunday in southwestern Pennsylvania, carefully staged for maximum camera appeal and intended to showcase Mr. Clinton as the Democrat who could best motivate and unite his party. 
 But the Arkansas Governor has spent considerable time in the past several days mending divisions within his party. He first had to fend off criticism last week from Pennsylvania's Governor, Robert P. Casey, a Democrat, who questioned Mr. Clinton's chances of defeating President Bush in November.
And then today Mr. Clinton had to contend with another potential brushfire when the Rev. Jesse Jackson was quoted in The New York Daily News as demanding that he be Mr. Clinton's Vice-Presidential choice. Mr. Jackson later tempered his comments.
Such eruptions threatened to overshadow what Mr. Clinton and his aides have seen as their real mission: to use this state's primary campaign as the place to prove that he is a man of integrity who has a message for voters weary of tough economic times.
Pennsylvania, with 169 delegates to the Democratic National Convention, , is one of the biggest prizes of the primary season, and Mr. Clinton is hoping to exceed 50 percent of the vote.
Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts won 67 percent of the primary vote here in 1988 before going on to become the Democratic nominee. But the Republican nominee, Vice President George Bush, won the state in November, with 51 percent of the vote to Mr. Dukakis's 48 percent.
Now, because of Senator Wofford's success in defeating Dick Thornburgh, President Bush's first Attorney General and a former Pennsylvania Governor, in a special election last November, the state is viewed by both parties as an important battleground.
 
Target Is Bush, Not Brown
 Saying that he would "lead a crusade to change the country" if elected, Mr. Clinton has directed his fire exclusively at Mr. Bush while campaigning here, ignoring his only remaining major Democratic rival, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California.
Mr. Brown also campaigned in Pennsylvania today, but at an Independence Hall rally in Philadelphia he no longer sounded like a candidate.
In what was billed as a major address, Mr. Brown railed against the political establishment. Although he also repeated that he was in the race to stay, the speech was a clear signal that he intended to emphasize his anti-establishment crusade rather than realistically seek the party's nomination.
Mr. Clinton, in a rally at City Hall Plaza here later, borrowed some of the anger that Mr. Brown directs at the political system when he implored voters to go the polls Tuesday.
"Scrap your cynicism," he said. "Get out tomorrow, get your friends and neighbors to vote and take your country back."
linking him to the question raised by Ronald Reagan in 1980 when he asked voters to use a new standard in deciding whether to re-elect President Jimmy Carter.
"Do you remember what that standard was?" Mr. Clinton said at a rally in Steelworkers Plaza in Pittsburgh. "Are you better off today than you were four years ago?"
The crowd responded with a resounding "No!"
Mr. Wofford and Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, who dropped out of the Democratic race last month, traveled with Mr. Clinton today, and each took turns exhorting union members who have supported Mr. Harkin and Pennsylvania Democrats who supported Mr. Wofford to vote on Tuesday for Mr. Clinton.
