HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Brown's Standard Campaign Speech: A New Vision of America

 BODY:
In his campaign addresses around the country, Edmund G. Brown Jr. rarely reads from a text or notes and his speeches vary considerbly from place to place, but he always focuses on the same themes: the corruption of American politics and his crusade to return control of the nation to "the people."
The former California Governor almost always invokes Thomas Jefferson, and he never forgets to plug his toll-free number for campaign donations, usually drawing good-natured laughter and some of his biggest cheers.
Though he tailors his pitches slightly for labor audiences or other groups, he is unlike most politicians in that he rarely studies up on the details of where he is visiting, and does not often include references to local supporters. 
 Mr. Brown's basic speeches tend to run longer than most Presidential candidates', sometimes more than a half hour. He prefers speaking in generalities, and often tells audiences that he abhors ticking off lists of facts and figures and things he would do in the White House.
Among his best-received lines are when Mr. Brown tells audiences that Mr. Jefferson said the country needed a rebellion every 20 years and that the country is ripe for one now. He also gets a good responses when he pokes fun at the trade pact with Mexico and suggests exporting the Congress to Mexico. He draws laughs when he tells of how people dismiss him as a flake, as Governor Moonbeam.
Sometimes Mr. Brown falls flat. He usually makes fun of fancy fund-raising dinners, saying they eat sherbet and call it "sorbet." The line does not always get much of a response, but he includes it in his speeches anyway.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	 Following are excerpts from the speech that Edmund G. Brown Jr. delivered to the Building and Trades Council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in Washington on March 31, as transcribed by the Federal News Service. The content is representative of the standard addresses that Mr. Brown gives around the country in his campaign for President.
 In this election, if I make any point, it's that this is not just some kind of personality contest between Mr. Clinton and myself. It's a question of the identity of the Democratic Party, of who we are, what we want to do, what we represent and our vision of America. And that is the most important question. And the different flurries of questions and stories that come out, we got to get down to the bedrock of what does this party stand for. Who do we represent?
And coming, talking, to a group of people from New York, it's very appropriate to raise the whole question of how did the Democratic Party get started. It got started when a man by the name of Thomas Jefferson went on an expedition along the Hudson River in 1791 with James Madison. And they were very worried about a group of wealthy elites taking over this country, subverting the revolution and putting a new aristocracy in power. That was the Federalists.
And our party's origins stem right from that first battle for the soul of this country, whether we're going to be run by the few, or are we going to be serving the yeoman farmers of the South and the working men of the North. That's how it all began. And Jefferson at that time said that the goal of the Democratic Party was to stop the power of the few from rioting on the labors of the many -- stop the power of the few from rioting on the labors of the many.
And that's still the challenge of this party, because the few have done well, and the many are increasingly suffering -- jobs being exported, wages being driven down and cities being utterly destroyed by neglect and indifference in a country that is the richest in the world, that is generating $6 trillion of gross national product every year, and yet can't seem to find the political will to invest in our own people. And that is the test. Jefferson said something else that is appropriate to this campaign and this election year. He said, "This country needs a rebellion every 20 years." And we haven't had one in 200. And I say it's about time. See, what's happened is people who are running this country have figured out that you can make profit for your shareholders without having American workers. And that's why they -- just as easy -- not just as easy, they'd rather send the job to Mexico, where they can pay two bucks an hour, rather than keep it going in this country. And that is a real threat.
And that's not a trade union issue, that's an American issue. And more and more, as I've gone along in this campaign, I've seen the utter gap between those who make the rules and those who don't; those whose jobs are protected from being exported and those who suffer when business moves its enterprises offshore.
 
'Mortal Threat' of Job Losses
 And when you think about it, the people making the rules, what if, what if somehow you could export the Congress to Mexico? What if? And what if instead of paying them $130,000 a year you pay them $13,000 a year? You think they'd vote for a fast-track then? You bet they wouldn't. And that's the problem, whether it's the media, whether it's the Congress, whether it's the lobbyists or whether it's the investment bankers or the lawyers, they're not afraid of their jobs being exported. That's why they don't get it.
And they don't get the mortal threat to a man or woman that's worked their life only to be standing on an unemployment line for the best years of their life. It's rotten, it's wrong, and anything I can do to stop it, I'm going do that. This is about America, protecting our jobs and our future.
And that's the problem, whether it's the media, whether it's the Congress, whether it's the lobbyists or whether it's the investment bankers or the lawyers: They're not afraid of their jobs being exported. That's why they don't get it.
Now, maybe a few years ago I wouldn't have experienced it in the same way that I do now. But as I've campaigned across this country in Michigan at Willow Run, where thousands of people are looking at unemployment, New York, Connecticut, over the other night in Eau Claire, Wis. I was picked up at the airport by a rubber worker who has been working for 25 years at the Uniroyal plant, a plant that has now been taken over by Michelin and will be closed down in June. I looked at this man, he's 50. I thought to myself, "What's going on here?" This is not an isolated incident.
In state after state, I'm meeting people who have worked their whole lives to build this country and now they're just being forgotten about. And why? Because they're 50 now. They're 55 and they have medical bills. And so management says, "Well, wait a minute, these bills are getting a little high. We can go down to Mexico. We can find some young kids. Their medical costs are lower. They'll work for $2 an hour. You've got a company union. You've got a compliant government. You don't have pollution regulations. You don't have the Davis-Bacon Act. Why not?"
And I say why not because I look at this person, this man, and I saw America in his eyes, in his furrowed brow, in the lines on his face, the wrinkles, the calluses on his hands. That is America. And if we're going to export America to foreign countries, then we're doomed and this election is not just about a bunch of little personalities and sound bites, it's about survival. It's about our way of life and about everything you've fought for. So let's get together and take it back, take it back for your kids. Take it back for your unions. Take it back for our future.
 
Protecting Unionism
 Well, just to go back a little bit before I was elected, the politics of the Brown family started with one pivotal issue. In 1958, my father was running for governor. There was an issue on the ballot, a referendum to establish a right-to-work law. And he ran fighting it; his Republican opponent supported it. And he was elected overwhelmingly in the coalition of trade unionists, Democratic activists this country has seen in the last 40 years. And it was that galvanizing event that brought home to me the power and importance of the trade union movement.

 	 	 		. . .	 	And I've seen these two events -- the beginning of my father's administration when he won, and at the end when Ronald Reagan emerged from his political B movies to the prominence of California. Civil rights, trade union solidarity, the right of representation and with the support of government -- those are two basic principles that I've never forgotten. During my tenure as Governor I was able to sign collective-bargaining bills for local employees, teachers, state workers, in fact, millions of public employees -- state, county, local, school employees. We did it, and I don't think there's ever been a governor in history that brought so many people under collective bargaining.
If you look at the record, California -- you know, if you just compare the record between my opponent and myself, in Arkansas you've got right to work. California -- we've rejected it. Now, in Arkansas you don't have prevailing rates. California, you do. Arkansas -- the Governor there went over to Korea and bragged about the fact that Arkansas had the fifth-lowest rates, wages, in the country. It's a different experience.
In the state of California over two million jobs was created in eight years. Two million. O.K.? And those were public works; those were jobs of all kinds. We accelerated a whole program, particularly in water projects, sewage, infrastructure and all the rest. In fact, if you total up the number of jobs during my administration, they exceed that which George Bush has been able to create in four years for the whole nation. And you can throw in anything Clinton did in Arkansas and you still wouldn't come close to the 2.2 million jobs we created in California. And that's what we're talking about. Is this a country that's going to work to put Americans to work or not?

 	 	 		. . .	 	You know, they couldn't get 50 votes to break down the so-called wall between the Pentagon budget and the civilian budget. While American people are out of work, they're still fighting to protect a Pentagon budget that's spending tens of billions of dollars in Europe. And you know what they're doing? We're spending money to defend the Germans; the Germans are paying the Russians to house and feed and clothe the Russians. So it turns out your jobs are killed so we can pay money to pay soldiers to defend Germans who are paying Russians against whom we're defending them in the first place.
You know, we've got 35,000 troops in Japan. Do you know who we're defending Japan against, by the way? Who? Tell me. Do you know? Us.

 	 	 		. . .	 	 This isn't about me, and I'm trying to say that. Look, I'm a politician. I was in this business. I've raised more money than Bill Clinton ever did. I acknowledge that. I know how the system works. I won't tell you who wouldn't -- well, that's another story. But I can tell you more stories than all the rest of them.
But what I want to say is, I'm standing with you. I'm standing with the trade union movement, with students, with environmentalists, with pensioners, with African Americans, Latinos. I want this to be a candidacy, a cause, a movement to shift the direction in this country. And that's what I want. I want to be the proxy for all of you. I want to be the voice of those whose voices are being ignored. I want to be your lawyer and your lobbyist and your insider so we can turn this country around.
And that's what the election's about: Who are we and where are we going? Are we going to be macho policemen to take care of all the disputes all over this planet, or are we going to come back home to New York City and Buffalo and Los Angeles and Detroit and clean up the mess by putting people to work? It's just that simple, and we can do it. But we're not going to do it unless we get a real change. That's what you've got to do.
Now, you know, that's what's so amazing to me. We're in a $6 trillion economy -- $6 trillion. And people are saying, "Well, where's the money? Where is the money?"
Well, just last year, Bush was able to forgive a $7 billion loan to Egypt -- $7 billion of loans. I mean, you can think of all the small businesses, all the cities that could desperately need that. You know, I mean, they're not getting it.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Anti-Drug Failures
 You know, crack was invented in the 80's. You know that, don't you? It was invented under Reagan and Bush. They didn't have it before then. That's when -- you know, you've heard about supply-side economics. You've heard about deregulating cocaine. That's what crack is.
Now, seriously, they had this guy -- there were two people. You had Bush, who was picked out by Reagan to keep the stuff out, and Noriega was on the payroll to bring it in. Now, who did a better job? Yeah. I mean, in his zeal to get at the contras, the Reagan-Bush Administration was willing to look the other way about the activities of Noriega. Now, they're putting him on trial, and to get him, they're going to have to give leniency to a bigger drug kingpin.
Ten billion dollars in the anti-drug war. The biggest housing program in America is now prison-building. Prison-building, that's the new public housing, other than housing for Bush and Quayle. You know, they're in public housing, too.

 	 	 		. . .	 	If you can build a B-2 bomber, you can build a B-2 bullet train and all the infrastructure needed. And you don't need to have roads and bridges that are falling apart. You can take the people who are out of work and put them to work. And if we start going on what this country needs in energy efficiency and high-speed trains and retrofitting buildings and housing and all the other stuff that's been neglected for 20 years, we can have full employment. We have the money; we just don't have the political will. And this election is about galvanizing that political will.
It's a great contest. You know, a few months ago they said, "Hey, Brown, you can't do this. You don't have the money. You don't have the money."
Yeah, 1-800----. You think I'm going to say it now. Even President Bush has got to talk about it. They've even got a joke about it. Doonesbury put 1-800 in, and the calls were ringing around the weekend, 24 hours a day.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
An Insider's Disillusion
 I've been at it longer than anybody else. I started back in 1976. So I know a few things about how the process works. I've won several primaries then. And I came back and I saw as leader of the party in California -- I mean, I saw the thing wasn't working, because we're spending all our time with the top 1 percent trying to pick up those thousand-dollar checks in big bundles to then try to manipulate and enroll a disappearing constituency. People were running away from us as fast as we can catch up with them. And I can tell you after two years of going to power breakfast, power lunch, power dinner with the same elite, it doesn't work.

 	 	 		. . .	 	It doesn't work if you're going to the power of the few to attempt to save and serve the majority. And that's why the majority of young kids are not identifying with the Democratic Party. That's why in New York almost 70 percent of the people didn't vote in the last Presidential election who could have.
I mean, the whole system is rigged against the kind of activism and participation which alone will revitalize the trade union movement. And this is now a matter of crisis. It's a crisis for the country. It's a crisis for you. We're going to have either low wages, low productivity or high wages, high productivity.
And in Germany the average factory wage is $22.50 an hour. They have health care for everyone. O.K. And they have a very strong unionized work force because there's participation, there's a commitment to modernization, and a commitment to jobs and they can compete. And they don't let their wages get pushed down by cheap labor.
As a matter of fact, they're exporting more cars to Japan. They're exporting more as a percentage. And yet they can protect their wage structure. They protect it because they have a social compact. They don't let the market be the closest dictator. Whenever the market says we're going to stand around, and -- O.K..
Well, if you let the market dictate everything, you won't pay anybody anything. Slave labor is probably as efficient as you can find. And it's only when you can stand between unbridled profit and the humanity of those you represent that we can get anything done. And that's called a trade union movement. That's called the representation. It's giving power to the powerless. It's called solidarity. And I recognize it, I support it and I stand with you.
 
Bringing People Back
 Nothing's going to happen until we can bring millions of people back into the process. And that's precisely what's happening in my campaign. In Maine, in Colorado, in Connecticut, people came in and started voting who had never voted before. In Maine two-thirds of the people showed up at the caucuses who had never been to a caucus before.
And if we're going to win in November, you can't present some kind of watered-down, neo-conservative something or other. You have to appeal to people. You have to reach out and say, 'Look, this country is for you. This election is going to make a difference." You have Bush on one side, you have a privileged character who would rather play golf than invest in this country, who cares more about Egypt than he cares about New York City. And you've got to bring people in, in a sense they can control it.
And this idea of limiting the campaign to $100. I thought long and hard about it, because I certainly raised it the old-fashioned way before. And I really believed that if we could just get the cause clear and be honest about it, that people would come. And the first week, you know, what did we do, we get a few hundred people to contribute and then a few thousand and then tens of thousands till now over $5 million has been pledged through that "800" number. That's people saying, "Hey, I want the government back." And that's what we call a movement, we call a cause. It's a coalition.

 	 	 		. . .	 	There is a mood out there: It's angry. And if we could just unite the workers who are losing their jobs because the greedy elite on Wall Street doesn't give a darn, and we could unite that with trade unionists who are out of work, with blacks who have never had a chance, with Latinos, with students who think the whole thing is a big rip-off and a joke, now you're talking about something, because we're looking at a country where half the people have seceded.
Back in the time of the Civil War, Lincoln defined the struggle as the necessity of proving popular government's not an absurdity. At that time a third of the people had pulled out, had seceded by states.
Today, half the people have pulled out. It's the same test. Is government of the people -- is it absurd, or is it real? Well, if it's real, it's got to work for people. If it's got to work for people, they got to have jobs. And when you can spend money to bail out an S.& L., when you can spend money to take care of yourself and your perks and all the rest of it and forget about your own people, I say it's time to make a change.
I say it's time for a wakeup call. We have the money. We have the capacity. We have the unmet needs. Just look at the bridges and the roads and the lack of efficiency, the lack of health care. We can do it. I mean, in Canada they've got a health-care program that covers everybody.

 	 	 		. . .	 	It's the political will to recognize the cold war is over, that America is being pulled apart, and that millions and millions are in despair and hopelessness because they can't support their families. And I come from a Catholic social tradition that says every person is worthy of their hire, they're worthy of earning a living family wage.

 	 	 		. . .	 	I say wake up. The battle is right here, and it's not incoming missiles, it's incoming inequality. And jobs and unemployment. We can do it. This is a coalition. It's a coalition like you haven't seen before. I'm appearing in union halls that are packed shoulder to shoulder, with students, with environmentalists, with trade unionists, building trades, C.I.O. unions, everything.
This is a spark that is -- that -- it's much bigger than myself. I mean, it isn't because of me, I've got too much -- you know, you know all the stories -- Moonbeam, and Flake, and all the other stuff -- isn't me, I want you to understand that. It's you, and it's the American people having a sense -- hey, it could be different.
And remember after World War II what happened. People were saying, "Hey, we're going to have a depression. It's terrible." We didn't. What did we do? Two things: we sent the G.I.'s to school, not making them borrow money so they were going to be in debt 25 years. We gave them the money, and we built the most prosperous country, and then we created an Interstate highway system and spent hundreds of billions. All right. The cold war is over. We spent our $12 trillion, and now let's go to work to make this country flourish again in the same way we did after World War II. We can do it, take it back, we the people, we the trade unionists, fight 1430, fight right to work. We can do it.
Thank you very much.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. and World Bank: Lenders to the Nations

BYLINE: By CAROLINE RAND HERRON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank are products of the Bretton Woods monetary conference, held in New Hampshire in 1944. The meeting was called to supervise a fixed exchange rate system and help industrialized countries emerging from World War II cope with trade and capital imbalances.
The monetary fund started with 39 countries -- excluding the Soviet Union, which declined repeated invitations to join. Dominated by industrialized nations, the fund helps developing countries draw up and carry out large-scale economic reforms aimed at growth without inflation. It often provides loans along the way to help them in this painful process, which often involves cutting government food and energy subsidies that help the poor. 
 Left-of-center critics say the I.M.F.'s prescriptions help countries pay their international debt but hurt their long-term health. Right-of-center analysts fault the institution for an emphasis on central planning rather than economic growth.
The World Bank, the sister organization of the fund, has the same membership. It is typically involved in more narrowly focused programs than the fund, helping countries develop their transportation, health and education systems and their private sectors.
The bank is made up of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and its affiliate, the International Development Association, which makes low-interest loans to the poorest countries. Two other affiliates are the International Finance Corporation, which lends to private companies in developing nations, and the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency, which assists foreign investment in poor countries.
In a nutshell, the monetary fund works at stabilizing economies, while the World Bank works at developing them long term.
Once various formalities involving the 14 former Soviet republics are complete, the monetary fund will have 170 members, which contribute money to it under a formula based on their economic output. The United States provides nearly a fifth of the financing for the monetary fund and the World Bank. Membership in the fund is required for joining the World Bank and for assistance from the two organizations.

HEADLINE: Forest Service May Alter Rule Blocking Logging

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27

 BODY:
As part of an election-year assault on regulations that it says are choking economic recovery, the Bush Administration has proposed limiting a rule that environmentalists have used to block logging on millions of acres of national forests.
Under the 85-year-old rule, members of the public have been able to delay or stop timber sales simply by mailing written critiques about the probable environmental harm of the logging to the United States Forest Service within 45 days after the service has put the timber on the market. The rule requires the Forest Service to respond to the challenges within 115 days by rejecting the challenge, changing the terms of the sale or withdrawing the timber from the market. 
 In place of these challenges, called administrative appeals, the Administration wants to set up a procedure by which the public could comment on Forest Service plans before timber is offered for sale. Once the sale was offered, the only recourse left to opponents of the plans would be to take the Government to court.
 
Rule Could Deter Challenges
 That is likely to deter challenges by small environmental groups that make a majority of the appeals. They said lawsuits were more difficult, more expensive and without a court injunction would not delay the sale. Currently, fewer than 1 percent of challenges go on to court after the 115-day review period.
The Administration said it was making the proposal because the number of challenges to commercial timber sales had climbed to 636 in 1991 from 133 in 1987. The amount of timber affected by the appeals has risen to 1.79 billion board feet, or 31 percent of the timber sold last year, from 633 million board feet, or less than 7 percent of all Federal timber sold in 1986.
A public comment period ends today for the proposal to change the logging rule, made by the Department of Agriculture under a broad review of regulations President Bush ordered in the State of the Union Message. In ordering the review, Mr. Bush directed agencies to stop issuing new rules and to review existing regulations with an eye toward reducing the costs to business. The moratorium on new rules ends Wednesday, but in a speech scheduled for that afternoon at the White House, the President is expected to extend it.
 
Moratorium Is Criticized
 Critics of the moratorium have criticized it, saying it is a moratorium in name only, as the Administration goes ahead and adopts new rules it likes but blocks others.
But most public comments on the new rule were positive, and the Administration has the authority to issue the new regulation later this year.
The proposal is the latest political thrust by the Administration into a slashing fight between the timber industry and community environmental groups in the West and South over how much of the nation's last great stands of spruce, fir and Ponderosa pine will be cut.
The nation's 155 national forests, covering 191 million acres in 44 states, provide roughly a third of the timber used in home construction. Timber shortages have to the closing of sawmills across the country and thrown thousands of loggers and mill workers out of work, the Forest Service and timber industry executives say
The shortage has also worried the White House because it has raised lumber prices this month to record levels. The White House says higher lumber costs have slowed construction of new homes, which has historically led the nation out of recessions. The cost of lumber, which typically accounts for just under 10 percent of a new home's cost, has climbed by 40 percent since January, according to industry figures.
"There is ample opportunity for public input under all our environmental statutes," said Michael Deland, chairman of the President's Council on Environmental Quality, a White House agency that helps set policy, in an interview last Wednesday. "But in some instances we feel there are duplications that have led to long delays. The fact is that in administrative appeals there is an opportunity for giving any citizen the right to tie up projects for an interminable period."
Forest Service officials and timber industry executives say the new comment procedure would give the public more opportunity to influence decisions because citizens could get involved during the planning of a timber sale.
The Government argues that the change will eliminate last-minute appeals and insure a steadier supply of wood. Timber companies, sawmill operators and thousands of industry workers say that because of the ease of challenging timber sales, environmentalists are abusing the process and unnecessarily delaying or halting logging in the national forests.
"Innocent, hard-working people and communities have been badly hurt by the actions of a few extremist appellants that happen to be well-organized, own computers equipped with modems and have a good supply of envelopes and 29-cent stamps," said Bob Boeh, a resident of Whitefish, Mont., who wrote one of the 6,000 comments on the proposed rule change that the Forest Service has received.
 
Town Fears for Sawmill
 One of the communities that is most enthusiastic about the proposal is Panguitch, Utah. The tiny town is almost wholly dependent on timber from the Dixie National Forest in southern Utah for employment and tax revenue. Loggers in the region feed the voracious timber appetite of a sawmill in town, and schools and roads are supported by tax revenue the Government returns to Garfield County from timber sold in the national forest.
School teachers, loggers, and sawmill workers blame appeals of timber sales for closing a Garfield County mill in Escalante about 45 miles southeast of Panguitch, throwing 70 people out of work. They said in letters to the Forest Service in support of the President's proposal that shortages of timber caused by appeals was also threatening the mill in Panguitch.
"Finally I can see hope in the future for my job and my family," said Wallace R. Veater, a forester in Panguitch, said in one letter. "Thank you for listening to the silent majority on this issue and for using common sense in keeping this nation alive and strong by keeping the working people working."
But environmentalists, particularly those belonging to small community and state groups, say the appeals process has proved to be the most effective means available to the public not only for slowing the Government's aggressive cutting in the national forests, but also for saving millions of acres of virgin forests. A study this month by the Congressional Research Service found that in a third of the challenges last year critics demonstrated that the timber sales would cause severe ecological damage, causing the Forest Service to withdraw or reconsider the sales.
 
'It's a Joke'
 Critics of the agency, including some agency employees, have said in Congressional hearings that the Forest Service, which provides an opportunity to comment on timber sales before the appeals process, routinely ignores the earlier public comment. Critics say that is why the appeals process is so important.
"The appeals process was one of the most effective ways for grass-roots groups to make the Forest Service reconsider its plans for cutting tracts that would destroy habitat for grizzlies, or ruin a salmon stream," said Jeffrey St. Clair, editor of Forest Watch magazine, a monthly environmental journal in Portland, Ore., that focuses on national forest issues. "The Forest Service says that after this rule is final, if anybody has a problem they can go to court. It's a joke. Most grass-roots groups can't afford a lawyer."
No type of regulation has come under more scrutiny than those to safeguard the environment. President Bush is attacking environmental rules with a fervor not seen in Washington since the earliest days of the Reagan Administration. The Administration has also proposed opening half the nation's wetlands to development and supported efforts by property owners to require the Government to pay for lands restricted by environmental regulations to protect wildlife and water.
In recent months, the Administration has backed the coal industry's efforts to dismantle the nation's strip mining law, proposed weakening the hazardous waste law, and altered enforcement rules for the 1990 Clean Air Act, reducing its effectiveness.
Mr. Deland and other Administration officials say the modification of environmental rules is a completely reasonable response to excessive regulations that are raising costs, choking businesses and interfering in the lives of ordinary citizens. Environmental leaders say the price that the nation will eventually pay for the President's deregulation drive is degraded lands and dirtier air and water.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The links between the environment and the economy become more sensitive in an election year. The Bush Administration is trying to ease a rule that has blocked logging on millions of acres of national forests. On Washington's Olympia Peninsula, trees have been clear-cut. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Suffolk Legislators to Vote On County Building Deal

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., April 27

 BODY:
Strapped for cash, Suffolk County is hoping to get a quick infusion of funds by selling its most prominent government building to a newly created public trust, which would then lease it back to the county.
While such a deal may sound like a one-shot gimmick, most Democrats and Republicans, as well as municipal-bond rating experts, say they can support the concept, which has been used at the state and county level from New York to California. 
 The sale-leaseback plan is the cornerstone of a finance bill proposed by the Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, to help fill a $78 million gap in the county's $1.3 billion budget for the current year. The County Legislature is to meet in special session on Tuesday afternoon to consider the measure. Mr. Gaffney, a Republican, expects it to win approval with the help of the Republican majority.
Under the plan, the county would sell the 12-story H. Lee Dennison Building, where Mr. Gaffney has his offices, for an estimated $25 million, then lease it back as the main tenant.
 
Renovations Needed
 Charles K. Stein, the deputy county executive for finance, said the transaction would not be a sale in a traditional sense, but "something like a glorified equity loan."
The county would set up an entity called a "grantor trust," which would sell tax-exempt bonds called certificates of participation to finance the purchase, he said. The county would then sign a lease with the trust, with payments equal to the debt service on the bonds. After 20 to 30 years, ownership would revert to the county.
Mr. Stein said the county was awaiting the results of an appraisal of the property, which he said needed some renovation work.
 
'Fingers Crossed'
 Tim Ryan, a spokesman for Mr. Gaffney, said today that the County Executive had received "several inquiries" from investors interested in the bond sale since Mr. Gaffney outlined the sale-lease idea in his first State of the County message in February. "We've got our fingers crossed that everything will go well when the Legislature votes on this," he said.
But not everyone favors the idea. William Greiner, president of the real-estate firm of Greiner-Maltz, said, "It's just another way of borrowing money and putting a building up for collateral."
He warned that "it will be expensive money," adding, "This can only mean an extra burden on the taxpayers in the long run, just to get some immediate dollars."
 
Credit Agencies Watching
 The Dennison building was named for Suffolk's first county executive. Itcost $16 million to build and opened in 1973. It now houses courtrooms, the offices of the District Attorney and County Executive and the departments of audit and control and economic development and planning.
Mr. Stein said that under Mr. Gaffney's plan, the health and social services departments would also move into the building, and the money they now pay for rent would be used to help pay off the bonds.
Mr. Gaffney hopes approval of the financial package will assure Wall Street that Suffolk bonds are a good investment. The major bond-rating agencies have placed Suffolk on their credit-watch list. Kenneth Kurtz, an assistant vice president at Moody's Investors Service, said today that Moody's would not revise its bond rating for Suffolk just because of the sale-leaseback arrangement.
"We would look at it not so much for being a sale-leaseback, but as a form of deficit financing, a way of getting some funds right now and borrowing to do it, but realizing that it will impose costs in the future," he said.
"A key element of our rating is the overall budget-balance plan," Mr. Kurtz said. "Deficit financing can be appropriate if reasonable and tied to other actions that restore an ongoing balance."
 
Sale of Attica
 Nassau, also pressed for revenue, is closely watching the outcome of the Dennison building proposal.
Similar sale-leaseback deals are being used in counties in California and Ohio, said Arthur J. Kremer, a senior partner in the law firm of Rivkin Radler & Kremer in Uniondale.
Mr. Kremer, a former Democratic Assemblyman from Long Beach, said the revenue-raising practice was also being used at the state level, including in New York. For example, he said, the state sold its correctional center at Attica to the state's Urban Development Corporation last year for $212 million, then leased it back.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Maytag's President To Add Chief's Title

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
The Maytag Corporation said yesterday that it would name Leonard A. Hadley chief executive at today's annual meeting, adding to his current responsibilities of president and chief operating officer. He will replace Daniel J. Krumm, 65 years old, who is retiring as chief executive but will remain chairman.
Mr. Hadley, 57, has spent 33 years with Maytag. He has shepherded the corporation through some tumultuous acquisitions, after heading a task force in the late 1970's to plan the company's long-term strategy. That panel recommended a series of acquisitions to overcome the slow growth Maytag was facing in a mature home appliance industry. 
 During the 1980's, Maytag scooped up the likes of Jenn-Air, Magic Chef and Hoover, bringing change to a conservative corporate culture that had been shaped through decades of narrowly focusing on laundry equipment and dish washers. "The acquisitions at the time, given the culture, were certainly big news," Mr. Hadley recalled in a telephone interview yesterday from the company's headquarters in Newton, Iowa.
Mr. Hadley will face stiff competition in the appliance business, an industry in which sales have declined each year since 1988 and lower prices have put pressure on profits.
Mr. Hadley is banking on several changes to improve the fortunes of Maytag, which last year earned $79 million on sales of $2.97 billion, down from profits of $98.9 million on sales of $3.05 billion in 1990. Its net income rose nearly 90 percent in the first quarter, to $28.5 million on sales of $753.2 million.
Mr. Hadley said demographic trends suggested that the company's sales of higher-priced, upscale models of dishwashers, ovens and other major appliances would increase in the future. The company is investing $160 million this year, in addition to $143 milllion last year, in new plants and other capital improvements to build new models.
Mr. Hadley said, however, that he had seen little of the rise in orders that would point to an improving economy. "It's better, but it's not thrilling," he said.
Mr. Hadley joined Maytag as a cost accountant in 1959 and held a series of financial posts before being named assistant controller in 1975. He was elected vice president of corporate planning in 1979, and president of the Maytag Company unit in 1986. He was promoted to executive vice president of the corporation in 1989, when he became head of the appliance group. He was named chief operating officer in March 1990, and was elected president and chief operating officer last year.
Mr. Hadley received an accounting degree from the University of Iowa in 1958. He and his wife, Corine, have a son and daughter, and live in Newton.

HEADLINE: Compaq Profit Fell 60.3% in Quarter

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: HOUSTON, April 27

 BODY:
The Compaq Computer Corporation said today that its first-quarter earnings fell 60.3 percent from a year ago, and blamed a price war in the computer business for the poor results.
The news surprised Wall Street, and Compaq's shares tumbled $3.375, to $23.75, in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 The Houston-based personal computer maker said it earned $45.3 million, or 53 cents a share, down from $114.3 million, or $1.26 a share, in the first quarter of 1991.
Compaq said lower prices for computer products were the primary reason for the drop in earnings.
"Our financial results for the remainder of the year will continue to be influenced by aggressive pricing and increased expenses," Eckhard Pfeiffer, the company's president and chief executive officer, said.
He cited an ambitious advertising schedule, the planned introduction of new products late in the second and third quarters, and expansion of distribution.
"We are unlikely to see the positive impact of our plans on earnings before the fourth quarter," Mr. Pfeiffer added.
First-quarter sales fell to $783 million, from $971 million a year earlier.
Personal computer makers have been engaged in a price war for the last year, which has hurt profitability as they have fought for buyers in a tough economy.
Eric Zimits, an analyst with William Woodruff & Company, said that even if Compaq's earnings improved in the fourth quarter, "It's not clear they'll have positive earnings year-to-year by then."
The company, known for putting out high-quality products, embarked on a new strategy last year when it laid off 1,400 workers, accepted the resignation of its president and founder Joseph (Rod) Canion and said it would begin offering lower-cost computers. But some analysts predict the company would have problems differentiating itself from its low-priced competitors.
Compaq, under the leadership of Mr. Pfeiffer, plans to introduce a new group of low-cost computers in June, backed by a $20 million advertising campaign.
Compaq is expected to benefit to some extent from its name, but perhaps not as much as was once predicted because "the value of a name brand in a PC system has diminished to the point where just matching price and features isn't necessarily going to put Compaq back in a leadership position," Mr. Zimits said.
That likelihood, combined with lower margins caused by the company's low-price strategy, means that Compaq is not likely to return to its days as a high-flying Wall Street darling with 30 percent earnings, said Brandy Brandon, a Duff & Phelps analyst.
"The dynamics of the industry just won't permit it," he said.

HEADLINE: The Downfall of a Merchant of the Old School

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
After R. H. Macy & Company filed for bankruptcy protection in January, Edward S. Finkelstein vowed repeatedly that he would remain at the helm of the big retailer during its climb out of bankruptcy. The way back promised to be a difficult couple of years, but only last week the 67-year-old Macy chairman sounded like his old ebullient, optimistic self.
In an interview with his favorite trade publication, Women's Wear Daily, Mr. Finkelstein delivered a relentlessly upbeat assessment. Macy's inventory levels, he explained, were about normal -- "right on plan" -- and the merchandise offerings were "much more current and fresh."
 
No Surprise to Analysts
 
 "We're entering a period of stability," he declared. "The bleeding has stopped."
But the bloodletting in the Macy executive suite had not. Yesterday's announcement that Mr. Finkelstein would step down immediately as chairman and chief executive of Macy came as no surprise to retailing analysts who doubted that he would be the best man to guide the troubled chain out of bankruptcy.
To be sure, in an earlier decade his imagination and flair had rejuvenated a dowdy department store that was an also-ran in San Francisco, and he had later sparked a revival at Herald Square in Manhattan.
"Ed Finkelstein is a brilliant department store merchant, but one of the old school," said Kurt Barnard, a consultant. "He's not a modern, high-tech manager. He had to go."
He was a master merchandiser, analysts agreed, but he was also an autocratic manager who too often ran Macy as a corporate fief, hidebound and insular. In the end, he was undone -- personally and professionally -- by his outmoded management style and a vision for expansion that turned the company into a debt-laden debacle.
To recover, Macy must get in line with some of the best department store retailers in America by aggressively adopting the modern retailing regimen of tighter financial and inventory controls, linked by computers, to improve efficiency and regain profitability. And Mr. Finkelstein seems a man from another era.
"The day of the merchant prince in retailing is rapidly drawing to a close," said Louis W. Stern, a marketing professor at the Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University.
Of course, Mr. Stern said, there are successful retail operations that have been controlled by a single personality guided by a marketing vision, with the most noteworthy example being Sam Walton and his Wal-Mart Stores Inc. But in a case like Wal-Mart, Mr. Stern noted, the success stories have come when a company harnessed the latest retailing technology to a shrewd marketing concept.
Despite the setbacks of recent years, Mr. Finkelstein had an extraordinary run of success for most of his 43-year career at Macy. Even his critics concede that to some degree the inbred corporate culture that prevented Macy management from spotting warning signals in later years was a byproduct of Mr. Finkelstein's long winning streak. The boss had been right in the past, so his judgment went unquestioned.
"He surrounded himself with yes-men and believed his own rhetoric," said Alan Millstein, editor of Fashion Network Report, a garment industry newsletter. "But he was insulated partly by his past successes."
Since he joined Macy in 1948, after earning an M.B.A. from Harvard, Mr. Finkelstein had showed a flair for marketing. In 1969, he was named president of Macy's California and quickly proceeded to overhaul the division's merchandising and image so its stores catered to a more affluent, stylish clientele. One innovation was establishing the basement of Macy's San Francisco store as "the Cellar," a cheery mart filled with the latest in housewares.
On the heels of his success in California, Mr. Finkelstein was appointed president of Macy's New York in 1974, where he engineered an even more impressive overhaul of the once-drab flagship store on 34th Street. Having shown his mettle with the retailer's showcase store, Mr. Finkelstein was named Macy chairman and chief executive in 1980.
But Mr. Finkelstein's sure hand deserted him during the 1980's, and Macy lost its way as much on Wall Street as on its sales floors. For it was Mr. Finkelstein's grand vision of a retailing empire built with acquisitions of prestige department stories like I. Magnin and Bullock's -- all backed with a mountain of debt -- that led to Macy's undoing.
Of course, the recession and the slump in consumer spending clearly magnified the problems at Macy. But the cash squeeze that pushed Macy into Chapter 11 bankruptcy earlier this year was the result of Mr. Finkelstein's overly ambitious strategy.
The $3.6 billion leveraged buyout in 1986, led by Mr. Finkelstein, placed a considerable debt burden on the company. Yet the larger mistake, according to analysts, was paying $1.1 billion for I. Magnin and Bullock's in 1988, sharply increasing Macy's debt burden just as the economy softened.
"That really stretched him too far," said Walter F. Loeb, a consultant and former Macy manager.
For his part, Mr. Finkelstein had a lucrative career at Macy, but not nearly as lucrative as it might have been had the 1986 buyout worked as planned, instead of collapsing into bankruptcy. The projected payoff for the $4.4 million Mr. Finkelstein personally invested in the buyout was as much as $375 million, if Macy had been sold to the public according to plan sometime in the 1990's.
Now, that bet is lost. Still, at $68 a share, the buyout price, Mr. Finkelstein received an estimated $9.75 million for his 143,460 shares in 1986. And for years, he was one of the highest-paid executives in retailing, making $1.1 million last year. He will be a consultant to Macy and he will presumably receive a severance payment as well.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Declines Abroad But Is Mostly Up in the U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar weakened abroad yesterday after the finance ministers of the world's industrialized nations called the Japanese yen undervalued, but it overcame much of the selling pressure and ended mostly higher in domestic trading.
Gold prices eased slightly. At the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery fetched $336.60 an ounce, off 30 cents from the previous session. At the Republic National Bank in New York, gold was later quoted at $336 an ounce, also off 30 cents from the same time in the previous session. 
 Currency brokers said the principal bit of news moving the market came late Sunday, when finance emissaries of the so-called Group of Seven industrialized nations meeting in Washington urged Japan to stimulate its economy and concluded that the yen's recent weakness was hurting Japan's trading partners.
A more expensive yen would make Japan's products more costly overseas, helping the competitiveness of rival producers.
 
Remains Lower Against the Yen
 The communique from the seven nations -- Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Germany, Japan and the United States -- initially pushed the dollar down around the world, as traders reasoned that the yen would rise, at least temporarily, in response. The dollar later rebounded against other currencies but still remained somewhat weaker relative to the yen.
Zlatko Glamuzina, a senior trader for the Banco di Sicilia's New York office, said that "the dollar did surprisingly well" for the first day after the announcement.
Currency traders said much of the dollar's resilience focused on the mark, despite significantly higher interest rates in Germany. They said the situation reflected investor unease over the stability of the German economy. The latest German crisis is a public employees' strike that has crippled public transportation in many German cities.
"People are concerned about the German economy in general," said John McCarthy, manager of foreign exchange trading at the New York branch of ABN-AMRO bank of the Netherlands. "The dollar is holding its own."
In Tokyo the dollar fell 1 yen to close at 133.65 yen. Later, in London it was quoted at 133.05 yen. By the time trading concluded in New York, the dollar fetched 132.85 yen, down from 134.45 yen late Friday.
In London the British pound rose to $1.7795, from $1.7715 late Friday. Later in New York the pound fetched $1.7775, slightly more expensive than its $1.7750 exchange rate late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, were: 1.6540 marks, up from 1.6500; 1.5235 Swiss franks, up from 1.5295; 1.1972 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1861; 5.5775 French francs, up from 5.5715, and 1,245.00 Italian lire, up from 1,241.25.

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Woody Hochswender

 BODY:

Fashionable Molecules
Close your eyes and breathe deeply. Think pretty thoughts. And have your credit card ready.
Origins, a new freestanding cosmetics store of Estee Lauder, officially opened for business yesterday at 402 West Broadway, at the corner of Spring Street. The shop features cosmetics for both "inner and outer beauty," in a setting with lots of marble, no tropical hardwoods. It represents a move by a major cosmetics company outside the traditional channels of retail sales, namely department stores, whose main-floor selling areas have become vaporized battlegrounds for consumer dollars. 
 None of that fragrance frenzy here. The best-selling of the Origins products, Estee Lauder executives said, are "Peace of Mind," a minty lotion applied to the temples, and "Open Mind," an orange-and-anise inhalation that is diffused in a room, like incense. Such inhalations will "rid your air of foul foes," according to a press release. "Within five minutes a normal-sized room is saturated with beneficial molecules."
There are also plant spirits, honey elixirs and "environmentally responsible accessories" (cotton T-shirts, vegetable-straw brushes, etc.) designed to promote "total well being."
And you don't even have to say "Om" or anything.
 
Designer Politics
 This is an election year. So for a video presentation shown last week to the Fashion Group International, an organization of executive women, several leading designers were asked two questions: What would you do if you were President? And what would you do to help the fashion business?
In the video, Geoffrey Beene said he would support more exposure of American designers overseas. Christian Francis Roth called for the building of a fashion industry center in New York, with a park where designers could lunch. Marc Jacobs said he would make Elizabeth Saltzman, a fashion editor at Vogue, First Lady.
While noting that the idea of being President was "totally foreign" to him, Isaac Mizrahi warmed to the subject. "If I were President, I would make my whole Cabinet women and all the senators women," Mr. Mizrahi said. As to improving the fashion economy, he said, "I would make the men print more money and give it out on the street. Wouldn't that encourage spending?"
In stores, he "would change the lighting entirely," he said. "It's always incredibly unpleasant.
"Smoking would be allowed, for sure. How do you decide to buy a $3,000 cashmere jacket without a smoke?"
Dial 1 (800) Mizrahi.
 
Fashion Follies
 The Fashion Group International is also planning to bring Seventh Avenue designers to the Broadway stage for "Fashion Follies," a musical performance at the St. James Theater on Nov. 9 as part of its annual Night of Stars fund-raiser.
The evening will incorporate more than a dozen musical numbers performed by stars and designers, with each act followed by a short vaudeville routine, like a dog or magic act, said Robert O'Rourke, who is the executive producer of the show.
A chorus of 50 nonprofessional dancers will be selected at an open call at the Supper Club, at 240 West 47th Street, on June 7, when employees of fashion businesses may sing and dance their hearts out.
 
A Harper's Hiring
 Harper's Bazaar is expected to announce today the appointment of Tonne Goodman, a former vice president of advertising at Calvin Klein, as a fashion director. Ms. Goodman would have the same title as Paul Cavaco, who was hired last week.

HEADLINE: Harlem Dance Troupe Knocks on Doors To Enlarge Audience

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
There will be more than one doctor in the house when Dance Theater of Harlem opens tonight in a two-week engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
The theater in fact will be full of doctors, and their friends and patients, in an event that marks a new development in the life of the Provident Clinical Society, a 92-year-old, Brooklyn-based professional organization for black physicians and dentists. In a departure from its usual fund-raising projects, the organization has bought out the theater for opening night. Dance Theater of Harlem's audience development task force, an innovative new marketing program, has struck again. 
 The Brooklyn season marks the company's first major New York engagement since 1990, when financial pressures led to a six-month layoff of personnel. Dance Theater has learned to exist in a lean new world, in part by reaching back to its social roots. Financially hard-pressed companies like Dance Theater have had to become corporate entities in order to survive, putting aside the kind of seat-of-the-pants administration that was adequate in more prosperous times. They have also had to forge new partnerships with the business world. Dance Theater, for example, has wooed and won new support from American Express, Philip Morris and New York Telephone.
But while the troupe has learned to behave like a corporate institution, it has also developed a marketing strategy that has the ring of down-home socializing. No one -- lawyers, churchgoers, schoolteachers, doctors and members of social clubs around the country -- is beyond the reach of the task force, a juggernaut under the gentle direction of Donna Walker-Collins, the company's young associate marketing director.
 
Results of a National Survey
 Arthur Mitchell, the director of the company, and Ms. Walker-Collins began in 1988 to explore the reason for the comparatively small attendance by blacks at the ballet. The following year, the company conducted a national audience survey and, after extensive talks with presenters of its national tour engagements, formed the task force.
Now, six months before an engagement in a new tour city or New York-area community, Ms. Walker-Collins visits the place and recruits church and social leaders and representatives of minority businesses -- Hispanic and Asian as well as black -- to form committees to get out the word about the company's impending engagement. "We open the doors and let people see what's going on at Dance Theater of Harlem," Mr. Mitchell said in a recent interview at the company's Harlem headquarters. "Mostly, people are told to go buy tickets. They're not asked to be involved."
Ms. Walker-Collins talks with the local sponsor or producer of the season as well as minority newspapers to get names of black leaders. "I only need two strong people to start with," she said. Eventually committees are established to work on public relations, marketing and fund raising and to connect with churches, schools, the local government and businesses.
 
Community Participation
 Committee members help develop projects that will involve the people they live and work with. In Brooklyn, a restaurant called Two Steps Down is displaying the ballet company's traveling photo exhibition and has made it possible for diners to fax ticket requests to the theater. One task-force member passed around a toe shoe at a service at her church, suggesting that congregation members put their hands inside the shoe and try to imagine the feel of it on a foot. She then urged them to go see the company perform. And Brooklyn Union Gas offered local businesses a challenge grant to raise money to buy tickets for schoolchildren to attend Dance Theater performances.
Some groups have even sponsored gifted but needy children for ballet classes at selected local schools. The children are spotted during the company's lecture-demonstrations, which include mini-performances with running commentary by a company member and time for young audience members to dance on stage. And, Mr. Mitchell said, the company is now able to offer those demonstrations in six languages, including Japanese. He talked of delighted audience response recently when the troupe was able to conduct the program in Spanish at Barcelona's ornate old Liceo theater.
Ideally, Ms. Walker-Collins said, the task-force approach can also help local sponsors and arts organizations to avoid duplication of marketing programs as they develop minority audiences. "Pacific Northwest Ballet had never heard of Links, a black women's charitable audience that raises money for the arts and education," Ms. Walker-Collins said of a Seattle-based troupe. "You get the Links involved and you're guaranteed a success. But you have to know about them."
Peter H. Hansen, Dance Theater's director of development and marketing, said that the program's success is reflected in larger group sales and increased attendance by minorities.
Mr. Mitchell said the company was healthier financially than it had been when he called the layoff of dancers and technical staff in 1990 to try to avoid a projected $1.7 million deficit after the cancellation of two tour engagements. The layoff attracted the attention of new friends, like the Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund, which awarded the company a $1 million stabilization grant in 1990. "We opened our books so that people could see the layoff was not because of mismanagement," Mr. Mitchell said. "Those were hard steps, but once you take them you find it's much easier to keep going."
The company has an annual budget of $6 million, which also covers expenses for its school. Its total deficit, accumulated, Mr. Mitchell said, over 23 years, is $700,000. "There are new words in my vocabulary now, like 'cautious,' " he said. He has learned to work with advisers, a new experience for him. And he said he was ready for what he feels may be the even harder economic times ahead for dance institutions.
If he is right, the company seems to have found some loyal new audiences through its task-force program. "We're trying to develop consistent audience members," Ms. Walker-Collins said. "We tell people we're just beginning. You can't simply tell them to go to a performance. They have to feel it in their bones."

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Within Child Welfare, A Tragedy of Neglect

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Tonight "Frontline" goes after Gov. Bill Clinton. "Who Cares About Children?," at 9 on Channels 13 and 49, relays charges that the Arkansas Governor and professed champion of children avoided doing much about the state's "inadequate and dangerous child welfare system" until he was forced to move by the threat of a class-action lawsuit. The program leaves the impression that political motives were behind both his years of inaction and his sudden support, after the New Hampshire primary, for increased financing.
"Who Cares About Children?" borrows its point of view from Mr. Clinton's critics, particularly William Grimm, a child-welfare attorney from San Francisco who was brought to Arkansas in 1990 to put pressure on the state. He is the hero of this hour. Set against the pictures of Mr. Grimm delivering impassioned pleas ("How many more children have to die in Arkansas before somebody does something?"), Mr. Clinton's statements seem unfeeling and glib. 
 The horror stories of inadequate foster care evidently come straight from those who brought the suit, and the interpretations of Mr. Clinton's actions come mainly from his critics. John Brummett, editor of The Arkansas Times, says: "He's a pure pragmatist, and he's looking for the things he can get done that will do him the most good."
It's a tendentious hour, but not an implausible one. Even if you are put off by the out-to-get-Clinton spirit, the examples of the workings, or nonworkings, of an overburdened child-welfare bureaucracy bring home conditions that go beyond Arkansas. The number of abused and neglected children doubled in the state in the 1980's. Social workers, everyone seems to agree, are undertrained, underpaid and underexperienced. Even the most conscientious foster parents may not be up to handling infants born addicted to drugs or infected with H.I.V. And for many children, foster care, which often involves frequent moves, leaves its mark in emotional deprivation and confusion.
The strong reports of hard cases make the charges of political calculation seem almost trivial. The Arkansas system may be no model for the nation, but where is the system that can repair the damage done to the youngest victims of family breakups, economic troubles and personal problems reflected here? The question viewers are left with is much bigger and tougher than whether Bill Clinton really cares enough about children.
 
'Listening to America With Bill Moyers'
Channels 13 and 49
Tonight at 10
For those who can stand more politics, "Frontline" is followed by another installment of Bill Moyers's series "Listening to America." On "Can We Govern?" Mr. Moyers talks with several politicians, including Senator Warren Rudman, the New Hampshire Republican who recently announced that he was leaving the Senate. The most interesting comments come from E. J. Dionne Jr. of The Washington Post, who is seen practicing journalism the old-fashioned way, listening and taking notes. The answer to the title question seems to be maybe or maybe not. To be continued next Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
The Unseen Candidates

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN

 BODY:
Plastic. That's what I couldn't help thinking last week as I watched Jerry Brown and Bill Clinton campaign for votes in the Pennsylvania primary being held today. Speeches, interviews, smiles, even policies: as glossy, polished and thin as plastic. No wonder millions say they prefer None of the Above to the Presidential candidates available this year.
But to talk to Bill Clinton and Jerry Brown is to recognize there is grit behind the gloss, weight behind the plastic. Governor Clinton is engaging and very smart indeed. He talks interestingly about shaping reform policies in a ferociously conservative state like Arkansas. Mr. Brown, grandiloquent and glib in public, is honestly, even relentlessly inquisitive in private. 
 Why do lively, thoughtful people come out looking like such stiffs? The very question offers a devastating comment on the election process.
Jerry Brown started out responsibly enough before a group of of unemployed Philadelphia residents. The audience, he said, had been victimized by corrupt Washington politics and the absence of a social contract -- the sense that Americans bear collective responsibility for the plight of their neighbors. His answer: a flat tax to break the political stranglehold of special interests and to provide a stronger safety net.
But after that, he slipped into demagogy and foolishness. Congress proved it was corrupt by bailing out banks rather than people. But Jerry Brown knows -- or should know -- that Congress bailed out ordinary depositors, not banks. Besides, Jerry Brown knows -- or should know -- that Congress can responsibly borrow virtually any amount to replenish bank accounts because such loans don't drain the economy as a whole.
Mr. Brown blamed low-wage Mexican workers for taking work from Pennsylvanians. Yet Jerry Brown knows -- or should know -- that low foreign wages alone don't explain American joblessness.
Afterward, however, in private, when asked to defend his flat tax against accusations that it would punish the poor, he puts rehearsed rhetoric aside. Rather than dismissing criticism, he delves into details and declares a willingness to modify his policies so they can better achieve his objectives. Jerry Brown in public is angry, desperate and glib. Jerry Brown in private sometimes verges on the profound.
Bill Clinton displays a similar divergence in personas. Talking to the press after a dutiful tour of a Philadelphia prenatal clinic, he pronounced some meaningless promises about health care reform. The presentation seemed almost a parody of his detailed and inventive policy proposals.
Indeed, the punishing campaign seems to have reduced him to a plastic version of the Bill Clinton who traveled around the country last fall, trim, energetic, bursting with ideas and enthusiasm. On the stump in Philadelphia, he came across hoarse, heavy and tired.
Only afterward was there a glimmer of his personable side. Most reporters had rushed off to the next campaign stop. Walking back to his car, Mr. Clinton came upon a young man who appeared afflicted by Down syndrome.
"What's your name?" Mr. Clinton gently asked, the plastic smile turned genuine. "Bill," the man said shyly. "Why, that's my name, too!" Mr. Clinton exclaimed, and struck up a warm conversation.
Intelligence, warmth, curiosity and ideas. They're there, sure enough. The shame is that voters don't get much chance to see, under the plastic.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
One Thing Missing

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: NORFOLK, Va.

 BODY:
Somebody is giving Ross Perot the wrong advice, most likely Ross Perot. It's running out of value for himself and for the country.
Mr. Perot wants to be President. Never mind the laid-back attitude. He wants it a lot, and sensibly he is using the two strongest tools he has. 
 One is lots of money. He made it himself and the Constitution guarantees him the right to use it for himself. Ross Perot's other tool is his own personality -- intelligent, successful, witty.
Put together, those two tools have helped rocket him up, up. Now he pushes the probable candidate of the Democratic Party in the polls. The experts are still saying he can never be elected President -- only not so loudly.
So if he has gone this far on his strategy, why is it wrong?
The answer is a compliment: He is not being true to himself or to the people who are reaching out to him.
The Perot campaign so far is based on a political recipe that, for a man of his admiring vision of himself and his country, is unbecoming and unworthy.
Recipe: Give voters the right straight-shooter personality. Display it often enough on TV. Feed in distrust of all elected officeholders and the political-economic system that made you successful. Mix with high-tech phone banks and commonsensical two-liners.
Do all that and voters won't push you too hard to show that you can put your mind where your mouth is.
One reason Mr. Perot has been getting away with it is that President Bush has disappointed so many who once voted for him. So bitter is their disappointment that they are willing to switch to a man who not only has never been in government but will not say exactly what he will do if he ever gets there. If ever there was a devastating verdict on Mr. Bush's performance, the Perot rocket is it.
And, of course, Mr. Perot profits by the goring of Bill Clinton -- by Bill Clinton, the press and Democratic back-stabbers who can't forgive him for having the courage to run when so many hotshot Democratic politicians suddenly found safer things to do.
Given his own abilities and the American love for the underdog, Mr. Clinton and his wife may stroll in the Rose Garden. Counting him out is ridiculous and manipulative.
But like Mr. Perot, Bill Clinton will need the votes of Americans who voted for George Bush once, but will not twice. So at least the President has the comfort of knowing that a vote for Perot is one vote less for Bill Clinton.
But if Mr. Perot is to get the votes, he will have to give us what he demands for himself -- respect. In politics that means clarity of intention.
For starters, I want to know about Mr. Perot's drug-fighting plan. He says he has one, that it won't be pretty, but that it will work and be within the Constitution.
I'm sorry for addicts, but sorrier for their victims -- crack babies, patients infected with diseased blood, passers-by shot in streets, children packing guns at 9, dead at 12.
A national horror. The only reason I can think of for Mr. Perot to conceal his drug plan is that it will be criticized. Fighting drugs demands a commitment of money but also of intellectual endeavor. Any decent plan has to take in not only law enforcement but therapy enforcement.
A Perot drug plan will be examined and criticized -- no question. All the more reason for him to bring out the drug plan now, and any other specific ideas he has to deal with crime, budget, defense, jobs, housing and Saddam Hussein.
Yes, every plan will be examined critically by citizens, legislators, judges and bureaucrats. Isn't that what the Constitution is about, something called balance of power?
Isn't that the stove that gives off the heat in the White House kitchen?
And isn't it time Ross Perot showed us if he could stand getting his hands warm?
"Ross, I have a plan right here in my briefcase -- how to double your company's profits and make all your employees live longer too."
"Legal?"
"Hundred percent."
"Let's see it."
"What? Now? Oh, no -- not until you promise to bring me into the company and make me chairman and chief executive officer."
Come on. How long will a man with so much respect for himself and country keep using a sales pitch for which he would boot anybody out of his office, right straight out?

HEADLINE: Our Economy Needs Japan's Investments

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"When the Japanese stock market plummeted 10 percent," you write in "False Fears About Japan's Crash" (editorial, April 10), "fear struck Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged nearly 100 points in two days and Americans wondered whether Main Street would be next." You then go a long way toward dispelling the Chicken Little dialogue heard in international financial circles. "Stock market crashes can be traumatic," you conclude, but "they don't need to be economically crippling."
Unfortunately, you miss the mark on the fundamental impact that the deflating of the bubble economy has on global prosperity. 
 In the last year, Japanese banks have reduced their deposits with United States financial institutions by approximately $35 billion. They have also decreased their participation in Treasury auctions from 40 percent of total sales to less than 10 percent. Beyond that, incremental corporate lending has all but ceased, and so has direct investment.
This pullback of liquidity is driven by the distortions caused in bank balance sheets by the decline in Japanese stock and real estate values.
What complicates it is that the United States runs a trade deficit with Japan of more than $4 billion a month. This outflow of cash must be recycled back into the United States economy. If the Japanese are unable to put investment back in, the United States recession will be increasingly difficult to bring to an end and could, in concert with other developments, even evolve into full-scale depression.
It just may be that the sky really is falling. Slowly, but falling nonetheless.
 
RICHARD PHILLIPS
New York, April 10, 1992

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
Lack of Party Discipline Makes Contest Untidy

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, April 27

 BODY:
Back in the Pleistocene era of American politics, which ended about the same time the Vietnam War heated up, there was something called party discipline. It gave a phrase to the language: either "toe the party line," they said, or get in trouble with its elders.
With the popular rebellion against the fighting in Vietnam and the attendant changes in social values, insurgency became a more or less permanent political condition, especially in the Democratic Party. Big-city bosses and ward heelers passed from the scene. Congressional and legislative leaders lost their clout. Smoke-filled rooms were replaced by primary elections. 
 Now there is no party line, no party discipline and no party elders (or, to be more accurate, none that anyone pays much attention to).
Which is one reason why the contest for the 1992 Democratic Presidential nomination is so untidy, and one reason it is likely to remain so after Tuesday's Pennsylvania primary.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas seems sure to win here, and to keep winning, except perhaps in California. His lone active rival, former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, sounded today as if even he knew the game was up. After the Pennsylvania votes have been counted, 7 of the 10 biggest delegations to the Democratic convention will have been chosen, with the other three -- from California, Ohio and New Jersey -- to be picked on or before June 2.
It is becoming almost impossible to find knowledgeable politicians who doubt that Mr. Clinton will be nominated. Yet there are plenty who talk wistfully about an open convention, who savage Mr. Clinton's record or his character and question his electability, who fantasize about what might have been -- all of which contributes to the impression of party disarray.
Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania is not alone in hesitating to endorse Mr. Clinton and to urge party unity against the Republicans, although he has been much more explicit and outspoken than most in his criticism. The Democratic governors of three other big states already won by Mr. Clinton have also held back: Mario M. Cuomo of New York, Ann W. Richards of Texas and Lawton Chiles of Florida. So have dozens of prominent Congressional Democrats. And so have Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, two of Mr. Clinton's vanquished rivals.
Only Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, a man from an older tradition, swallowed his pride after his early withdrawal from the race, endorsed Mr. Clinton and took to the road to solicit votes for his erstwhile adversary. For his pains, he has been denounced as a hypocrite by Mr. Brown.
One major reason for the party's tardiness in rallying around its presumptive standard-bearer, obviously, are the questions raised about Mr. Clinton's private life, his financial dealings and his draft status during the Vietnam War, and what those questions have done to his chances of defeating President Bush in November. As one Senator put it, "This is more than we're usually asked to swallow in the name of party unity, so it takes awhile."
But a larger reason, perhaps, is the lack of party discipline. It is every man or woman for himself or herself in American politics these days, and there are no real sanctions anyone can take against the naysayers.
Of course, those who hope for preferment in a Clinton Administration, through a judicial nomination or a Cabinet or sub-Cabinet position or an ambassadorship, will not be likely to hesitate. But since relatively few Democratic politicians seem to believe at the moment that Mr. Clinton can win, the loss of a potential political plum is not that much of a deterrent.
Once upon a time, a Jim Farley or a John M. Bailey would have come down hard on those who refused to play ball. But Democratic national chairmen no longer have that kind of power; Ronald M. Brown, the current one, feels he has to be extremely careful even in suggesting that the time may be at hand for the party to turn its attention to combating Mr. Bush in the fall.
What he says in his private phone calls may be another matter, but in public Mr. Brown is not willing to go much beyond the comment that an open convention "means a death-knell fight at the convention with a lot of Democratic blood on the floor, which I don't think is going to help us."
On the NBC News program "Meet the Press" on Sunday, Ronald Brown complained about "this search for a knight in shining armor," insisting that "there is none." But when he was asked directly whether Jerry Brown should fold his tent if he loses in Pennsylvania, the chairman begged off with the comment, "That's a question for him to answer, not for me to answer."
There is no cost to the individual politicians who continue to resist the all but inevitable. But there is clearly a cost to the party as a whole and its fragile hopes of winning the White House for only the second time since 1964. With a wounded incumbent and an economy still struggling toward recovery, the Democrats describe themselves as hell-bent on victory.
Their behavior so far suggests they don't really mean it.
