HEADLINE: Confirming Split, Last 2 Republics Proclaim a Small New Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 27

 BODY:
Serbia and Montenegro today proclaimed the establishment of a new, truncated Yugoslav nation shorn of the four republics that have seceded over the last 10 months. The move amounted to a confirmation of the breakup of the old Communist Yugoslavia and an implicit acceptance of the independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina within its existing borders.
The decision to proclaim a new Yugoslavia was rushed through in a subdued, almost regretful, ceremony of less than 10 minutes, reflecting the discomfort of people acting to accommodate demands from Europe and the United States. 
 In finally acknowledging the demise of the Yugoslavia that had existed since 1946 and proclaiming a nation with less than half its area and with a population of 10.5 million compared with 23.5 million, the leaders of Serbia, dominant partners in the new nation, were effectively seeking to evade or forestall growing pressures for Serbia's international isolation.
In the Constitution for the new Yugoslavia proclaimed today, its leaders declared the borders to be those of Serbia and Montenegro as they existed in the Communist Yugoslavia established by Tito after World War II. In an accompanying declaration, the leaders said the new nation, to be called the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia like its Communist predecessor, "has no territorial claims" on neighboring republics.
Diplomats said this amounted to a renunciation of the claim made in the past by Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian President, and by other Serbian nationalists that all Serbs in the old Yugoslavia had the right to be included in a single state that others called "a Greater Serbia."
The significance of this appeared to extend not only to Bosnia and Herzegovina, whose 1.7 million Serbs are the largest Serbian group outside Serbia, but also to the three other republics that have seceded: Croatia, Slovenia and Macedonia. Serbia fought a war on behalf of Croatia's 580,000 Serbs last year similar to the one in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
The pressures on Belgrade to give such assurances, led by the United States and the European Community, intensified last week after Serbia gave its backing to a military offensive in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
 
Offensive Kills 200
 The offensive, in which a dozen or so towns were captured, killed at least 200 people and forced tens of thousands of Muslim Slavs and Croats to leave their homes. It also raised fears that Serbia would eventually annex the captured territories or seek to partition Bosnia and Herzegovina by recognizing a separate Serbian republic there.
The decisions announced here today created new optimism among the Muslim Slavs and Croats in Bosnia and Herzegovina, who approved the republic's independence in a vote eight weeks ago. The vote was boycotted by the republic's Serbs, who account for about 30 percent of the population.
The proclamation of the new Yugoslav nation and its renunciation of territorial claims served as a signal for the new Government in Bosnia and Herzegovina to renew pressures for removing 10,000 Yugoslav Army troops who have been garrisoned there.
Tonight, a statement from the Bosnia and Herzegovina presidency, issued on behalf of the Muslim Slav and Croatian leaders, formally demanded the withdrawal of the army from the republic, and said that those Yugoslav troops who wished to remain should join the republic's newly established territorial defense force.
 
Another Cease-Fire Broken
 But the statement had hardly been read over the radio in Sarajevo, the capital, before Serbian forces in the suburb of Ilidza responded with a barrage of recoilless cannon and machine-gun fire that appeared to be the most serious breach yet of the cease-fire that was agreed between the rival forces last week.
At the weekend, as part of its moves to ease Western pressures for its diplomatic isolation, Serbia dispatched the acting Yugoslav Defense Minister, Gen. Blagoje Adzic, to open negotiations on the army's presence in Bosnia and Herzegovina with the Alija Izetbegovic, a Muslim Slav who is the republic's President. But in a seeming effort to allay the concerns of the republic's Serbs, the army commander in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Col. Gen. Milutin Kukunjac, a Serb, told reporters in Sarajevo today that while the army might pull out of "certain areas," it would remain in Bosnia as "the army of the people who accept us." This appeared to imply that the army would remain in areas of Serbian population.
The declaration accompanying the new Constitution included other gestures toward Western governments, among them a pledge that the new nation would abide by the principle of "not using force to settle open questions."
The declaration also said that Yugoslavia, in its new form, would be a democracy based on respect for human rights and on the principles of a "market economy." Further, it pledged to negotiate with the four breakaway republics on all "open questions," including the division of the old Yugoslavia's assets, through the European Community's Conference on Yugoslavia.
Many Serbs who attended today's ceremony at the copper-domed parliament building were subdued, and their spirits seemed unimproved by efforts to foster a spirit of celebration. Few joined in when a choir of women in white robes sang "Hey Slavs!" the anthem of the old Yugoslavia and of the new one, and only a small crowd gathered outside to watch the raising of the new flag, the same tricolor of red, white and blue that was flown by Communist Yugoslavia, minus the red star at the center.
Some of those present saw the new nation as a poor relation to the two previous ones: the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes, which lasted from 1918 until the Nazi invasion in 1941, and Tito's republic, which covered 98,765 square miles, more than double the 39,380 square miles of the new state.
"I was born in one Yugoslavia, grew up in another, and now I'm a citizen of a third, and it is the smallest of the three," a woman said at the ceremony.

HEADLINE: 'Baby Bell' Layoffs Due

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, April 27

 BODY:
The Bell Atlantic Corporation said today that it might have to slash its work force by up to 6,000 workers to cut costs because of increased competition and the recession.
The Philadelphia-based telecommunications giant, whose units include regional telephone companies in mid-Atlantic states, said any cutbacks would occur through early-retirement incentives. 
 "If we determine we have to further downsize, we will make sure it is by a voluntary effort," said Larry Plumb, a spokesman.
He said Bell Atlantic was still recovering from the recession, unlike companies in other industries that were pulling out faster.
Initial company estimates are for cuts of 4,000 to 6,000 nonmanagement workers, or about 5 to 8 percent. But Mr. Plumb said that the figures were preliminary and that the company was still discussing the possibility of cutbacks with union officials.
Contracts with the Communication Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers expire in August. Together, the unions represent 52,000 of the company's 75,700 nonmanagement workers.
Last summer, Bell Atlantic offered incentives for up to 3,500 management workers to retire before year-end; the company said 3,200 took the offer. Bell Atlantic now has about 17,000 management workers.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 2, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A headline in Business Day on Tuesday about possible staff reductions at the Bell Atlantic Corporation misstated the way in which they would be made. Any cutbacks would occur through early-retirement incentives, not through layoffs.

HEADLINE: Coup in Peru a Blow to Its Copper

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TACNA, Peru

 BODY:
Democracy may not be the only victim of the upheaval in Peru.
 About six months ago, Charles G. Preble, the president of Peru's largest private company, announced a $300 million investment in new projects -- by far the largest foreign investment in years in Peru -- and said he was considering spending an additional $150 million. 
But he had one big worry: He was not certain international banks would be willing to lend up to $150 million to finance the projects. After all, Peru is considered a high-risk country for business, mainly because of its persistent terrorist activity.
 Now, Mr. Preble's worst fears have been borne out. With this month's seizure of near-dictatorial power by President Alberto K. Fujimori, about $200 million in capital has already fled the country, presumably for the United States and Europe, according to Peruvian Government officials.
 Financing for Mr. Preble's Southern Peru Copper -- which is owned mostly by Asarco Inc., the big American mining company -- and a host of other private projects seems increasingly remote. International businessmen who have been looking at Peru as one of the real long shots of Latin American development, worry that the coup has set back their plans months, perhaps years.
 Moreover, as the United States puts pressure on its allies and world lending organizations like the Inter-American Development Bank to withhold economic aid to Peru, the future of the country's recovery has a large question mark over it.
 Such uncertainty could be nearly disastrous. There are few countries in Latin America where foreign investment and international assistance is more critical for lifting the economy. Though a nation of 22 million people with an abundance of natural resources, Peru's development is minimal and the country's ability to generate earnings from exports is nearly paralyzed.
 Indeed, about the only sure flow of funds come from illegal drug trading, which experts estimate brings more than $1 billion a month into Peru's banking system. The money is a two-edged sword: It keeps the monetary system remarkably liquid but by overvaluing the local currency; it also makes the cost of living in Peru among the highest in Latin America and its exports uncompetitive.
 What executives fear the most is that since the coup was illegal under the country's 1979 Constitution, any contracts or agreements with his Government could be subject to nullification if Mr. Fujimori is forced out of office.
 
No Clear Title?
 "Under the Peruvian Constitution, this Government has no legitimacy," said one foreign businessman in Lima, who insisted on anonymity. "So who is going to invest? You don't build a house on a piece of land if you don't have clear title."
 Despite the gloom, however, not everyone thinks Mr. Fujimori's power grab is bad for business. Especially among local executives, optimism is high. As an example, a few days after the coup a group of local businessmen invited Mr. Fujimori to give a major address to the country from their organization's headquarters. Many say they feel the problems of the country, a corrupt legal system and failure to stop terrorism, were so entrenched that a strong authoritarian hand was the only way out.
 That sentiment is significantly buttressed by the overwhelming support of the Peruvian people so far, which gives Mr. Fujimori 75 to 90 percent approval ratings.
 "The people here have been so upbeat over the past week," said Iric R. Ivey, manager of Southern Peru's copper smelter, which is about 100 miles north of here in the city of Ilo. Mr. Ivey, like other American businessmen working in Peru, is guarded on his personal feelings about the power seizure. But among Peruvian business executives and workers, "there's a sense that things are changing, that corruption will be dealt with," he said.
 "It's very upbeat," he added. "Only time will tell."
 
Opening Before Coup
 What encouraged these investors is that before the April 5 coup, Mr. Fujimori had been showing a remarkable willingness to open Peru to the world's markets. Through a series of free market and austerity measures he had brought inflation down to 139.2 percent in 1991 from the hyperinflation rate of 7,650 percent in 1990, by, among other things, removing price-support subsidies, easing tariff barriers and cutting Government spending.
 He deregulated the country's ports, liberalized labor laws and permitted free currency exchange so businesses could send profits back to their home countries. And he announced a privatization program for more than 40 large state-owned companies.
 The response from businessmen was beginning to pick up. Besides Southern Peru's plans for up to $450 million in investment, Occidental Petroleum agreed to spend $60 million on oil exploration, and Argentine and Chilean companies were snapping up brewing and construction companies. Besides Asarco, Southern Peru Copper's ownership includes Newmont Mining, Phelps Dodge and the Pritzker family of Chicago.
 Mr. Fujimori has promised to continue such free-market policies and honor all Government commitments. Many here believe he will.
 Officials at Southern Peru Copper, which had revenues last year of $650 million, say they have no plans to halt any of the projects they agreed to in November. In fact, they note that under the investment program they hope to increase their profitability significantly.
 In their huge open-pit copper mines, in Cuajone and Toquepala, some 150 miles north of here, the company plans two secondary recovery operations, costing up to $80 million, using a leaching process that extracts copper from rock that is often wasted in traditional mining. The projects will increase production at both mines by a total of 15 percent, and raise Peru's total cooper output by 9 percent.
 The company has also agreed to a five-year, $100 million investment in new equipment, a much higher rate than in recent years.
 And it has agreed to spend up to $120 million on three pollution-control projects, the most expensive of which will capture up to 15 percent of the 600,000 tons of sulfuric acid that its Ilo copper smelter belches into the atmosphere every year.
 Company officials say privately they would also consider buying Peru's state-owned copper refinery in Ilo, which has an estimated value of about $80 million, and might buy another mining property. Buying the refinery could cut copper production costs significantly, since under an agreement with the Government, Southern Peru Copper must keep the refinery operating at full capacity and, under Peruvian law, pay almost double the going world rate for raw copper.
 Such good-citizen concessions, which in its 35-year history have made often the company a marginally profitable business, are receding only slowly. Indeed, in Tacna, the anti-gringo sentiment is still high, reflecting the traditional leftist politics of this part of the country.
 Still, there is plenty of good will Southern Peru Copper can draw upon, particularly from its 5,000 workers and their 20,000 dependents. Recent surveys have found that 75 percent of the residents do not like the presence of this American corporate giant, dubbed by some as the "gringo octopus," but almost all concede that they want to work for it.
 No wonder. The 5,000 workers and their 20,000 dependents get free housing, education, electricity, water, medical care and food in the mining camps and in the smelter town of Ilo -- services the vast majority of Peru's workers live without all their lives. The company also subsidizes college education for children of its workers. A tour through both Cuajone and Toquepala found them to be more like modern rural United States towns, with manicured lawns, clean buildings and streets. The hospital in Cuajone is considered perhaps the most modern in Peru.
 So far Southern Peru has been able to avoid the lash of terrorism that companies in other parts of the country have suffered. The Maoist Shining Path terrorist group has operated mostly in the Lima area and in the highlands region.
 But there have been signs of some terrorist infiltration in recent months. Shining Path literature has been found in Ilo, and Shining Path cells are rumored to be here in Tacna. That has made the company tighten its security measures even more.

HEADLINE: BUSH IS EXTENDING REGULATION FREEZE AS A GREAT SUCCESS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM with KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
In some cases, for better or worse, the Bush Administration has really cut red tape in the last three months with its 90-day moratorium on new Federal regulations and its review of existing rules. In other cases, the red tape has merely been fluttered by political hot air.
In any event, President Bush regards the examination of regulations that he announced in his State of the Union Message to have been a rousing success. On Wednesday, with the fanfare of a speech in the White House Rose Garden, the President is to announce that the moratorium and review will be extended for at least another several months. 
 For Mr. Bush, this represents a full-circle turnabout.
As Vice President, he headed a Reagan Administration team devoted to weeding out regulations, many of which had been imposed when Jimmy Carter was in the White House.
 
Regulatory Growth
 But in the first three years of his Presidency, Mr. Bush was anything but hawk-eyed against Government rules. He proposed and signed many laws that added to the regulatory burden on business, including the Clean Air Act of 1990, the Americans With Disabilities Act and measures in diverse fields like airplane noise, oil spills, bank and savings and loan lending practices, food labeling and tax policy.
By the end of last year, according to the Government's own count, the number of new Federal rules under consideration had risen to nearly 4,900 from about 4,000 in President Ronald Reagan's two terms. The number of people writing regulations, as calculated by the Center for the Study of American Business at Washington University in St. Louis, had grown to 122,000, the most ever.
National Journal, a nonpartisan weekly magazine aimed at readers who want detailed coverage of the Government, ran an article last fall calling Mr. Bush The Regulatory President.
But at the outset of this election year, with the economy flagging, the business community demanding relief and the right wing of the Republican Party challenging his ways, President Bush reversed course. As befits a President running for re-election on the theme that the country needs change, he became a born-again deregulator.
In his State of the Union Message on Jan. 28, Mr. Bush promised a "top-to-bottom review of all regulations, old and new, to stop the ones that will hurt growth and speed up those that will help growth."
Much of the effect so far has been felt in environmental rules. For instance, the Administration halted for 80 days the identifying of rare plants and animals under the Endangered Species Act, delayed rules to carry out the Clean Air Act, restricted the ability of environmentalists to block logging in national forests, and limited the liability of banks and other lenders for the cost of cleaning up toxic waste.
 
Other Affected Areas
 These other areas have also been affected:
*The Labor Department delayed rules it was drafting to protect the safety and health of workers by limiting their exposure to chemicals and other toxic substances sometimes used in manufacturing, agriculture and construction.
*The Federal Communications Commission more than doubled the number of radio stations a single company can own, from 12 AM and 12 FM stations to 30 of each.
*Several agencies have proposed relaxing biotechnology safety rules for testing and producing living genetically altered organisms.
*The Consumer Product Safety Commission killed proposed regulations that would have required certain toys designed for small children to be labeled "choking hazards."
*The Securities and Exchange Commission has made it easier for small companies to sell stock and for mutual funds to invest in new, small companies.
*The Food and Drug Administration speeded up its testing of new drugs for safety and effectiveness and postponed deadlines for food processors to put nutritional labeling on products.
*The Federal Reserve began preparing to lift some barriers between large banking companies and their securities affiliates.
 
Effects of Moratorium
 Most of this could have happened anyway, without the hoopla of a moratorium. The White House and the Office of Management and Budget have always had the authority to review regulations imposed by the departments and agencies. A senior Senate staff assistant who was assigned by his boss to review what had happened in the last 90 days came away baffled.
"The problem with the moratorium is that it is impossible to tell what it has done," the staff expert said. "The Federal river is awfully wide, and saying that such-and-such happened or didn't happen because of the moratorium, you just can't be sure."
But Murray L. Weidenbaum, who heads the business study center at Washington University and who was instrumental in abolishing regulations as chairman of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, said the steps taken by the Bush Administration "must be having some effect, given all the howling."
Top officials in the Bush Administration say the effect has indeed been widespread. Vice President Dan Quayle, who is heading the President's Council on Competitiveness, said this month that $10 billion to $20 billion a year had already been saved by scotching costly and unnecessary rules.
In an interview today, Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers and a coordinator of the review process, said, "In this 90-day period alone, dozens of regulatory reforms and initiatives were taken that removed unnecessary obstacles to business expansion and job creation."
The Administration's critics in Congress and in various interest groups around Washington dispute those assertions. Representative John D. Dingell, the influential Michigan Democrat who heads the Energy and Commerce Committee and staunchly defends the automobile industry against expensive environmental rules, contends that the Administration has "done little but cause a great proliferation of litigation and cause the making of rules and regulations to move from Government administrative agencies to the courts."
And an Administration expert who is sympathetic to the goal of quashing rules said he was nonetheless skeptical of success. "You will never find an agency killing a regulation," he said.
Groups like Public Citizen, which is affiliated with Ralph Nader, and O.M.B. Watch, which is normally critical of Republican Administrations, maintain that the softening of environmental, health and safety rules will lead to illness, injury and even death.
But while Mr. Dingell says the public will "quickly figure out that all this is a gimmick," the Administration clearly believes it is getting political mileage out of the deregulation issue.
In part that is true because regulations really do cost the economy a great deal. The Environmental Protection Agency estimates that complying with its rules will cost business $140 billion this year, three times what it cost 10 years ago.
It is also true because public mistrust of Government has become so prevalent. White House officials have been spreading around a poll taken last month by Penn & Schoen Associates showing that more than 80 percent of Americans believe the Government has too many unnecessary regulations.
In the Administration's view, the months ahead are more important than the last 90 days.
Administration officials said that in his Rose Garden speech on Wednesday, the President would describe in some detail what he calls the unintended consequences and hidden tax on the economy from excessive regulation.
"The 90-day moratorium, in the scheme of things, is not nearly as important as what will happen over the next 90 days," said Richard Morgenstern, acting assistant administrator for policy at the environmental agency.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primary;
CLINTON AND BUSH PREVAIL IN PENNSYLVANIA PRIMARIES; FEMINIST IS SENATE NOMINEE

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, April 29

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton kept rolling toward the Democratic nomination Tuesday with a commanding victory in the Pennsylvania primary, reinforcing his dominance over former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.
With 96 percent of the precincts reporting, Mr. Clinton had 57 percent of the vote, Mr. Brown had 26 percent and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas, who withdrew from the race last month, had 13 percent. 
 On the Republican side, with 99 percent of the precincts reporting, President Bush continued his sweep of the primaries, with 77 percent of the vote to Patrick J. Buchanan's 23 percent. The Bush campaign asserted that the President had gone over the top in the delegates needed to secure the nomination, although a compilation by The New York Times showed him a few delegates short.
 
Strong Words From Bush
 Still, the voting in Pennsylvania only underscored the new phase of the campaign, in which Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush begin to take each other's measure -- while keeping a wary eye on Ross Perot, the Texas businessman considering an independent campaign for the Presidency. Mr. Clinton's big victory means that he can keep his focus on Mr. Bush instead of Mr. Brown. The President tried to signal Tuesday that he was ready for the Governor from Arkansas.
"I'll be damned if I'm going to roll over for a lot of these outrageous charges that are coming out of the opposition day in and day out," Mr. Bush told his campaign workers in Washington. "We don't have to take that."
 
More Than 33% Turn Out
 About 850,000 people voted in the Republican primary Tuesday, just more than a third of registered party members in the state; about 1.2 million people voted in the Democratic primary, roughly 45 percent of registered party members. The combined total was a quarter of the state's voting age population, according to Voter Research and Surveys.
A survey of voters leaving the polling places suggested that in Pennsylvania Mr. Clinton had eased some of the doubts about his character that had haunted him in other states. About 6 in 10 Democratic primary voters here said he had the honesty and integrity to be an effective President, considerably higher than the proportion that felt that way in recent primaries in Connecticut, New York and Wisconsin.
"All I know is in Pennsylvania we ran a strong campaign based on change," Mr. Clinton said Tuesday. "I got back to what drove me into this campaign last October. I talked to people about their problems and their future."
Mr. Clinton's allies were hoping that the magnitude of Tuesday's victory would silence some of the grumbling in the party. Many Democrats have publicly worried about the strength of a Clinton candidacy this fall, and Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania spent much of the past week criticizing his party's presumed nominee and arguing the case for an open convention at which other candidates could emerge.
 
'Irrelevant to the Process'
 But Ann F. Lewis, a Democratic strategist, said Tuesday, "I would say by now, those kinds of naysayers are irrelevant to the process."
James Carville, a top strategist for Mr. Clinton, suggested that the elected officials and party leaders who are superdelegates at the national convention, a critical bloc, would recognize the political reality.
Alluding to an earlier body of political wisdom, Mr. Carville said: "Mr. Dooley says the first thing the Supreme Court does is read the election returns. I suspect the superdelegates do the same thing."
A compilation by The New York Times showed that Mr. Clinton gained 110 delegates Tuesday, putting his total at 1,436. Mr. Brown gained 52 and rose to a total of 329, while Mr. Tsongas gained 7 and rose to 530. A total of 2,145 are needed to secure the nomination.
On the Republican side, The Times showed Mr. Bush with 1,092 delegates, just short of the 1,105 needed to nominate. Mr. Buchanan had 56. Despite the early scares from Mr. Buchanan, Mr. Bush has long seemed to have a lock on the nomination and securing a majority of the delegates has long seemed only a matter of time.
Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said tonight, "I cannot imagine a set of circumstances that would keep Bill Clinton from having a majority of the delegates by the end of the primary season, based on his performance today." Mr. Brown added that he had long hoped for an early nominee "so we can focus our time and attention on George Bush."
The feeling was mutual. Mr. Bush visited his campaign headquarters in Washington on Tuesday, telling his workers that he had held his fire so far but was looking foward to the coming battle with the Democrats. Mr. Bush, whose 1988 campaign was widely criticized for its slashing attacks on Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee, promised a "gloves off" campaign that would, nevertheless, be conducted "with a certain sense of honor, a certain sense of decency, a certain compassion and a certain caring."
Perhaps more to the point, the White House was filled with cautious talk about improvements in the economy, the dominant issue of the campaign. With new figures showing that the economy expanded at a 2 percent annual rate in the first quarter, Mr. Bush told reporters on Tuesday, "I think most people would say that a 2 percent growth is not recessionary."
He added, "There are some areas that are still hurting, but clearly this is a good sign, and there are a lot of other good signs."
The returns Tuesday were grim for former Governor Brown of California, who already seems, in recent speeches, to be transforming his campaign for the nomination into a crusade for political change with a life beyond the convention in New York. Still, many Democrats think he will stay in the race through the June 2 California primary.
Phil Angelides, the chairman of the California Democratic Party, argued, "He's got everything to gain and nothing to lose in terms of increasing his delegate count and therefore his voice at the convention."
Mr. Brown asserted at a news conference in Indianapolis that his showing in Pennsylvania, while not a victory, represented "a powerful constituency." The former Governor said he would stay in the race until the Democratic convention.
The polls Tuesday showed Mr. Clinton running well across the board, even with some voting groups that had proven less supportive of him in the past, including Roman Catholics. He carried more than half of the white vote over all, 7 in 10 of the black voters and 6 in 10 of the union households.
Some analysts said his strength reflected a simple fact of life: For the first time in a very long time, Mr. Clinton was not facing a barrage of character questions. "He still has a long way to go," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker, "but he's got the chance to run the kind of campaign he needs to run. He got that chance in Pennsylvania; he wasn't fending off a new charge every day."
Pennsylvania, in fact, was a remarkably quiet primary, particularly after the clamorous two weeks between the ones in Connecticut, where Mr. Brown won an upset victory, and New York. Mr. Clinton, after winning New York, tried to use the Pennsylvania campaign to begin sounding like a potential President, focusing his fire on Mr. Bush instead of Mr. Brown.
"I thought it was my sort of state and mostly my sort of campaign," Mr. Clinton said Tuesday. "I like issues and people problems and trying to solve problems and getting things done."
Still, there were signs of lingering problems. Almost 4 in 10 of Mr. Clinton's voters said they strongly favored him, the survey polls showed, but nearly half of his voters said they liked him with reservations. More than half of the Democratic voters said they were not satisfied with their party's candidates and would like to see someone else enter the race. (On the Republican side, more than 4 in 10 wanted other candidates to enter the race.)
And Governor Casey, Mr. Clinton's critic here, did not sound like a convert tonight in an interview with WCAU-TV in Philadelphia. He congratulated the Arkansas Governor but added that he was still worried about "the big show in November."

LENGTH: 1243 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Senate Race;
After Making Specter the Issue, Newcomer Wins Bid to Face Him

BYLINE: By MICHAEL DeCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Wednesday, April 29

 BODY:
Lynn H. Yeakel, a fund-raiser for women's charities, sprang from virtual anonymity a month ago to become the upset winner of Tuesday's Democratic Senate primary in Pennsylvania.
With 97 percent of the votes counted at about 2 A.M., Ms. Yeakel had 45 percent to 33 percent for Lieut. Gov. Mark S. Singel. The remainder was divided among three other candidates. 
 The outcome turned on Ms. Yeakel's criticism of Senator Arlen Specter in the hearings last year on the nomination of Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court, and it set up a confrontation over women's issues for the fall election.
Mr. Specter, a two-term incumbent, handily defeated his rival for the Republican nomination, State Representative Stephen F. Freind. With 93 percent of the votes in, Mr. Specter, who is seeking his third term, had 65 percent of the vote to 35 percent for Mr. Freind.
Ms. Yeakel's apparent victory over Mr. Singel, who was the front-runner until last week, was termed "a stunning upset" by G. Terry Madonna, a political analyst who is director of the Center for Politics and Public Affairs at Millersville State University in Lancaster. "There is no corollary for this in Pennsylvania politics," Mr. Madonna said. "She is the complete outsider. She will be formidable against Arlen Specter. I think this is the year of the woman in politics."
 
'We Did It!'
 Shortly after 10 P.M., Ms. Yeakel, who says she is a champion of womens' issues, which she says are "central to this society," appeared at the Philadelphia Hilton to thank a large gathering of supporters. "We did it!" she said. "We did it! We did it!" She went on, "This was a hard-earned victory; it was not a miracle."
Mr. Singel had conceded a half-hour earlier, saying he had called Ms. Yeakel to tell her that she would be an outstanding Senator. "I'm just proud to go back to continue my work as Lieutenant Governor," he told his supporters.
Pennsylvania has never elected a woman to the Senate; it has elected three widows of incumbents to its delegation in the House. Only 7 percent of the members of the state's General Assembly are women.
The other Democratic candidates were Robert E. Colville, 56, a five-term District Attorney in Allegheny County, who had a sixth of the vote in the survey; Freddy Mann Friedman, 47, a psychologist from Ardmore, a suburb of Philadelphia, who had less than 1 in 20 votes, as did Philip Valenti, 42, a follower of Lyndon LaRouche who lives in the Philadelphia suburb of Upper Darby.
 
Percentage Point a Day
 Ms. Yeakel, 50, was virtually unheard of in statewide political circles when she began campaigning Feb. 6. Her support climbed by more than a percentage point a day, due partly to her television advertisement reminding voters of Senator Specter's aggressive questioning of Anita F. Hill in the Thomas hearings.
Ms. Yeakel also got help from newspaper endorsements, which generally praised her positions on women's issues, the economy and education and dismissed the 38-year-old Mr. Singel as a career politician lacking conviction.
Mr. Singel's position on abortion was particularly unclear because he said that he personally opposed abortion but that it should be legal in most circumstances.
Neil Newhouse, Mr. Specter's poll taker, played down the threat that would be posed by Ms. Yeakel in the general election. "Arlen Specter is no Mark Singel, and he has a very solid record on women's issues," Mr. Newhouse said.
A survey of voters leaving the polls, conducted by Voter Research and Surveys, showed that Ms. Yeakel's largest bloc of support was coming from educated, high-income voters as well as voters under age 60. Voters with only high school degrees were more apt to support Mr. Singel.
Ms. Yeakel, who lives is Rosemont, a suburb of Philadelphia, won about two-thirds of the vote in Philadelphia and its suburbs; Mr. Singel, who lives in Johnstown, in the western part of the state, won a third of the vote in the Pittsburgh area. More than half the women and 4 in 10 men voted for Ms. Yeakel. By contrast, Mr. Singel was backed by a third of the male and female voters.
More than half of Ms. Yeakel's supporters said in the survey that Justice Thomas should not have been confirmed. Ms. Yeakel's supporters also included more than half of the two-thirds of the Democratic voters who said that abortion should remain legal.
 
Possible Ominous Sign
 In the Republican primary, the survey found that a quarter of the voters opposed the confirmation of Justice Thomas. But 6 in 10 of those same voters still backed Mr. Specter, who had voted in favor of Judge Thomas's confirmation.
More than half of the Republican voters said that abortion should be kept legal, and about three-fourths of these voters supported Mr. Specter. Mr. Specter also won the votes of about 6 in 10 of the Republican women.
In a possibly ominous sign for Mr. Specter, only 6 in 10 of the Republican voters said they would vote for him in the general election if he was running against Ms. Yeakel. One in four Republicans said they would vote for Ms. Yeakel. Democrats were not asked this question in the survey.
Ms. Yeakel's rapid rise from underdog to electoral victory matches that of Senator Harris Wofford, who won last November's special election to fill the seat of Senator John Heinz, who died in an airplance crash.
Gov. Robert P. Casey appointed Mr. Wofford, who had served in his cabinet, as interim Senator in the spring. But going into the fall campaign for the three years remaining in Mr. Heinz's term, polls showed Mr. Wofford trailing Dick Thornburgh, the former Republican Governor and former United States Attorney General, by more than 40 percentage points. Mr. Wofford, calling for new leadership and national health insurance, defeated Mr. Thornburgh 55 percent to 45 percent.
Just as Mr. Wofford's victory sent shock waves through the Republican Party and gave Democratic candidates some powerful campaign themes, Ms. Yeakel's showing is likely to catch the attention of the male-dominated structures of both political parties.
 
Second Woman in 2 Months
 Political analysts say that female politicians, who have had limited electoral success in the past, may have come into their own this year, when voters are saying in surveys that the country is on the wrong track and that they want all new people in government.
Ms. Yeakel is the second woman in two months to surprise the Democratic establishment. In Illinois, Carol Mosely Braun, a 44-year-old Cook County recorder of deeds, ran a primary campaign that was also fueled by outrage over the Thomas hearings, and she defeated the Democratic incumbent, Senator Alan J. Dixon, a Thomas supporter.
In the Republican primary in Pennsylvania, voters had a stark choice between Mr. Specter, 62, who supports a woman's right to abortion, and Mr. Freind, 47, who is the author of the Pennsylvania anti-abortion law that is before the Supreme Court.
In comments following his victory, Mr. Specter gave little attention to Ms. Yaekel's criticism but said that she would need to find other issues in the general election campaign.
"It sort of felt for a long time like I had two opponents. I heard what Steve Freind had to say on the right, and I kept seeing those television commercials for Ms. Yeakel on the left," Specter said. "And now I look forward to saying, simply put, there's a lot more to a United States Senate race than a single issue."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.M. Posts First Profit Since 1990

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 28

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation today announced its first quarterly profit since the second quarter of 1990.
The company, which has been scrambling to reorganize its management and operations to help erase its string of losses, said it made $179 million in the first quarter, compared with a loss of $1.1 billion, excluding nonrecurring gains, a year earlier. 
 G.M. was able to make a profit mainly because of improvements in its troubled North American automotive operations, although the company acknowledged that the operations were still not profitable. In previous quarters, losses in North America more than negated profits from overseas and from the company's non-automotive subsidiaries.
General Motors' revenues in the first quarter rose nearly 10 percent, to $32 billion, from $29.2 billion a year earlier. The company's profit attributable to its regular common shares, one of three classes of G.M. stock, amounted to 2 cents a share.
 
Bodes Well for Stock Sale
 The overall profit, albeit small for a company of G.M.'s size, should augur well for the pending sale of up to 57.5 million new shares of G.M. common stock, announced on Friday. G.M. hopes to raise $2.3 billion or more to help shore up its balance sheet. G.M. reported a net loss of $4.45 billion for 1991, the company's worst year ever.
G.M.'s share price rose 37.5 cents today, to $40.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 Analysts were upbeat about G.M.'s improvement in the quarter, but no one would comment for the record, citing S.E.C. restrictions against public comment during a registration period for new stock. Because of the size of the G.M. offering, most large brokerages are part of the syndicate that is selling shares; their analysts, therefore, are barred from public statements that might lure potential investors until the S.E.C. has finished reviewing regulatory filings.
But several analysts who granted interviews on the condition that they not be identified noted that G.M.'s profit margins had improved and that the auto maker was finally showing the effects of cost-cutting and efficiency measures, in addition to higher sales. But analysts also warned against too much optimism, saying the strength of the economic recovery and the revival of automotive demand remained big question marks for G.M. So far this year, retail automotive sales in the United States are running below G.M.'s projections.
 G.M.'s embattled chief executive, Robert C. Stempel, echoed the analysts' caution, saying: "We are encouraged that our efforts to make G.M. competitive and profitable are paying off. However, while we have made significant progress in improving the financial performance of the North American automotive operations, there is a considerable way to go before we will be fully satisfied with our financial results."
[In a speech to business writers on Tuesday night in Chicago, Mr. Stempel said G.M. planned to accelerate the scheduled closings of 21 plants, The Associated Press reported. "We're looking at accelerating all of our decisions," he said.]
The $1.1 billion loss a year earlier would have been narrower except for $942 million of special items. On a net basis, the company had a much smaller loss of $144 million because of special gains, including a profit from the sale of the General Motors Building in New York. The results a year earlier were also restated to reflect the effects of an accounting change relating to income taxes.
Two of G.M.'s three main non-automotive subsidiaries, Electronic Data Systems and GM Hughes Electronics, posted higher earnings on Monday; the General Motors Acceptance Corporation reported lower earnings.
A company spokesman said a 6.8 percent improvement in factory sales of cars and trucks to G.M. dealers -- 1.76 million worldwide, compared with 1.66 million a year earlier -- was an important reason for the company's improved first-quarter performance. During last year's first quarter, dealers were liquidating inventories of unsold vehicles, which meant weak factory sales and poor financial results.
In North America, G.M. benefited from a higher proportion of its factory sales going to individual retail customers, rather than to fleet buyers like car-rental companies. Retail customers pay higher prices than fleets. A company spokesman said fleet sales constituted about 34 percent of car sales, compared with 37 percent last year.
 In the first quarter, G.M. customers also bought a higher proportion of high-profit large cars like the Cadillac Seville and Eldorado, Pontiac Bonneville and Buick LeSabre. All of those models were redesigned and introduced within the last year.
To compensate for its financial losses, G.M. raised funds by issuing $3.4 billion worth of preference stock in late 1991 and early this year. The auto maker is facing huge costs in connection with the development of new car and truck models, as well as costs connected with the revamping of its North American operations.
Three weeks ago, in a move that appeared aimed at Mr. Stempel's authority, G.M.'s outside directors demoted two top officers and appointed a new president and chief operating officer.

HEADLINE: U.S. and World: New Economic Order

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
Although there has been much talk about building a new political order in the post-cold-war world, the events here in the last few days make clear that a new economic order is also rapidly emerging.
Consider these developments in the whirlwind of high-level economic meetings in Washington: 
 *The 15 republics in the former land of Lenin will soon be joining two bastions of capitalism, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
*Hamstrung by debt and deficit, the United States, once so economically powerful that it could singlehandedly finance the reconstruction of postwar Europe, now feels compelled to turn to the I.M.F. to lead the effort to rebuild the former Soviet Union.
*Sounding like an economic development official from Kansas, Deputy Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, Russia's chief economic policy maker, came to the symbolic heart of capitalism -- the United States Chamber of Commerce -- to woo companies with arguments that Russia was fertile territory for outside investors.
*The United States pressed Germany and Japan to do more to spur the sluggish world economy, but German officials (angrily) and Japanese officials (diplomatically) said they were too big to be pushed around by Uncle Sam. Besides, they said Washington should clean up its own economic house, before it tells others what to do.
 
Pieces of a New Mosaic
 These developments are all pieces in a new economic mosaic in which the war between Communism and capitalism has ended, and almost all countries have turned to a market economy. Although China and Cuba continue to embrace large parts of Communist ideology, even they are using more and more features of a market economy.
The new mosaic also shows that the United States is no longer the undisputed economic colossus able to muscle other countries into line.
"Germany and Europe have gained in economic strength relative to the U.S., hastened by the weakening of the U.S. fiscal situation in the 1980's," said Stanley Fischer, an M.I.T. economics professor who used to be the World Bank's chief economist. "With the decline of the Soviet threat, the tendency of Europe to do what the United States wants, and make strategic concessions on the economic front, has definitely declined."
 
Among Industrial Friends
 Disputes over whether Angola or Afghanistan should be Communist or capitalist are past. Now the hottest disputes are among industrial friends on issues like the European Community's refusal to accept Washington's demands to slash its farm subsidies. Or Bonn's reluctance to follow Washington's call to cut its budget deficit so that Germany's central bank would have room to cut its interest rates and stimulate Europe's economy.
With economic growth weak in the United States and the world, Washington -- with much less room for pump-priming than in previous recessions because of its huge budget deficit -- also called on Tokyo to spur growth by increasing Government spending and lowering interest rates. Like a robust new giant confronting an aging one, Tokyo politely told Washington to take a walk at Sunday's meeting of Group of Seven finance ministers.
Washington cannot bankroll a Marshall Plan for the former Soviet republics because the task is so enormous and because the American economy is debt-ridden and no longer so dominant. That is why Washington has asked the I.M.F. to run the rescue operations, which are expected to cost $44 billion this year.
"The U.S. no longer has the money to put into various international agencies and efforts that it use to have," Professor Fischer said. "It leads from financial weakness."
 
Relations May Be Stormy
 A major addition to the economic order is that the I.M.F. will be prescribing economic reforms to the former Communist world. These proud countries seem eager to embrace capitalism, but their relationship with the I.M.F. promises to be stormy.
According to the Interfax news agency, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia said today: "We do not intend to work under the direct orders of the I.M.F. We do not agree completely with this organization's viewpoint, and we will stick to our point of view." But I.M.F. officials, seeking peace, said the fund never dictates policies to countries when they sign I.M.F. reform agreements.
For countries like Ethiopia and Bangladesh, the new economic order seems full of injustice and disorder. Officials from many developing countries complain that they removed their import barriers at the urging of the rich nations, but now the wealthy countries are loathe to remove their barriers on third-world products, like apparel and peanuts.
"The first tier of countries will remain the first tier in the post-cold-war world," said Jean-Claude Paye, secretary general of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a grouping of 24 rich nations. "But if they don't get their act together and open to the needs and problems of others, we'll have no economic order."
 
The Japanese Model
 With the dispute between Marxism and the market withering away, a new debate is picking up steam: what form of capitalism is best for the developing world. Because of the huge recent successes of Japan, Korea and Thailand, Japanese officials argue that Africa and Latin America would be wise to follow Tokyo's economic model, where the Government helps guide companies, rather than Washington's hands-off model.
"What could emerge is a period of competition between different capitalist models which all accept the premise that you have a right to private ownership and would acknowledge that private incentive is necessary for development," said William R. Clines, a senior fellow with the Institute for International Economics in Washington. "But there will be a debate between the Japanese model which gives a bigger role to government planning, the U.S. model which is essentially laissez-faire and the European model which gives more emphasis to social welfare."

HEADLINE: Panama Grows, Reaching Skyward, Yet Down Below Much Pain Remains

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
In this city stretched out beside the Pacific Ocean, new high-rise office buildings and condominiums are joining the already gleaming white skyline at the dizzy pace of a boomtown, creating vast traffic jams as construction crews maneuver around each other on dozens of sites.
Most major economic indicators are rising with what one business executive likened to the sharp, sure climb of a jetliner. The Panama Canal has been doing record business. Politics is flourishing, and so is the mainstream press, both in its news pages and its advertising linage. 
 Yet on the day this month when a Miami jury convicted Panama's former strongman, Manuel Antonio Noriega, on drug trafficking and related charges, the elected President who now governs the country, Guillermo Endara, could pause only briefly to savor the moment.
Then he had to return to the week's woes, including demonstrations by the jobless in the Atlantic port city of Colon, a strike by banana workers that tied up Puerto Armuelles in the west, land struggles between peasant squatters and indigenous groups, and a crime rate that everybody seemed to think had reached untenable proportions.
 
An Unanswered Question
 While Panama today is making a headlong recovery from the effects of the American invasion two years and four months ago and the two years of rising political tension that preceded it, the recovery has not been fast enough to soak up all of the jobless and resolve myriad other economic and social problems.
An unanswered question about the recovery is how much of it is linked to Panama's continuing role as a drug transshipment point and money-laundering center.
American and Panamanian officials say the capture and trial of General Noriega eliminated the "one-stop corruption" that existed before, under which traffickers paid him and a small group of collaborators for transshipment privileges. But it did not halt trafficking through Panama.
 
Feuding in Coalition
 Seizures of cocaine shipments by the Panamanian police with American help have been rising, as they have throughout Central America and Mexico. American drug experts say that is a result of improved police cooperation but also reflects the fact that more cocaine is probably being moved through the isthmus and Mexico because detection has improved on direct routes between Colombia and the United States.
Panama's recovery is further complicated by increasingly strident feuding among the leaders of the coalition that led the political opposition to General Noriega and took over the Government as the invasion began on Dec. 20, 1989.
A year ago, the coalition fell apart when President Endara forced the Christian Democrats, led by his First Vice President, Ricardo Arias Calderon, out of the Government. Today, Mr. Arias leads the opposition, although he is still formally the First Vice President, and his party has continued to give some legislative support to the Government.
But the United States Ambassador, Deane R. Hinton, said in a recent speech that the problems were a natural part of the process of learning to live in democracy.
"Many Panamanians are so busy complaining of this and that and criticizing so and so for something or other," he said, "that they have lost sight of the truly immense progress Panama has made and is making."
 
Tradition Is Blamed
 Rogelio Cruz, the Attorney General, who is under criticism from many Panamanians for not proceeding faster to prosecute General Noriega's collaborators still in Panama, said the tensions were "partly the result of being in political transition, but also part of Panamanian tradition; we get it from our Spanish history."
Mr. Arias said: "What has happened is that once democracy was installed, all the social and economic matters that had been postponed in recent years began to emerge. The overall economic figures sound good, but there is an enormous accumulation of poverty at the lower levels."
Mr. Arias complained that Mr. Endara was a weak President who acted only when a crisis erupted. More neutral analysts at least partly confirmed that assessment by describing Mr. Endara's style as "collegial."
"This is more serious than normal transition problems," Mr. Arias said, "because we have a presidential system and practically don't have a President."
Some analysts pointed out that Mr. Endara had not really expected to become President when the opposition coalition was pieced together for the May 1989 elections. Although he won easily, General Noriega gave him no chance to take office until the Americans landed six months later and dropped the job in his lap.
 
The Real Power Struggle
 As a result, the real power struggle is played out between Mr. Arias and Ruben Carles, the powerful Controller General, a former private banker whose fiscal conservatism and reputation for honesty please the United States and international creditors.
Louis Martinz, who handles international press relations for the President, says the dispute boils down to the fact that the Christian Democrats want to put more money into social programs, while Mr. Carles gives priority to the $5 billion foreign debt.
Panama's two and a half million people have long been accustomed to one of the highest living standards in Latin America. The services-dominated economy is aided by thousands of relatively well-paid jobs on the Panama Canal and on 10 American military installations, plus more than 100 banks making up the international banking center and the Colon Free Zone, where businessmen from all over Latin America buy merchandise.
Government statistics show that the economy grew an impressive 9.3 percent in 1991. Although some private economists have slightly lower estimates, everyone agrees that the economy has essentially recovered the level of 1987, considered the last good year under the old regime.
Economic analysts point out that most of this recovery is the product of private enterprise and has come about despite the Government's fiscal conservatism and the fact that aid from the United States has been slower and smaller in amount than the Endara Government had expected.
The United States has committed itself to about $1 billion in aid -- both grants and credits -- but only $544 million has been disbursed so far. Of that, $130 million went to help Panama pay its arrears with the international lending agencies so it can resume borrowing from them and more than $100 million went to private banks for re-lending to investors at commercial rates.
According to figures supplied by officials of the construction industry, construction activity this year is running 10 percent above that of 1987.
Although the most visible construction activity is in the ultra-modern towers and shopping malls, construction experts say there has also been considerable construction of much more modest housing.
 
Fire Left 2,700 Homeless
 That includes new houses or apartments for the 2,700 families who lost their homes in the Chorrillo slum when fire tore through the neighborhood after American troops attacked the headquarters of General Noriega's Panama Defense Force as the invasion began.
The United States paid for the new homes as part of its aid package.
The Union of Industrialists estimatesd that manufacturing output and sales have also returned to 1987 levels. In the Colon Free Zone, trade increased by 31 percent last year, attributed to strengthening economies and more liberal foreign trade policies in much of Latin America.
The Panama Canal, which not only provides 6,000 to 7,000 jobs but also makes tonnage-based payments to the Panamanian Government, had its second-best year ever in tonnage terms in 1991, aided by the Persian Gulf war and increased shipments of refrigerated fruit and vegetables out of South America. Canal officials say this year's traffic is running at about the same level.
What confounds the Government and economic experts is the lingering high jobless rate. Although it has fallen from a high of about 18 percent in 1990, it is still put at 15.7 percent, not including substantial underemployment. The rate was 11.8 percent in 1987.
Some analysts fear that some of the construction growth could be coming from the continuing laundering of drug profits, a longtime problem in Panama. But others point out that the overall strength of the economy, plus the fact that a number of construction projects had been postponed during the crisis years, also help explain the boom.
As for the apparently rising crime rate, Mr. Cruz, the Attorney General, said he could not confirm that "because we never had crime statistics before." He acknowledged that increased crime was quite possible.
"Criminals used to be afraid to act for fear the security forces would kill them," he said. "Now, they know they'll get due process and have lawyers."

HEADLINE: Shift of Funds From Schools Is Protested

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
School officials yesterday accused Mayor David N. Dinkins of diverting $67 million that the New York Legislature had pledged for education, and they warned that the lost money would force a harmful increase in class size in the early grades.
Their criticism was the first to come on the New York City budget, which was unveiled Monday by the Mayor. Much of the sniping across the East River between City Hall and the board's headquarters at 110 Livingston Street in Brooklyn is part of a traditional springtime exercise. But it takes on added significance this year, school officials contend, because the size of elementary-school classes is at stake. 
 The city's budget director, Philip R. Michael, acknowledged yesterday that class size could rise in first through third grades to 27 students, from 25. But he said that was the least distasteful of the unsavory choices the school system faced.
Responding to the school district's criticism, Mr. Michael accused school officials of distorting the budget picture and urged the board to find the least damaging trims.
"I think you would find an overwhelming consensus that a bureaucracy that has $7.5 billion can find efficiencies of 1 percent," he said.
Mr. Michael acknowledged that $67 million ostensibly set aside for education had been steered to other agencies, but said City Hall did so only because the Board of Education until now had suffered less than those agencies. In effect, he suggested, the books were being balanced.
At other agencies affected by the budget, there was barely a whisper of grumbling yesterday, though some city officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity said they planned to lobby City Council members privately. A year of bleak news on the city's economy seemed to have diminished expections, prompting most agencies to take whatever cuts they received in the Mayor's budget and be thankful there were not more. Moreover, just before releasing his budget, the Mayor had announced some programs, like the creation of 20 health clinics in poor neighborhoods, that may have taken the edge off potential criticism on the budget.
Joseph DePlasco, a spokesman for the Transportation Department, said that while the agency would have less money to repair potholes and replace street signs, "we are grateful that the budget for bridge repair and maintenance remained untouched."
And the Parks Commissioner, Betsy Gotbaum, said, "It's not too bad this year because there's really nothing left for them to take." Her budget for park maintenance was cut.
But the Mayor's school budget drew fire from one of his most important political supporters. Unhappy with his budget proposal and the pace of negotiations on a new contract, Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, snubbed a fund-raising dinner for the Mayor's re-election campaign Monday night and said through a spokesman yesterday that she was reconsidering her support for his candidacy.
And in Albany, Assemblyman Angelo Del Toro, a Manhattan Democrat and chairman of the Assembly Education Committee, said he had always understood that the $67 million pledged by the Legislature would go directly to the school system. He said he was sending a letter to the Mayor signed by other colleagues protesting the Mayor's decision.
On Monday, the Mayor announced a $29.5 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1, and it contained modest growth in spending by city agencies. But at the Board of Education, the $7.5 billion allocation for schools was seen as a betrayal.
"Everyone is enraged about it," said Stanley S. Litow, the deputy chancellor for operations.
What angered him and Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez was the Mayor's decision to steer to other city agencies the $67 million that state legislators had restored last month to the public schools. The money, it turned out yesterday, had been pledged to the city, not specifically to the Board of Education and so could legally be channeled anywhere the city saw fit.
 
Drastic Reductions Forecast

 Derek Wheeler, a deputy budget director, said the board had generally been on the winning end of earlier budget cuts by the state, and did not merit the restoration that the state voted last month.
Mr. Litow said if the Mayor's budget proposals are enacted by the City Council, the cuts for the board in the 1992-93 school year will total $151 million and compel drastic service reductions. These, he said, include an increase in class size in the elementary schools, deeper cuts in already threadbare supplies, attrition in the ranks of assistant principals and guidance counselors and reductions in the maintenance and painting of the city's decaying schools.
The threat of an increase in class size in the first, second and third grades from 25 pupils per room to 27 most worried leaders of educational advocacy groups. In 1984, the City Council invested money in rolling back early-grade class sizes that had crept up during the fiscal crisis. Since then class sizes for kindergarten through third grade have hovered around 25.
Most pupils learn to read and calculate in the early elementary-school grades, and students who do not grasp fundamental concepts often find it hard to catch up later. Indeed, many educators credit the reduced class sizes with stabilizing reading levels during the late 1980's and improving them in the 1990's.

HEADLINE: Israel Opposes U.S. Plan for Arab Panel at Talks

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
Israel's Foreign Minister, David Levy, told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today that Israel would not take part in the regional peace talks on refugee matters and economic development if the United States continued to insist that Palestinian refugees from outside the West Bank and Gaza Strip be able to attend, Israeli officials said.
The United States and Russia formally issued the invitations on Monday for the five different regional talks, which are intended to accompany and support the core negotiations between Israel and its immediate Arab neighbors, Syria, Jordan, Lebanon and the Palestinians. 
 Unlike the talks between Israel and her immediate neighbors, which focus on the issue of land for peace, the regional talks are supposed to bring together Israel, Saudi Arabia and a wide array of Arab countries, Europeans, and even China and Japan, to address problems that affect the Middle East region as a whole.
Five different regional working group sessions are scheduled for next month: talks on refugee problems in Ottawa on May 13, talks on economic development in Brussels on May 11, talks on the sharing of water resources in Vienna on May 12, talks on environmental issues in Tokyo on May 18 and talks on arms-control issues in Washington on May 11.
 
Separate Regional Talks
 The Palestinians boycotted the opening plenary of the regional talks in Moscow in January after the co-sponsors, the United States and Russia, refused to accredit their delegation because it contained Palestinian refugees who live outside the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Under the rules negotiated for the Madrid and Moscow peace conferences, only Palestinians from inside the occupied territories could take part.
The Palestinian negotiating team argued, though, that if issues like refugees and economic development were being discussed they had to be allowed to broaden their delegation to include Palestinian refugees from outside the occupied territories. The Israelis refused, saying that to include such refugees would be to imply that Israel is ready to discuss their right of return one day to their homes in Israel or the occupied territories, and it is not.
Israel said it was only ready to discuss a settlement with those Palestinians now living in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The Israelis said those were the terms of Palestinian representation that they agreed to for the Madrid peace conference, and the Moscow regional conference, and therefore they also had to apply to the separate regional talks.
The Americans agreed with the Israelis, but said the rules of representation applied only to the Moscow and Madrid sessions. Mr. Baker insisted that different rules could be applied to the lower-level regional working group talks. In an effort to get the Palestinians to agree to take part, he said they could bring to the regional working groups on refugee matters and economic development Palestinian refugees from outside the occupied territories, provided that they are not members of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
 
Ground Rules in Dispute
 Briefing reporters on the Levy-Baker meeting, Israel's Ambassador to the United States, Zalman Shoval, said the Israeli side "raised some questions with regard to the multilateral talks -- as you know, there are still some points of disagreement between Israel and the United States on certain aspects of these talks."
Mr. Shoval said Mr. Levy "made our position very clear."
"We reiterated that Israel would not agree to participate in any working group in this peace process which does not function in accordance with the ground rules which had been set up originally for this whole process."
"It is very clear to us, and I think it should be very clear to anybody who knows anything about it, that the insistence of the Palestinians to include outside Palestinians or diaspora Palestinians in this process is in order to get the right-of-return question back into the whole process through the back door," he said. "Otherwise, there's very little reason why they should insist all of the sudden for so-called diaspora Palestinians to be included. And Israel will not agree to that."
 
Talks on Elections
 Mr. Baker, officials said, responded that Washington would not force Israel to talk with anyone it does not want to, but he did not intend to alter his position on Palestinian participation in the working groups.
The American view is that it would be meaningless to have discussion of refugee issues without the full range of Palestinian refugees in attendance.
Mr. Baker urged Mr. Levy to reconsider. Mr. Levy said that Israel felt it was being presented with a fait accompli in this delicate matter, and that was not conducive to negotiations.
Mr. Baker later told reporters that despite the reservations raised by Mr. Levy, the Israeli minister stopped short of giving a formal rejection of the American invitation for the working groups.

HEADLINE: State Senate Passes Bill to Allow Queens to Begin Secession Effort

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 28

 BODY:
The State Senate approved legislation tonight that would allow the borough of Queens to begin the process of seceding from the City of New York.
But the bill, which is viewed here primarily as a vehicle for election-year grandstanding by Queens politicians, is not expected to pass the Assembly. A spokesman for Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat, said that Mr. Weprin believes that the Legislature should study Staten Island's secession efforts before giving the same authority to Queens. 
 The Legislature enacted a law in 1989 allowing Staten Island residents to vote on whether a commission should be formed to study the possibility of secession. The referendum was approved overwhelmingly in 1990 and the commission is at work.
 
Dinkins Opposes Bill
 "The Speaker's general feeling is we have another borough looking to secede right now and they're certainly farther along in the process," said Steven Greenberg, Mr. Weprin's press secretary.
Mayor David N. Dinkins opposes the bill. "There is no evidence of widespread dissatisfaction among Queens residents," the Mayor told the Legislature. "Even if there were, such dissatisfaction cannot justify the breakup of a city that has been in existence now for almost 100 years."
The Queens secession bill passed 34 to 20 in the Senate, which has a Republican majority. Senator Roy M. Goodman of Manhattan was the only Republican to vote against the bill. Senator Jeremy S. Weinstein of Queens was the only Democrat to vote for it.
The bill would give Queens voters the opportunity to vote in a referendum to establish a commission that would write a charter for the proposed city of Queens. With 1.9 million people, Queens would become the country's fourth largest city.
"I think the perception and the reality is that Queens County residents feel they are being shortchanged on services and that they are a dumping found for some of the socially undesirable projects that may do a lot for New York City but little for Queens County," said Senator Serphin R. Maltese, the Queens Republican who sponsored the bill. Senator Frank Padavan, another Queens Republican, said the idea of secession made sense because New York City had simply become too large and too unwieldy for Queens to get its fair share of the government's money and attention.
But Mr. Goodman said secession would hurt Queens. "In 1898, the separate parts of the city were put together and as a result of that action the city grew to be the greatest city in the world," he said. "To seek to separate it now would be like creating an explosion in a paint factory and would make little sense economically or socially."

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Backs More Records on Bond Sales

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
Breaking ranks with both the Bush Administration and the Federal Reserve Board, the Securities and Exchange Commission endorsed legislation today that would make it easier for regulators to monitor the $2 trillion government securities market by requiring securities dealers to keep more thorough records.
Richard C. Breeden, the commission's chairman, told a House panel that any new legislation on the government securities market should require better record-keeping by dealers. He said such a measure would deter market abuses and make it much easier to prosecute them. 
 "It comes down to a simple question of do you want an honor system or do you not?" Mr. Breeden said to the members of the House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Domestic Monetary Policy. He has also sought greater authority for the commission to police the primary market and set the rules for trading in government securities.
 
Response to a Scandal
 The proposal to improve audit trails was made by some lawmakers after the scandal at Salomon Brothers became public last August. The firm has acknowledged that its traders tried to corner the market in several government securities.
Better audit trails have been opposed by both the Treasury and the Federal Reserve, which argue that the benefits of any new paperwork would be outweighed by the costs.
"We believe the prescription of reporting to the S.E.C. is overkill and not justified," said an Assistant Treasury Secretary, Jerome H. Powell. "We don't think this is a market shot through with problems."
At the hearing, David W. Mullins, the vice chairman of the Fed, said the Government's regular sales of notes, bills and bonds would be converted to a computer system by the end of the year, and he urged the lawmakers to refrain from acting before then.
"A legislative mandate is not needed," he said. "The board would prefer to see this run its course."
With only three lawmakers at the hearing, it was impossible to discern how Congress might act, or even whether it would act soon. Legislation has been pending for almost a year.
 
Proposals Announced
 At a briefing this afternoon at the White House, Mr. Breeden announced what he called 80 initiatives to reduce the regulatory burdens on companies seeking financing. The briefing was part of the White House's review of all Federal regulations.
All of the significant proposals described by Mr. Breeden had already been announced by the S.E.C. or disclosed by senior officials -- some of them months ago -- and many of the proposals remain months away from being finally acted upon.
Mr. Breeden said it was not inconsistent for him to argue for greater record-keeping requirements in the morning, and in the afternoon participate in the White House's much publicized efforts to cut red tape.
"There's nothing inconsistent, in my judgment, with trying to target regulation on the heart of wrongdoing, try and get the job that needs to be done and protect investors done, but do it with the lowest cost and the least interference with the workings of the marketplace as possible," he said. "I don't see any contradiction whatsoever."

HEADLINE: Yields Flat On C.D.'s and Bank Funds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit were flat for the week ended today, according to The Bank Rate Monitor. And as in the previous week, declines were smaller.
Robert K. Heady, publisher of the interest-rate publication, said he expected deposit rates to drift in their present range for a while before setting a definite course. 
 He said the slow, steady erosion in bank C.D. yields was an indication that banks were still not convinced that a bottom had been reached for this down cycle in interest rates. "This is despite the fact that yields on some government securities have ticked up recently," Mr. Heady said. "The jury is still out."
At the Treasury's closely watched auction of new three- and six-month bills, rates were mixed on Monday. The bill auction is usually held on the first day of each week and is considered by many rate watchers as a good barometer of what many banks could eventually end up paying their deposit customers.
The average discount rate for the three-month Treasury bill rose 3 basis points, to 3.71 percent, this week, up for the second consecutive auction, while the six-month bill slipped a basis point, to 3.85 percent, after a smart gain at the previous auction. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
Yields at New York-area banks fell slightly in the latest week, with the money market account and three-month certificate down 2 basis points, to 3.53 percent and 3.59 percent, respectively. The longer six-month C.D. was unchanged at 3.75 percent.
Broken down, the numbers show commercial banks making the larger cuts on C.D.'s, though they pay less than the savings banks. The commercial three- and six-month C.D.'s fell an average 2 basis points, to 3.39 percent and 3.48 percent, respectively, while the money market accounts remained unchanged at 3.28 percent.
Savings banks meanwhile, cut their three-month certificate a basis point, to 3.80 percent, and left the six-month at 4.01 percent. They did cut the money market accounts a little more, to 3.78 percent, down 3 basis points.
The largest yield adjustments among the area banks were at the Hudson City Savings Bank, based in Paramus, N.J., which reduced the yield on its money market account by 26 basis points, to 3.82 percent, and at Chase Manhattan; the commercial banks sliced a quarter of a percentage point off the yield of a three-month certificate, to 3.10 percent, and dropped the yield on a six-month certificate by 26 basis points, to 3.15 percent.
For 20 large banks outside the New York market, the yield declines were harder on money market accounts, which were down an average of 3 basis points, to 3.42 percent, with the average six-month certificate off a basis point, to 3.78 percent.
