HEADLINE: Economy Grew at 2% Rate in First Quarter

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
The economy grew at a 2 percent annual pace in the first three months of the year, the fourth straight quarterly gain and the best George Bush has witnessed as President, Commerce Department figures showed today.
The growth in gross domestic product -- the total output of goods and services by labor and operations in the United States -- was fueled by consumers, who account for 67 percent of the $4.89 trillion economy and who were inspired to spend by relatively warm weather and Government efforts to pad their wallets. 
 But optimism over the gain was tempered by a separate report of an unexpected 14.8 percent plunge in sales of new homes during March, the biggest drop in more than 10 years.
Still other economic indicators published today on consumer confidence and employment costs were mostly favorable but with their own weak points. Analysts said that altogether the data continued to point to a recovery that was likely to continue but would remain relatively subdued.
The White House, mindful that what appeared last spring to be a solid rebound subsequently flattened out, greeted today's data cautiously.
"I think most people would say that 2 percent growth is not recessionary," President Bush said when asked by reporters whether he thought the recession had ended. "There are some areas that are still hurting, but clearly this is a good sign."
Most private analysts agreed that for various reasons, including sharply lower short-term interest rates, recovery has now definitely taken hold and growth may even accelerate to as much as 3 percent or so in coming quarters.
Still, the National Bureau of Economic Research, the private-sector group charged with determining the beginning and end of recessions, has yet to schedule a meeting to declare an official end to the recession that began in July 1990. This is in spite of four consecutive quarters of growth rates averaging 1.4 percent a year. They followed two quarters of contraction averaging 3.2 percent that occurred at the end of 1990 and the beginning of 1991.
By comparison, recoveries since World War II have typically begun with 5 percent to 6 percent growth in the first 12 months.
Today's report on gross domestic product was largely as expected in its 2 percent annual rate of growth. The two top officials of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan and David W. Mullins Jr., both made midmonth predictions of 2 percent growth, a figure subsequently embraced by Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
 
Inventories Shrink
 But the report surprised some analysts in showing such a sharp drawdown of inventories. Inventories fell at a $26.1 billion pace during the first quarter after rising $7.5 billion in the October-December period, a swing that held back G.D.P. for the quarter but left the economy well positioned to benefit from sustained demand.
Final sales -- output minus inventory change -- spurted at a 4.8 percent rate, the biggest gain since the first quarter of 1988; sales had declined in the two preceding quarters.
This combination of lean stocks and stronger demand "sets up the conditions for stronger production gains in the second and third quarter," observed John E. Silvia, an economist for Kemper Financial Services in Chicago.
Spending on personal consumption, in fact, jumped even faster than final sales, rising at a rate of $42.7 billion, or 5.3 percent.
 
More Money to Spend
 "Consumers have repaid installment debt and taken advantage of lower interest rates to reduce interest payments on home mortgages," said J. Antonio Villamil, chief economist for the Commerce Department. This, he added, has increased discretionary income for consumers, who may have also been encouraged to spend during the quarter by reduced withholdings of income tax, part of the Administration's modest program of economic stimulus.
Other analysts pointed to other possible spurs to consumer spending, including unusually warm winter weather, earlier and larger tax refunds than usual, a Federal pay increase and a rise in various Government transfer payments, including extensions of unemployment benefits.
Over all, purchases by all levels of government rose at a 2.8 percent rate during the quarter, while international trade contributed modestly.
Investment by business, however, was a clear soft spot as spending fell for the sixth straight quarter. A small gain in spending for equipment was more than offset by another decline in spending for nonresidential structures, producing a 1.5 percent rate of decline.
Few analysts, however, believe that the consumer can continue the first-quarter spending spree. This is because some of the factors that put more money in the consumer's pocket in the first quarter will not recur and because both the job market and the growth of basic incomes remain relatively weak.
Partial evidence of this was in today's quarterly Labor Department report on employment costs, which presented an encouraging message of continued subdued inflation. Wages and salaries, however, grew only nine-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter, the same as in the preceding quarter and down from 1.1 percent in the comparable 1991 quarter.
Similarly, a Conference Board confidence survey showed a sharp rise in expectations about the future but said consumers were still uneasy about present circumstances.
On the other hand, the plunge in new-home sales was seen by many analysts more as an adjustment to exaggerated early-year gains than as a sudden March disaster. Edward F. McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman Sachs, called the G.D.P. numbers "reassuring" and the home-sales decline simply "a reminder" that the recovery still has to overcome such obstacles as sluggish car sales, declining business investment and a shrunken military.
Other data in today's output report showed that the bulge in consumer spending during the quarter cut the savings rate -- personal savings as a percent of disposable personal income -- to 4.7 percent from 5.2 percent.
Inflation, as measured by the fixed-weighted price index covering all items bought by American residents, rose to a rate of 2.7 percent from 2.2 percent. This was a bit more than expected, but was said by the Commerce Department to mostly reflect the Federal pay increase that is treated as an increase in the price of purchased employee services.
G.D.P. in current dollars instead of constant 1987 dollars rose at a 4.9 percent pace during the first quarter, compared with 2.2 percent in the final three months of last year.
Corporate profits from current production for the fourth quarter of 1991, the department also reported, were revised downward by $1 billion at an annual rate.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Small Stocks Getting Short Shrift

BYLINE: By SUSAN ANTILLA

 BODY:
Are small stocks worn out? From the looks of things in the past week, they are rather ragged. And analysts who make it their business to track stocks of small companies are heaping more and more scorn on them.
Perhaps the only thing going for stocks of companies with market capitalizations under $500 million is the contrarian view: nobody loves them, thus, there's likely some money to be made. 
 After reaching an all-time high of 644.92 on Feb. 12, the Nasdaq composite index has fallen 13.1 percent. In two weeks, the index, compiled primarily from smaller stocks, dropped 5.8 percent, to yesterday's 560.33.
 
Blue-Chip Indexes Steady
 All the while, indexes that track larger blue-chip companies have held relatively steady. The Dow Jones industrial average went on to hit six highs after the Nasdaq's peak, reaching its latest record of 3,366.50 on April 16. The Dow since dropped back to yesterday's 3,307.92 close, up 4.28 percent for the year, compared with an 8.08 percent drop this year for the Nasdaq.
So what ails the little companies? The carnage is largely the result of having come too far too fast. While the Standard & Poor's 500 gained 9.31 percent in 12 months, the Nasdaq composite soared 16.24 percent -- despite the pullback since February.
Though bargain-hunting is an inevitable temptation, analysts caution that it could be perilous for investors to fight the trend at the moment. Small stocks do best in a rapidly growing economy, points out Art Micheletti, director of research at the money management firm Bailard Biehl & Kaiser Inc. in San Mateo, Calif. But he is placing his bets on slow growth in the months ahead. Mr. Micheletti said a market timing model that he keeps flashed a sell signal for small stocks in February, and has not budged since.
Investors would do best to stick to large companies, he said. "You don't have to chase small caps," he explained. "You can buy big caps with good track records." Several drug stocks among these have fallen 20 percent from their 52-week highs, he added, noting that Warner Lambert looks particularly attractive at yesterday's $64.625 close.
Indeed, the investors who historically have turned in the most abysmal performance are the ones betting most heavily on stocks of small companies right now. Small investors who buy stock options have a notoriously bad record, said Donald Fishbach of the Cleveland-based Investment Research Institute, which studies patterns in options trading. Those folks are now quite bullish on little companies, heavily buying call options -- a bet on higher prices. "This is the dumb money and the dumb money is almost never right," Mr. Fishbach said.
Based on their heavy purchases of Microsoft call options, Mr. Fishbach is calling stock of that company "the No. 1 short for the rest of 1992." Meanwhile, what Mr. Fishbach calls "the old fuddy-duddy smokestack companies," like Alcoa, International Paper, and the auto makers, look attractive because they have not attracted the stock options players.
Contrarians who dare to buck the analysts' negative consensus on small stocks should keep in mind where the relative strength is. Small companies known for their fast growth prospects have been worst hit in the recent downturn, while stodgier small companies perceived as good values have not.
The T. Rowe Price Small Cap Value Fund, for example, has risen 8.97 percent so far this year, while T. Rowe Price's New Horizons Fund -- a small-company growth fund -- has fallen 9.57 percent. New Horizons lost 5 percent last week alone while the Small Cap Value Fund was up three-tenths of 1 percent.
The small stock indexes will not rally for another quarter or two, said Alan Radlo, who runs the Fidelity OTC Portfolio. It will take at least that long before investors begin to focus on 1993 earnings, which will turn the spotlight from cyclical stocks back to the small companies that are actually delivering earnings -- not promises. It will also take that long to rebuild investor confidence in the stock market generally, he added, saying, "You need new highs in the big caps to get all this jump-started again."
Patient investors might follow Mr. Radlo's brave advice to take advantage of the current disgust with small company stocks. He is buying shares of small health care companies and banks, including Wilmington Trust, First Tennessee National and St. Louis-based Mercantile Bancorp. "This is the time to buy solid companies cheap, as opposed to buying cheap companies," he said.
Such arguments do not persuade pessimistic technical analysts who shrug and point to history as their investment guide. Peter Eliades, who publishes Stockmarket Cycles, an investment letter, said secondary stocks tended to rally, then fizzle toward the end of a long bull market cycle, marking the last blast of speculation. "They have a run and then the big caps have a last fling," he said -- not unlike market action since January.

HEADLINE: Dow Advances by 3.36, But the Market Is Lower

BYLINE: By Reuter

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks rose slightly yesterday in a late wave of buying, but the market was broadly lower, hurt by rising bond yields and losses in technology issues.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.36 points to close at 3,307.92, but declining issues outpaced gainers, 961 to 724, in heavy New York Stock Exchange volume of 189.2 million shares. 
 The Dow was lower for most of the session until a late wave of technical buying pulled the blue-chip index higher, traders said.
Analysts shrugged off the Dow rally and said the market remained vulnerable to a downturn.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 0.66 point, to 409.11. The American Stock Exchange index fell 1.94 points, to 383.04. The Big Board's Composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.18 point, to 225.12.
Reports that the economy grew in the first quarter and that consumer confidence rose sharply did little to improve sentiment on Wall Street.
The Government said gross domestic product rose at a 2 percent annual rate in the quarter, while a business group said consumer confidence rose in April to its highest level in seven months.
"Two percent growth in G.D.P. is good news but below what you would normally get at this stage in a recovery," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Company. "The recovery in earnings is clear but somewhat uninspiring."
Erosion among secondary and technology issues led the way yesterday and dragged the Nasdaq over-the-counter index below its 200-day moving average. The index fell 6.61 points, or 1.2 percent, to 560.33.
Gregory Nie, analyst at Kemper Securities, noted that broader indexes had been unable to match the Dow's speedy rise, a negative sign for the market in the near term.
Analysts said high bond yields were luring investors away from stocks, although the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond was up about half a point, or $5 per $1,000 face amount, cutting its yield to 8.06 percent from 8.11 percent Monday.
"We've already seen assets moved from the stock market to the bond market," Mr. Johnson said. "The institutions are starting to do that in a formal way. I am hoping we will see the Dow stabilize at 3,250. If it were to go below that, we could have a serious downdraft."
The growing popularity of Ross Perot, the Dallas billionaire, as a possible Presidential candidate was cited as a factor pulling down stock prices yesterday.
Kemper's chief investment strategist, Rao Chalasani, recommended a shift from stocks to cash. Among the factors he cited in a report, Mr. Chalasani said Mr. Perot's possible candidacy "brings increased uncertainty to the U.S. market."
Among individual issues, Unocal jumped 1 1/8, to 25 1/4, and was the second-most-active stock on the Big Board. Dean Witter upgraded the stock after the company announced a plan Monday to cut its debt.
Xerox rose 1 1/8, to 74 3/8. Traders said Merrill Lynch repeated a positive opinion on the company.
Boeing, which posted earnings Monday, fell 5/8, to 44 3/8.
General Motors rose 1/2, to 40 1/4, after reporting its first quarterly profits in nearly two years.
Financial shares dropped on nervousness about the real estate giant Olympia & York's financial situation. BankAmerica dropped 5/8, to 45 3/8; Chemical eased 3/8, to 35 5/8, and Chase Manhattan lost 1/2, to 26 1/2.
On the over-the-counter market, Centocor fell 1 3/8, to 13. The troubled biotechnology company announced the resignation of its chief executive.
Microsoft slipped 4 1/4, to 109, on the company's expectations of slower growth.

HEADLINE: Wages Post 0.9% Gain, Same as in Prior Period

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
Pay and benefits for American workers rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter, the same gain as in the previous quarter, the Labor Department said today, indicating employers face little pressure to raise wages.
The department also reported that union contracts settled in the first quarter gave workers a 3 percent average annual raise over the life of the contract. That was down from previous raises. 
 "It's a case where workers, especially unions, realize that companies just don't have the money to add to wages," said Jean Sundrla, an economist at Evans Economics Inc. "They are more focused on job security and other benefits."
 
 
Down From Previous Year
 The rise of nine-tenths of 1 percent in pay and benefits was down from the 1.1 percent gain during the first quarter of 1991, the department said.
Much of the slowdown stemmed from smaller gains for government workers, whose compensation has been lagging behind that in private industry because of state and local governments' budget constraints.
The slight rise indicates that wage pressures are modest, said Kathryn Kobe, an economist at Joel Popkin & Company.
"Unemployment is high," she said, "and it puts people in a poor position to push for wage increases. It also shows that industries won't be facing a lot of wage costs."
In the 12 months ended in March, salaries and benefits of civilian workers, as measured by the Employment Cost Index, rose 4 percent, compared with a 4.6 percent rise in the previous 12-month period.
In private industry, workers' compensation rose 1 percent in the first quarter, the same as in the fourth quarter, but below the 1.2 percent rise in 1991's first quarter.
Wages and salaries for private- and public-sector civilian workers rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter of 1992, compared with a rise of nine-tenths in the fourth quarter and a 1.1 percent increase in the 1991 first quarter.
 
Variation in Data

 
 Benefit costs for civilian workers rose 1.3 percent on a seasonally adjusted basis in the first quarter after a 1.2 percent increase in the fourth quarter and a 1.4 percent rise in the first quarter a year ago.
The 3 percent wage gain in collective bargaining agreements was the first time in 11 quarters that settlements were lower than in the contracts they replaced. The previous contracts had given workers average annual increases of 3.2 percent over the contracts' lives and 3.4 percent in the first year, the department said.
The 36 new contracts, which covered 127,000 workers, raised wages 3.1 percent on average in their first year.
William Davis of the Bureau of Labor Statistics cautioned that the first-quarter numbers may not be the start of a downward trend because only 36 contracts expired or were renegotiated during the period. Between 100 and 200 contracts will be settled or renegotiated in the current quarter, he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Retreats After Data Show Housing Weakness

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most foreign currencies in overseas trading yesterday but retreated later to end mixed in the United States, weakened by a plunge in domestic housing sales that suggested more economic weakness.
Gold prices rose marginally. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery fetched $336.90 a troy ounce, up 30 cents. At the Republic National Bank in New York, gold was quoted at $336.05 a troy ounce, up 5 cents from a day earlier. 
 Currency dealers said the dollar began the trading day with strength, particularly against the German mark, which has been hurt by Germany's economic problems, a public employee strike and the nation's vulnerability to political convulsions in neighboring republics of the former Soviet Union.
At the same time, however, the Commerce Department reported a 14.8 percent tumble in March housing sales, the worst monthly decline in a decade. When currency brokers saw that number they began to sell dollars, reasoning that the United States economy may be faltering or the outlook was at best unclear.
"After that, the dollar just kind of sagged through the day," said Carl Forcheski, a foreign exchange trader at the Chemical Bank in New York.
Still, many currency strategists said they did not expect the dollar to make any dramatic moves in the forseeable future.
They said the dollar continued to show notable strength against the mark, despite much higher interest rates in Germany that theoretically make investments there more attractive.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 133.07 yen, from 133.65 yen Monday. Later in London, it closed at 133.30 yen. By the time trading concluded in New York the dollar fetched 133.20 yen, up from 132.95 yen Monday.
The British pound fell in London to $1.7750, from $1.7795 Monday. Later in New York the pound fetched $1.7768, cheaper than its $1.7775 exchange value Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with rates Monday, were: 1.6540 marks, unchanged; 1.5170 Swiss francs, down from 1.5235; 1.1957 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1971; 5.5770 French francs, down from 5.5775, and 1,243.25 Italian lire, down from 1,245.00.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Fell A Steep 14.8% in March

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
New-home sales suffered their steepest loss in more than 10 years last month, the Government said today. Declines were concentrated in the Northeast and the West.
Analysts said the surprisingly steep 14.8 percent drop in sales did not signal an end to the housing recovery, but did support forecasts that the economic rebound would be modest, even occasionally erratic. 
 They attributed the March decline to rising mortgage rates; uncertainty over attempts to enact a Federal tax credit for some home buyers, moves that eventually proved unsuccessful, and good weather in January and February, which lured sales to those months that otherwise might have been made in March.
 
A Note of Caution
 "It's a caution sign," said David F. Seiders, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders. The accompanying increase in inventories "suggests that builders put a bit more in the ground than demand warranted."
Sales in March totaled 513,000 at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, according to the report by the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development.
The drop was the steepest since sales plummeted 20 percent in January 1982, during the previous recession. It pushed the rate to its lowest level since a 499,000 reading in September.
Sales fell nationwide. The Northeast posted the biggest decline, down 31.4 percent, to a rate of 48,000. It was followed by the West, off 28.2 percent, to a rate of 127,000.
Sales were off 6.8 percent in the South, to 218,000, and eight-tenths of 1 percent in the Midwest, to 120,000.
The decline was the fourth for the housing industry since it began climbing out of its recession in February 1991. The revised 602,000 rate for February was weaker than the 613,000 in an earlier estimate.
Still, helped by a rate of 647,000 in January, sales so far this year are 24 percent higher than in the first three months of 1991.
The average sales price of a new home fell in March to $146,500 from $147,100 in February. The March price was down markedly from the average sales price of $156,400 in March of last year.
The median sales price last month rose to $119,900 from $118,000 in February but was down from $122,500 last year.
 Allen Sinai, an economist with the Boston Company Economic Advisers, said of the rise in sales that "there is a gradual housing upturn in process," but added, "the earlier burst was just not sustainable."
The March decline helped raise the seasonally adjusted estimate of new houses for sale to 276,000, a supply of 6.5 months at the current sales rate.
The first jump in inventories since September followed four straight months of strong gains in construction of new houses and apartments.
As for existing homes, the National Association of Realtors reported on Monday that the pace of their sales had also slackened in March, remaining at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.49 million for a second straight month.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Fun, Games, Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IMPERIAL Graham Cracker's troubles really began years ago, when management decided to coat with melt-resistant chocolate. The mega-losses came, though, only after hasty decisions to recoup falling revenues by diversifying into insecticides and laundromats. And now Imperial's heralded foray into the adult drinks market, a graham-flavored malt liquor called Macho Baby, is under fire from regulators.
With the creditors howling for their money, one might expect Imperial Graham to crumble. But thanks to the Chapter 11 provisions in the 1978 bankruptcy law, Imperial's managers may still live to make a few thousand more urgent business trips on the company's Gulfstream IV. Indeed, with a little luck in the draw of bankruptcy judges, the president may get the chance to invest Imperial's remaining cash on a scheme to recycle cookie crumbs. 
 Apocryphal? Sure. But bankruptcy law is widely faulted for the presumption that insolvent corporations are worth preserving -- and that management should be given a shot at pulling it off. Indeed, some critics of Chapter 11 want to go back to the future, advocating automatic liquidation if creditors cannot fashion a rescue on their own.
But three clever economists, Philippe Aghion (European Bank for Reconstruction and Development), Oliver Hart (M.I.T.) and John Moore (London School of Economics) argue they already have a better way. Building on an idea of Lucian Bebchuk at the Harvard Law School, they would give creditors an efficient method to assert their rights without prejudicing the decision to save or liquidate bankrupt companies.
Corporate reorganization under the eye of an impartial judge seems like a good idea. As a practical matter, however, Chapter 11 rarely works according to Hoyle because different classes of creditors have divergent interests.
Those with the highest priority claims may prefer the certainty of, say, 90 cents on the dollar through liquidation to a chance of full payment through reorganization. Junior creditors and stockholders, however, may have little to lose from keeping the company on a resuscitator. And judges, who often shrink from the duty of destroying jobs, are prone to give reorganizers the benefit of a doubt. Thus, Chapter 11 is typically a bazaar for negotiation, in which junior creditors have disproportionate bargaining power, and managers are often free to throw good money after bad.
Indeed, Michael Bradley at the University of Michigan and Michael Rosenzweig, a partner in the Atlanta law firm of Rogers & Hardin, argue that Chapter 11 is an irremediable mess that leads to the misallocation of capital. Their study in the March 1992 Yale Law Journal concludes that protection against summary liquidation has led to net losses for stockholders, as well as creditors.
But the Aghion-Hart-Moore team believes such pessimism is premature. In a paper, to be published later this year by the National Bureau of Economic Research, the economists start with Professor Bebchuk's remarkable prescription for eliminating conflicts between creditors.
Under the Bebchuk approach, the debts of a bankrupt company would be canceled. All the stock would be divided among senior creditors in proportion to the sums they are owed.
Junior creditors would receive options to buy this stock from senior creditors at a price that covered the debts to senior creditors. And the original stockholders, in turn, would get options to buy the options from junior creditors at a price that would cover every penny the company owed.
This would go a long way toward repairing the flaws in Chapter 11. Shares and options would be freely tradable, effectively creating a market for previously illiquid debts. Control of the business would not be a matter for negotiation, but one of amassing a majority of shares and options. Best of all, every former creditor and equity holder in the firm would have a parallel interest in maximizing the value of its assets.
But the three economists suggest one more step is needed to insure that entrenched managers do not take advantage of their insiders' position. The bankruptcy judge would solicit outside offers for the company's assets. And after giving shareholders and option owners a few months to rearrange their portfolios in light of the bids, the judge would supervise a vote on liquidation.
If a majority voted to liquidate, the sale would proceed. If it did not, the court would withdraw, leaving the reorganized company free of debt.
Skeptics doubt all creditors could establish their claims on the tight schedule needed for efficient reorganization. But Mr. Hart notes that stragglers could always be paid later, in newly created shares of the reorganized business.
Would it all work? Perhaps not so slickly as a first look suggests. The better question, though, is whether it would work better than Chapter-11-as-usual. That is not a hard one at all.

HEADLINE: Taiwan Backs Aircraft Deal

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 28

 BODY:
The Taiwan Government has decided to support a plan by the Taiwan Aerospace Corporation to invest $2 billion in the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, according to Economic Minister Vincent Siew. But the deal is still subject to final review by the Parliament in Taiwan and by the United States Government.
Mr. Siew gave his support to the joint venture in a statement summarizing a feasibility study prepared for Wednesday's parliamentary hearing. Copies of the report were distributed to legislators earlier this week. "The joint venture contains high risks but great opportunities," Mr. Siew said in the report. 
 Lin Sou-shan, a legislator of the governing Nationalist Party, said most legislators were undecided on whether to support the project. "The investment will have a long-term impact," he said. "We still have our doubts, and we need more details on the joint venture."
Taiwan Aerospace, 29 percent Government-owned, signed an agreement in November to acquire up to 40 percent of McDonnell Douglas's commercial aircraft operations. Under the agreement, Taiwan Aerospace will build wings and fuselages for the McDonnell Douglas MD-12, a new wide-body passenger jet.
Mr. Siew gave no indication how much the Government would invest in the project. Opposition legislators have opposed the deal, saying Taiwan should not buy shares in a commercial aircraft maker with financial problems.

HEADLINE: There in the Crystal Ball, Forecasters Are Thriving

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
OVERNIGHT, national boundaries have dissolved. Bitter enemies have suddenly become friends, while former compatriots go to war. Once-secure bank jobs disappeared without warning, as did the banks that symbolized all that was solid and dependable. Even the weather isn't what it once was.
When the world seems unpredictable, there is one business that thrives: predicting the future. Whether they stare at palm lines or trend lines, people who believe that they have some ability to forecast events of the next day, the next year or even the next decade are finding a growing demand for their services. 
 "Shocking things -- good or bad -- scare people," said Arnold Brown, chairman of Weiner, Edrich, Brown Inc., a consulting firm in New York. The restructuring of the economy brings a lot of pain. The end of the Cold War ought to have generated happiness, he said. But because it caught people by surprise, he said, it left them angry. "For powerful people, it strikes at their core to think they don't have control," Mr. Brown said.
A number of consultants who specialize in forecasting the future, and who call themselves futurists, said in interviews that their business has picked up markedly in the last year or so. Chief executives are showing more interest in the future than they did in the 1980's, according to Leaders magazine, a publication for C.E.O.'s. The magazine is responding to their interest by running more future-oriented articles like "The Future's Greatest Inventions" and "Leadership in the 21st Century."
And while sober researchers in think tanks may believe they have nothing in common with psychics and astrologers, those who use intuition to forecast the future are also finding a growing interest in their services.
A proliferation of both computer software for creating charts and "900" numbers for telephone consultations have made astrology more pervasive and more accessible. Even the elite among psychics and astrologers, who charge more than $100 an hour, now offer sessions by telephone and accept credit cards.
"I have people I've never seen," said Joy Herald, a psychic in New Jersey who said her business has gone up since she began the telephone consultations three years ago.
Earlier this month, more than 1,500 astrologers attended the United Astrology Congress in Washington to discuss matters like "No Nonsense Mundane Forecasting." That was a big jump over attendance at the last convention three years ago, which drew about 1,000 people, according to organizers.
"There is a definite revival going on," said Angel Thompson, an astrologer in Venice, Calif., who edits the newsletter for the Association for Astrological Networking, which has 1,000 members worldwide. The interest in astrology shown by Ronald and Nancy Reagan had an effect. "That changed minds," she said.
Ms. Thompson has not seen this much interest in astrology since the early 1970's. "People are desperate," she said. "They see an economy that's a disaster. They see a government that's totally corrupt. They are willing to try anything."
But even the business of forecasting is not without its uncertainty. The economic crunch has hurt some astrologers and psychics because clients must conserve money for here-and-now needs like food and rent.
While many companies may be hiring outsiders to do some consulting, there is no boom in staff jobs for futurists. "I don't see any indication that corporations are hiring staff to do forecasting," said Barbara Samuels, a vice president at Chase Manhattan Bank and president of the Council for International Business Risk Management.
Tom Mandel, a futurist at SRI International, a consulting company in Menlo Park, Calif., said that while his business had picked up, many people may have concluded that analyzing the future is a waste of time.
"There are a lot of ways people are adjusting to turbulence and change," he said. "One way to deal with this is to say, 'Let's just coast the waves.' "
The futurists who find their client list growing say they are in demand because rapid global change and a persistent recession have overturned old expectations. But the approach of the year 2000 may be a factor, too.
"The millennium is functioning as a psychological landmark," said Joseph Coates, president of Coates & Jarratt Inc., a forecasting firm in Washington. "It seems to be acting as an excuse for stock-taking. It's seen as a transition point for the economy and society."
Mr. Coates said he was selling projects to companies that would not have garnered interest five years ago, like an analysis of technology's impact in the next 35 years.
Maybe because so many past forecasts turned out to be wrong, like ones for fusion energy and the paperless office, clients are more skeptical, he said. "Rather than asking about the future, they want to know, what are the alternative ways the future can evolve," he said.
Long-range studies, though, tend to be the exception, not the rule. Most spinners of tomorrow's tales propel themselves not into the distant future, but into next year and the year after. That's very different from the late 1960's, when practitioners blithely looked ahead 100 years.
"At that time, you could think about the future and it was a pleasant thing to contemplate," said Michael Marien, editor of Future Survey, a monthly abstract of books, articles and reports about the future that is published for 2,400 subscribers by the World Future Society in Bethesda, Md. "I think there's a lot of fear of the future," he said. "You can't talk with too much authority about what's coming."
Futurists scan information from a vast array of sources. They provide reports to clients and hold meetings in which they discuss what the trends might mean for particular businesses. Basically, they are just astute observers who try to put together disparate pieces of a puzzle.
There is a lot of money, consultants say, for practical marketing-oriented advice, but little financing from government and private sources for long-range future fantasies.
Clients want that practical advice. "Hardly anybody is interested in a forecast 10 or 15 years out," said David Snyder, a futures consultant who is a partner in the Snyder Family Enterprise in Bethesda, Md. "They say, tell me what is going on now." His business, he said, was up about 15 percent last year over the year before. A similar burst occurred in the last recession. "As soon as apparent prosperity came back, business dropped off," he said.
Clients want to know what is going on worldwide so that they can decide on tactics and strategy.
"Things are changing so rapidly that to do business as you've always done it -- you're going to die," said Dolores Schatz, director of strategy and planning for Nynex, the telephone company based in White Plains.
Smart businesses, she said, are becoming like good poker players: they pay attention to everything that is happening. "Unless you are doing a really good job of monitoring your operating environment," she said, "things will blindside you."
When life appears clearer, forecasters seem less necessary. "If you can see to the horizon, anticipating the future is no trick," said Joel Arthur Barker, the head of Infinity Limited Inc., a consulting company in St. Paul. "Right now there is a lot of fog out there."
For an individual who cannot call in a futurist, a psychic or astrologer may be a substitute. It is impossible to know how many people visit these specialists, or how they regard the advice they receive. But the practice is becoming so much more mainstream that a number of spas now offer astrological readings and consultations with psychics. A year ago, the Sonoma Mission Inn and Spa in Sonoma, Calif., began offering guests the services of a tarot-card reader. "It still isn't as popular as a facial or a massage, but we get very positive comments from it," said William Blum, a company spokesman.
With chaos the defining concept of the age, approaches once derided for their nonrational base seem less dubious. "Science is turning out to be as much of a psychic game as anything else," said Nancy Stark, who reads palms at Raoul's Brasserie, a restaurant in SoHo.
Jill Goodman, who reads charts and tarot cards, said that for a long time she resisted the idea that she could be aware of events that had not yet happened. But when her forecasts turned out to be accurate, she began to respect cards and charts as legitimate tools.
The customers for psychics include fast-food cashiers and Wall Street traders. Averi Torres, a psychic in Malibu, Calif., who charges $275 an hour for an initial consultation, said most of her clients are entrepreneurs. "People who are educated know they need advice from as many sources as possible," she said.
While some futurists believe that their business is booming because times are bad and people are scared, Marvin Cetron, president of Forecasting International in Arlington, Va., attributes the surge to a growing belief that the recession is ending. His clients are trying to figure out the best places to put money now so they can profit from the coming prosperity.
There is, of course, another explanation offered by astrologers for all this future thinking. They say that the transit of Saturn through the sign of Aquarius, which last happened in 1962, is bringing interest in new and unconventional ways of learning.
But a word of warning: the current Uranus-Neptune conjunction, which comes around only once every 200 years, also promises sudden and unexpected change.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
America's Red Diaper Baby: The Left

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

The Rise and Fall of the American Left
By John Patrick Diggins
Illustrated. 432 pages. W. W. Norton. $22.95.
As a political idea and force in the United States, what's left of the left? Of the old reformist-minded left, the Marxist-oriented left, the more moderate democratic left? 
 After the downfall of the dictatorial Soviet and Soviet-dominated states, nationalism, ethnicism and tribalism have reappeared in several corners of the world. Political parties once considered on the left are in disarray in western Europe. What do these revolutionary changes and elections like the Labor Party's recent loss in Britain signify for the American left, if there still is one?
To help clarify what's happening requires a historian's long view. The necessary enlightenment appears in "The Rise and Fall of the American Left," by John Patrick Diggins, distinguished professor of history at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. It updates the facts he presented in his 1973 work, "The American Left in the 20th Century."
His new book is a highly readable account of American radicalism and the liberal impulse that resulted in major reforms in this century. Professor Diggins says we live in a curious time in the United States; the class war has been lost in the factories and fields. He maintains that the left no longer has political significance but still has educational influence in the battle for "cultural hegemony" on college campuses.
The most important point the author makes -- and it's one that the old Congressional un-American activities committees, the latent McCarthyites, the radical right and its neo-conservative cousins never acknowledged -- is this: "The American left was born in the United States."
"Contrary to popular belief, it was not the product of foreign powers and alien ideologies," he writes. "Although each left generation would have its rendezvous with European Marxism, Marxist ideas were usually embraced to support a radical movement that had already come into being. Most left intellectuals and activists in America read Thomas Jefferson and Walt Whitman before they read Karl Marx or, later, Mao Zedong, and many caught the flame of William Jennings Bryan or John Fitzgerald Kennedy before they felt the fascination of V. I. Lenin or Fidel Castro."
"The Rise and Fall of the American Left" is especially informative about the differences between leaders of the left and their aims in the 20th century. Professor Higgins divides the left's history into four groups: the Lyrical Left, the Old Left, the New Left and the Academic Left. Although these labels are arbitrary and they overlap, they do serve as useful signposts.
The Lyrical Left is placed before and after World War I, when Greenwich Village and environs was home to Socialists, anarchists, single taxers, suffragists, birth-control advocates and politicized poets. On the front lines of social and personal revolt were such legendary figures as John Reed, Max Eastman, Morris Hillquit, Emma Goldman, Mabel Dodge, Edna St. Vincent Millay and Margaret Sanger.
Their radical influence extended far beyond New York; writing about them in 1912, the artist John Butler Yeats said, "The fiddles are tuning as it were all over America."
Professor Diggins says the Massachusetts trial and execution of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, the Italian anarchists, was the rallying cry in 1927 for the Lyrical Left. John Dos Passos captured the shock of the execution in his 1936 novel, "The Big Money."
The Old Left is linked to the Depression. Its high points were the Spanish Civil War (Americans who served in the Abraham Lincoln Brigade against Generalissimo Franco's Fascists were listed in Federal Bureau of Investigation files) and Stalin's Moscow trials. The Old Left was convulsed by the purge of former Bolshevik leaders; the phony trials aggravated the split between the Trotskyites and those who continued to look to Moscow for guidance.
After World War II, the cold war discredited the Old Left in the eyes of the younger generation. The Soviet occupation of Eastern Europe caused many Old Leftists to realize that democratic freedom and one-party rule were incompatible. In this country, the assault against individual liberties by home-grown McCarthyites briefly gave the Old Left scattered sympathy but not political influence. After the failure of the revolution abroad, few veteran leftists were able to sustain their vital spirit.
To define the New Left's posture in the 1960's, the author quotes Jerry Rubin, one of its standard-bearers: "Communism? Who the hell knows from Communism? We never lived through Stalin. We read about it, but it doesn't affect us emotionally. Our emotional reaction to communism is Fidel marching into Havana in 1959."
The growth of American militarism and the Vietnam war, Professor Diggins says, "dramatized to young antiwar dissenters the powerlessness of idealism." But unlike Big Bill Haywood, the Wobblies and early radicals who had come out of the labor movement, the New Leftists had come out of the colleges. The New Left emerged in Madison, Wis., Ann Arbor, Mich., and Berkeley, Calif.; the author writes respectfully of such ideological groups as Students for a Democratic Society, founded at the University of Michigan in 1961.
Today's controversies over higher education find a home in Professor Diggins's Academic Left. At its center is the dispute over multi-culturalism and political correctness on campus.
If there is a shortcoming in Professor Diggins's book, it is that he doesn't reach back far enough into American reformist history. Nor does he place enough emphasis on the truly radical reforms achieved during the Administrations of the two Roosevelts, Theodore and Franklin, the first by regulatory agencies and trustbusting during the muckraking era, the second by New Deal legislation that remains so deeply ingrained in American lives that only one President since the 1930's, Ronald Reagan, tried to weaken the social gains in the name of privatization.
Child-labor laws, safety in the workplace, minimum wages, unemployment insurance, Social Security, environmental concerns: all were once denounced as Socialistic and un-American. Particularly in a Presidential election year, Professor Diggins's "Rise and Fall of the American Left" deserves to be read and pondered to understand the evolution of once radical ideas into accepted reforms.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Deputy Chairman Is Named To the Top Barclays Post

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
Andrew R. F. Buxton, deputy chairman and managing director of Barclays P.L.C., was named yesterday to succeed Sir John Quinton, who has been chairman and chief executive of Barclays, Britain's largest bank, since 1987.
Leaks to the British press last week that Sir John would step down caught analysts by surprise and generated speculation that the Barclays board, angry about the bank's poor performance, had suddenly forced out Sir John. 
 But Sir John, who who is 62 and underwent heart surgery two years ago, told The Times of London that his retirement had been planned for several months. "There has been no board room coup," he said. Mr. Buxton, 53, will become chief executive on May 1 and chairman at the end of the year.
There is no questioning the need for drastic steps at Barclays, which has been hit hard by its slowness to control rising costs, expensive ventures into Continental Europe and bad loans in Britain and the United States. It is a big lender to troubled companies with large real estate holdings, like Olympia & York in Canada and Heron International and Speyhawk in Britain.
Last year, Barclays took a charge of 1.76 billion, or $3.28 billion, to cover bad and doubtful loans, and its earnings fell by 59 percent, to 242 million, or $452 million. The bank was $179.3 million in the red after paying its dividend.
Analysts yesterday questioned whether Mr. Buxton, as a quintessential insider, was the man to shake up Barclays and improve its performance. Mr. Buxton is a member of one of the founding families of the banks that merged to form Barclays. Most Barclays chairmen have come from those families. Sir John was a rare exception.
"A lot of criticism leveled at Quinton has been fair, but it is also something that could be leveled at the whole management team," said Christopher Wheeler, an analyst at Lehman Brothers International.
Mr. Buxton, who read politics, philosophy and economics at Oxford University, joined a fast-track management program at Barclays in 1963. He worked in branches and served stints in the United States and in various regional management positions in Britain.
In 1979, he was appointed general manager in charge of the bank's corporate division. During the recession of the late 1970's and early 1980's, he headed a unit that worked with troubled corporate customers. He became vice chairman in 1985, managing director in 1988 and deputy chairman last year.
As managing director, Mr. Buxton has been responsible for the bank's day-to-day operations. To the concern of analysts, no plans were announced yesterday for him to relinquish that job.
Mr. Buxton is married and has two daughters.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN
Woman in the News: Lynn Hardy Yeakel;
Skillful Political Novice

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, April 28

 BODY:
Last Thanksgiving Porter Hardy Jr., a retired Congressman from Portsmouth, Va., bluntly told his daughter, Lynn H. Yeakel: "This ain't no time to be in Washington."
But Ms. Yeakel, a 50-year-old fund-raiser for women's charities, also listened to other advisers. Like her, they were outraged by the Senate Judiciary Committee's hearings on Judge Clarence Thomas's nomination for the Supreme Court, and they were also confident that it was the right year to shake up that most exclusive of men's clubs, the United States Senate. 
 "If it hadn't been for those hearings," Ms. Yeakel (pronounced YAY-kul) said in an interview Monday, "it never would have occurred to me to run against Arlen Specter. He's a frightening adversary."
On Feb. 6 she began campaigning in the Democratic primary contest for a chance to challenge Mr. Specter, the state's two-term Republican Senator. Her candidacy was summed up in newspaper headlines like one in The Philadelphia Inquirer on March 13: "Unknown, Inexperienced -- and Sure She Can Win."
Political analysts say Ms. Yeakel ran a flawless campaign, quickly establishing herself with a television advertisement that seemed to capture the mood of voter disgust with Washington. The commercial uses a segment of the televised hearings in which Mr. Specter, a former Philadelphia district attorney, questions Prof. Anita F. Hill of the University of Oklahoma about her sexual-harassment accusations against Judge Thomas. Ms. Yeakel then appears on screen and asks, "Did this make you as angry as it made me?"
Today, many voters apparently said yes, it did.
Ms. Yeakel says those hearings were a landmark in advancing the political candidacies of women, and she said it most forcefully in a recent interview on WHYY-FM public radio in Philadelphia.
"I believe that the backlash from those hearings is somewhat stronger than anyone has documented yet," she said, "and that in history we're going to see the Hill-Thomas hearings as being the turning point for American women in terms of really stepping forward, taking political power, using the vote, using our money to elect the candidates who represent our values and stand for our rights."
But Ms. Yeakel, who is trying to avoid being cast as a single-issue candidate, emphasizes that women's issues are everybody's issues. "I am running as a champion of women's issues, which are issues that are central in this society and include child care, pay equity, housing, education, jobs and the economy," she said Monday.
Lynn Hardy Yeakel was born July 9, 1941, in Portsmouth to Lynn Moore, a school teacher from Tennessee, and Porter Hardy Jr. Her younger brother, Porter Hardy 3d, died in a car accident in 1986.
Although she waited 50 years to run for public office, she has a personal knowledge of politics and Washington. She was 5 years old when her father began serving his first of 11 terms in the House, and she went to school in Alexandria, Va., with some of Dwight D. Eisenhower's grandchildren.
Her father once took her to hear Harry S. Truman's State of the Union Message. She also remembers meeting Queen Elizabeth at a British Embassy party, dancing with President John F. Kennedy at the White House and having Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson pick up a pack of cigarettes that she had dropped at that party.
"One of the things I took for granted was that I was as good as anybody else," she said.
In 1963 she graduated, Phi Beta Kappa, from Randolph-Macon Woman's College in Lynchburg, Va., and then worked at an advertising firm in New York. In 1965 she met Paul M. Yeakel on a blind date; six months later they married. "It was her brains and beauty," explained Mr. Yeakel, now a senior vice president of Kidder, Peabody & Company.
The couple have two children, Courtney, 24, a second-year law student at Boston University School of Law, and Paul Jr., 23, a third-year student at Wooster College in Wooster, Ohio. Ms. Yeakel likes to play tennis, lift weights and read mysteries, her husband said.
The Yeakels have lived in Rosemont, an affluent suburb on the Main Line in Philadelphia, for about 25 years. During most of those years Ms. Yeakel was a homemaker and volunteer in community organizations, serving on the board of trustees at Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church. In 1980 she helped found Womens Way, an organization that has raised up to $2 million a year for 35 women's groups that provide shelters for battered women, job training, health care and housing. Until she began campaigning she was executive director of the organization, which now has chapters in 15 states.
About the worst thing her friends say about Ms. Yeakel is that she tends to be a perfectionist and tends to overextend herself. "She absolutely refuses to let anything get in her way once she set her mind to it," said Patricia D. Henkels, a member of the board of Americans for Democratic Action.
Ms. Yeakel's fund-raising skills and her family wealth have come in handy. She has contributed or lent a total of $280,000 to her campaign and raised $550,000 more from 2,600 contributors. "She's run an almost textbook-perfect campaign," said Michael L. Young, professor of politics and public affairs at Pennsylvania State University in Harrisburg. "And she's had some lucky breaks, too."

HEADLINE: Grand Jury Indicts Ex-Aide To Reagan's Housing Chief

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
Deborah Gore Dean, executive assistant to the Reagan Administration's Housing Secretary, was indicted today on charges of soliciting and accepting an illegal gratuity and making a false statement to the Senate.
The indictment of Ms. Dean, a top aide to Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr., brought to six the number of people indicted or convicted in the investigation of the scandal-plagued Department of Housing and Urban Development during the Reagan years. 
 A Federal grand jury charged Ms. Dean with seeking and receiving $4,000 from an unidentified person in connection with that person's requests for a grant under the department's Moderate Housing Rehabilitation program. The program provided rental subsidies and tax credits to developers who rehabilitated low-income housing.
 
Nomination Not Confirmed
 She was also charged with making a false statement to the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs in denying that she was not involved in "potential conflicts of interest." The written statement, submitted on April 29, 1987, was made in connection with her nomination as Assistant Secretary for community planning and development in the housing department. The nomination never reached the Senate floor, and she was not confirmed.
If convicted of both charges, Ms. Dean would face a maximum penalty of seven years in prison.
Arlin M. Adams, the independent counsel who is investigating allegations of mismanagement, influence-peddling and favoritism in the department, said in a statement that the indictment was returned today to avoid the five-year statute of limitations.
Moreover, the indictment preserves the independent counsel's ability to obtain a superseding indictment, if warranted by a continuing investigation of her activities.
Ms. Dean strenuously denied the charges at a news conference today.
"I am outraged and saddened by today's indictment," she said. "I am innocent of all charges. They have hoped by threatening to ruin my reputation with an onslaught of accusations that I would relent, plead guilty, testify against my bosses at H.U.D. and in doing so, become an enthusiastic accomplice in the pursuit of their brand of justice. I'm not going to do that."
But she then acknowledged that there were problems at the department. "I am not saying that there weren't bad apples at H.U.D.," she told reporters. "Some people sold influence," she added, but she declined to say who they were.
She said that she was aware of the $4,000 referred to in the indictment, and that it "involves a close friend." But she refused to discuss any circumstances surrounding the money.
 
Response From Lawyers
 Her lawyer, Stephen V. Wehner, said, "This story will be told completely as soon as we get into a courtroom."
Mr. Pierce said in a statement issued by his lawyer, Paul L. Perito: "This accusation is inconsistent with her conduct as I knew it when she worked for me for several years at H.U.D. She is well represented, and I trust that there will be a speedy exoneration."
So far, two people have been convicted and three others have been indicted in the investigation of H.U.D. during Mr. Pierce's eight-year tenure.
DuBois L. Gilliam, an aide to Mr. Pierce, served an 18-month prison sentence after pleading guilty to conspiracy and gratuities charges in 1989.
 
Income Tax Evasion
 Last February, Samuel P. Singletary, a New York businessman close to Mr. Pierce, pleaded guilty to attempting to evade taxes on income he received from a consulting firm that had a grant from the housing agency.
The Federal grand jury also previously indicted Victor R. Cruse, a former Connecticut housing official and business associate of Paul J. Manafort, a Republican political consultant. Mr. Cruse was charged with lying to the grand jury and obstruction of justice in connection with Mr. Manafort's alleged efforts to block a H.U.D. grant to a housing project in Georgia because a bank had refused to finance his company's bid to buy the project.
Also awaiting trial are Lance H. Wilson, Mr. Pierce's former executive assistant, who was indicted on charges of fraud, conspiracy and making false statements, and Leonard E. Briscoe, a Texas real estate developer indicted on charges of filing false statements to obtain a $2.4 million H.U.D. grant.
Ms. Dean, 37 years old, joined the department in November 1982 as special assistant to Secretary Pierce. She became his executive assistant in June 1984, and resigned in July 1987 after her nomination as Assistant Secretary failed.
Before working for the Government Ms. Dean was a part-time bartender and publisher of "City Life," a life style magazine in Washington. She now runs an antique store in the Georgetown section of Washington.
Saying she looked forward to a chance to face her accusers in the courtroom, she asserted: "It's been five years for me. I want this over."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. ANNOUNCES A WELFARE POLICY

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 28

 BODY:
Deciding they need substance as well as scandal to make major gains in the November elections, House Republicans today unveiled the first of several legislative proposals they plan to introduce to show they are serious about domestic policy.
Today's example demanded work from welfare recipients. 
 The proposal would require recipients of Aid to Families with Dependent Children, if their children were 3 years of age or older, to work part time or go to school to remain eligible for benefits. It would also set a limit of four years' eligibility for benefits; after that, a welfare recipient would be expected to find a full-time job.
The proposal was introduced at a news conference here and was later echoed at 90 or so sessions around the country, where Republicans running in open seats or against Democrats announced their support of the plan.
 
'We Have the Ideas'
 Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the second-ranking House Republican, said the sessions were intended to show that "we have the ideas to solve real problems."
He said other topics of the monthly sessions would include education, health care, crime and litigation. In October, the House whip said, Republican candidates from all over the nation would be invited to come to the Capitol and pose for a picture with President Bush as a demonstration of teamwork.
"Most Americans know they're angry," Mr. Gingrich said at the news conference. "They want to know what you're going to do about their anger."
The Republicans, who now hold 166 House seats to the Democrats' 268, would need to gain 52 seats in the November election to win control of the 435-member body and carry out their plans. One seat is currently is held by an independent.
Mr. Gingrich said the Republicans constituted a "team for change" and would pass these proposals in the first 90 days of a new Congress if only the voters put them in charge.
The way Republicans were using the Gingrich initiative was shown by Bill Cleveland, one of five Republican candidates who attended the session here.
After Mr. Cleveland had listened and stood silently with Mr. Gingrich and other Republican lawmakers, his aides handed out a press release saying:
"Washington, D.C. -- Alexandria Vice Mayor and Eighth District Congressional candidate Bill Cleveland today announced a national welfare reform package, and pledged to work to enact the plan once he is elected to Congress."
Afterward at a news conference with Mr. Gingrich and Representative Vin Weber of Minnesota, Mr. Cleveland said: "The welfare state, despite the noble intentions of its founders, has become an albatross around the neck of our economy and our society. By reducing and even removing the inducements for holding down a steady job and keeping families together, what was meant to be a short-term assistance for tough times has become a wretched life style, passed down from generation to generation.' "
In other places, candidates broadcast the Washington news conference over loudspeakers for half an hour and then explained their support for the proposal.
Mr. Gingrich said 95 non-incumbent candidates were backing the proposal, a substantial part of an unusually large number of Republicans seeking House seats this year. Kirsten Fedewa, spokeswoman for the National Republican Congressional Committee, said there were at least 820 Republicans seeking the 435 seats in the House. She said that was a record and "at least twice as many" as there were at this point in the campaign two years ago.
The proposal itself was presented in only bare outline today. Mr. Weber said its objective was "lifting people out of welfare and making them independent."
He said the program was designed to say that four years "is as long as people are going to sustain you on the welfare rolls."
Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., Republican of Florida, said the measure was intended to see that welfare caseworkers, "in every way possible, encourage these people to go to work."
Before holding their news conference at the National Press Club, Mr. Gingrich and some colleagues explained it to the President at the White House. Mr. Gingrich said later that Mr. Bush was enthusiastic.
"You have a team for change in the House and Senate and Presidential Republican Party," Mr. Gingrich said.

HEADLINE: Mayor Dinkins and the Silver Lining

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration's new budget comes bound with a bit of shiny ribbon and includes the promise of some small but appealing initiatives. The politicking is forgivable even in these tough times because taken as a whole, the 1993 budget offers a prudent, candid plan that should serve New York City well.
If the Mayor keeps to his plan and does not give city workers a raise, he will manage to balance the budget without gimmicks, borrowing or an enormous tax boost. His budget makes conservative assumptions and continues to trim fat. 
 How did Mayor David Dinkins find a small surplus, some of which will finance new undertakings? Mostly through admirable diligence. The administration had a long-term plan to reduce spending and held to it steadfastly. Also, tax collections came in a little higher than expected.
The city is not out of trouble. The recession goes on. Jobs continue to disappear. But the new budget shows that the Dinkins administration has learned how to manage adversity.
Things didn't look so sensible a week ago. City Hall seemed mired in confusion as the Mayor, who has known nothing but municipal poverty since taking office, suddenly began making attractive promises. He talked about expanded library hours, community health clinics and other programs.
But now that his $29.5 billion budget is available for analysis, the good news can be seen in perspective. The $455 million surplus is only a thin silver lining, and the Mayor soundly uses much of it to avoid the need to borrow $250 million next year.
Any talk of a surplus, no matter how small, put labor leaders in a difficult position with workers who are not getting raises. Even so, the leaders reacted disingenuously last week. So did legislative leaders and Felix Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. They all had to know that the surplus is made up of non-recurring revenues that cannot go to wage increases, and does not eliminate the need for $115 million in state-authorized taxes or for $100 million from the M.A.C.
The budget has flaws. Mr. Dinkins could try for deeper cuts in the municipal work force and could truly overhaul the way government operates instead of making incremental changes. Moreover, the deficit in the fiscal year that begins in June 1994 already looms large.
But Mr. Dinkins and his budget director, Philip Michael, admit the problem and show a willingness to confront it. That candor, combined with prudence demonstrated in the budget, goes a long way toward restoring confidence in city government.

HEADLINE: When the Irish Came Into the American Club;
Slowly Changing Land

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As Anthony Lewis maintains, "Ireland is a changing country" (column, March 26), but visitors and readers should be cautious in interpreting visible symbols of change (including memorials to Oscar Wilde and Samuel Becket or the election of Mary Robinson as President) as evidence of a substantively different society.
Ireland has been changing since the late 1950's, when a major transformation in government economic policy began to restructure the economy. By the late 1970's, Ireland had many of the characteristics associated with modernization: the primacy of agricultural production and employment was displaced by manufacturing and services sectors, and the majority of Irish people were living in urban areas. There were increased participation in education, increased labor force participation by women and declining fertility rates. 
 Cultural change, however, was only partial. Modern Ireland steadfastly resists institutionalizing cultural options available in other Western societies such as divorce and abortion.
Since the early 70's, opinion polls demonstrated increasing support for divorce. By the beginning of 1986, only 24 percent believed divorce should never be permitted. That April, following the Government's announcement of a divorce referendum and publication of proposals for restrictive divorce legislation, 61 percent of those polled said they intended to vote for the divorce amendment.
But after nine weeks of debate -- during which, incidentally, the Roman Catholic bishops, reaffirming their post-Vatican II position differentiating law and private morality, stated that "Catholics in good conscience could vote in favor of the amendment" -- the Irish voted 64 percent to 36 percent against divorce. (Two months later, a poll majority again expressed support for divorce.)
Three years earlier, a "pro-life" amendment to the Constitution aimed at strengthening the criminal status of abortion, was overwhelmingly endorsed. Despite recent support for the 14-year-old girl who was at first banned from seeking an abortion in England following rape, it is unlikely that the Irish, if a future referendum were to be held, would vote for even restrictive abortion.
Although Prime Minister Albert Reynolds has expressed openness to another referendum on divorce and to exploring the moderation of the abortion ban, the party he leads, Fianna Fail, has politically exploited divorce and abortion, invoking the specter of "a stalking Frankenstein" as synonymous with change.
The Irish have been adept at disentangling their economic interests from their cultural identity; I have no doubt that the vote on European integration will be consistent with this pattern.
 
MICHELE DILLON
New Brunswick, N.J., April 9, 1992
 
The writer, an Irish citizen, is an assistant professor in communication at Rutgers University.

HEADLINE: Remembering a Father Of Social Security

 BODY:
To the Editor:
This month marks the 100th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Epstein, a founder of the American Social Security system. It is because of his conviction and courage that millions of Social Security beneficiaries -- retired and disabled workers, their families and survivors -- receive dignified Social Security, rather than suffer the misery of the poorhouse or the humiliation of the dole.
Born in Russia, Epstein came to the United States at age 12, graduated from the University of Pittsburgh, worked for the Pennsylvania commission to draft the first old-age pension bill, taught at New York University and Brooklyn College, and devoted his life to the principles of economic security for workers and their families. In the 1920's, he castigated "blind greed, selfish materialism and rampant individualism," championed the needs of the elderly and unemployed, and preached mutual protection and public responsibility. 
 His writing, speaking and lobbying helped mobilize public opinion and to pass the Social Security Act of 1935. From then until his death in 1942, Epstein argued for reforms in unemployment insurance and a national health system. Although poor in money, power and fame, he converted ideals into reality. His contributions have improved the lives of millions, and his pragmatic idealism should inspire us.
 
JEAN T. D. BANDLER
Associate Professor of Social Work
New York University
New York, April 15, 1992

HEADLINE: U.S. Informally Offers to Cut Rise in Climate-Warming Gases

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 28

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has for the first time offered to curb the increase in climate-warming gases released into the atmosphere by American factories, trucks and automobiles as part of a proposed agreement being prepared for a top-level international environmental conference to be held in Rio de Janeiro in June.
This American negotiating position was stated in Paris earlier this month during informal talks on the planned treaty between the industrial nations and some developing countries, officials said. 
 But the United States is still refusing to join the rest of the industrial world in accepting a treaty commitment to stabilize the emission of these "greenhouse gases" at 1990 levels by the year 2000.
 
Already Succeeding, Bush Says

In a document released last week, the Bush Administration suggested that there was no need for it to join in this pledge, contending that environmental programs the United States has already put into effect would reduce its emissions of greenhouse gases by 7 percent to 11 percent below what they would have been by 2000.
But officials acknowledged that the levels of such gases released into the atmosphere through American industrial production and use would still be 1.5 percent to 6 percent higher in 2000 than they are today.
At the Paris preparatory talks, the United States, in convoluted language, pledged only "to contribute to the global effort" on climate stabilization by "recognizing that the reduction of growth of net anthropogenic emissions of the total of all greenhouse gases not covered by the Montreal Convention would be an appropriate signal that longer-term emission trends have been modified consistent with that objective."
The Montreal Convention bans the release of gases that damage the ozone layer, meaning man-made emissions of carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide. In the view of many experts, these gases threaten environmental havoc by trapping heat in the atmosphere and melting portions of the polar ice caps, raising ocean levels.
The Bush Administration's stand at the Paris talks, which ended on April 16, is being seen by many diplomats and officials here as an indication that the United States is becoming slightly more flexible on global warming, which until recently it refused to recognize as being a problem at all.
Nevertheless, its position remains far from that taken by leaders of other industrial nations, in refusing to set legally binding targets for curbing greenhouse gas releases.
And in a presidential election year, the Administration appears reluctant to make commitments that might hamper economic growth. The President has not yet said whether he plans to attend the Rio meeting, which is known as the Earth Summit.
For officials in Washington, there are also considerations of life style. Americans, per person, consume more energy and other resources than Europeans or Japanese, and much more than citizens of third world countries. And many of those Americans who benefit from energy-intensive industries, or who enjoy well-heated houses and big cars, will vote in November. Their preferences are not likely to be overlooked as the Administration considers its positions in Rio de Janeiro and in the preparatory talks.
Negotiators from rich and poor countries are to meet here on Thursday to try once more to draft a climate-change treaty in time for the Rio meeting.
Such a treaty would likely be the most important achievement in Rio, and many heads of state and government are likely to make their attendance conditional on its being ready for signature then.
The United Nations officials organizing the meeting also hope to agree on another convention aimed at preserving the world's animal and plant life, as well as a general declaration on the need to insure that economic growth is environmentally sustainable. And they will seek a vast plan of action for cleaning up the global environment over the 21st century.
 
Help From Tokyo
 Officials said that in Paris earlier this month, Japan dropped its insistence that it be allowed a 6 percent increase in greenhouse gas emissions by 2000 to compensate for its expected population increase. This enabled industrial nations except the United States to agree on a single target.
America's negotiating offer to reduce the degree of increase in the levels of these gases leaves it the option of compensating for increased emissions through a large-scale reforestation program. Forests and oceans naturally absorb many warming gases.
The use of this Washington standard -- a reduction in increase, rather than a stabilization or reduction in existing levels -- might encourage countries like Brazil or Malaysia to preserve and expand their forests because it would give them room for industrialization while creating less danger to world climate.
But there is as yet no agreed method for calculating the quantity of greenhouse gases absorbed by oceans, forests and grasslands. And some experts express fear that the United States might use this lack of scientific agreement as a pretext to delay reducing emissions.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 30, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Bush Administration's policy on controlling the emission of gases believed to contribute to global warming misstated the focus of the international accord called the Montreal Protocol. It sets a timetable for phasing out chlorofluorocarbons and other chemicals associated with destruction of the earth's ozone layer; it does not cover "greenhouse gases" linked to global warming.
