HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Despite Grip on Nomination, Bush Still Gropes for Agenda

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 29

 BODY:
Although President Bush claimed his party's nomination Tuesday night, Administration officials say he has recognized what many Republican strategists concluded long ago: that he has not given the rest of America a good reason why he deserves a second term.
That is why the President has instructed his staff to focus on defining a broad agenda for the next five years, the officials say, an order that came as Mr. Bush shifted his attention to the general election and away from a primary season that had been much meaner than any of his advisers had predicted. 
 The political urgency of this effort was underscored by the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. Fifty-eight percent of the 1,151 registered voters questioned April 20-23 said the Administration was drifting without clear policies. More than a third said it was moving carefully to develop its plans, a reversal from April 1989, at the start of the Bush Presidency, when 61 percent said the Administration was moving carefully.
The pressure on Mr. Bush also comes from the elders of his own party. At a fund-raising dinner in Charlotte, N.C., on Monday night, the President sat tight-jawed watching a videotape in which Senator Jesse Helms chided him for not running an aggressive enough campaign and for the flip-flop on tax increases that led many Republicans to conclude that Mr. Bush did not have strong convictions on economic issues.
"Mr. President," the Senator said, "tell them once again, 'Read my lips,' but this time with gusto."
Acknowledging that Mr. Bush had not yet given Americans a vision of where he would take the country in a second term, Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, said, "By the time of the convention we want to have laid out an intellectual framework of what's been accomplished, what needs to be reformed and our vision of the future."
Mr. Fitzwater said the President wanted to begin doing that this spring in commencement addresses at four universities. But Mr. Fitzwater and others said the effort had not progressed beyond a general sense that the White House and the Bush campaign must address the problem.
The first speech, delivered at Florida International University in Miami on Monday, was little more than Mr. Bush's standard stump speech. In an address to a fund-raising dinner in Washington on Tuesday night, the President ended up sounding more like Ronald Reagan than George Bush as he talked about the "miracle called America." And a much-advertised Presidential announcement on deregulation today turned out to be a sparsely attended event in the Rose Garden in which Mr. Bush talked about the dangers of step stools.
Some Republican strategists say that events like these indicate that the Bush team still has to overcome the organizational obstacles and, equally important, the philosophical hurdles that have colored Mr. Bush's Presidency and hindered his campaign.
Associates and friends of Mr. Bush say he has never clearly understood the need to explain his decisions to the public. And they say he is intensely frustrated that the public does not give him enough credit for being a world leader, as shown in particular by what he sees as his bold command in the Persian Gulf war.
 
A Passive Presidency
 More broadly, Mr. Bush's problems in outlining his agenda for a second term spring from the custodial nature of his Presidency. Elected as the heir to President Reagan, Mr. Bush has run an essentially passive Presidency and has only recently tried to paint himself as an agent of change with his own ideas about where the country should go.
"It's going to be difficult for them to shape a vision now that is distinctive from what the Bush Administration has been, and that is a managerial and maintenance sort of Presidency, one of limited change," said Charles O. Jones, a professor of political science at the University of Wisconsin and a scholar of the Presidency.
"The President didn't explain all that well why he should have a first term," Mr. Jones said, adding that the 1988 election was in essence a decision "to go ahead with the Reagan-Bush Administration, with Bush now in the White House, since Reagan couldn't be there any longer."
 
Challengers With Vision
 But the political landscape in 1992 is much changed. Not only is Mr. Bush struggling with public discontent over his own record, but he has also been confronting challengers who offer a strong ideology and a clear vision.
Patrick J. Buchanan challenged Mr. Bush's claim to the support of the Republican right. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who has an impressive oratorical style -- something that has always eluded Mr. Bush -- is presenting himself as the true apostle of change.
Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Buchanan and Mr. Clinton increased the pressure on the President to lay out his own vision of a second term. But his efforts so far have been halting at best.
Consider this exchange during an hour-long news conference that Mr. Bush called in the Rose Garden on April 10 for no apparent central reason. The President was asked for his single most important domestic policy goal in a second term.
"Single goal?" he said. "There are several goals, and I've been spelling them all out."
He added: "But if you had to single out one, education covers so many of these fields and our goals to achieve those goals cover more, because I'm talking about -- one of them is being ready to learn. That's Head Start. And another one is a place where you can learn. That is drug-free schools. So when I talk about education, I'm talking about all of these things."
 
Typical Speaking Style
 That sort of free-range response, typical of Mr. Bush's speaking style, may have been adequate when his popularity ratings were soaring on the strength of the dissolution of European Communism and the gulf war victory.
But when the economy started going sour, Mr. Bush was confronted by an electorate who thought he was out of touch and uncaring. His Administration touched a raw class nerve with its initial comments about the recession.
The President and his aides said the downturn was part of a natural business cycle that some even suggested might be healthy. White House aides now concede that such explanations served only to annoy voters who did not see it that way.
Mr. Bush then tried to show his compassion and offered short-term fixes intended to demonstrate that he was addressing the recession. Administration officials were fully aware, however, that Congress was not going to pass those proposals, and the effort failed to halt Mr. Bush's political slide.
The White House then began a series of Presidential speeches and policy pronouncements that were supposed to summarize Mr. Bush's record on his "five pillars of reform" -- law, education, health care, government and foreign trade -- and offer new initiatives.
 
Incremental Changes
 But most of what the President has suggested were incremental changes or recycled versions of old proposals, and Mr. Bush still did not address the broader question of his own vision for a second term.
"Every incumbent thinks first of all that people judge him on his record, on what he's already done," Mr. Fitzwater said, describing Mr. Bush's frustration at how swiftly his popularity faded after the gulf war. "Something like this: 'I've been President for three and a half years. You know what I've stood for and how I've governed, and I believe it has been sound.' "
A senior Administration official said that everything the White House tried to do to help Mr. Bush this year was stymied by disarray in the White House ranks and by what the official called Mr. Bush's own disdain for public relations.
Mr. Fitzwater said the White House organization had improved. But he conceded: "We used to give a speech once and never came back to it. We never give the 'why' of things. We're just getting around to the 'why' now."

HEADLINE: Conservatives Call for PBS To Go Private or Go Dark

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
With a Senate appropriations bill as the battleground, public television is facing the bitterest political opposition in its history in a struggle that public television executives say could threaten the future of the Public Broadcasting Service.
In the last six months, public television has come under a well-organized attack by conservative politicians and organizations who charge that public-affairs programs on PBS have exhibited what they call a "liberal tilt." More recently, the charges have evolved into a suggestion that PBS is no longer a necessary or even worthwhile source of programming, because cable networks have arisen that offer the same kinds of programs.
 
The Possibilities
 The possible outcomes range from a cut in the requested appropriation, which is significantly higher than it was in the last two amendments, to adding some form of Governmental editorial oversight, to a delay that would put off consideration of the financing until next year, effectively hobbling the system. 
 The opposition is from a group of conservative organizations that define themselves as media watchdogs. Among the groups are the Heritage Foundation in Washington, whose Bradley Resident Scholar, Laurence Jarvik, has served as the point man in the attacks on public television. Mr. Jarvik was among the first to charge that the system has "outlived its usefulness."
He has urged that the Federal financing arm of the public television system, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, be sold outright to anyone willing to buy it, "anyone from the BBC to Ted Turner," Mr. Jarvik said.
Another vocal critic is David Horowitz, the chairman of a group in Los Angeles called the Committee on Media Integrity, which monitors pubic-affairs programs on public television. Mr. Horowitz had previously worked as a speech writer for Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader.
Senator Dole has been a principal player in the political sparring over the bill that would authorize Federal money for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. During debate on the Senate floor last month, he said, "I have never been more turned off and more fed up with the increasing lack of balance and the unrelenting liberal cheerleading I see and hear on the public airwaves."
The conservative opponents charge that the public-affairs programs on PBS have violated a law that requires "balance and objectivity" in programs. They have focused here on a PBS decision to put its programs on the 1992 political campaign into the hands of two journalists, Bill Moyers and William Greider, whom they identify, in Senator Dole's words, as "two liberal Democrats."
PBS executives have responded that the Public Broadcasting Act was interpreted by a Circuit Court in Washington in 1975 to mean that political views had to be balanced not within the same program or the same series of programs but across the spectrum of programming on PBS. These executives said PBS did indeed offer balance, and as proof they point to regularly scheduled programs whose hosts are such identifiably conservative or Republican figures as William F. Buckley Jr., John McLaughlin and Tony Brown.
Created by the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967, the public-television system was intended to be a noncommercial educational alternative to the commercial broadcast networks. The system has always been a maze of conflict and interdependency among public television stations, loosely united under a central organization based in Washington. Financing for programs has always been a complicated mix of Federal grants, corporate underwriting, foundation support and contributions from individual viewers.
The Federal portion of the overall PBS budget has declined over the years and is now down to 17 percent. For this year, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting received $251 million from the Government. An additional $253 million is already allotted for next year. The appropriation in dispute is for the years 1994 through 1996. PBS executives say it is imperative that financing be allocated at least two years in advance so that programs can be developed and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting can be insulated from exactly the sort of political pressure that is now being exerted in the Senate.
The Federal authorization of $275 million for 1994, an allotment already approved in the House, is facing several amendments suggested by the Republican opposition. The amendments, said Nancy Neubauer, the director of communications for America's Public Television Stations, the lobbying organization for public television, are likely to impose some oversight on the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
The president of PBS, Bruce Christensen, said the organization was not offering to compromise on the issue of freedom from political interference. "We responded to any request for changes by saying we don't want any amendments," he said.
 
Concern Over Attacks
 Mr. Christensen says the opposition to PBS may do lasting damage. "I'm concerned these ideological attacks may be effective," Mr. Christensen said. "I'm concerned public television will come out of this with editorial restrictions and less money to do education programs."
Mr. Chistensen said he feared that if the Republicans opposing the current appropriation failed to get the oversight they sought they would simply insure that the appropriation never gets through this year. "I have heard that this whole thing may be a tactical maneuver to get year-to-year oversight," Mr. Christensen said. That would eliminate much of the shield from governmental interference that PBS has had, Mr. Christensen said.
The argument has reached the point where some conservative opponents of public television are suggesting an end to the current public television system to be replaced by a privately owned system with no governmental backing. Among their arguments is that cultural programs similar to those shown on PBS are already available on several cable channels and that the audience for PBS is made up of the elite and affluent so these people ought to be able to afford to pay to see the same programming on cable channels.
 
On Disenfranchising the Poor
 PBS executives respond that their overall mix of programming is not matched elsewhere, that no other channels do the same kind of independent public-affairs programming (the kind that has raised conservative ire) and that its audiences are far from elite and instead largely matches the overall television audience.
Moreover, PBS argues, relying on cable for the kind of programming PBS provides would disenfranchise many of the poor and minority groups the service is intended to reach and would cut off educational programs.
While Mr. Jarvik argues that public television partly justifies its continued reliance on Government financing because of the status any association with the Government confers, he said money was still at the center of the dispute. A main reason that the Corporation for Public Broadcasting appropriation has come under fire, Mr. Jarvik said, is that the request was so high in a time of recession.
"They came in looking for a 50 percent increase," he said. "If they had asked for less money, it's likely no one would have said a word."
Mr. Christensen called that reasoning a "smokescreen for the right-wing political objectives" and pointed out that the requested increase was to be used for additional educational programs.
Some Democratic Senators, including Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, have seized on the conservative attacks on public television as a threat to the future of such an American institution as Big Bird, the tall yellow star of "Sesame Street."
Possibly because of its value as a symbol of what PBS has done well, "Sesame Street" itself has become a target of the right-wing criticism of public television.
Mr. Jarvik and Mr. Horowitz have charged that the Children's Television Workshop, of which "Sesame Street" is part and which made $24 million last year through licensing agreements with a theme park, a stage show and toy makers and has an endowment of more than $50 million, is so rich that it ought not to receive any Federal financing for any of its programs.
Fran Kaufman, the vice president of public affairs for the Children's Television Workshop, said that "Sesame Street" itself had not received any money from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting since 1982 and that the organization pours millions of dollars of its own money into its program, more than $90 million in the last 10 years.
Still Mr. Jarvik disputes the value of Big Bird as a positive symbol for PBS. " 'Sesame Street' is just another kids' show," Mr. Jarvik said. "No better than 'Underdog' or 'The Flintstones.' What did the taxpayers get for their investment in 'Sesame Street'? A generation of kids who spray graffiti on the walls of New York City. If 'Sesame Street' was so effective, why do we have such a literacy problem?"
Mr. Christensen said many charges leveled at PBS result from deliberate distortions. He said PBS had become a new scapegoat for right-wing organizations that previously attacked the National Endowment for the Arts over its backing of "Tongues Untied," the much debated PBS documentary about the experience of black homosexuals.
Mr. Moyers said he had been subjected to charges of liberal bias since his days working for the Lyndon B. Johnson Administration. He labeled the charges about PBS as "caricature and misrepresentation" and said the critics never actually "talk about the context of the programs."
One chief piece of evidence the conservative groups now offer as proof of the "liberal tilt" to PBS documentaries is a recent study by S. Robert Lichter of the Center for Media and Public Affairs, which is financed by conservative organizations and studies how the news media treat social and political issues.
Mr. Lichter said he studied all prime-time public-affairs documentaries on PBS for the 1987-88 television season. His conclusion: "The ideas expressed were far more consonant with the beliefs and preferences of contemporary American liberals than those of conservatives."
The battle has been so overtly political that it has left some PBS executives dispirited and gloomy about the future. "This is the most frustrating experience I have ever been through," Mr. Christensen said.

PUB-DATE: April 30, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 1103 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Front-Runner;
Clinton Goes to the Capitol Seeking Democrats' Favor

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 29

 BODY:
He has castigated them for giving themselves a pay raise, chastised them for being part of Washington's policy gridlock and proudly declared himself a virtuous outsider.
But today, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas came to Capitol Hill to call on the Democratic Senators and Representatives and seek the votes of those who are guaranteed positions as superdelegates to the national convention. And from many quarters, he received their support. 
 Mr. Clinton and the Congressional Democrats he came to court were on their best behavior in meetings on both the House and Senate sides of the Capitol. But the political delicacy of the situation was lost on neither the Democratic Presidential candidate nor on the members of Congress. Both have had their share of career-threatening distractions in the last few months, and some were trying to push Mr. Clinton along the road to recovery.
"I think this thing is beginning to really move," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader and a Clinton supporter. "Momentum is building in this campaign. Pennsylvania may have broken the ice, and I think his numbers are going to quickly climb."
Senator George J.Mitchell, the majority leader, said Mr. Clinton had amassed "broad and enthusiastic support" in the Senate.
Such statements represented the kind of good news that had been slow in coming to Mr. Clinton, as some members of his own party took turns publicly criticizing him as too weak to defeat President Bush.
The Arkansas Governor has lately begun emphasizing in his speeches his contention that he will be the best candidate of change, a message that takes a page from the approach of former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California and attempts to cancel Ross Perot's claim that he is the true outsider. In today's appeal he said, he was calling for a "partnership for change."
"While it is true that I have been critical in the past of some things that have happened in the Congress, as I think the Congress members themselves have, the essential truth is that we're not going to turn this country around until we have a President and Congress jointly committed to change, committed to change the lives of this country and restore the leadership of this country economically," Mr. Clinton said.
After listening to the Arkansas Governor, several members of Congress who had not endorsed a candidate said they would support Mr. Clinton at the Democratic National Convention.
Among those in the House who said they would help Mr. Clinton gain the party's first ballot nomination were Representative Jolene Unsoeld of Washington, Robin Tallon of South Carolina, Gerry E. Studds of Massachusetts and Vic Fazio of California. In the Senate, Mr. Clinton was endorsed by Senators Edward M. Kennedy, Terry Sanford of North Carolina, Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, and Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio.
 
Not All Are Swayed
 "Bill Clinton is going to be the next President of the United States," said Mr. Tallon, who is among the lawmakers who have worried that their own re-elections would be endangered without a strong figure at the top of the ticket. "It's time for all Democrats to come together and lend support to Bill Clinton to get this country moving."
But not all Congressional Democrats were swayed by Mr. Clinton, who spent his day on Capitol Hill talking policy, not politics.
"We're supposed to be uncommitted," said Representative Romano L. Mazzoli of Kentucky, who said he would not endorse Mr. Clinton yet because it would conflict with his role as a superdelegate. "That's the whole theory of the designation, to try to figure out how to win a race."
But the general direction of the political winds were shifting in favor of Mr. Clinton after his victory in the Pennsylvania primary on Tuesday. Even so, the reasons for the sudden rush to unity seemed to have more to do with pragmatism than enthusiasm.
 
'Getting on Board'
 "He's going to be the nominee, so good Democrats are getting on board -- that's it in a nutshell," said Representative Don Edwards of California, who committed himself to Mr. Clinton.
Many remained preoccupied with their own troubles, including a nationwide bout of anti-incumbency fever that has been fed by the House banking scandal and aided by redistricting that has threatened members with seats that were previously safe.
When asked whether he would support Mr. Clinton, Representative Norman Y. Mineta of California responded: "Frankly, I haven't focused on it yet."
There was much speculation today that Mr. Clinton would seek to play down the Capitol Hill endorsements to preserve the ground he has staked out for himself as an agent of change. Today two dozen lawmakers gathered behind the Governor at a news conference laughed nervously when Mr. Clinton was asked if appearing with such an array of Washington lawmakers would damage his credibility.
 
Clinton Takes Middle Road
 "Not if people think about it," he said. "I have not come here to change a position I have taken." He said he had urged the House members to introduce a stronger bill to change campaign finance laws if President Bush vetoed the one now Congress.
Mr. Clinton appeared to settle on a middle path between bashing Congress and identifying too closely with its members. "I know, and I think the American people know, that we cannot hope to turn this country around unless the President and the Congress are in harmony, working together to get something done."
But when he was not on Capitol Hill yesterday, Mr. Clinton worked to keep his arm's length approach to Congress on display.
"I think that maybe I am just different from them," Mr. Clinton said when he was asked by reporters about why there had been so much grumbling about Mr. Clinton's electabilty among Washington lawmakers. "I've been a Governor for 11 years. I've been used to living with a much higher level of budget discipline, a much higher level of ability to convince people to invest in the future more. The whole background of what the states have had to do in the last 11 years is so different from the kind of division and discord and paralysis that has characterized Washington, that they may think I'm coming from a different place."
Some members of Congress returned the needling. Representative Wayne Owens of Utah said he still had "a concern that he's not, in the end, going to be electable."
"I want to see how he does in California," said Representative Leon E. Panetta of California. "I have some concerns that a lot of people have over what he's going to confront in November."

HEADLINE: Speaker Backs Cuomo Plan to Take On Medicaid Costs

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 29

 BODY:
Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin today gave his unqualified endorsement to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's complex and potentially expensive proposal for the state to assume the local share of Medicaid costs.
Mr. Weprin's announcement, in an interview with New York City reporters, was the first significant display of legislative support for a proposal aimed at protecting New York City's and other local governments from the explosive growth in the cost of Medicaid, the primary health-care program for the poor. 
 "I certainly will be in favor of it," said Mr. Weprin, a Queens Democrat. "I think the Governor's proposal makes a lot of sense, not only for the City of New York but even more so for a lot of the counties."
Mr. Weprin said he had not yet discussed the proposal in detail with other members of the Assembly. But he predicted that the proposal would be approved by the chamber, which is controlled by Democrats.
 
New Lobbying Effort
 Under Mr. Cuomo's proposal, which was first unveiled last September, the state would gradually assume responsibility for Medicaid costs currently covered by local governments. By the year 2000, when the phase-in would be complete, the local governments would save $1.6 billion annually, the Governor estimates.
In exchange, the state would retain revenue generated by the personal income tax in New York City and by the sales tax in the state's 57 other counties. The proposal assumes that Medicaid costs will grow at a faster rate than local tax revenues. If not, the plan guarantees that local governments will not give up more in tax revenue in any year than they would otherwise spend on Medicaid.
The Speaker's endorsement came on the same day that Mr. Cuomo kicked off a lobbying effort for his proposal by showcasing a bipartisan coalition of local officials who support the plan, including Mayor David N. Dinkins. Mr. Cuomo said at a news conference with the local leaders that he would make the Medicaid financing plan one of his priorities for the rest of the legislative session.
The group included a number of prominent Republican officials, like the Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the 1986 Republican gubernatorial nominee.
 
Skepticism in the Senate
 But officials in the State Senate, which has a Republican majority, said they still had serious reservations about the proposal's potential cost to the state.
"It has to be demonstrated to us that this is going to be as much of a win-win situation as the Governor suggests, with counties not losing out in terms of what they're giving up and with the state not having to raise taxes to pay for it," said John E. McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino. "We are not convinced."
New York is one of the few states in the country to require local governments to pay a share of Medicaid costs. Local governments currently pay about 21 percent of the state's total Medicaid costs, with the state government paying 36 percent and the Federal Government paying 43 percent.
Mr. Cuomo said in a statement today that if left unchecked, local Medicaid costs, currently about $2.7 billion a year, would grow by more than 12 percent this year and would reach more than $7 billion by the end of the decade. The state's share of Medicaid costs is now more than $4 billion and has nearly tripled since Mr. Cuomo became Governor in 1983.
The principle behind the Cuomo plan is to use the state's larger tax base to pay for expected growth in Medicaid. The primary source of state revenue, the personal income tax, is considered more progressive than the property taxes and sales taxes used by local governments.
"The real-property tax is the worst and the dumbest and most retrogressive," Mr. Cuomo said. "It's a foolish tax and we've got to get away from it. Just keep shifting the burden as we can from them onto the state, which has an income tax and not a real-property tax, and put the burden on the income tax."
The key to the plan's success is for the state to cut Medicaid costs sufficiently in the next few years to insure that it does not inherit a fiscal nightmare. The new budget approved by the Legislature and Mr. Cuomo produced savings of $1.1 billion in welfare and Medicaid programs.
When Mr. Cuomo originally proposed the Medicaid plan, many critics suspected that it was meant to help New York City -- home to most of the state's Medicaid recipients -- more than other parts of the state. But today's news conference demonstrated that local leaders from across the state had decided that all regions would gain from the measure.
The New York State Association of Counties released statistics today showing that while New York City has the largest share of local Medicaid costs, the program's growth is far greater in other counties than in the city. Local spending on Medicaid grew by 15 percent in New York City last year, but 44 of the 57 other counties had higher rates of growth, the statistics show.
"The growth of Medicaid costs at two or three times the rate of inflation is robbing our residents in Westchester County and throughout all of the counties of nonmandated services that they'd like to fund, like day care, recreation, enhanced public safety, some drug education programs, senior citizens, the arts," Mr. O'Rourke said. "The Governor's proposal is the last, best chance I believe that we will have to curtail this fiscal monster that eats into our county budgets."

HEADLINE: Transit Union Reaches Deal On a Contract

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Transit officials and leaders of the transit workers' union, whose 32,000 members rejected a contract last month, said yesterday that they had reached a new agreement that would prevent a threatened strike by New York City's subway and bus workers.
"The strike threat is gone," said Sonny Hall, president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union. "There is not going to be a strike." The agreement contains a provision that both sides will agree to binding arbitration should the rank and file reject the new contract. 
 Transit officials said the new agreement would not cost any more money than the rejected one. Nor would it require an increase in the $1.25 fare, they said.
The first contract, rejected by a 2-to-1 vote, had called for a 4.5 percent raise this year and an additional 2 percent raise next year. It also featured a one-time payment of $1,000 to cover inflation for the period since the last contract expired last May and a worker-productivity program.
 
2 Percent in First Year
 The new contract calls for a 2 percent raise retroactive to last May with an additional 2.5 percent on Sept. 1 and another 2 percent in March 1993, officials said. It eliminates the $1,000 payment and the worker-efficiency program, two components that union leaders said the workers found particularly offensive.
Despite the agreement between the union's leaders and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, it remained uncertain whether the pact would forestall wildcat job actions that have been threatened by dissident factions in the transit workers' union.
The dissidents, who worked hard against the first contract proposal and who oppose arbitration, have said that they would stage a job action during the week of the Democratic National Convention in July.
They have also scheduled a rally for Friday afternoon in downtown Brooklyn. After a similar rally in March, some transit workers pulled the emergency cords on at least six subway trains, shutting down two major lines on the Upper West Side for almost an hour.
 
Cuomo Had Asked for Meeting
 Asked about his opponents within the union at a news conference late yesterday afternoon in the offices of Governor Mario M. Cuomo at the World Trade Center, Mr. Hall said, "I am not aware of wildcats or any opponents in my union. We've dealt with that vast majority who wanted to reframe the proposal." Mr. Cuomo had asked the two sides to meet yesterday. After five hours of negotiations they emerged to announce their new agreement.
Two weeks ago, Mr. Hall debated Tim Schermerhorn, a leader of New Directions, one of the dissident groups, at The New York Times. Mr. Schermerhorn said during the debate, which was held at Mr. Hall's suggestion, that he would oppose arbitration and would support a job action in July. Mr. Schermerhorn could not be reached last night for comment on the new agreement.
Although the new agreement splits up the 4.5 percent raise into two years, which means that the first year's raise would be compounded in the second year, the proposal would not increase the total cost to the M.T.A. That is because the dates on which the raises would go into effect have been shifted slightly to offset the compounding, Gary J. Dellaverson, the M.T.A.'s director of labor relations, said last night.
Mr. Hall had called the first contract proposal the best that could be obtained during the city's deep recession. After it was rejected, he went back to the M.T.A. seeking more money.
But transit officials, and later the Governor, insisted that there was no more money to give. The bargaining broke down two weeks ago, with transit officials asking the state to appoint an arbitrator.
Mr. Hall said initially that he would oppose arbitration, and then said he would ask for a strike vote by his membership. He never said when, or even if, he would actually call for a strike. But he said he would mail out strike ballots to his members by the end of this week.
 
Medical Plan a Problem
 The possible bankruptcy of the union's medical plan, which is financed by the M.T.A. and operated by the union, further complicated the dispute. The January proposal called for the M.T.A. to pay an additional $40 million to stabilize the health fund and to maintain the level of benefits. Transit workers would have had to begin paying $10 for each doctor's visit.
After the first contract was voted down, the M.T.A. said that it would not advance any additional money to help the health plan. As a result, union members were to lose some benefits, including coverage for prescription drugs and dental care, at the end of this week.
Transit officials said that, under yesterday's agreement, they would advance $5 million to the health plan to maintain existing benefits.
He said that by Saturday he would mail ballots to his members asking them to choose between the latest contract and binding arbitration. Simply voting against the new proposal will apparently not be an option.
The deadlock over the terms of a potential arbitration was broken when both sides agreed to limit the issues to be the subject of arbitration to those that had been under negotiation for the last year. That would include wages and benefits, as well as proposals from the M.T.A. for trains without conductors and part-time bus drivers.

HEADLINE: Revenue Up For Bechtel

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 29

 BODY:
Bechtel Group Inc. said that despite the recession its revenues jumped 34 percent, to $7.5 billion, in 1991, the biggest annual gain in nearly a decade for the huge construction and engineering company.
Privately held Bechtel, which had suffered during much of the 1980's, also had a more profitable year than in any of the seven previous ones, the company's president and chief executive, Riley Bechtel, said Tuesday. He declined to be more specific. 
 "It's been a very dry market for six or seven years," Mr. Bechtel said. "The whole industry has been flat on its back for so long. But I think we've seen the start of a turnaround."
The results pushed Bechtel past the Fluor Corporation of Irvine, Calif., as the nation's biggest construction and engineering company in terms of revenue. Fluor's revenues fell to $5.8 billion from $6.4 billion in its fiscal year, which ended Oct. 31, although the company posted record profits.
Nearly all of Bechtel's business lines -- including petroleum, chemical and pipeline -- recorded sharp gains, particularly in international markets.
A major portion of revenue was earned in Kuwait, where Bechtel put out hundreds of oil and gas fires that had been touched off by Iraq during the Persian Gulf war.

HEADLINE: Curb on Population Growth Needed Urgently, U.N. Says

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 29

 BODY:
After revising upward its forecasts for world population growth, a United Nations agency called today for "a sustained and concerted program starting immediately" to curb the expansion. It said such action was needed to reduce poverty and hunger and to protect the earth's natural resources.
Releasing its latest population projections, the United Nations Population Fund said the world's population would probably rise from 5.48 billion in mid-1992 to 10 billion in 2050 before leveling off at 11.6 billion after the year 2150. 
 This means that the world's population is expected to stabilize at a level that is one billion higher than the United Nations predicted in its last long-term forecast, in 1980, but about 50 years later in time. In 1980, the agency predicted that global population would level off after 2100 at 10.6 billion people.
 
97 Million More a Year
 The new projections show the world adding 97 million new people every year until the end of the century and 90 million a year thereafter until 2025. The following 25 years will see annual additions of about 61 million people, the report said.
"Ahead lie four decades of the fastest growth in human numbers in all history," the report said.
Ninety-seven percent of the increase is expected to occur in developing countries, with Africa alone accounting for 34 percent of the rise. The report warned that such rates of growth mean greater numbers of poor and hungry people, increased migration toward cities and richer countries and increased pressure on the world's reserves of food, water and other natural resources.
"This crisis heightens the risk of future economic and ecological catastrophes," Dr. Nafis Sadik, a Pakistani physician who runs the Population Fund, said at a news conference in London today.
The United Nations Population Fund, which seeks to encourage family planning throughout the developing world, called for an urgent new campaign to curb the third-world population explosion in the coming decade.
The United States, which used to provide about 27 percent of the voluntary contributions governments make to the agency, suspended all funding in 1976 in a quarrel over abortions in China. The agency's current budget is about $225 million a year.
 
Growth Could Be Cut
 While it calls a rise in the population to 10 billion by 2050 the most likely development under current circumstances, the Population Fund believes a stepped-up campaign in favor of smaller families during the next decade could push this figure down by 1.5 billion to 2 billion people.
This would be in line with its alternative low population forecast, and some four billion people fewer than its high projection, which sees world population reaching 12.5 billion in 2050 and 20.7 billion a century later.
The crash program it favors emphasizes better education and health care for women in the developing world; it points out that 300 million such women do not have access to safe and reliable forms of contraception. The Population Fund calls for a number of measures "to raise the status of women," including giving women property rights and improved access to labor markets.
The report says that while it was once believed that rising incomes and an urban life were preconditions for reducing the size of families, the evidence from countries like Sri Lanka and Thailand shows that fertility rates can drop sharply in poor societies if governments adopt the right policies.
In 1965, the average Thai woman had 6.3 children, but by 1987 this figure had fallen to 2.2. Significant drops in fertility have also occurred in China, Cuba Indonesia, Tunisia and other countries, the report notes.
While the percentage of people living in poverty in developing countries fell from 52 percent in 1970 to 44 percent in 1985, the actual number of very poor people rose over the same period from 944 million to 1.1 billion because of population growth, it said.
The Population Fund predicts that with future growth of the world's population largely concentrated in developing countries, more and more poor people will seek to migrate to richer lands in search of a better life.
They will also be doing so at a time when the active working population of most northern industrial countries will be static or declining although the number of retired people will be increasing.
In Central America, for instance, the labor force is expected to rise by 50.5 million between 1990 and 2025, while in North America it is not expected to increase at all, except through migration from the south.
The report said that the third world's expanding population means increasing demands for food. Food production lagged behind population growth in 69 out of 102 developing countries between 1978 and 1989.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "A Crowded World" shows the estimates by the United Nations Population Fund for world population.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Women;
With Outsiders In, Female Candidates Come Forward

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 29

 BODY:
Harriett Woods, president of the National Women's Political Caucus, asserted today that Lynn H. Yeakel is only the latest in a string of "stealth women candidates" who are primed to shock the male-dominated political establishment this year.
"This is a unique year for the outsider," said Ms. Woods, who described a political climate that has changed dramatically since her two failed bids for the Senate from Missouri in the 1980's. "And women are seen as the outsiders -- even when they're inside." 
 Across the country, women are waiting in the wings, hoping they can seize on voters' newfound receptivity to them, as did Ms. Yeakel, who won the Democratic Senate primary in Pennsylvania on Tuesday. A record number of women are seeking Federal office: they are running in 21 of the 34 Senate contests, and 173 are vying for House seats, more than twice as many as in 1990, according to the National Women's Political Caucus.
A confluence of political factors bodes well for these candidates. With the cold war over, people are focusing on domestic issues like child-care and education that men had often dismissed as the domain of women. In a year when it is fashionable to be a political outsider, women have long been considered to be on the fringes of the political process and are generally perceived in voter surveys as more honest than men.
Further enhancing the prospects of women is that record numbers of lawmakers are retiring from Congress. Many of these incumbents are afraid of being defeated because of voter unrest, hurt by redistricting or frustrated by the whole institution.
"We've come a long way from the time I first ran for state representative in 1974 and had a bumper sticker that said, 'People for Morella,' " said Representative Constance A. Morella, a Republican from Maryland. "My son came in and said his friends wanted to know what dad is running for. I think the mood is set."
More than ever before, Ms. Morella said, she is fielding calls from women who want to run for office, as well as from organizations looking for women to run for office.
 
'Women Can Win This Year'
 Indeed, after years of struggling to be taken seriously by the people who raise money for campaigns, women's political organizations report that their contributions this year have doubled over the level two years ago. And for the first time this year, a Republican group was established to collect money exclusively for female candidates, as a Democratic group already does. "Certainly women are being encouraged by the fact that this year they start with an advantage with voters because of their gender," said Nikki Heidepriem, a Democratic consultant here.
The victory of Ms. Yeakel, a fund-raiser for women's charities, comes one month after Carol Moseley Braun pulled off an upset in Illinois, beating incumbent Senator Alan J. Dixon in the primary. Polls of voters in both states show striking parallels in that Ms. Yeakel and Ms. Braun each drew wide support from women as well as from voters who had also embraced the insurgent message of Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former California Governor who is seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination.
As a possible sign of strength for Ms. Yeakel in the general election, nearly one quarter of the voters in the Pennsylvania Republican primary said they would back her in November against the Republican incumbent, Senator Arlen Specter. Only 17 percent had said they would cross over against Mr. Specter had Lieut. Gov. Mark Singel won the Democratic primary.
"The message is that women can win this year," said Patty Murray, a state Senator from Washington State who is running in the Democratic Senate primary there. "There were a lot of barriers in the past to women winning. But this year, people are willing to invest in long shots because they know they can make it. Carol and Lynn showed that."
Despite the receptivity to female candidates, there are risks as well. Some women said they had to be careful not to alienate voters by being tagged as feminists who are one-issue candidates concerned only about issues like abortion rights.
 
The Other Issues
 "These women candidates have to get a message out that's broader than the narrow women's agenda to be successful," said Keith Haller, a Democratic poll taker. "I don't believe the Clarence Thomas or abortion issues will override the economy as people's most important concern."
But unlike in 1984, when Geraldine A. Ferraro ran on the Democratic Presidential ticket and many pundits wrongly predicted that it would be the year of the woman, Mr. Haller said many signs point to success for women in 1992.
"From a polling standpoint, there's far greater receptivity toward women running at the national level than we've seen in some time," he said, "and it's largely driven by the fact that people want dramatic change." In one of the most visible races involving women, Ms. Ferraro is running for the Senate this year from New York and faces Elizabeth Holtzman in the Democratic primary.
In New Hampshire, the two women who have announced their candidacies for Governor will get a boost because of their sex, according to a survey released today by the University of New Hampshire Survey Center.
In the survey of 541 adults, 41 percent said they would be "much more inclined" or "somewhat inclined" to vote for a woman over a man for Governor if the candidates were similar in opinions, experience and personalities.
 
Hearings as Catalyst
 "These figures do mean that the public is at least favorably oriented to women as candidates for Governor," said David W. Moore, director of the survey center, "and in a close race, they could even have the advantage."
Ms. Woods, who lost two hard-fought Senate races, said it would have been "extraordinarily easier" had she run for Senate in 1992. "When I ran in '82," she recalled, "women were measured against whether they were tough enough to face up to the Soviet Union. And there wasn't the funding base. And to be real honest, women were not necessarily voting for women. This is the first year we're seeing it all come together."
The outpouring of female candidates was clearly triggered by the Senate's handling last year of Prof. Anita F. Hill's sexual harassment accusations against Judge Clarence Thomas after his nomination to the Supreme Court. Although polls at the time showed that more women sided with the nominee than with Professor Hill, the hearings clearly aroused women's anger against the political establishment.
Ms. Yeakel, Ms. Braun and Ms. Murray cited outrage over the Judiciary Committee's conduct at the Thomas hearings as leading to their decisions, as did Jean Lloyd-Jones, a Democratic State Senator from Iowa who is running for the United States Senate.
"I had never considered running for the U.S. Congress or higher office than I hold now," said Ms. Lloyd-Jones. "After those hearings, I couldn't believe it. What we saw were 15 white males who looked after their own interests and did not protect the integrity of the process."
Although she is considered the likely Democrat to face Senator Charles E. Grassley, a Republican on the Judiciary Committee, in November, Ms. Lloyd-Jones said she is not trying to make it her principal issue. But she said "it keeps coming up -- everywhere."
By contrast, Ms. Yeakel built much of her campaign on Mr. Specter's role in the Thomas-Hill hearings. She established herself with a commercial that showed Mr. Specter at the hearings, after which she appeared on screen and asked, "Did this make you as angry as it made me?"
Though she has not served in public office, the 50-year-old Ms. Yeakel is not a complete political outsider. Her father, Porter Hardy Jr., served 11 terms in the House. She put her personal wealth to her advantage, giving or lending $280,000 to her own campaign.
Ms. Yeakel was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate in 1963 from Randolph-Macon Woman's College in Lynchburg, Va., and worked at an advertising firm in New York. Married to Paul M. Yeakel, a senior vice president of Kidder, Peabody & Company, she spent years as a homemaker and community volunteer before helping to found Womens Way, an organization that has raised as much as $2 million a year for women's groups.
It was the Thomas hearings that led her to run for office.
"I believe that the backlash from those hearings is somewhat stronger than anyone has documented yet," Ms. Yeakel said, "and that in history we're going to see the Hill-Thomas hearings as being the turning point for American women in terms of really stepping forward, taking political power, using the vote, using our money to elect the candidates who represent our values and stand for our rights."
Ms. Heidepriem, the Democratic consultant, cast the Thomas hearings in a slightly different light. "I would be curious," she said, "whether the White House now thinks Clarence Thomas was worth it."

HEADLINE: Pinochet Is 'My Franco,' Chile's Chief Says, Going His Own Way (Carefully)

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 27

 BODY:
President Patricio Aylwin says that when he meets other heads of state these days one of the first things they ask him is what life is like as President of Chile with Gen. Augusto Pinochet still head of the army.
"John Major asked me that," Mr. Aylwin said in an interview on Monday, referring to the British Prime Minister. "It's a unique experience. I said to Felipe Gonzalez once: 'Imagine what it would be like to be President of Spain with Franco still alive. I am with my Franco. It's General Pinochet.' " 
 It has been just two years since Mr. Aylwin assumed the presidency, signifying Chile's return to democracy and the end of the 17-year rule of General Pinochet, during which time more than 2,000 Chileans were either killed or "disappeared."
Until recently, all of Latin America, including Chile, was thought to have embarked on a new democratic age. But as Venezuela struggles in the aftermath of an attempted military coup, and Peru's military gives its support to the seizure of power by President Alberto K. Fujimori, long-term, stable democracies may be years away.
 
A Visit to the U.S.
 In Chile, which many regard as one of the most stable democracies in Latin America and a rare example of a peaceful handing over of power by a military Government, an inherently tense relationship continues between Mr. Aylwin's Government and the armed forces.
Politicians say Mr. Aylwin, who is 73 years old, has walked a careful path, not undoing the booming economy that General Pinochet left behind or putting excessive pressure on the military to come under civil authority. But at the same time he has dealt within the limits of his powers with human rights abuses of the past and paid attention to Chile's five million poor.
On May 9, President Aylwin leaves for an official visit to the United States, where he hopes to open direct negotiations on a free-trade agreement, establish closer political ties to the Bush Administration, and promote United States investment in Chile.
"We feel that the transfer to democracy is functioning well, better than we anticipated two years ago," said Joaquin Lavin, Secretary General of the Independent Democratic Union, the right-wing political party most aligned with General Pinochet. "Aylwin knows that you can't rock the boat too much, but after 17 years of military rule the most important thing is stability."
The transition has not always been easy, or without vivid reminders of the military past and fears about a possible return by General Pinochet to power if pushed too hard.
In December 1990, the general announced that the army had been put on full alert, sending a warning that he was not happy about an investigation into human rights violations during his Government. Last September, when unidentified remains of victims of his rule were being exhumed, he noted "what good economy" that two or more bodies had been buried in one grave, setting off a public outcry against him.
More recently, the Aylwin Government has admitted that one of its intelligence services spied on General Pinochet, other members of the armed forces and Pinochet-appointed Supreme Court justices.
Military experts predict that in the wake of the Fujimori coup the army is certain to press Mr. Aylwin to increase military spending in an effort to blunt territorial ambitions by the Peruvian armed forces, its traditional enemy.
Despite the tensions, Chile has become one of the most sought after countries in Latin America for foreign investment. The inflation rate this year, expected to be almost 15 percent, could be the lowest on the continent, and economic growth, currently 9 percent, is among the highest.
Much of this was undeniably the product of General Pinochet and the young Chilean economists trained at the University of Chicago who joined his Government in the early 1980's and shaped an open economy.
 
'Sort of a Father Figure'
 When Mr. Aylwin's coalition Government assumed power, many feared that he would change the economic model. But so far changes have been moderate. He has increased business and income taxes about 10 percent, raised the minimum wage, and promoted unionization. He has also increased spending on education, housing and health care for Chile's poor.
"He's sort of a father figure," said Gert Rosenthal, executive secretary of the United Nations Economic Commission on Latin America and the Caribbean. "He's had a very soothing influence on what potentially has been an explosive situation."
Criticism of Mr. Aylwin centers on the fear that out of his concern for social justice he might raise taxes or the minimum wage too much, forcing investors to look elsewhere. Also, critics say he has done little to rebuild Chile's relations with the United States and Europe after the isolated Pinochet years.
But what seems to trouble Mr. Aylwin most is that under his Government, which ends in 1994, he will not see a full return to democracy. This is mainly a result of the 1980 Constitution, written by the Pinochet Government, which gives the armed forces long-term protection from prosecution for human rights violations and prohibits the President from removing any head of the four branches of the armed forces, including General Pinochet, until 1998.
"We decided that we should be able to beat them on their own court, using their own Constitution," President Aylwin said.
 
'You Are My Boss
 On his relations with the general, President Aylwin said, "The day I took office he said, 'You are my boss; I obey you, but no one else.' " They also agreed that neither General Pinochet nor any members of the armed forces would engage in political debate and statements. President Aylwin says the former dictator has generally held to that agreement, but notes that he balks when he has to come under the authority of the Minister of Defense.
The Chilean head of state said his aim was to pursue the politics of the possible, not the politics of the ideal.
He said he advised President Fujimori to pursue such a course the day after the Peruvian President was inaugurated in July 1990, in the midst of intense rancor with the opposition political party of former President Alan Garcia.
"The address of Fujimori seemed to be of such an aggressive nature," President Aylwin said, referring to the Peruvian's acceptance speech. "I was very concerned. So the next day when I spoke with him I told him, 'Mr. President, I see you are going to have many difficulties establishing your Government in this type of political climate.' "

Augusto Pincohet. Mr. Aylwin is shown campaigning for the Presidency in 1989 when the military handed over power. (Bob Strong/Sipa)

HEADLINE: U.S. Further Eases Its Restrictions on Trade With Vietnam

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 29

 BODY:
The United States further relaxed its 28-year-old economic embargo against Vietnam today, saying it would allow commercial sales of items like food, medicine and farm machinery that meet basic human needs.
The State Department said that Washington would also lift restrictions on projects sponsored by American non-governmental and nonprofit groups. 
 The spokeswoman for the department, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said the Bush Administration decided to ease the embargo "in response to Vietnam's strengthened commitments to take positive actions on P.O.W.-M.I.A. issues and its support of the United Nations political settlement process in Cambodia."
"It is in keeping with the established U.S. policy of a step-by-step process for normalizing relations with Vietnam," she said in a statement.
The Bush Administration began improving ties with Hanoi last October after approving a peace settlement for Cambodia, which was invaded by Vietnamese troops in late 1978.
The economic embargo was imposed on North Vietnam in 1964 and was extended to the south in 1975 when the American-backed government there fell to the Communist north.
Last week a delegation of United States senators visited Vietnam to inspect a prison camp and several military bases where they believed American servicemen might be held. The Vietnam War ended in 1975 and the United States says 2,266 servicemen are still unaccounted for.
Most of those servicemen are believed to be dead, but there have been unconfirmed reports that Americans were seen alive after the war.
The senators said they found no evidence during their trip that any missing American servicemen were still alive. They praised Hanoi's cooperation and said they were were hopeful that the issue could be resolved soon.
For many Americans, this issue remains a highly emotional barrier to improved relations with Vietnam.
Over the last year, scores of United States experts, working with Vietnamese officials, have dug up graves and interviewed villagers about servicemen missing from the war.
Economic competition is also a factor in the improvement of relations. Many businessmen from Japan and other nations have been moving eagerly into Vietnam, and American businesses fear they will be at a disadvantage in a fertile new market.

HEADLINE: Mayor Said to Plan 5-Day Trip

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins is planning to travel to Western Europe for about five days in June to explore economic opportunities for New York City in a trip sponsored by local civic and business groups, officials familiar with the plans said yesterday.
The Mayor will be accompanied by Barry F. Sullivan, Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, and business leaders, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. 
 The trip is being sponsored by the New York City Partnership and the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry. Officials of the partnership declined to comment on the trip yesterday and referred inquiries to the Mayor's office.
Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's press secretary, said yesterday that details of the trip are still being worked out but that an announcement could be made as early as today. Mr. Jones said that if such a trip could be arranged, it would last about five days.
Mr. Dinkins's international travels have stirred controversy in the past, with critics raising questions about the financing and purpose of the trips.
After criticism last year, Mr. Dinkins abandoned plans to accept a free trip to Germany, where he was to attend a tennis tournament and meet with European business leaders.
Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens, whom Mr. Dinkins had asked to accompany him to Germany, declined the offer, citing the possible appearance of a conflict of interest. She later amended this to say she did not wish to be away from Queens at a busy time, but the Mayor was embarrassed.
Mr. Dinkins canceled the trip, saying that he wanted more time to plan and that another trip might take place in the spring.
It could not be learned what countries the Mayor planned to visit in Europe, but aides to Mr. Dinkins said that he would definitely travel to England and France.

HEADLINE: Entrepreneur Who Left U.S. Is Back, Awaiting Sentence

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 29

 BODY:
First he fled the United States after pleading guilty to running what New York officials called one of the largest gasoline bootlegging schemes in the nation.
Then he emerged as an entrepreneur in post-Communist Poland, founding a successful frozen-fruit exporting business and a private bank. 
 He even staved off a run on his bank when a Polish newspaper revealed his fugitive status, promising higher interest rates and a lottery for cars and apartments to nervous depositors who maintained their accounts.
But now David Bogatin, a Russian native with United States citizenship whom even his prosecutors concede is an indefatigable businessman, is back in New York and in jail and awaiting resentencing. Today a State Supreme Court judge denied Mr. Bogatin's request for bail while the authorities here and in Brooklyn and Long Island decide just what to do with him.
The 46-year-old Mr. Bogatin is the first person ever returned to this country under the terms of a 1927 extradition treaty between Poland and the United States. Mr. Bogatin and Polish officials both say that until the newspaper, Gazeta Wyborcza, published an article about him early this year, nobody in Poland had asked him any questions about where he or the money that he used to begin his businesses came from.
 
$5 Million Sought
 While Mr. Bogatin's financial triumphs in Poland may be emblematic of the freewheeling economic climate in that country, officials here said he was guilty of running a so-called daisy chain bootlegging outfit in New York that evaded state and Federal fuel taxes. They want him to pay $5 million in fines and restitution and serve the prison sentence of up to eight years that was imposed on him in 1987.
After Mr. Bogatin entered the courtroom today wearing a pin-stripe suit and handcuffs, his lawyer, Robert M. Simels, told Judge Joseph Harris that Mr. Bogatin should be allowed to revoke his old guilty plea and be released on bail because the offenses covered by the extradition treaty were less serious than the tax-evasion charges.
Judge Harris denied the bail motion, noting to Mr. Simels in an apparent reference to Mr. Bogatin's earlier flight in violation of a $500,000 bail payment, "Your client appears rather nimble afoot and has greater capacity to move about than most people."
 
Tax Violation Are Charged
 But the judge put off until May 13 any decision on how much jail time Mr. Bogatin will be required to serve. He is due in Federal court in Brooklyn on Friday on related charges in the scheme.
Nancy Connell, a spokeswoman for State Attorney General Robert Abrams, said Mr. Bogatin had filed false tax returns from 1982 to 1985 to avoid taxes on about 15 million gallons of gasoline that he distributed to other dealers in that time.
Evidence presented at the trial showed that the transactions involved an intricate series of transfers among dummy companies that created huge amounts of paperwork and confused tax responsibility.
Prosecutors said Mr. Bogatin and others in a network of Russian and Eastern European immigrants acted with Michael Franzese, an admitted captain of the Colombo organized-crime family who was given a 10-year sentence after being convicted on Federal racketeering charges for the scheme.
Polish authorities cooperated with American requests to bring Mr. Bogatin back here for resentencing. Neither he, nor his bank nor his fruit business have been charged with any violations of Polish law.
Mr. Bogatin was not available today to make any comment to reporters. Mr. Simel said in an interview that his client had been misled by a previous lawyer about the terms of his guilty plea, as well as about the terms surrounding the forfeiture of five condominiums that Mr. Bogatin owned in Trump Tower. He said his client now wished to "resolve the matter" in a way that would allow him to get back to his businesses in Poland as soon as possible.
As chairman and majority stockholder of the bank in Poland, the First Commercial Bank of Lublin, Mr. Bogatin has been reported by Polish authorities to have at least $6 million in assets. The bank was the first to receive permission to sell shares on the Warsaw Stock Exchange.
When the account about Mr. Bogatin first broke in Gazeta Wyborcza, hundreds of depositors came to its 14 branches and withdrew about $4.5 million. But many others kept their money in after Mr. Bogatin spoke personally with customers and offered to hold a lottery for cars and apartments for those who maintained their accounts for at least another year.

HEADLINE: U.S. Warns On Threats To Wiretaps

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 29

 BODY:
Sophisticated defenses against wiretapping are outpacing the Government's ability to monitor telephone communications for intelligence gathering and law enforcement purposes, senior Administration officials told a Congressional panel today.
The warning came at a hearing on foreign espionage against American companies. The Federal Bureau of Investigation relies heavily on court-ordered wiretaps in its pursuit of mob leaders and drug traffickers, while the highly secretive National Security Agency gathers military, political and economic intelligence by monitoring international calls. 
 The Administration officials never detailed why widespread eavesdropping might still be needed, now that the cold war is over. The most obvious possible explanation, keeping tabs on terrorist groups, was not mentioned, although the Justice Department has expressed this concern in recent weeks.
 
'We Will Be Denied Access'
 The Federal Government's biggest problem lies in the use of computers to transmit many calls simultaneously on a single line and to scramble individual calls for extra security. "Digital telephony has advanced to such a point that we are nearing the point that we will be denied access on a routine basis," William S. Sessions, the F.B.I. Director, told members of a House Judiciary subcommittee.
The Justice Department began pressing Congress last month for legislation that would require telephone companies to install equipment making it easier to conduct court-ordered wiretaps. The cost of such a move is unclear, and telephone users would pay for it in higher phone bills.
Testifying with Mr. Sessions, but consistently avoiding questions on private encryption issues, was James J. Hearn, the deputy director for information systems security at the National Security Agency. The N.S.A. has for years quietly discouraged university mathematicians and computer companies from developing cryptographic techniques that would make its code breakers' jobs more difficult.
 
Opposition by Phone Companies
 Yet telephone companies around the world are using computers to encode and consolidate calls on fewer and fewer lines to save money. And companies in many countries are responding to reports of increased economic espionage by using more and more encryption devices to scramble the voices and data they send on telephone lines.
Telephone companies, including the Nynex Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, have joined the American Civil Liberties Union in opposing the Justice Department's plans, which they see as an expensive obstacle to deploying the most advanced, cost-saving technologies available.
Philip S. Gutis, a spokesman for the American Civil Liberties Union, said that requiring telephone companies to make their equipment more compatible with eavesdropping gear was like forcing household appliance makers to install special microphones in all their products to save Federal agents the trouble. "It's just a question of how far our Government goes in making it easier for them to invade our privacy," he said.
 
Why Businesses Are Worried
 Computer and telecommunications industry officials and House Democrats said today that the Administration was avoiding a public-policy decision on high-technology communications in the United States. By insisting on the ability to eavesdrop on any call, they said, the Administration may delay the installation of advanced equipment necessary for reducing costs for industry, preventing the loss of trade secrets and preserving American competitiveness.
"Our Government is impeding the private sector in developing modern cryptographic technologies because they don't want those technologies to get too sophisticated -- whether it's the intelligence agencies or whether it's the bureau, or whether it's other law enforcement people," said Representative Dan Glickman, Democrat of Kansas.
But Mr. Sessions strongly disagreed. "If you woke me up in the middle of the night and threatened me with the most dire of consequences, I would say that is not so," he said.
"I would say that the F.B.I. wants very much to see advancing technology, greater capabilities, greater implementation throughout the world," Mr. Sessions said. "All we're asking is what the Congress has already given. That is, the continued lawful access."
The dilemma for American policymakers was best illustrated when Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, warned that American business executives should avoid leaving sensitive documents unattended in foreign hotel rooms.
James E. Riesback, an executive vice president of Corning Inc., countered later in the hearing that American executives would have less need to travel with important documents if they could depend on video teleconferences without worrying about eavesdropping by foreign agents.
Mr. Riesback did not mention that Corning is one of the world's largest producers of fiber-optic cables, which are used for most such video conferences.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Excellent Quarter For Mutual Funds

BYLINE: By Alison Leigh Cowan

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH the hectic pace slowed a bit in March, mutual funds had their best quarter in nearly five years during the first three months of 1992, figures released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute indicate, because of the huge torrents of cash that poured into stock funds.
Some $20.8 billion of new assets, net of redemptions and transfers, went into stock funds in the quarter, far surpassing the $15.7 billion record set the previous quarter. It was also the best quarter for three of the more speculative categories of equity products -- aggressive growth funds, growth funds and growth and income funds. 
 Although the $6.7 billion recorded in March for all equity funds fell shy of the February total, fund managers were surprised that the recent tremors in the stock market, especially in the more volatile over-the-counter market, did not do more to dim investor enthusiasm for stock products.
"Last year, the over-the-counter stocks performed spectacularly, but this quarter the Nasdaq is down 11 percent, which affects growth funds," said Frank Holmes, chief executive of United Services Funds in San Antonio. His company, which sells its products through brokers, has seen a net 7 percent outflow from its indexed stock fund this month.
Bond and income funds, meanwhile, netted $24.0 billion during the quarter, far short of the $32.5 billion record set in the first quarter of 1987. Analysts say fears about higher interest rates may have contributed to the slight drop-off in March, when bond and income funds pulled in $7.2 billion, versus $8.3 billion the prior month and $8.5 billion in January.
Together, the $44.9 billion of net new cash taken in by stock and bond funds came closer than in any previous quarter to toppling the record set in early 1987, when $45.8 billion poured into stock and bond funds.
Fund managers interviewed yesterday did not have strong convictions about how the second quarter would shape up. April is normally a strong month because so many investors shift assets into tax-favored individual retirement accounts before the annual tax-filing deadline.
This year was no exception, Michael Hines, senior vice president of marketing for Fidelity Investments in Boston, said. "The first four months of the year are typically a busy period, and the business tends to slow down after that," he said. "I would expect May's overall business to be less strong than April because of the seasonal factor of the I.R.A.'s."
Martin Gawne, a spokesman for Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago, said April would prove especially strong in light of the roughly $100 billion in relatively low-yielding bank certificates of deposit coming due this month.
"April was supposed to be a record month for C.D.'s coming due, and as long as rates on C.D.'s and bank products remain as low as they are, equity mutual funds remain one of the only games in town," he said.
The fund managers did agree, however, that current trends should persist as long as interest rates remain low and the stock market does not drop precipitiously.
'It's being driven by low interest rates and strong stock market performance," said William Shiebler, senior managing director of the Putnam Companies in Boston. "They have been the wind in the sails of the strong mutual fund business, and a negative change in either of those will slow this down."
Avi Nachmanie, an analyst with Strategic Insight, a research and consulting firm that specializes in the mutual fund industry, agreed. "As long as the stock market is within a trading range, only if the stock marget goes dramatically down will people buy less stock," he said.
Even though March itself was not a record breaker, several smaller categories did exceptionally well. Growth and income funds, which use dividend-rich stocks and bonds to assure investors some downside protection, pulled in $2.4 billion, $209 million more than January 1987, the prior record.
"Throughout the last few months, growth and income stock funds are where people are putting their money," Mr. Hines of Fidelity said.
On the fixed-income side, balanced bond funds -- which tend to have an even mix of bonds, stocks and cash -- were another standout. They drew in $794.1 million in March, their best month ever, and $2.1 billion during the quarter, their best quarter ever.
High-yield bond funds, which attracted a total of $730.6 million of net new cash, did not set a record, but had their best month in over five years, as investors cautiously increased their appetite for speculative issues.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields on Tax-Exempts Up, But Taxable Funds Are Off

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed in the latest week. Analysts do not expect to see any significant change in yield over the next few months as the economy continues to emit varying signals about the strength of the recovery.
For the week ended Monday, tax-exempt money fund yields were up smartly for the second consecutive survey period, following two weeks of declines. Analysts said the rise in yields was connected to the heavy supply of new tax-exempt issues. Yields on taxable funds were down slightly. 
 While there are other factors to consider when yields change, one always mentioned by analysts is the dwindling influence of banks and insurance companies as big investors that formerly purchased much of the tax-free paper. But the problems in both the banking and insurance industries over the last few years left only money funds, bond funds and unit trusts among the big purchasers.
The seven-day compounded average yield for a tax-exempt fund this week increased 18 basis points, to 3.11 percent, while the seven-day simple yield rose 17 basis points, to 3.07 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
For the same period, the 30-day compound average yield rose 4 basis points, to 2.96 percent, with the simple yield gaining a similar amount for an average yield of 2.92 percent.
Donoghue's said the average number of days left to maturity of tax-exempt securities held in portfolios declined by a day, to 48, as managers have become more cautious during this recent uptick in rates. They do not want to be caught holding longer positions during any change in interest-rate direction.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day compunded yield is 4.31 percent, while the equivalent in the 31 percent tax bracket is 4.50 percent.
Surveying tax-exempt funds with assets larger than $100 million, Donoghue's said the Fidelity Spartan Municipal Money Market Fund again produced the week's best return at 4.04 percent, beating by 16 basis points its best yield a week ago. The fund's distributor is the Fidelity Distributors Corporation of Boston.
In the taxable sector, assets of funds fell by $4.1 billion during the week, to $500.2 billion, with the decline almost evenly divided between institutional and retail money market funds. Assets of institutional funds were down $2.1 billion, to $163.6 billion, while retail fund assets fell by $2 billion, to $336.6 billion.
