HEADLINE: Further Delays in Taiwan-McDonnell Deal

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 29

 BODY:
The Taiwan Aerospace Corporation will make further evaluations before acting on a plan to acquire up to a $2 billion stake in the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, Taiwan's Economics Minister, Vincent Siew, said today.
A recent study indicates McDonnell Douglas was overly optimistic in estimating its market share for long-range passenger jets, and the Taiwan investors are apparently trying to see if they can use that information to get better terms for a deal with the American company. 
 Mr. Siew's announcement at Parliament's special hearing on the joint venture indicated there would be a further delay in the proposed joint venture. But Mr. Siew appealed to legislators to support the deal, saying Taiwan should not miss the chance to cooperate with the world's No. 3 aircraft maker.
"It has a low financial return and high market risk, but the investment will boost this country's technology and upgrade related industries," he said.
Mr. Siew said the Government would invest only indirectly in the joint venture and would persuade private investors to become partners with Taiwan Aerospace to reduce investment risks.
"The Government does not want direct participation in the project," he said. "Instead, we would provide guidance and assistance to the joint venture."
But he said the Government had withdrawn a plan by the state-run China Steel Corporation to invest in the deal, which would require approval from the Taiwan and United States Governments.
The chairman of Taiwan Aerospace, Earle Ho, said his company was considering a smaller investment in McDonnell Douglas.
"We surely will not purchase the 40 percent stake at $2 billion," he said, but added that he remained hopeful about a deal with McDonnell Douglas.
Some legislators agree that the deal would help Taiwan's budding aerospace industry, but others voiced doubts and opposition.
St. Louis-based McDonnell Douglas is struggling to compete in the passenger jet market with the industry leader, Boeing, and with Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Up Slightly in U.S. While Gold Closes Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed slightly higher yesterday in slow New York trading after a mixed showing abroad that reflected a dearth of news, a holiday in Japan and the coming three-day May Day weekend in Europe.
Gold prices fell. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fetched $336.10, off 80 cents from Tuesday. At the Republic National Bank in New York, gold fetched $335.50 as of 4 P.M., off 55 cents. 
 Currency brokers said the United States dollar stayed within a narrow range against key currencies throughout the trading day. In dollar-mark trading, for example, the dollar never broke out of the 1.6500 level but closed toward the upper end.
"There was just a lack of any movement, very quiet," said Charles Cossentino, a vice president at the New York branch of Deutsche Genossenschaftsbank, a German bank. "There was a lack of news."
The markets in Japan were closed for Greenery Day, a national holiday, which made the level of foreign-exchange activity sluggish elsewhere. Trading was further slowed in Europe because of a four-day week. Tomorrow, May 1, is the traditional workers' holiday and many markets will be closed.
Economic statistics released in the United States failed to give currency trading any direction, foreign-exchange brokers said. The Commerce Department said personal income increased six-tenths of 1 percent last month while personal spending rose three-tenths of 1 percent, but the figures provided little insight into the strength of the American emergence from recession.
Some traders said the dollar's slight improvement was really a sign of weakness in the mark, which has been hurt by Germany's growing political and economic problems.
The German Government has been thrown into disarray by the abrupt resignation Monday of Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. In addition, public employee strikes have paralyzed many services.
In London, the dollar rose to 133.40 yen yesterday from 133.30 late Tuesday. Later in New York the dollar fetched 133.50 yen, up from 133.20 yen Tuesday. At Tuesday's close in Tokyo, the dollar had finished at 133.07.
The British pound fell in London to $1.7700, from $1.7795 late Tuesday. In New York, the pound fetched $1.7725, cheaper than its $1.7768 value late Tuesday.
Other late-dollar rates in New York compared with rates late Tuesday, were: 1.6575 marks, up from 1.6565; 1.5210 Swiss francs, up from 1.5170; 1.1946 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1957; 5.5875 French francs, up from 5.5770, and 1,246.00 lire, up from 1,245.25.

HEADLINE: ADVERTISING;
Theeeeere Goes Johnny; Heeeeere's Big Money!

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
If you listen carefully amid the applause for Johnny Carson as he prepares to leave late-night television after 30 years, you might hear the sound of cash registers ringing.
Between now and May 22, when the final "Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson" will run, NBC will raise its rates for a 30-second commercial, in stages, about fivefold -- yes, fivefold -- to almost $200,000 for the finale. 
 That instant inflation from the regular price of $40,000 will place the show's rates on a par with what marketers like Miller Brewing and Wendy's might pay for a 30-second commercial on a hit prime-time series like "Roseanne." But it is still far below the $850,000 it cost for a 30-second spot during Super Bowl XXVI in January.
 
Second-Largest Audience
 The reason for the hefty price tag for Mr. Carson's farewell, of course, is clear: NBC anticipates that the show's normal audience of about 10 million will swell to about 35 million for the finale, said Curt Block, a network spokesman in New York. That would be the second-largest audience ever for "Tonight," after the 58 million who tuned in on Dec. 17, 1969, to watch the singer Tiny Tim marry his Miss Vicki.
The transition from Mr. Carson to his designated successor, Jay Leno, has been as carefully orchestrated as the media hoopla surrounding the abdication of the "king of late night." After all, in a medium that has witnessed the cancellation of a series after but a single episode, three decades is more of a reign than a run. Mr. Carson announced his impending retirement last May, followed a month later by NBC's selection of Mr. Leno, who has been his regular substitute host since 1987, as his replacement, effective on May 25.
Still, advertising and media executives are watching intently for signs of disruption following Mr. Carson's record stint as host of a show that routinely generates annual advertising revenues of $100 million.
In interviews yesterday, many expressed the belief that ratings for "The Tonight Show With Jay Leno," as it will be called, will slip to some degree compared with Mr. Carson's. But most of them do not expect any giant defections, by viewers or advertisers, to the growing number of late-night alternatives, from rival talk shows like Arsenio Hall's and Dennis Miller's to sexually provocative fare like "Studs."
"Jay Leno will hold the baton high and run with it," said Robert Ward, advertising services director for the Miller Brewing Company in Milwaukee. Miller Lite Beer is sponsoring a special promotion with NBC that includes spots on "Tonight" leading up to, and during, the final Carson appearance, he added, and when Mr. Leno arrives, "we will continue our participation in the show."
Paul Schulman, president of the Paul Schulman Company in New York, echoed that sentiment.
"I want to be in Leno's show just as we have been in Carson's show," said Mr. Schulman, who buys $175 million worth of network television time a year for clients like Ralston Purina and the Gap.
As for speculation that NBC affiliates nationwide might delay broadcasts of Mr. Leno's "Tonight" show into the wee hours, threatening the network with advertising revenue losses of $10 million or more, he added, "Leno will schmooze those affiliates into being in his corner."
One post-Carson possibility advanced by Jack Klues, vice president and media director at Leo Burnett U.S.A. in Chicago, would be that Mr. Leno loses viewers, not to Mr. Hall, or to Chevy Chase's proposed talk show, due next year on the Fox network, but "just because they'd turn off their sets after the late-night news."
"We would guess the ratings will slip," he added, "on the basis of when you lose someone of the star magnitude of Johnny Carson, it would not be unexpected. But will there be no 'Tonight' show? We don't paint such a dark picture."
Nor does Steve Auerbach, executive vice president of national broadcast at DeWitt Media Inc. in New York.
"It's only natural for the ratings to decline a while until Leno finds his own audience," said Mr. Auerbach, whose company buys about $100 million in network time for clients like Reebok International and American Family Publishers. He likened the transition to the replacement of Walter Cronkite by Dan Rather as anchor of "The CBS Evening News" in 1981.
"Somewhere down the line, you'll get a divvying-up of the audience," he added. "There might be three or four or five shows with ratings of from two to five, versus a five to six rating for 'Tonight' now." A rating point represents 921,000 households.
Mr. Block at NBC said no advertisers had indicated that they would leave "Tonight" because Mr. Carson was leaving.
He also offered reassurance to those worried about the concurrent departure of Ed McMahon, Mr. Carson's foil and second banana, who has served as the show's pitchman, performing commercials "live on tape" for sponsors like Alpo dog food. (The phrase refers to television events taped as they happen for presentation later, usually without editing. This accounts for the broadcasting of occasional canine accidents.)
While that type of spot has diminished greatly in recent years, Mr. Block said, advertisers wanting that option would be able to use Mr. McMahon's successor, the announcer Edd Hall.
Mr. Carson's departure comes amid a frenzy of finales on the Big Three networks. Tonight, NBC bids goodbye to "The Cosby Show" after eight seasons. Last Saturday, ABC reaped its best Saturday ratings since October 1989 with consecutive series finales of "Who's the Boss," "Growing Pains" and "MacGyver."

HEADLINE: Ford Turns Profitable In Quarter

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Mich. April 29

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company, reversing a string of five money-losing quarters, today became the second Big Three auto maker to post a quarterly profit. Ford said it earned $338 million, or 60 cents a share, for the first quarter, compared with a loss of $884.4 million last year.
The big swing to a profit reflected a 33 percent jump in sales of cars from Ford to its dealers in the United States as well as a more profitable mix of vehicles like the popular Ford Explorer utility vehicle and light- truck models. 
 Ford also benefited from a larger percentage of its vehicles being sold to individuals, which is more profitable than selling cars to fleets, which usually buy cars for little or no markup. The No. 2 auto maker also said its average rebate for a car dropped to $1,000, from $1,150 in the fourth quarter of last year.
 
Profitable Financial Units
 About 75 percent of Ford's profit, however, came from the company's financial services businesses like Ford Motor Credit, the First Nationwide Financial Corporation and the Associates.
Like the General Motors Corporation, which yesterday reported its first quarterly profit since 1990, Ford was cautious about calling the latest results a signal that the American automotive industry was entering a sustained and strong period of cyclical growth.
"It's too early to declare victory on the economy," said David N. McCammon, Ford's treasurer. "We're still in a slow recovery." Ford last recorded a profit, a scant $102 million, in the third quarter of 1990.
The Chrysler Corporation is scheduled to announce financial results on Thursday, and most stock analysts predict Chrysler will post a small operating loss. Last year, it had a $598 million loss.
Ford revenue for the first quarter was $24.6 billion, up 15.5 percent from last year's $21.3 billion.
 
Success With Restyling
 Mr. McCammon also singled out the restyled Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable midsize vehicles for improving their share of the midsize market. Many analysts and reviewers had raised doubts whether the modestly restyled exterior and interiors were bold or eye-catching enough to attract new customers.
Mr. McCammon said only 29 percent of Ford cars were sold to fleets during the quarter, compared with 37 percent fleet business a year earlier.
Harold A. Poling, Ford's chairman, said in a statement, "A continuation of the turnaround will depend greatly on a sustained recovery in the United States and other key Ford markets."
Profit from Ford's financial services group fell 6.6 percent, to $253 million. But Mr. Poling said the group's operating performance was excellent, and explained that the decline was caused by one-time gains last year that inflated profit.
In the short term, Ford and Wall Street are already counting on the auto maker's second quarter, ended June 30, to be more profitable than the first. Mr. McCammon implied as much when he said that vehicle production in the quarter was much stronger, with Ford using overtime to increase use of its North American factories to 105 percent of capacity on two shifts, up from 81 percent in the first quarter.
A mitigating factor in the second quarter will be higher start-up costs for several new models Ford is bringing out, among them a Ford Probe sports car and the Mercury Villager mini-van that is being developed with the Nissan Motor Company of Japan. The additional production, moreover, will mostly be passenger cars, which have not been as profitable as trucks.
Ronald Glantz, an automotive analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco, raised his second-quarter earnings estimate today to $1 a share from 75 cents. For the year, Mr. Glantz raised his estimate to $1.75 from $1. Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York, predicts Ford's 1992 profit will top $1 billion. In 1991 Ford lost $2.25 billion.
Because Ford's first-quarter results were better than analysts had expected, the company's common shares moved sharply higher, finishing at $45.75 , up $1.875 a share, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Nevertheless, Ford's American automotive operations were still running at around the break-even point at best. Automotive operations in the United States earned only $57 million, but that amount reflected a $61 million one-time gain from the sale of a computer services business. A year earlier, automotive operations in the United States lost $947 million.
Overseas automotive operations earned $28 million in the quarter, compared with a loss of $208 million last year. Worldwide sales of vehicles to dealers rose 17 percent, to 1.46 million.
Mr. McCammon said Ford was not expecting the recovery to run out of gas, but "if it starts to wane the Fed can lower interest rates further."

HEADLINE: Stocks Climb, With Dow Rising by 25.26

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stock prices posted healthy gains yesterday, as more good news from Detroit car makers restored confidence in the market.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended 25.26 points higher, at 3,333.18. In the broad market, advancing issues led declines, 1,090 to 602, on active volume of 206.8 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. The average share gained 23 cents. 
 The badly battered over-the-counter market got caught up in the rally, with the Nasdaq index jumping 9.61, or 1.7 percent, to 569.94, buoyed by strong gains in technology stocks.
Ford Motor reported a $338 million profit for the first quarter -- a sharp turnaround from its $884 million loss a year ago. Ford shares climbed $1.75, to $45.625, and were the third-most actively traded issue.
The good news from Ford came after General Motors on Tuesday reported its first profit in nearly two years. It cited improved results in its North American automotive operations for the gains. G.M. gained $2, to $42.375.
Stocks were not directly affected by a report that personal income rose six-tenths of 1 percent and personal spending increased three-tenths of 1 percent in March, but analysts said the data reinforced a sense that the economy was reviving.
"When you see that the economy grew at 2 percent last quarter and confidence is beginning to build, that is what prompts prices up," said Cummins Catherwood, managing director at Rutherford, Brown & Catherwood.
"C.E.O.'s, directors -- people who are closer to the fire than I am -- are saying they feel pretty good about things. Despite my personal misgivings, that makes me feel pretty good, too."
Concern remains, however, that weakness among the broader averages could cause a drop in the Dow in the near future.
Ed Nicoski, technical analyst at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood, said: "There have been some genuine buyers, but how far we can go, I don't know. I do not see this as the beginning of another significant upthrust."
The Treasury's refunding notice had little impact on the stock market. Bonds fell after a brief rally on news that the Treasury will auction $36 billion of paper to raise fresh cash for the Government.
Among technology stocks, Novell rose 2 3/4, to 52 1/2. Microsoft gained 2 3/8, to 111 3/8. Intel moved up 1 3/8, to 52 1/8. Apple rose 2 3/4, to 57.
Du Pont rose 1 5/8, to 52 5/8, after the nation's biggest chemical company announced a 5 percent rise in its dividend. Cooper Industries fell 1 5/8, to 50 1/4. The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 2.91, to 412.02. The American Stock Exchange index gained 2.74, to 385.78.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite index of all listed common stocks rose 1.46, to 226.58

HEADLINE: Du Pont's Earnings Fell By 18% in First Quarter

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reported yesterday that its quarterly earnings were off 18 percent from the comparable period a year earlier, and it announced a 2-cent dividend increase, to 44 cents a share.
The earnings report exceeded analysts' expectations, and trading in the company's stock was brisk, with 2.3 million shares changing hands, as the price on the New York Stock Exchange rose $1.625, to $52.625, its high for the year. 
 "These are good earnings," said George J. Krug, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company. "They exceeded expectations, even though expectations have been creeping up for the last couple of months."
He said the dividend increase was an indication that the company feels that the recession is ending and that better economic times lie ahead.
That was the note sounded by Edgar S. Woolard Jr., Du Pont's chairman. He noted that the decline in earnings resulted largely from lower prices being paid for the petroleum products made by its Conoco subsidiary compared with the high prices during the Persian Gulf war last year.
"It is encouraging to see indications of broader economic improvement as reflected in stronger earnings performances for many of our other key businesses, notably fibers," Mr. Woolard said. He said the increase in the cash payout "underscores the board's confidence in the future course of the business."
Du Pont said it earned $482 million, or 71 cents a share, in the first quarter, down from $590 million, or 88 cents a share, in the 1991 period. Sales declined 5.2 percent, to $9.2 billion from $9.7 billion. This was attributed to lower petroleum prices and the exclusion of the coal operation, which is now part of a joint venture.
The company's operating earnings in the petroleum segment declined 63 percent, to $118 million from $322 million. In addition to reduced margins as a result of lower prices, the company said that last year benefited from advance crude oil sales at favorable prices.
The fibers segment of the company earned $165 million, a 45 percent increase. It said the improvement was the result of higher demand for its Lycra product in Europe and Dacron polyester in the United States and for nylon carpet fibers in both regions.
Earnings in the polyments segment increased 56 percent, to $106 million, as a result of higher demand for paints and finishes. But the chemicals business declined 25 percent, to $72 million, because of lower sales of intermediate products and the costs of expanding production capacity for white pigments.
Diversified business earnings improved 29 percent, to $120 million, excluding a one-time benefit last year from the sale of a business. The company said the agricultural and medical units of the segment profited from higher sales volume and the electronics and imaging systems unit benefitted from lower costs.

HEADLINE: Personal Income Up 0.6% And Spending by 0.3%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 29

 BODY:
Personal income increased six-tenths of 1 percent in March, the second consecutive gain, while spending rose three-tenths of 1 percent, the Government said today in a report suggesting continued economic recovery.
The Commerce Department said incomes totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.99 trillion. The March advance followed a 1 percent gain in February, revised down slightly from an earlier estimate of 1.1 percent. 
 Consumer spending, meanwhile, totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.04 trillion. March marked the fifth consecutive spending increase and came after an eight-tenths of 1 percent rise the month before. The February gain had been estimated at nine-tenths of 1 percent.
The March increases in both spending and income were slightly better than economists were projecting.
"The March personal income figures show that the recovery is a cautious recovery," said John M. Albertine, a Washington-based economics consultant. "Consumers made modest gains in income, but they are not jumping in their cars and speeding off to the malls. They are saving some of their additional income."
 
Modest Growth Indicated
 Today's report on consumer income and spending was in line with a report on Tuesday showing the overall economy growing at a modest 2 percent annual rate in the first quarter.
That report showed that growth so far this year was being supported by a rebound in consumer spending, which represents roughly two-thirds of all economic activity.
Analysts, however, are concerned that if the economy does not begin producing more jobs soon, income gains -- and consequently the increased spending -- will fizzle.
The nation's unemployment rate in March remained at 7.3 percent, a six-and-a-half-year high.
Income gains in both February and March were bolstered by subsidy payments to farmers and by a speedup in life insurance dividend payments to veterans ordered by President Bush.
The main component of incomes -- wages and salaries -- rose four-tenths of 1 percent in March after a 1.2 percent gain the month before.
 
After-Tax Income Up
 Disposable income -- or income after taxes -- rose 1.1 percent in March and nine-tenths of 1 percent in February. The Commerce Department said the March gain was supported by a reduction in Federal income tax withholding, ordered by Mr. Bush to stimulate the economy.
The modest spending gain in March, meanwhile, came entirely from an eight-tenths of 1 percent gain in spending on services -- items ranging from medical care to auto repairs. That more than offset declines in spending for durable goods, big purchases like automobiles and appliances, and spending on nondurable goods, like food and clothing.
Spending on services is by far the largest category in overall spending.
The fact that incomes rose faster than spending raised Americans' savings rate from 4.5 percent of income in February to 5.3 percent of income in March.

HEADLINE: Iran Struggles to Attract Investors

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran

 BODY:
For more than a year, Mohammed Hussein Adeli, who heads Iran's central bank, has painted a rosy portrait of his country's economic future, one that is filled with stable currency exchange rates, double-digit growth, single-digit inflation, a balanced budget, foreign investment and loans, even credit cards.
First comes his profit pitch: "There are lots of opportunities now, because Iran is emerging as one of the economic magnets of the region with the wealth it has and the new policies and economic opportunities it can create." 
 He follows that by characterizing the Islamic Republic of Iran as politically secure: "The country will remain stable and very firm, and anyone can rely on our policies. We are pursuing a democratic way of life in Iran."
Finally, he says, his countrymen are good at business: "Iranians have always been very clever in doing business and managing the economy for hundreds of years and thousands of years."
But shortly before leaving for a visit to the United States, Mr. Adeli, an economist who studied at the New School for Social Research in New York and earned a Ph.D. in business administration from the University of California at Los Angeles, paused for a moment and acknowledged, "Maybe we are overestimating ourselves."
That certainly has been the case so far. Despite promises by Iran's revolutionary leadership to bring prosperity to its people, the ambitious campaign by the Government to transform a stagnant, subsidized and centralized system into a free-market economy has fallen far short of its goals. Largely because of the country's volatile, often mysterious investment environment, few foreign companies have been willing to invest much money in Iran.
Investors do not know, for example, which of the country's three widely different exchange rates will be used to convert their money, either going in as investment or going out as profit. The Iranian authorities frequently impose new regulations with no warning. Last year, the Government ruled that foreign managers had to pay an additional 23 percent in tax on locally earned income.
Iran has resurrected and amended a foreign investment law from the overthrown monarchy that allows foreign partners a 49 percent stake in joint ventures and full ability to take their profits out of the country. But on the other hand, the Constitution still prohibits foreign investment in some important industries, and the Central Bank is sometimes unwilling to approve letters of credit. And despite the change in the law, it is still almost impossible for foreign companies to transfer the profits they earn in local currency out of the country.
 
Businesses Have Their Doubts
 "Most of the businessmen I talk to do not find these conditions for investment good enough to come here," said a commercial attache to a Western embassy.
Patrick Clawson, an American economist knowledgeable about Iran, put it more bluntly. "If you ask me, 'Is Iran's economic policy pretty good when compared with other oil-producing countries?' I'd say yes," he said. "If you ask me whether to invest in Iran, particularly if you're an American, I'd say no."
Part of Iran's economic malaise has little to do with the country's revolution. The plummeting oil prices in the early 1980's, combined with Iran's limited oil reserves and inability to substantially increase its production, resulted in a striking income loss from which the the country has still not recovered. Since the 1979 revolution, Iran's population has soared from 34 million to nearly 57 million, because of one of the highest birth rates in the world. That has caused a severe shortage of housing and an unemployment rate of 25 to 30 percent.
The revolutionary Government nationalized the banks and important industries, forced foreign companies to close, emphasized self-sufficency in agriculture and industry and drove out two million skilled workers. Then came the eight-year war with Iraq, which killed and wounded hundreds of thousands on both sides, drained the economy and damaged or destroyed thousands of Iranian cities and towns.
In addition, Iran is burdened with four million Afghan and Iraqi refugees, as well as a large number of its own people displaced by the war with Iraq.
Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini led the 1979 revolution against the Shah to elevate the country's "mostazafin," or oppressed, a promise that fueled the expectations of the masses and led them to believe that the hothouse growth of the 1970's would continue or even increase. Thirteen years later, per capita income has fallen to half of what it was before 1979.
President Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, who campaigned in 1989 on a prosperity platform, has tried to follow guidelines from the International Monetary Fund and eliminate Government subsidies, rationalize the exchange rates, reduce inflation and put industry back into private ownership.
Soon after becoming President, he pushed a recalcitrant Parliament to approve $27 billion in foreign borrowing as part of the country's five-year plan. So far, Iran has been able to attract only $7 billion, in part because as an oil-producing country and a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, it is deemed too rich to qualify for government-to-government loans.
The Government also hopes to stimulate growth by the continued privatization of companies seized during the revolution. Since 1990 it has floated shares in about 70 companies, recently decided to privatize more than a dozen more and returned some small businesses to their prerevolutuionary owners.
 
Growth of Economy Has Slowed
 In Iran's 1990 budget year, the gross domestic product rose about 9 percent, but last year the growth rate was about 5 percent. This year it is expected to be slightly lower, primarily because of lower oil prices.
The most pressing priority for Iran, Mr. Adeli says, is to meld its three-tiered exchange rate and eliminate costly subsidies.
Food staples are now sold as if they were imported at the official rate of 70 rials to the dollar, and some state corporations are given foreign exchange at the commercial rate of 600 rials. But the free-market rate, which is used by the private sector, is about 1,440 rials to the dollar. Some bazaar merchants and high-ranking Government officals have gotten rich on the system, buying goods at the official rate and selling them for 20 times as much.
Because of subsidies, a round-trip ticket from Teheran to Resht, about 150 miles away, costs less than $3, the same as a taxi ride from downtown Teheran to the northern part of the city. A motorbike costs 50 percent more than a tractor.
Mr. Rafsanjani and his coterie of aides are hopeful that his apparent landslide victory in the first round of parliamentary elections on April 10 will give him the mandate to make deep -- and painful -- changes in the economy that will in turn attract foreign investment.
"If you ask my personal opinion, I'd like to see the changes as soon as possible," said Mr. Adeli, who is 39 years old. "We have to say: 'We don't have enough money to subsidize you. We don't have this. We don't have that.' The people may not be able to absorb it all at once, but they will be able to eventually."
 
A Need to Move Carefully
 But Mr. Rafsanjani's Government has to move quickly enough to satisfy potential investors and lenders but slowly enough to avoid fomenting rebellion. When the Government lifted subsidies on chicken last year, the price jumped more than 1,200 percent. Mysterious fires erupted in the central bazaar in Teheran last summer, an ominous message to the bazaaris who have gotten rich on the revolution. There have been sit-ins at Teheran University over tuition increases and isolated strikes among workers protesting their low salaries.
There is still a powerful minority of revolutionary purists who are anti-capitalist, anti-Western and anti-luxury. Mr. Adeli and Mosen Nourbakhsh, the Finance Minister, visited the United States last year to urge several hundred Iranian expatriates to return home to develop their country. But the two officials were excoriated in the Iranian press for trying to woo back people who the writers asserted had been thieves and exploiters during the Shah's reign. The expatriates were even accused of wearing symbols of Western imperialism -- neckties.
Seated in a board room in the Ministry of Trade and Economics, at a table laden with cucumbers, oranges, pencils and paper for a group of visiting foreign journalists, Mr. Nourbakhsh, 42, who has a doctorate in economics from the University of California at Davis, acknowledged that Iran was facing an uphill struggle in its campaign to make itself atractive to outside investment.
"Security and confidence of investors is basically a psychological issue, and the passage of time is necessary," he said. "There are no measures you can take to alleviate the perception."

HEADLINE: Review/Opera;
A Bustling 'Turandot' by Philadelphia Troupe

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, April 25

 BODY:
It did not help, in approaching a production of "Turandot" by the Opera Company of Philadelphia at the Academy of Music on Friday evening, to have heard Luciano Pavarotti sing Calaf's big aria, "Nessun dorma," on the same stage two nights earlier. Still less did it help to have seen authentic Chinese opera in New York on Thursday.
Mr. Pavarotti has been something of a patron saint to the company in recent years. But his ringing "Nessun dorma," in the Philadelphia Orchestra's farewell tribute to its music director, Riccardo Muti, put the vocal shortcomings of the production's Calaf, Ermanno Mauro, into sharp relief. This upstaging by the orchestra also pointed up a larger problem: in the overworked, overstuffed academy, which is owned and operated by the orchestra, the opera company cannot establish a permanent presence or even find room over short periods for sizable sets. 
 Not that "Turandot" needs Zeffirellian excess. But in Charles Vaughan 3d's scenic design, the unit set, a revolvable greenish-gray heap wreathed by a reptilian tangle, did little to suggest mythological grandeur.
As if to compensate, Bliss Herbert's stage direction relied on busyness, populating the stage densely with bodies, either in motion or frozen in pseudo-Oriental poses. Arms and hands waggled. Ping, Pang and Pong supplemented the projected supertitles with semaphore. The gauzily clad female dancers, an annoying lot throughout the evening, twirled their arms in the first act as if leading perky cheers for the prince soon to be beheaded.
Here was the great contrast with actual Chinese opera and drama, where bodily action is held in restraint. The essence of stylized gesture is economy, and the spectacle of a stageful of people running willy-nilly through a stock of exotic postures quickly became absurd.
The costumes, designed by Allen Charles Klein and realized by Richard St. Clair, were mostly evocative but occasionally silly, as in the Halloween get-up for the children's choir. The executioners' skimpy breechcloths revealed some formidable sumolike masses of flesh.
All of this made the wait for the production's one great asset, Alessandra Marc in the title role, seem interminable. When Ms. Marc finally sang, midway through the evening, she dominated all else with a big, dark soprano, poured out with ease, and a warmly communicative manner that gave the character unusual human dimension. The high-lying part seemed ideally suited to her strengths. Only once did her pitch stray notably, drifting flat for a phrase.
Mr. Mauro, too, produced considerable volume, but his sonority was brash and unrefined, seemingly incapable of real tenderness. Too often, he scooped up effortfully to high notes, and his tone finally splintered under the pummeling in the last act.
Maryanne Telese played Liu effectively, though her pitch, too, occasionally edged flat. Dong-Jian Gong sang solidly and acted affectingly as Timur. As dislikable as the physical characterizations of Ping, Pang and Pong were, Richard Zeller, Melvin Lowery and Douglas Perry sang the roles well.
The choral and orchestral work showed good preparation by the conductor, Steven Mercurio, though ensemble loosened considerably as the evening wore on. Puccini's unfinished score was presented in the first and longer of Franco Alfano's two completions, adapted by Mr. Mercurio.
A final performance of "Turandot" was to end the company's season on Sunday.

HEADLINE: Corporations Must Police Executive Salaries

 BODY:
To the Editor:
There's something terribly wrong on the executive compensation scene these days, and it's not just the horde of overpaid chief executive officers portrayed in the news media. The problem is the effort by some legislators and consultants, wielding some slippery statistics, to micromanage a compensation system that has largely fulfilled its goal of spurring good performance and profits from American business. 
 Concentrating their fury on wide use of stock option plans, the new "pay police" have led the news media into a virtual pack attack on America's top executives, using catchy slogans such as "stealth compensation" and "reverse welfare." The few instances of real abuse -- very highly compensated executives presiding over very poorly performing companies -- are repeatedly trotted out, and their impact on each company's bottom line is exaggerated.
Certainly, the tempest has focused attention on genuine problems. There is a need to fine-tune stock and long-term incentive plans to insure they encourage long-term thinking. Proxy statements should plainly set out how much top executives will earn that year -- and explain why. And pay-for-performance bonus plans must make tough demands for results that warrant reward.
Those adjustments are being made -- by companies themselves. In response to legitimate shareholder concerns, compensation committees are showing a healthy skepticism toward management proposals. In setting executive bonuses, boards are relying less on formulas than on a subjective, strategic, year-end appraisal of company performance -- including penalizing executives for poor results. Many require that executives hold onto their stock for a set period. More boards are turning to outside advisers for a third-party perspective.
For the last four decades, stock options have instilled in executives a long-term shareholder view and have provided a vehicle for cash-strapped companies to compete for top talent in an open market.
Wealthy executives, even deserving ones, are an easy target. But it's fundamentally unfair to compare American executives with lower-paid peers in Japan -- ignoring that in Japan, job security is absolute, insider trading and sizable perks are acceptable, and a chief executive officer is a first among equals. Many of the biggest and most criticized executive paychecks handed out in the last few years were to individuals of such accomplishment that their boards deem them to be virtually irreplaceable.
Our struggling economy needs stimulation, not more bureaucratic restraint and regulation. Compensation simply cannot be made the scapegoat for every ill on the American economic scene. Government intervention will cripple the ability of American companies to retain and motivate their most effective leaders.
To defuse this issue and keep government out of the board room, corporations must police themselves and convince stockholders, legislators and the news media that they can do it effectively.
 
PEARL MEYER
New York, April 15, 1992
 
The writer is president of Pearl Meyer & Partners, executive compensation consultants.

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
The End of Ideology

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Thirty years ago Daniel Bell, the Harvard sociologist, published his book "The End of Ideology." It is time for a new edition with Britain as a striking example.
Through this century the Labor Party has brought a heavy element of ideology to British politics. Labor based itself on egalitarian Socialist principles. In office, it nationalized leading industries, built massive public housing and established the National Health Service. 
 In recent years the Labor leader, Neil Kinnock, has worked hard to strip the party of ideological anachronisms. Little remained of the Socialist ideal except a commitment to spend more on public services such as health.
Even so, Labor lost the election three weeks ago -- lost in the middle of a bad recession, after 13 years of Conservative Government. And one of the main reasons for its defeat was a campaign promise to raise tax rates on higher incomes.
The defeat has persuaded many in the party that it must shed the last remnants of ideology, recognizing that Britain is now a country of would-be capitalists. The next step will probably be for Labor to cut its links to the trade unions. It will try to make itself a mildly reformist middle-class party, perhaps under a new name.
The Conservatives, meanwhile, are happily discarding the ideological tone that lately marked their party. That was the strident voice of Margaret Thatcher.
With her message of unbridled free enterprise, Mrs. Thatcher had a profound effect on British attitudes in her 11 years as Prime Minister. But by the end of her reign she had worn out her welcome. She had substituted for property taxes a head tax that was as stiff on the poor as on the rich. She had taken to referring to herself as "we," like the Queen.
Mrs. Thatcher's nannying state of mind was displayed, unwittingly, in the piece she wrote for Newsweek last week. She spoke condescendingly of Prime Minister John Major as a mere disciple carrying out her policies: "I don't accept the idea that all of a sudden Major is his own man."
In fact, the Conservatives won this election because they made the extraordinary decision in 1990 to ditch Mrs. Thatcher and then chose the bland Mr. Major as leader. He is the very model of a non-ideological politician, offending practically no one.
The interesting question now is what is left to argue about in British politics. Are the two major parties merely going to compete over who can manage things more capably?
There is a subject that should be on the British political agenda, urgently so. That is the need for restraints -- constitutional restraints -- on official power.
In the United States, officials are hemmed in by all kinds of constraints: constitutional limits, the tensions between Congress and the President, the states and the Federal Government. In Britain there is what has been called an elective dictatorship. When a political leader commands a majority in the House of Commons, she can govern as she wishes.
The only constraints in the British system have been respect for tradition and the fear of defeat in the next election if a government is too arrogant. Mrs. Thatcher had little respect for tradition or civil liberty, concentrating power at the center and imposing new levels of official secrecy. And now the Conservatives have less and less reason to fear defeat.
David Marquand, a former M.P. turned professor of politics at Sheffield University, wrote recently that "single-party hegemony" of the kind now looming "might be tolerable . . . in a constitutional order that diffused power, guaranteed fundamental rights and tamed authority with checks and balances." But in a system like Britain's, dependent on self-restraint, "it is profoundly dangerous."
In short, Britain should be thinking about a written constitution. There is more talk about that subject than ever before. Mr. Kinnock's likely successor as Labor leader, John Smith, has said he favors a bill of rights. But the constitutionalism that is bred in the American bone -- the instinct of looking to fundamental law for limits on official power -- still seems a long way from reality here.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Essay;
Clinton's 'The' Speech

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Old speechwriters wait for thespeech one that a politician knows by heart and believes moves his audiences -- to see if candidates grasp the dynamic of their own campaigns.
Voters don't get to see it in full on television. George Bush has only just hired Peggy Noonan to put his together. But Bill Clinton has been out on the stump hammering his message out, and The New York Times published the text just before his Pennsylvania victory. 
 "We have had it their way for 11 years," he says, picking up speed after a slow, statistical start, "and we're going downhill as a nation. The middle class is collapsing. Poverty is exploding. What is the alternative? That's what I represent."
He then presents an inchoate economic plan he calls "dramatically different" (a modifying phrase he ought to drop because women know it as the name of an Estee Lauder moisturizing lotion). His anti-tax-and-spend idea needs beefing up and tying into his central theme, which is a call to responsibility.
That theme, original for a Democrat, will blend nicely with time-for-a-change and don't-waste-your-vote messages in October. But as he turns to health care, Mr. Clinton fails to punch up the difference to consumers between his centralized plan and the more diffuse Republican approach.
Not until "what you earn depends on what you can learn" does he hit oratorical stride. Clinton has a constructive idea to bring a college education to those who cannot afford it: a "national service trust fund," or new G.I. Bill. Students could repay the Federal Government for an education with a year or two at low-pay, high-involvement local public service.
A domestic Peace Corps with an education bonus is not a new idea, but its combination of idealism and practicality fits his educational responsibility theme: "I live in a state where we can fine parents if they won't show up when their kids are in trouble in school. A lot of people think that's harsh. . . ." Not most voters, as the speaker knows; we like making other parents more responsible for their kids.
Then he gets personal, responding to the "cop-out" of those who say "all the politicians are a bunch of bums and the country can't work anymore." The only major Presidential candidate who is neither a millionaire nor a billionaire recounts being raised by grandparents while his widowed mother went to school to become a nurse, and tells how he borrowed from the Government to go to college, working through law school to pay it back.
Governor Clinton does not dwell on this, but most Americans identify with someone who had to make his own way. It sets the stage for a powerful peroration, replete with train whistles in the night, which the speaker does not yet have, but the campaign is young.
What else is missing? Clinton's "the" speech needs both a differentiation and an attack.
He should clearly draw the difference between Mr. Bush and himself on abortion. A centrist, discourage-but-permit stand will reach deep into the Bush core support among conservative women; the Supreme Court will make it the sleeper issue in the '92 campaign.
The attack can be on Mr. Bush's claim to fame: his defeat of Saddam Hussein. Only now are we beginning to discover the extent to which the secret Bush National Security Directive 26 -- which the White House should be challenged to make public -- helped build the Iraqi dictator into a world menace.
No wonder Mr. Bush reacted to Iraqi aggression with such uncharacteristic alacrity. The loyal opposition might point out that the monstrous nuclear threat that it took a half-million American warriors to defeat was in effect financed by Bush blindness and appeasement.
Development of the "the" speeches of candidates is a marvelous thing to watch. We will see their summer blossoming at the conventions, in acceptance form; catch their essence this fall in summations at the end of television debates; and watch their culmination on election eve.
"The beginning of everything," concludes Mr. Clinton, becoming a happier warrior, "is believing that we can do better."
He has a good, inspiring "the" speech. I believe he can do better.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
